## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] " Jay, hello."
## [1] " Hey, what’s up man?"
## [1] " It’s a lovely day down here in the depths. I’ve been actually trying to keep my crypto radar slightly turned off for the last weekend."
## [1] " Why?"
## [1] " I had got to the point where I was like, “I’m just gonna stop looking at the price. I’m gonna limit myself to like once a day.”"
## [1] " So you’re going like, basically paleo-crypto."
## [1] " Paleo-crypto."
## [1] " Like, “OG, I don’t care about price. I want the price to go down, so that people can start focusing on the tech.” That’s where you’re at right now?"
## [1] " No, more I’m kind of actually these stories are kind of capturing my imagination, more so than the financial elements."
## [1] " So you’re in the “I’m just a storyteller” phase of crypto?"
## [1] " Yes. I’m just weaving the dream catcher to catch the narrative of Bitcoin in the 21st century. Okay, so we wanted to talk about Petro coin."
## [1] " I think this is our third attempt to talk about Petro coin. This is not our fault. The Petro coin story does keep changing. I don’t know, I think that there’s probably no more interesting story, just in pure ramifications, and what it could mean to the crypto space. There’s nothing funnier in terms of the meme potential than Petro coin, and yet it seems to encapsulate so much of what people are talking about in crypto, and what people are scared about with crypto, that I just think that we should talk about for a bit."
## [1] " It’s a classic story that I’ve read several articles about. I’d like to consider myself at least somewhat knowledgeable about the space it takes place in, and I’m still hugely confused by. Break it down for me."
## [1] " Alright, so Petro coin is Venezuela’s attempt to create a crypto-currency, right?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Venezuela, the country that is racked by US sanctions. The economy has completely failed."
## [1] " For a minute there I thought you were gonna say that Venezuela was wrecked."
## [1] " Oh yeah. Well, Venezuela is rekt. Yes, R-E-K-T."
## [1] " Nationally rekt."
## [1] " Completely rekt, yes. A lot of it because of policies by Nicolas Maduro, who is the president of Venezuela, but a lot of people would call him more of a dictator. So, Maduro decides that he’s going to create a crypto-currency, and it’s going to be called Petro coin, because the one thing that Venezuela does have, is that is has … I don’t know why this adjective is always tagged to it, but the adjective always used is vast. Vast oil reserves."
## [1] " A lot of people say it has larger oil reserves than Saudi Arabia."
## [1] " Yeah. Why is it always vast with oil?"
## [1] " I always like when it says one country that’s always the comparison, the Pilar was like “It’s an area the size of Connecticut."
## [1] " I have never in my life heard it’s an area the size of Connecticut."
## [1] " Really like a giant forest."
## [1] " I’ve heard the size of Texas."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Moving on."
## [1] " All right. So, moving on."
## [1] " So Venezuela is experiencing one of the most tumultuous recent economic histories of anywhere in the globe, a massive inflammation, total runs on all sorts of goods, no money to import anything."
## [1] " Yeah, and their solution to this is to create an ICO, or one of the solutions right?"
## [1] " They’re not calling it an ICO though."
## [1] " No they do call it an ICO."
## [1] " Oh, they do call it an ICO!"
## [1] " Yeah, they’re saying it will be the biggest ICO ever, which I think at this point if you believe any of their numbers, which there’s no reason to believe any of these numbers, it is the biggest ICO of all time. So, last week Maduro goes in front of, this is a video I think that we have on our Instagram page, but he sets up this sort of theater when all the press is there, and he walks around and he’s turning on … Do you know that Instagram feed Kim Jong Un pointing at things, [crosstalk 00:04:35] Tumblr?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " It’s kind of like that, except it’s Nicolas Maduro turning on mining rates."
## [1] " Yeah, I would say that there’s definitely an aesthetic to those kinds of videos. There’s usually an angle, and it’s a lot of times an autocrat gesturing the technology as if they understand it, but what they’re gesturing to, in this case, Nicolas Maduro is gesturing to a bunch of bit main and ant miners."
## [1] " Yeah, so he’s turning on ant miners, which for reasons that will come up very soon, and make no sense."
## [1] " So if you were listening, the ant miner is like the classic, every crypto currency rig you’ve seen, which is basically a long tube with a fan on it and a bunch of graphics chips in it. It’s not exactly a technology you can point to and gesture gladly."
## [1] " It’s not like a fighter jet-"
## [1] " It’s not an inter ballistic missile."
## [1] " So, Maduro then sits in front of this gigantic logo, which was also very funny, the logo was like seven times bigger than it needed to be, and announces that Petro coin in its first day of the ICO has raised $735 million, which is a lot of money."
## [1] " Good ICO."
## [1] " Yeah, it’s a great ICO."
## [1] " Okay, so I usually feel like I’m on enough ICO Reddits, that when there’s really like a token for sale, I hear about people who actually bought some. Are there account of people buying Petros? Will I be seeing it on Cryptopia?"
## [1] " Okay, just now I was in the office and some guy I work with, who will remain unnamed, but a wonderful young man, and he is very into crypto, told me that he had been thinking about buying Petro coin. And I was like “You can’t buy it in the United States, because buying Petro coin actually violates US sanction laws,” and he was like “Oh yeah, I figured that out like halfway through and then I was like, ‘I probably shouldn’t buy Petro coin, or else I’ll be violating US law.’”"
## [1] " So there’s presumably almost nobody in America who is buying it, but Maduro says that there’s a lot of interest in Europe, and Asia, and South America, and other parts, that has contributed to this $735 million, which nobody can confirm because the government hasn’t released any data or any sort of numbers, and also nothing has moved on the blockchain. We’ll get into that a little bit later."
## [1] " Yeah. So it’s a typical ICO in that no one has any idea what’s going on, or who’s behind it, or what you really get."
## [1] " Yes, that is the long and short of what has happened so far."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Okay. So, the problems with Petro coin are myriad. The first is that … The way that Maduro was explaining at the beginning, it essentially made it seem like if you owned a Petro coin and you went to the Petro coin store or something or whatever, like the Petro coin exchange, and you give them a Petro coin, they would like reach behind the counter and pull up a barrel of oil and give it to you."
## [1] " And this is like a financial concept that does have historical roots. When you talk about oil futures or something like that talking about like the value of a barrel, there is a present day a barrel of oil price. So when he presented the idea, my understanding and as usual I leapt to a like an overly rational explanation was like, “Oh, it’s like a token that you can exchange for one barrel of oil whatever the value of barrel of oil that are.” And like we’ve talked about tether. One tether is always supposed to be worth one dollar, this is worth one X, X equals that day’s barrel of oil in Venezuela price."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " That’s not what it is though, right?"
## [1] " No, no, no, no, no, no, no. The first iteration of it was essentially him saying that it is actually pegged to the physical oil."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Yeah. So that it really did seem like if you went in and you’re like, “Hello sir, here is my ledger hardware wallet. As you can see I have 30 Petro coins. Could you please hand me my three barrels of oil?” Like that’s what he made it seem like in a bad description, it might have been bad translation, but at some point he transition to basically saying, “This is not actually the actual oil. Come on guys it’s fucking crazy. It’s actually the price of oil,” which is manipulated all the time in Venezuela and so it is another sort of layer on top of it, where this thing becomes more and more vapor and less commodity backed cryptocurrency that it says it was."
## [1] " Well, to the discussions we’ve previously had about tether and go back and listen that episode if you’re curious. The big accusation against tether was, “Oh, they don’t actually have a dollar for every token that they’ve issued.” We don’t really know how much oil Venezuela has, and we also don’t really seem to know how many tokens they’re issuing. These tokens are not like mineable up, this is like they’re just basically printing them. They’re just making as many as they want."
## [1] " The [inaudible 00:09:08] says, “Nicolas Maduro on Bitcoin miners.” [crosstalk 00:09:12] would be actually a very funny Tumblr for a very, very small audience. I don’t even know if Tumblr still exists in that sort of way."
## [1] " Everything about that idea defunct."
## [1] " The problem with that is that all the coins are pre-mined. It’s on the NEM Blockchain. I think there’s 100 million of these things."
## [1] " Yeah, it’s like what does 100 million represent in the overall oil reserves of Venezuela?"
## [1] " I have no idea. I guess you would take the total value of the oil reserves and divide it by a 100 million and each Petro coin is worth some level of that."
## [1] " Forgive me if I’ve completely misunderstood this, but the one sort of use case that’s already been presented for the Petro is that people in Venezuela will be able to use Petros to pay their taxes?"
## [1] " Okay. So yes, you can use Petro coin. And in Venezuela where you cannot buy groceries with the Bolivar and where there are all sorts of lines on any type of staple food, where it’s very difficult to get rice or flour or even clean water right now. The one thing that you can do with a Petro coin is not buy groceries or buy like a car, the only thing you do is pay your taxes. And I was trying to think about, what is the least appealing use case that would make it so that people do not want to buy crypto-currency? And it’s like, “You can use this thing to pay your taxes.”"
## [1] " Well, and also if you unpack the flow of money in that, so you get paid in Bolivars, which are basically worthless, massively losing to inflation at every moment, which you can’t really buy food with, and then you pay taxes on your Bolivar income in Petros?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " If Petros have any value, you wouldn’t want to do that. The only scenario, which that’s a good idea is if Petro loses value against the Bolivar."
## [1] " Exactly, so like the Venezuela government’s pitch to the Venezuelan people to please buy Petro coin is like, “Okay, you can buy this stuff and then you can use it to give it back to us.”"
## [1] " Yeah, it’s like if I was like, “Hey Jay, do you mind if I pay you in US dollars but you have to pay your income tax in Bitcoin?”"
## [1] " Or in Lammer coin."
## [1] " In Lama coin."
## [1] " [crosstalk 00:11:19] can only be used to pay Aaron Lammer."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " It would be like, “Would you like to buy a Lammer coin?” It would be like, “No actually Aaron, I don’t really feel like paying you for anything, so why don’t I buy Lammer coin?” It is fundamentally the most sort of confusing thing that I have looked at in the ICOs space. Some things are just outright scams and they’re not confusing because you’re like, “Oh, this is clearly a scam.” But this is backed by a government, and you would think that given the amount of press that was around there, and given the desperation of Maduro’s government and the ambitions of it, which was to raise like billion something dollars, that they would have tried a little bit harder to make it make sense. Now, I don’t know. Maybe it does make sense in some sort of way."
## [1] " I mean it makes as much sense as a lot of ICOs."
## [1] " Yes, but those ICOs are clearly scams."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Yes. So that’s what I mean. It falls somewhere in the realm of ICOs that don’t make sense but they only make sense, but they only make sense because you realize that they’re scams and you’re like, “Oh, it makes sense because nothing in here is actually real. It’s all a scam.” So if you zoom out like two pixels then it’s a scam."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Petro Coin you can’t really do that because it’s like a bigger project. I don’t know if that make sense."
## [1] " I think that all makes sense, I mean this is also not totally unprecedented. Governments issuing really junky bonds based on their junky economies that often like go bankrupt."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " A lot of these crypto stories are basically just a crypto spin on an age old collapsing economy, like patrolled by a dictator kind of tactics."
## [1] " I feel like North Korea might do this, because you know North Korea has a ton of mineral reserves. And they’re not really quite sure how to mine it, maybe perhaps what they could do is create cryptocurrency that is based on their unmined mineral reserves. But like-"
## [1] " Back to our editor James Nicholson … Go ahead."
## [1] " Last thing I wanted to bring up about the weird, weird, weird world of Petro coin is that things keep changing every single time they make an announcement. So for ever the white paper said that this is going to be an ERC-20 token that was on the Ethereum Network."
## [1] " Yes, which would have been a big deal for Ethereum. They’re really like, “Oh, what’s on Ethereum? ‘Venezuela?’”"
## [1] " Yeah, and the entire Venezuelan [crosstalk 00:13:31]. It changed without telling anybody at the last second, to NEM Blockchain and there was all this funny confusion, where there was like this sort of Reddit silly thing and they were looking at the photos of Maduro turning on ant miners’ meeting and they’re were like, “That guy works for NEM!” And then NEM had to come by and be like, “Actually we’ve never seen that person or that person does not work for NEM.” And people come back feel like, “Is it on NEM or is it not on NEM?”"
## [1] " And then come back feeling like, “We do not support any sort of state government and we have no influence in politics but perhaps Venezuela has decided to put their crypto currency on our blockchain.” So in the end it ends up being a NEM token. NEM, the only reason you and I have ever talked about it on the show is A, one of the cryptocurrency girls that J-Pop band that we featured in an earlier episode, is named after NEM. And the second reason is because, almost all the NEM in the world was stolen."
## [1] " Yeah, I think 523 million dollars worth NEM was stolen."
## [1] " Yeah, that Coincheck Hack."
## [1] " In the Coincheck Hack. So I did a little looking into NEM just because I was curious after this and one of the things I didn’t know is that, NEM is another pseudonymous Lee created currency, no one really knows who made it. It was originally supposed to be based on NXT and was going to use the NXT code base and then decided to do its own code base. There’s a variant of it that’s being used as a corporate blockchain in Japan. It’s not particularly well known to be putting the country of Venezuela on."
## [1] " Yeah. Well, that was proven by their PR people who were going around being like, “We don’t know who that guy is.” And then couldn’t really answer the question for a while if the entire oil reserves of this country of Venezuela. This actually is very, very arguably illegal in Venezuela. And the opposition party in Venezuela has pointed to a very, very strict instanter law that says you cannot issue debt against the oil reserves or any sort of natural resource commodity."
## [1] " And Maduro has done what a lot of crypto people say and said, “You know, it’s not debt issuing. It’s a crypto currency, it’s a new thing.” And so, half of the government of Venezuela and a lot of the people of Venezuela have basically decided that this thing is not even legitimate, that it’s illegal and that sort of calls back to the history of cryptocurrency in Venezuela, which is that, like around 2014, 2015 because the Bolivar was going so crazy, a lot of people in that country started turning to Bitcoin and even opened a Bitcoin Exchange."
## [1] " And there was a big mining and a big crackdown on mining by the government."
## [1] " All those people got arrested. And if you talk to some of them who are a little more conspiracy minded, they’ll say that they stole all their miners, they stole all their Bitcoin and they’re just using it to do research to do this Petro coin. I think that the sort of rebuttal to that would be that, if they had actually done that, they might have done a better job."
## [1] " But there was a lot of conspiracy theory even at the time that they were raiding people who were mining in Venezuela and taking their mining equipment and that there was government mining facilities, set up that were using free power and work mining for the government, which is also a story we’ve heard about North Korea."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. Well, look Maduro had to get those fucking miners to point to and turn on from somewhere, right?"
## [1] " I feel like by the time you’re like a strongman and you’ve dissolved the opposition, doing a shady ICO that breaks your own regulatory stuff, it’s kind of a small potatoes [inaudible 00:17:05]."
## [1] " It might be a false bag to hide absolutely."
## [1] " Although it maybe like a sort of like Nixonian sense it’s like, “In the end it was a cryptocurrency scheme that brought him down.”"
## [1] " I will say that, if I was going to go on Venezuelan conspiracy threads, I would think that there are probably a lot of people saying that this is some sort of false flag operation or something like that. So we do not say that because we’re not conspiracy theorists."
## [1] " No, I don’t know why you buy that. Okay, if I was to tell you, “Hey there’s a crypto currency that represents basely this.” and I was like, “The future of the Venezuelan economy.” You’d be like, “Pass. Hard, hard pass.” Like why would someone-"
## [1] " Controlled by the Venezuelan government."
## [1] " What is the case for wanting to own a cryptocurrency that’s pegged to the value of Venezuelan … Is it just because it’s oil that it doesn’t matter where it is?"
## [1] " Well, I think that it might appeal to those of us who … You and I might be closer than we want to admit, who feel like the shadier something is-,"
## [1] " The more potentially profitable."
## [1] " The more potentially profitable it might be."
## [1] " Okay, I’ll be."
## [1] " As long as we can time the pump before the dump or something like that."
## [1] " Well, I guess you could say it’s a little bit like the era of privatizing within post-Soviet Union era, where all these Russians became billionaires by buying into state assets that were getting privatized. I mean on some level if he’s selling off all the oil in Venezuela to the private market."
## [1] " But he’s not even selling the oil. It’s just currency pegged to the oil. Like you can’t actually go in and get that barrel and put it on a plane and ship it out."
## [1] " Does it not mean that if you own all the tokens you own all of the oil? No?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Then I definitely I’m not buying."
## [1] " No, it is pegged to the oil. So all these questions really bring up one larger question, which is that it feels, at least to me, there’s doom and gloom about all things crypto, that we have crossed the Rubicon. That a government has finally become involved in crypto, and that perhaps of all the governments in the world, this is like a top 10 worst government to be involved in crypto. And that we might start seeing crypto technology being employed by other states in some sort of malicious or scamy sort of way. I don’t know what the actual ramifications it is, I am not so gloom and doom that I think that it’s going to have any effect on the health of Bitcoin, but man it’s kind of a bad story, don’t you think?"
## [1] " Yeah I mean … When you said this is about one of the worst governments, I mean it was like North Korea would be the worst government but one of the things that made me wonder is, like if you’re NEM or you’re Ethereum Foundation, would you want Venezuela on your blockchain? It seems like taking on a big risk. Like it seems like some of these events such as the NEM hack of 523 million dollars worth NEM are situations where there’s going to be a huge political push to wheel it back after a hack or doing a fork or something to like man the chain after some sort of a catastrophe. I just don’t know if I’d want to be part of a scamy Petro coin. I would be kind of like, “Let someone else’s chain experiment with this. Once you screw it up with North Korea and Venezuela, we’ll get like Finland on the blockchain in like five years like we’re cool.”"
## [1] " I think that NEM probably does not have that much choice in the matter."
## [1] " That was very trampy in how I used Finland as the good country."
## [1] " Yeah, what the fuck men. I don’t know if they have that much of a choice, you know if somebody wants to use that blockchain and copy and paste an issue cryptocurrency like [inaudible 00:20:51]."
## [1] " Is that the case that they don’t … Where they can’t reject someone from using chain like that?"
## [1] " I mean that would be a pretty big statement I think if they did. They’re the second … You know this is [inaudible 00:21:02] like sort of saying like … Let’s say you’re like a dude and you make like $15,000, you made $20,000 last year. You live in your mom’s basement."
## [1] " This is my basement, Jay."
## [1] " This is your basement outside the basement that you rent. Like what are you really turned it down? Yeah, maybe it’s not the perfect person who comes into your life, but you’re probably going to take on anything that is going to help you that comes through that door and I think that the government of Venezuela doing a “735 million dollar ICO,” in one day, that is a thing."
## [1] " They didn’t have any other options."
## [1] " Yeah and also, if it works, that’s awesome."
## [1] " If it works all kinds of … You’re going to see so many countries like doing ICOs, if this even vaguely works."
## [1] " I mean I feel like the sort of cat is out of the bag on that. I mean if Maduro is able to prove all that this is anywhere close to 735 million dollars and that he was able to skirt US sanctions to try and get some sort of form of outside funding into his country, why wouldn’t you do it?"
## [1] " I mean one of the things that I saw people bring up is, it’s ultimately a somewhat cynical enterprise, because you can’t buy … I don’t think you can buy Petro coin with Bolivars. You can’t use Petro coin to prop up your life savings. You can only buy them with Bitcoin and Ethereum, and the gateway to Bitcoin and Ethereum are primarily US dollars and euros and these … So they’re basically like taking foreign money in for the most part."
## [1] " Yeah, well that’s the idea. They want to bring in foreign investors into Petro coin."
## [1] " Yeah. I mean you can’t buy them with Bolivars, is there really any evidence that it’s going to like help people who live in Venezuela?"
## [1] " No, there’s no evidence and I think that’s the biggest problem, which is that, it seems like, you and joke quite a bit about me starting can coin and then disappearing."
## [1] " That was a joke?"
## [1] " It depends how well the ICO goes, but starting an ICO and then bouncing. We’ve seen it happen, it happens once a month it feels like. I think this is the Venezuelan government’s version of the this. Like I think that maybe one day you will type in Venezuela.gov into a browser and you completely plug in [inaudible 00:23:22] in the corner and they’ll all be gone. Like that’s what it feels like, it feels like a onetime cashout type of deal or an emergency fundraiser. And look, I kind of give credit to Maduro because of all the ways to do a completely corrupt fundraiser and to bring in sucker money, like an ICO is not that bad. I actually can’t think of anything that might get people who are a little bit stupid to buy into it."
## [1] " All right, second country to do an ICO."
## [1] " All right, the second country to do an ICO."
## [1] " What are the odds were looking at here? I feel like all the best odds are going to be Caribbean countries."
## [1] " Yeah, for sure."
## [1] " Can you imagine the scheme, it’s a tax shelter but you can get citizenship if you have 100,000 tokens but you can trade those tokens for like tax dodging and citizenship."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. I mean that would also go into our money laundering ETF."
## [1] " Oh, definitely."
## [1] " Actually basically everything we talk about, in the show. Petro coin is definitely the money laundering-"
## [1] " Yeah, I’m going to say like Virgin Islands coin."
## [1] " What about that tiny European countries that you only see during the Winter Olympics like Andorra, Liechtenstein."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. I mean I could also see … I mean the craziest one in the like Dark Horse but this is huge if true, Switzerland."
## [1] " Swiss coin? I do not see a Swiss coin."
## [1] " Monaco?"
## [1] " Monaco coin, yes. I feel like they should print out blockchain based tokens that you can exchange for citizenship if you want to compete in the Winter Olympics under their name."
## [1] " Yeah, I think there’s definitely some good outlets in Europe, Estonia of course, also. A lot of blockchain activity in Estonia."
## [1] " That is true. All right so the third thing I think we should talk about and this is the sort of big question, if this was This American Life, this would like when Hourglass comes back on and-"
## [1] " This is American Life, Hourglass would call and say, “Why you guys are talking so much about cryptocurrency? Because this isn’t really a story per se.’"
## [1] " I don’t even know if this is an episode. This is when he would go and introduce the reporter to do the big point, right?"
## [1] " Yeah, what’s big point?"
## [1] " The big point is, what do we really make of the fact that a government is able to do this? And do you think that the movement in crypto right now is working against Satoshi Nakamoto’s original vision of decentralized stateless currency, because in my opinion, a lot of the news that we’re hearing these days does seem to kind of … Like people are kind of pushing that idea stateless decentralization away."
## [1] " I think that we are seeing the coming conflict between two extremes. One, which is the most extreme original vision, which really I fundamentally believe that at its core Bitcoin is destructive to the state. I think the idea of people keeping their money outside of states is a very provocative and dangerous idea. And I think because it’s a provocative and dangerous idea, there’s going to be a counter movement to co-opt it and to do something just as radical for the state itself, within the state itself to assert even greater control. I mean I don’t think it’s any accident that we’re seeing this rise in like autocratic leadership around the world. We have an autocratic leader issuing a scamy ICO token. All of these storylines feel like they’re going to converge and there will be both increasing numbers of people trying to live in ways that are antithetical to the state, and then I think the state getting deeply involved in all kinds of blockchain stuff that also presents like a new vision of society."
## [1] " Yeah, co-option I think is the right word, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Most co-option happens in anything whether activist movements or anything like that it happens voluntarily. People sort of relent and I think that, that’s happened quite a bit, like the sort of rise in the price of Bitcoin, the growth of companies like Coinbase. The amount of money that people now have invested in these things, the lack of security. All that has sort of professionalized Bitcoin in a way, it has helped prop up the price, but it certainly has made the idea of decentralization like almost a fantasy. Like if you have Bitcoin, you have it on Coinbase, like you don’t believe in decentralization. You actually believe in the extremely centralized bank, which is kind of the only bank."
## [1] " I think it’s set up for competing visions to fight each other though. That’s always been part of this idea of consensus and part of this idea of voting with the nodes and the chain itself. It’s almost like it expected to be co-opted and sort of built controls within itself that are at least ideally checks and balances against that."
## [1] " I think that is a generous way to read it, because I would say that, I think that the Bitcoin community has essentially itself co-opted in that sort of way. But I think that the saving grace would be that … And maybe actually this is similar to what you’re saying, maybe saving grace is that the technology if treated correctly is still decentralized vision and it can’t actually be co-opted at some level. Like you can have Bitcoin off of Coinbase. Like you don’t need to use it. You don’t need to use a ledger. You can just print out your keys and laminate them, put them like in your floorboards or whatever you want to get."
## [1] " Or mega churches, but you also can just build an altar in your own house and worship as you see fit."
## [1] " I do think that as states get more and more involved, that there’s going to be a civil war within the crypto community. And I think that the Cypherpunks and the original narco-capitalists [inaudible 00:29:22] everyone who only eats meat. They’re going to have to basically redefine the line of where they are. And I think that’s going to be pretty hard because a lot of them are super rich now and I think that redefining that line will probably force them to have to like relinquish some of those riches."
## [1] " I think religious movements are kind of the right parable for this kind of thing. There was no way that this extremely valuable and extremely intriguing project was going to sit out there and take in billions of dollars and not attract the attention of Silicon Valley and not attract the attention of corporate America and American government. What’s sort of unique about this form of technology is that it can potentially exist both ways at once, it’s not like one thing, it’s not Apple and trying to wrest control who’s going to be the CEO. Potentially like all these visions can be lived out at once I think."
## [1] " Well, yeah especially since Bitcoin is infinitely forkable. There might be a fork that takes a more philosophical route to it. But even like, if two X or four X or eight X or Bitcoin cash becomes a dominant player, you might see a reversion back to like very small block sizes as a way to sort of push ideology. I think all that is really important right now though, because I do think we’re like at this point where we’re kind of losing the script, we’re kind of losing the message of what it’s supposed to be and everything is about price speculation, everything else about incoming government regulations, everything’s about sort of this funny meme world and I kind of mess like raging and narco capitalist, “Fuck the state let’s bank the bank list and create our own weird commune style of Bitcoin,” messaging."
## [1] " I feel like that’s what you would have said when we were racing past 15,000. It was like, “Oh, now it’s all about price speculation and [inaudible 00:31:20],” but it’s like and now it’s back down again. I feel like by the time I start even recognizing the narrative of what’s happening, we’ve actually like moved on. I feel like we’re like several steps removed from that like [crosstalk 00:31:33]. I don’t know where we are now."
## [1] " But I also think that, that’s sucks. Not that I agree with the politics of any of this I don’t. But it is also is kind of what made Bitcoin cool, because it was this alternative world. Now I just think that it really has become kind of a centralized thing. It’s not just a vision of the original people who are working on the project, but it’s also become centralized in a sense like, now the government of Venezuela thinks it will be funny to do an ICO."
## [1] " It’s funny, it is like a classic like New York was better right before you moved there kind of situation."
## [1] " Exactly, that’s what I’m saying."
## [1] " Better like when? Like when we got into it? Like less than a year ago?"
## [1] " No, I would say that before I bought Bitcoin or before I had skin in the game but when I was reading about it or when I was like chasing Dorian Nakamoto around in his car. And I was interested in Bitcoin but I just did own any. I think it was cooler back then."
## [1] " It’s a little more diverse now and I don’t mean gender or ethnically, [crosstalk 00:32:28]."
## [1] " It’s definitely not gender."
## [1] " But I think the … Like the story is getting bigger and broader. I feel like there’s just more and more angles and tentacles all over the world."
## [1] " All right, I can accept that. I can accept that."
## [1] " Okay, so will you be buying Petro coin?"
## [1] " Definitely not, because I do not want to go to jail for violating US sanctions."
## [1] " What country’s ICO would you buy?"
## [1] " I don’t think I would buy any country’s ICO."
## [1] " I’d get in on some like Canada maybe."
## [1] " Canada? Why Canada coin?"
## [1] " It seems stable. [crosstalk 00:33:00]."
## [1] " You’re growing fed-"
## [1] " Canadians do not seem like scammers to me in my experience."
## [1] " Canada coin is like pegged to the production of hockey players and [crosstalk 00:33:09]."
## [1] " It’s based on the price of a grog grade C syrup."
## [1] " I get [inaudible 00:33:16] honestly but I think I would probably go back to like my degenerate side and buy the most speculative country. Okay, last prediction I want you to make."
## [1] " Shoot."
## [1] " Does Petro coin ever get distributed and traded on exchanges? Because right now one of the news items that has come out has said that they have found the Petro coin wallet, and it’s all still sitting there."
## [1] " I think it probably is going to eventually be traded somewhere. If Trump coin and Pepe coin can make it to cryptopia, Petro coin can make it somewhere. Do we know what the logo looks like yet?"
## [1] " Yeah it’s like a Bitcoin logo, but instead of the B it’s a P."
## [1] " Very creative."
## [1] " So we have all the links to articles that we discussed and the Maduro pointing at ant miners video on our page."
## [1] " Yeah, we’re going to try and start putting out more stuff. So follow that Instagram @Cointalkshow."
## [1] " Yeah, I think our Instagram is honestly the most underappreciated part of our show."
## [1] " And we could do a lot more on it. There’s a lot of hilarious crypto video."
## [1] " And likely the one part of our entire enterprise that I would point to and say, “Hey, [inaudible 00:34:25] is actually a good.”"
## [1] " All right, I will talk to you next week."
## [1] " All right."

## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] " Hey. You’re still out in Berkeley, huh?"
## [1] " I’m flying out tomorrow. Still in Berkeley. Still lovely here. Still looking at a very nice sunset."
## [1] " It’s been about a week since we talked, maybe not actually … It’s been about four days-"
## [1] " No, not even a week"
## [1] " … since we talked last. How many crypto related or blockchain related t-shirts have you seen walking around the Bay area?"
## [1] " At least a dozen."
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " Actually, I was in the Japantown mall in San Francisco, the Japan Center yesterday, having some ramen with a friend from college and he does not know or care about this topic at all. And I was sheepishly being like, “Oh, yeah, I’m hosting this cryptocurrency podcast,” and I could see someone at the next table ear prick up and wanting to jump in, like he wanted to switch tables with his girlfriend and come to our table."
## [1] " Yeah. Let me tell you. That does not happen here in New York and I have seen zero cryptocurrency related t-shirts, except the one I wore a couple days ago, which is the Roger Ver Bcash t-shirt that I sometimes wear to work."
## [1] " I will say that, in addition to the t-shirts, I feel like there’s been a batch this week of articles by writers that I like outside of the crypto universe writing about cryptocurrencies, which is something I’ve always known was coming, but I’m enjoying people whose voice I otherwise want to hear about different topics weighing in on this topic."
## [1] " Yeah. It’s sort of circled over finally to the, I don’t want to use the word pundit because I feel like, at least for me, that’s a pejorative term because I respect these writers too. But I’ll just say that people who think about big things out loud and write very well and you trust whatever their vision of the universe is or whatever they’ve thought through, you trust that, so, yeah, I noticed that as well. Paul Ford, who is somebody I think we’re both a fan of, I think-"
## [1] " I think that Paul Ford encapsulated this moment well. I think he tweeted this out. He was like, “Bloomberg asked me to write something for them.” And he was like, “276 pitches later, blockchain?” and they’re like, “That’s the one we want.” I don’t even know if this is actually enthusiasm on the part of these writers or it’s enthusiasm on the part of their editors, but I’m enjoying them doing the work so I don’t have to. And I was actually hoping that we could maybe use one of those articles that came out this week as a springboard to have the conversation that we’ve been putting off where we try to understand what the blockchain itself is."
## [1] " Yeah. Look, we discussed a little bit last week about what we were going to do for the show and one thing that I think that we want to do when we launched a show, which was to give sort of a primer for people, or primer, I don’t know how one explains … I say primer, but, it’s actually [crosstalk 00:05:42]-"
## [1] " Jay, you’re setting all kinds of trends out here."
## [1] " … it’s actually right. That’s actually right, a primer for people who don’t know what terms are or trying to get into this crypto space. And I don’t even think that doing an episode to explain blockchain is really something for newbs or for beginners only because I think a lot of people who walk around and think that they know a lot about crypto, they might not really know blockchain either. And I think that, for a long period, included both you and me."
## [1] " Yeah. I feel like, in a lot of ways, you can wrap your head around some weird alt-currencies and still not really wrap your head around the blockchain. And I don’t totally know that I’ve wrapped my head around it, but I generally gauge questions that normal people ask me as important. The question I’m getting a lot from people I know’s parents, like the grandparents of little kids who are running around at these little kid birthday parties that I’m cursed with now, is this question of “Yeah, but what do you think about that blockchain is the real innovation and this Bitcoin thing is just a fad?” That’s something I’ve heard from a lot of people."
## [1] " Let me ask you a question then. Let’s say I meet you at a kid birthday party and I’m like, “Hey, Aaron. I know that you have a Bitcoin podcast. I’ve heard a lot about blockchain. What is blockchain?” What do you say?"
## [1] " Okay. At its basic level, the blockchain is a ledger. Think of a blockchain as, you know when an accountant in a movie in the 1800s takes down that giant leather bound tome and starts dipping their quill and writing on a line, that’s a ledger. And if we’re going to use the Bitcoin blockchain as an example, the Bitcoin blockchain is a ledger of every transaction made ever on the Bitcoin network."
## [1] " Let’s pretend that we’re actually doing the role-playing here. You have just said that to me and I think the thing that I would say, I would interrupt you, and I would say, “Wait. There’s a Bitcoin blockchain and there’s another blockchain?”"
## [1] " All of those things are basically like … An Excel spreadsheet would be a pretty good metaphor. It’s a really long Excel spreadsheet that explains every time a transaction has happened that moves coins from one wallet to another wallet."
## [1] " Okay. What is the difference between that and what American Express does to keep track of all of my credit card and everyone else who has a credit card? It’s far more people than use Bitcoin. How is that any different than that ledger system?"
## [1] " Well, when you go and use your American Express card, say, to purchase a NBA League Pass, real world example in my case, it creates a bill in your credit account and it sends money from American Express to the people behind NBA League Pass and all of that is stored in, I would say, a fairly similar transaction, but that transaction is stored only on American Express’s servers and I don’t have any access to those servers by design. American Express could make a mistake, etc., I just have to trust that they are correctly keeping tabs on that."
## [1] " I think that there’s no two sentence way to explain any of this, right, but Google has tried. And so before we even talk about blockchain, it is important for us to try and define it in some way that people can hold in their head. I don’t think anything that you said is wrong, but I just feel like this is the problem that people always encounter. It’s why people like Venkatesh Rao, who is a writer that we both like, Paul Ford, I think that’s why they’re assigned things, or in Venkatesh’s, takes it upon himself, to write these things that try and use some sort of metaphoric way to explain the blockchain because in itself, it is both a very simple thing to grasp, but it also has so many caveats and, “Well, it’s different in this way,” that it becomes very vague. Here’s Google’s definition. I want you to respond to it."
## [1] " Yeah. And this is from, just to credit, both of us really enjoyed this Adrianne Jeffries article about the blockchain that was in The Verge, so shout-out to Adrianne Jeffries."
## [1] " Okay. Here’s Google’s definition, “Blockchain is a digital ledger in which transactions made in Bitcoin or other cryptocurrency are recorded chronologically and publicly.” That’s it."
## [1] " That sounds about right. I think the part that is really important beyond that, I’m not sure it actually has to be digital, but let’s say that’s splitting hairs, I still think it could be a blockchain if you somehow were able to create a analog blockchain, but the part that’s really tough to wrap your head around is that public, like what public means. Does public just mean it’s on a web page or you can see it or does it mean that there’s some sort of a public consensus about it and that multiple people are hosting it concurrently and validating that there is data integrity across the multiple copies of it?"
## [1] " Yeah. And, look, the one thing that the Google definition, I think, doesn’t include that I think most people in the Bitcoin community would insist upon is that there’s some sort of cryptographic protection in it, that it uses concepts of computer science cryptology to make sure that it’s secure. The best metaphor I’ve heard is let’s say that you do have that 1800s movie leather bound ledger that the old man takes down and writes in his pen. Imagine if there’s 12 of those or 500 of those or 500,000 of those and every time he wrote in his pen, people who he did not know where they were or who they were, whatever he wrote would also appear in their books through some sort of Harry Potter magic or something like that. That’s kind of the idea."
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah, it’s almost a little bit like, let’s say, there was a convention of the 1800 accountants every year and everyone kept their own ledger and then we would all get on our horses and come to Vienna and we’d all copy down everything that was in everyone else’s ledger, even transactions that we had actually had no part in, but, but doing so, we would create 500 identical copies of the ledger distributed across all of the other 1800 accountants in the Prussian Empire. And, therefore, if Johann got into some funny business-"
## [1] " This is borderline racist against Prussians."
## [1] " It’s actually legal to be racist against the Austrians. If Johann got into some funny business, we’d have 499 other copies that could prove what the true transaction record was. And so, in a lot of ways, the blockchain is not an innovation of Bitcoin. There are blockchains that predate Bitcoin. The novel innovation of Bitcoin is akin to the 1800s accounting convention, it’s how that ledger is distributed publicly and how it keeps itself safe from bad actors in the system and from people who would seek to alter it. And that itself is novel and that’s the system that requires, in the case of Bitcoin, miners who are the people who batch all the transactions together into blocks and those blocks get added to the ledger, so the people who run nodes and mine, I’m going to get to what these mean, to ensure all of those systems are working."
## [1] " I’m going to object to one part of your convention metaphor because the innovation or the decentralization of blockchain would mean that you don’t have to go to Vienna, you don’t have to be invited by the convention, you don’t have to wear a lanyard, you don’t have to have a 1800s degree in accounting, you can just be a person who shows up really from your own home and somehow they beam the whatever the ledger is into your ledger, if that makes sense. If there’s a change in it, then it shows up in your ledger. That’s the basic idea of it."
## [1] " Well, I think that’s a reasonable question, and when people’s parents ask me this question of, “Isn’t blockchain the real innovation?” at a party, I usually say, “I don’t think so.” I think the innovation is Bitcoin. I think that the killer product that’s possible because of this kind of a system is decentralized stateless money. The idea that you can have money but have no central authority, is itself a hugely provocative idea. I’m not sure that any other application of the blockchain that I’ve heard is nearly as provocative."
## [1] " Okay. But, look, there are tons of tech companies out there that use the internet and not all of them are like Google. There is different applications that can be done and it doesn’t have to be like overthrow the world economy."
## [1] " No, no. And, to be fair, I think what Civil is doing is great and I’m not sure that decentralizing money is a great idea, but I think it’s a profound idea and the system that was invented in Bitcoin, or not invented, perfected, or probably not perfected either-"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " … tried in Bitcoin?"
## [1] " Exists, it exists. We can say it exists."
## [1] " This decentralized ledger allowed people to create a currency from thin air that had a game that worked. The game allows for its own integrity. The game that they set forth with miners and nodes and coins has not been cheated on yet. And so I think that in some ways the block-"
## [1] " Is that true?"
## [1] " Well-"
## [1] " There are forks. There’s the Ethereum rollback. There’s some other problems."
## [1] " Oh, sorry, I was only talking about Bitcoin. I think that cryptocurrencies have had lots of problems."
## [1] " The context that we need to give here, I think, is that this is still us at this party. I am like annoying dad who doesn’t know that much about crypto who doesn’t want to deal with the morass of children opening presents, so I’ve started a conversation with you. Look, all I’ve heard about is companies like IBM. Even, I think, Facebook’s saying that they want to get into blockchain technology. Overstock’s starting an ICO and the CEO is saying, “Oh, I really believe that blockchain is the disruptive technology of the future.” All of that is, right now, basically what we have is that institution and corporations are basically saying, “We don’t necessarily know what to do with Bitcoin, but blockchain seems promising.” And the problem with that is that there has not been a blockchain product that’s created, other than Bitcoin or maybe Ethereum, that has been compelling or has had any use and this technology has been around almost 10 years."
## [1] " Yeah. I don’t get that. That’s what I enjoyed about the Adrianne Jeffries article. I also don’t understand what those people are talking about. Do you understand what they’re talking about?"
## [1] " No. And I think that as you and I have gone through this space, the educational process has been interesting to me because I think it probably reflects the way that a lot of people think about tech or learned about tech in the nineties, which is that you start not knowing anything because you have no idea what … you’re not a coder, you’re not an engineer. And you start to learn and everyone, by the way, is also like a snake oil salesman who is trying to sell you something, so it’s very hard to figure out what’s true. And so I think, as of three or four months ago, you and I were very interested in blockchain technology and what it was and-"
## [1] " Yeah, we definitely thought, hey, maybe we should just buy all these stocks of companies that say they’re going to get involved in blockchain. That seems like a good idea, right?"
## [1] " Yeah. And in the terms of a linear narrative about American industry, it does make sense that the internet would, at some point, be disrupted by something and that some new technology would come along and that places like Google would have some sort of competition from insurrectionary tech that they didn’t understand. This is the plot of Silicon Valley, the TV show, essentially. But, man, it has been nine years with blockchain technology. The fact that nobody can explain it in two sentences, as we’ve been proving for the past 15 minutes or 20 minutes, the fact that when you do explain it, you’re just like, “Well, look, my credit card works fine,” or “Microsoft Excel works fine. Microsoft Excel is actually a very good system.”"
## [1] " Yeah. Let me pause that briefly because I actually want to say I actually do believe in the idea of blockchain coming to influence these other industries. The part that I don’t believe in is in the IBM blockchain or the Overstock.com blockchain or the Ripple blockchain. These are all blockchains that are controlled by a single entity. They’re blockchains where one person controls the ledger, just like in American Express, so they’re really just sort of cryptocurrency wrinkles on the same old, same old. And what I think is provocative or important is the idea that there’s not a central authority."
## [1] " But Microsoft Excel is efficient. American Express-"
## [1] " Not really, if you’re running millions of lines of-"
## [1] " Compared to the Bitcoin blockchain and making one transaction?"
## [1] " Yeah, okay. Fair, fair. I’ll buy that. I’ll buy that. The whole Bitcoin blockchain is about 145 gigabytes, so it’s something that you could fit a $59 jump drive that you get from CompUSA, if that’s still in business."
## [1] " Definitely not."
## [1] " I think there’s one more part of the blockchain that we haven’t really talked about that I think is really important and is very much what I’m thinking of when we call Bitcoin an elegant system, which is mining. That’s probably the other thing that most people bring up at a party, is “Oh, why? Isn’t it using too much electricity?” What are miners doing when they’re burning all this activity? We know that they are solving these complex cryptographic problems, but what is the point of solving those cryptographic problems?"
## [1] " Well, they’re adding blocks, right?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Bitcoin-"
## [1] " Yes, which a block is just a bunch of transactions joined together."
## [1] " Bitcoin gets released into the blockchain. The blockchain chain gets amended or lengthened through mining. Adrianne Jeffries, who wrote the article, you should read it, it’s on The Verge, she’s very skeptical about blockchain, but one thing that she does say is that in the nine to 10 years that Bitcoin has been around, somehow the blockchain and the mining system has not been corrupted. It hasn’t failed yet. Look, I don’t think we need to explain mining. I understand what the blockchain is in theory. I understand what mining is in theory. I will say that when they are laid bare in this way and they’re explained, they do not seem, in my opinion, other than through the idea of it or the philosophy of it, of a decentralized, deflationary currency, they don’t seem really that special. They don’t seem like technologies that are revolutionary in any sort of way, like Elon Musk just revealed a subway that’s the size of a parking space. That’s-"
## [1] " I disagree with this. I disagree strongly."
## [1] " All right, so make a case."
## [1] " Well, I think that maybe the blockchain by itself is not revolutionary, but the idea of a decentral store of information or value that is kept alive in perpetuity and kept with integrity in perpetuity and is not controlled by any sort of central server, any sort of central state, it presents this new idea. It’s almost like-"
## [1] " But we already have that. We had that with BitTorrent. We had-"
## [1] " No, that’s not what BitTorrent is."
## [1] " We had peer-"
## [1] " BitTorrent is just the method to distribute the information."
## [1] " Sure, but we had a peer-to-peer network."
## [1] " This is the type of information that’s on BitTorrent. The ledger-"
## [1] " We had a peer-to-peer network that actually was revolutionary in many, many ways that changed industries massively, like the movie industry, the music industry. It was decentralized. It allowed people to share movies and music and books or whatever, back and forth from one another. How is this any different?"
## [1] " It’s different because there is an item, the coin, that was created purely on this blockchain that’s controlled on the blockchain and there is no one behind it. There’s not a company behind it or anything."
## [1] " But there’s no company behind BitTorrent either."
## [1] " But BitTorrent is just taking digital files that already exist elsewhere and could exist on any server and distributing them in a way that evades law enforcement. It’s not creating something new."
## [1] " Of course, it is. It created BitTorrent. It created the whole network. That’s what it created."
## [1] " What does BitTorrent do that you can’t do otherwise except that you can do it and not get caught?"
## [1] " What does Bitcoin do that you can’t do otherwise, so that you could do it and not get caught? It’s the same thing."
## [1] " Transfer money. Transfer money that’s not controlled by a state."
## [1] " I should say I’m playing devil’s advocate."
## [1] " No, I misunderstood you. I agree. Without its sidecar, I don’t think blockchain is revolutionary. People are waiting for a revolutionary application of blockchain, I think it’s currency."
## [1] " Okay. Then what is the big deal? Why is everyone saying blockchain is the future? Why are companies, like IBM, which obviously are legacy companies, why are they investing in this thing?"
## [1] " Yeah, I think this is fascinating."
## [1] " Why is the new mantra, when you … And, literally, if you go to a party and somebody knows a little bit about Bitcoin, but not a lot, the smart guy thing to say, in the same way that it was the smart guy thing to say, “Oh, well, Bernie Sanders can’t win the primary,” that type of received knowledge, I’m not-"
## [1] " Jay, you’re going to get us in trouble."
## [1] " No, but that level of, “Oh, well, of course,” this sort of … You have your New York City sort of guy-"
## [1] " Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. No, that’s a good comparison."
## [1] " Yeah. What they’ll say is, “I don’t like Bitcoin, but I heard blockchain is cool.” Where did this come from?"
## [1] " I think it makes sense that all these companies, at least on a R&D level, are looking into this. And I think that can explain some of the success of something like Ripple, it’s a sanitized version of the blockchain. And so I think that people are not yet comfortable with the idea of made-up money and Bitcoin and they want to come to the party, but they don’t want to look stupid and they don’t want to embrace a crazy idea, so they want to be down with the future, but not upend the order too much."
## [1] " No, not really, because I don’t, like I said, the more you learn about blockchain, the less impressive it gets, in my opinion at least. I don’t understand why it’s so revolutionary post-BitTorrent."
## [1] " I don’t get this BitTorrent thing. I don’t get why … BitTorrent does not do any of the same things really."
## [1] " It’s a decentralized way to send things from one person to the other, right?"
## [1] " It’s not really totally decentralized because you’re reading it from someone else’s computer."
## [1] " Well, neither is Bitcoin or the blockchain. It’s a peer-to-peer thing. It got around central servers."
## [1] " But there’s no one being incentivized to broadcast those files in a BitTorrent system. There’s no mining."
## [1] " A blockchain without Bitcoin, there’s no incentive either."
## [1] " Yeah. I agree with that. I think that for the blockchain to work, you have to create a game of it. I think of the blockchain like a bunch of game pieces in a box and you need to create the rules to the game to make it work and to make it fun and to make it sustainable. I agree, BitTorrent is a game that worked by putting a bunch of movies that people wanted onto BitTorrent, the BitTorrent network for those torrents have stayed alive for years. It used piracy to keep itself alive. I guess I think this is the first time that someone’s created a game with the blockchain that has been compelling enough that it’s got 10 years of life so far."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. I agree with you, in general, that blockchain without the Bitcoin, it’s almost like a catchphrase at this point. It doesn’t mean anything. I don’t really know what it means. But let’s move on. We have failed to define blockchain, I would say. The one thing I will say is that I think that we have failed to explain blockchain because there is a gap between the profundity of what you expect from what blockchain is, and this is something that Adrianne, in her piece, alluded to, which is that when you hear it, it seems mysterious and magical and futuristic, and that when you learn about it, you say, “Well, that can’t be it because it has to be more than that.” And, look, the idea of a decentralized ledger that keeps track of a lot of things that is not in the hands of a state, that’s not a tiny thing, but I think that we need to come to the conclusion that that actually is all it is."
## [1] " Can I punch in there with one idea, which is you asked why is IBM, why are all these people trying to get involved with the blockchain, and I think that there’s a dominant idea in technology that if you want to survive, you need to emulate the upstart little guys, the guys who are trying to eat your lunch. And I would say, if anything, the blockchain is threatening to places like American Express. The blockchain is a threat, not an asset, in my opinion, to American Express, but it doesn’t surprise me that they’re dabbling in it and doing research in it. That’s what you would try to do if you were going to try to not have it take you down."
## [1] " I’m actually more cynical than you are about it, which is that I think that, if you think about it, these companies, American Express, IBM, the companies that have come out and been very bullish on blockchain, for example Overstock, these aren’t really industry leaders. I refuse to believe that a place like Google does not have a lab that works on blockchain technology. They don’t announce it. They don’t make ads."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. They’re not like, “We have a partnership with Ripple.”"
## [1] " Yeah, exactly. I think the companies like IBM, American Express and Overstock, that part of their messaging and their marketing right now is built around this idea of the blockchain and that’s part of the reason why there’s so much confusion in the world about what it actually is and it’s sort of a marketing technique for their shareholders, I think, more than anything."
## [1] " I do. It’s not that I don’t think they’re doing it, I just think that if anyone had a really, really good idea, they wouldn’t tell everyone about it."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly, that’s how I feel."
## [1] " The fact that they’re telling everyone about it makes me think that … I think they’re their bases. These companies try everything. Everyone is trying self-driving cars. Everyone is trying everything that they can try. What will be interesting to me going forward, and something I would want to talk about on this show, is whether these faux chains ultimately make it hard for the true chains to survive. I think we’ve seen investors are just as interested in buying Ripple, which is a centralized chain, as into the Bitcoin chain. And if the only reason people really embrace decentralization is because they think it’s a good investment, I’m not sure it will survive. I think we’re shifting a little bit from the ideology of decentralization to just is decentralization a good investment, and so I think that these people are right. If they can convince people that their chains are better in some way, even though they’re centralized, they will nip this fairly profound idea in the bud."
## [1] " Yeah, I would agree with that. I wouldn’t say I totally agree with it, but I agree with it in this sense where, if you think about it from an investment standpoint, you have a new technology that is going to take over the world. You can either buy a cryptocurrency, like Bitcoin, with all of its attendant risks, or you can just put it in IBM and say, well, IBM’s blockchain will probably be better than these crazy anarcho-capitalists who keep fighting with each other on Twitter. In that way, from an investment standpoint, I do think that things will get diluted a little bit down the road if blockchain actually is promising."
## [1] " Totally agree. An example that I often think of is Western Union. We’ve seen Bitcoin ending up in places like the Philippines because it’s a very low cost remittance-"
## [1] " Or it was, and it is again. It is again, yeah."
## [1] " … or was and it sometimes is. And that has interesting cultural implications, that a bunch of people have Bitcoin on their phones who are in the Philippines and who know where that could end up in 10 years. But if Western Union looks at that and say, “Hey, somehow people are using Bitcoin instead of Western Union,” and they create the Western Union blockchain and the Western Union coin and are basically able to offer the same service at the same price, what does that mean for the future of Bitcoin? Can Bitcoin maintain a competitive advantage if people clone all of the features of Bitcoin? And I think that remains to be seen."
## [1] " Well, and that’s where we get into, I think, a place where you and I diverge a bit, which is that I think to win that fight, you need to have a better PR than Bitcoin does. And PR is maybe not the right term, but you just need a better, I guess, rallying cry that goes out to people. You need to convince the woman who is a domestic servant, I think is the right word, in Hong Kong who is from the Philippines who wants to send money back to her family and does so every month through remittances or every Sunday that it’s better to use Bitcoin than Western Union for X reason. It doesn’t matter what X reason is. It could be that, “Hey, this might triple in value,” whereas Western Union coin certainly won’t."
## [1] " Yeah. I think that I’m going to take the other side of this one and say that maybe this is the vibe between us as a journalist and non-journalist-"
## [1] " You are a journalist, by the way. I always object to you saying you’re not a journalist. You interview people for a product."
## [1] " … less objective journalist, a fake news journalist, is that I think the best PR is no PR. I feel like the fact that Bitcoin doesn’t have to explain itself and doesn’t have to answer to a board and doesn’t have to show quarterly profits is one of its great strengths. The fact that it’s doing something that corporations usually do and there’s no corporation is … I’ve never seen anything like that. It’s fascinating."
## [1] " Yeah. And, look, there’s no good answer because I think you’re right in the sense that if Bitcoin has a centralized messaging, then that’s bad. That’s not good for Bitcoin as a idea or as a currency. I think that the best thing that we could hope for is that the messaging becomes a little less toxic than it is right now and that’s about it. If it was null, then I would be, “Great,” but it definitely is not null right now, which I think is part of the problem in terms of getting some of these people who hopped in on board between October and the first of this year back on board."
## [1] " Sure, sure. Before we get out of here, you got anything to say about this market?"
## [1] " No, it’s about the same as when we talked about four days ago, right?"
## [1] " I feel like we got to go on strike here. Until the market goes up or down, we’re not going to talk about the market. You heard it here. Just start buying or selling, do something, give us something to talk about. It’s not investment advice. We don’t talk about the market. We’re just purely intellectuals considering the blockchain."
## [1] " Okay. All right. I’ll see you next week."
## [1] " All right. Talk to you next week."
