## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] " Welcome back to the crypto cave, Jay."
## [1] " I’m actually very happy to see that it wasn’t flooded by the recent storms that w had"
## [1] " It’s pretty shocking. I wo uld say it’s the first piece of luck that we’ve had in some time is the relative dryness of the crypto cave."
## [1] " I was expecting black mold and-"
## [1] " There has been black mold… When I got this place, there was black mold on the wall. I should warn you never let your child in here."
## [1] " Yeah. The child should not breathe the air of the crypto cave."
## [1] " I feel like if we totally go bust, we should just claim that both of us had some kind of toxic mold poisoning that was affecting our judgment here."
## [1] " Who can we sue then under OSHA laws? Do we have to sue you?"
## [1] " Anyone who’s done an ICO. I would have never bought some of these coins if it weren’t for this toxic black mold, which I think is actually a good segue to what I think we should talk about today. I don’t want to say the market bottomed out, but there was some kind of a bottom."
## [1] " Wait. Don’t say it. We might have to go back."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Don’t jinx it. Don’t jinx it."
## [1] " The market, I think the term is a double bottom, I think. We got down into the 7,000s in Bitcoin, and then we came back up a bit, and then went back down into the 7,000s. I thought this might be a good opportunity to discuss everything that we did wrong on the way up and the way down."
## [1] " Yeah, so we are closing in on, I would say, almost 10 months of you and me doing our sort of immature-ish and almost comical version of trading."
## [1] " I don’t even think about it so much in linear time anymore. I don’t think, “Oh, I’ve been in crypto for 10 months.” I think about I’ve been to the top of the mountain, and I’ve come tumbling down to the bottom of the muddy pond below."
## [1] " So you think of it as an actual hero’s journey."
## [1] " I do."
## [1] " There’s a narrative arc."
## [1] " That’s how I feel. I feel like there’s a narrative arc, and now we’re at the point where we’ve fallen far enough that I’m willing to talk about why we fell so far. We’re going to lose money no matter what during that market crash, but I definitely did much worse than I had to do."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah, yeah. The dragon has been met, and the dragon kicked us off the mountain. Now we’re convening around a table with mugs of mead and are trying to tell the tale and reflect on what had happened."
## [1] " I was also thinking I was on another podcast called Track Changes a few weeks ago."
## [1] " Oh no, a bigamist. A podcast bigamist."
## [1] " No, I was out there promoting our show, promoting. I was promoting our show, and the two hosts, noted no-coiners, Paul Ford and Rich Ziade. Actually, Paul is not a no-coiner. He just acts like he’s a no-coiner, but he actually does mine."
## [1] " He’s a fake no-coiner?"
## [1] " Yeah, he’s like-"
## [1] " Who mines?"
## [1] " Yeah, he was mining in 2009 he told me. He told me that at the very end. He’s like, “What is Bitcoin?” I was like, “Well …” Then he was like, “Yeah, I did some mining before …” I was like, “Oh, okay. You probably know more about this than I do.”"
## [1] " “I only have 500 Bitcoin.”"
## [1] " Something that I talked about with them about was this idea of needing to experience crypto firsthand to really wrap your head around it. I feel like we’ve embraced that hard in the show. We could just be sitting here reading the news, but we’re actually trading, often losing money for the benefit of you, the listener, out there."
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah. We have skin in the game."
## [1] " Yeah, we have skin in the game."
## [1] " You hear that in a Taleb? Unblock me on Twitter."
## [1] " You’re blocked by Taleb on Twitter?"
## [1] " I believe so."
## [1] " Wow. How are we going to ask … I’ll have to ask him to come on the show then. We’ve talked about our portfolios before. I’ll say at one point, I had doubled my money. Now I have lost that whole double, and I’m down money. Not a tremendous amount of money, but down a little bit. I’ve gone from 200% to 80%."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Are you on a similar arc?"
## [1] " In muted ways. I did not quite go up 100%, although at some point I think I was at it around there."
## [1] " I think you sold out a little bit faster on the way up, and you also protected yourself a little better on the way down I feel like."
## [1] " Yeah, I exited before you did on both ends."
## [1] " Me and Doug Kim were partying on you when you sold at 12,000. I appreciate that you have not been partying on us as we’ve white-knuckled our way all the way down."
## [1] " Well first of all, I’m a virtuous and fair man, but secondly, I will say that there is slight difference between saying, “Haha, you made money, but not as much money as me, and haha, you lost more money than I lost.”"
## [1] " Okay. So what do you think is the dumbest thing you did along the way? What was your worst mistake?"
## [1] " Okay, so I have a list of them."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " The first thing I would say that I did wrong, which I very, very much regret every single thing, is that I traded at all. Now if I looked, Coinbase recently put out your records. You can just see them in an Excel spreadsheet. This is nominally for tax reasons."
## [1] " Ah. I’m going to say I would trade all this knowledge back for that extra double in my money."
## [1] " I don’t think I would because I came into it as a complete ignoramus, know nothing about anything financial."
## [1] " Yeah, I agree. I’ve had a lot of fun. I’m just saying it would be fun to get that money back."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. No. It is a little bit close. I think if I might have invested for a larger portion of my amount of money I have in the world that I would probably feel differently, but I do think from a pure financial standpoint, there’s absolutely no argument that I would have done much, much better if I had just never tried to time the market, if I hadn’t ventured into alt, if I hadn’t, I guess, gotten greedy and tried to … I had seen other people who were saying on social media or on Reddit, “Hey, I turned this into this.”"
## [1] " Same. This one I don’t even blame myself for, because I feel like I did make a conscious choice that I was going to sample all of the food at the buffet, which is also something I do in real life. I made that decision knowing it was kind of stupid, but I’ll say this. When we were massively up, when you’re up 100% in six months, you don’t go, “Oh jeez, I would have been up 114% if I had just stuck with my initial bags.”"
## [1] " Break-even point."
## [1] " Break-even point. That was the point I realized, “Oh God, all of these …” I probably took it even further than you, because I was dabbling in the Microcaps, etc. Each time we fell in Bitcoin, I had an opportunity to just be like, “All right, correct course here. Just get everything into Bitcoin. At least from here on out, you’re not going to be doing worse because of trading,” because that’s the thing is once you trade, as long as you hold all of those things that you acquired when you traded, you’re still sort of in trading. Right now, I’m still holding Sumokoin. Even though I’m not actively-"
## [1] " Yeah, which is insane to me."
## [1] " … trading, I’m still in a traded position, relative. I don’t know how to get out of that. I’ll throw you back what I think my single biggest mistake was, which is not just trading, but trading without a coherent strategy. I think I have a coherent strategy around Bitcoin, which is to hodl it, but hodling Microcap coins is not a coherent strategy. I can tell you this from personal experience, because I bought Sumokoin very low and got to experience the great thrill of a moon shot. Was up seven or eight times on it."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah."
## [1] " Now it’s just literally one of the most wrecked coins around. We could not … If I had been like, “I want to do for the show a coin that gets really wrecked, a Microcap coin, I couldn’t have picked a better one than Sumokoin.”"
## [1] " I think that having a coherent strategy and having a sort of valueless look at all this stuff would probably have been smart for me too. There are certainly projects that I felt were more legitimate than others. The reasons why I thought they were more legitimate were completely based on just bullshit. For example Zero X, which I think is still a good project, it was because your friend John Libov was in the crypto cave and said, “Hey, this thing is kind of cool.” I was like, “This guy seems smart.”"
## [1] " We’ve got to have him back on the show."
## [1] " Then I read a bit more on it. Then I saw who was on the team. I was like, “Oh, well this might be a real thing.” Also, I was too lazy to sell it, because I have to buy it on Binnance, and it was the only coin I had on that exchange for a long time. I didn’t feel like signing in. At some point, I think I was up 100% on that. It had had this huge surge, and then another surge. Then like you in my head, I was like, “Oh, this thing is going to go. It’s going to be worth $3 each, and I’m going to be rich.”"
## [1] " Yeah, I think there’s also a psychological urge to … You’ve played poker. When you’ve made money, your first inclination is not like, “Let me take this money off the table and lock in. I’ve doubled my money.” You’re like, “Well now I’m playing with twice as much money. Imagine if I do that two or three more times?” It’s different than stock investing in so far as you can expect these Microcap coins are going to crash at some point. If you just stay in the water, you’re going to get attacked by a shark eventually."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah."
## [1] " That happened to me. I think that people maybe misunderstand the technical analysis guys a little bit, that they think that, “Oh, these guys think they can predict the future by reading these chicken guts?” What they’re doing more is they have a strategy for entering at good positions and exiting at good positions, these coins. That requires you to be very active, trade a lot, kind of know what you’re doing. Even so, you still probably have a good shot of getting stuck in the water at one of these inopportune times, because there’s unforeseen things, like the Mt. Gox trustee dumping Bitcoin."
## [1] " Was that even real? I heard that he wasn’t really market selling."
## [1] " I don’t know."
## [1] " He was definitely selling, even if it wasn’t market selling."
## [1] " Yeah. I think that it didn’t … Hey, let’s say, it didn’t help."
## [1] " It didn’t help. Okay, so the second thing that I think I made a mistake in, we’ve both done one now. The second thing I think is that the mistake that I made over and over and over again is that I kept FOMO-ing into coins based on people on Twitter saying that I should. That’s an embarrass … I had to stumble on it, because it’s an embarrassing thing to admit."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " But when it’s going down or when it’s sideways, they can get you in a lot of trouble. I think this is a point I think you and I have discussed quite a bit where our investments diverged, which is when Bitcoin was around $14,000 and going sideways, I sold all my alts. I had 16 alts, and it was all because of these guys. I just did it, because I was tired of checking everything."
## [1] " Whereas I was following the sideways corn (BTC) for alt season. Where the fuck is alt season?"
## [1] " Exactly. All these terms seem completely ridiculous now to me. Not all of them, but a lot of them. I think that saved me, which was I was once again saved by my own laziness, but there was a period where I was so exposed. It was because I was listening to so many of these guys."
## [1] " Yeah. I remember when I was a kid once, I told my parents, I was like, “Advertising has no effect on me, because I can see right through it.” It’s just like, “No you don’t.” Even if you look at Twitter and you’re like, “These guys are all dumb with the crypto cartoon characters,” if you look enough at that stuff, it’s going to influence your mind."
## [1] " Oh, for sure."
## [1] " Literally other than being that guy who doesn’t get any Trump news and lives by himself in Ohio and only watches Cavs games on mute, if you’re not that guy, and you’re on Twitter, and you’re on crypto Twitter, you’re going to be influenced by it, even if you think you’re ridiculous. This is something I have learned is that every single piece of information you take in does affect how you trade, if you’re trading."
## [1] " No, me neither."
## [1] " But everything is pulling you which way, and look, if you’re at an amusement park, you’re going to want to ride all the rides."
## [1] " Yeah, and-"
## [1] " If you see a bunch of guys whipping by on a roller coaster, and they’re like, “Woo! Dragon Coin!” You’re going to be like, “What’s that all about, huh? Those guys seem like they’re having a good time over there.”"
## [1] " Yeah, the Dragon Coin guys were having a ton of fun for a long time. Yeah, I even looked them up. I was like, “Ooh, they’re in Seattle, huh? That seems like a good party.” Look, I agree. I don’t have any malice towards them, and I certainly don’t think that what they’re doing is worse than what Bernie Madoff was doing. Obviously there’s-"
## [1] " That’s a pretty fucking low bar."
## [1] " No, no, no, but there’s no-"
## [1] " I think what they’re doing is better than what Jim Cramer is doing."
## [1] " Yes, exactly."
## [1] " Because they’re not getting paid for it. They’re just doing their thing."
## [1] " My point being there’s shills and there’s fraud everywhere and for a crypto shill who generally has a pretty good sense of humor, sometimes very problematic, but who is doing this in some sort of good faith, it’s actually better than the financial markets in a lot of ways. I don’t have malice towards them. I just wish I hadn’t listened to them so much."
## [1] " Yeah, and I agree with you that the overall message is probably just don’t trade. Don’t try to have a strategy within sort of listening to those guys or going against them. The only way you can really ignore them is to not trade, I think, although I’m going to keep trading, because it’s fun."
## [1] " Number two for you, what was it?"
## [1] " Okay, so my number two worst thing, I think this is actually my number one in terms of how much it actually cost me was I originally bought in. I think my first buys were in the 3 to 4,000 range of Bitcoin. At the point I crossed in my break even, I was at 7,500. I was like, “Whoa, how did that happen?” My break even point was double my first buy."
## [1] " You somehow traded away your entire profit."
## [1] " Basically what had happened was I had been pumping more money in as we went up, because I was like, “Hey, the last money I did made me money.” I just couldn’t get the money in fast enough. Literally I was just waiting for CoinBase to move the money into my account so I could immediately buy."
## [1] " I remember this. I remember this."
## [1] " That felt like it was working while the market was continually going up. I was like, “I don’t want to wait a day. I want to get my money in the market.” I thought that was good, because I thought I was cost averaging. What I was ultimately doing, I think, was taking a really good position and gradually making it worse and worse until my ultimate transgression, which was I did buy the very, very top."
## [1] " Or $5,800."
## [1] " $5,800 Bitcoin, but I had already put out my money in that $69,900 buy."
## [1] " I think that’s related to the first thing, which was that neither of us had a strategy at all. I had a friend who is very smart, and he didn’t care about the tech. He only saw it as a volatile investment. He said that his friend who does a lot of number crunching stuff, and is very smart, and is one of these sort of math whizes said, “Look, if it breaks parabolic form, then you should get out immediately, because it’ll be very ugly afterwards. But sure, buy it until it breaks parabolic arc.”"
## [1] " Yeah. I was thinking also, I think if I had it over again, if you really feel like you’re confident in this parabolic and knowing when it’s going to break, great. Otherwise, as it’s going up, and you’re getting close to doubling your money, you should be basically selling on the way up. If we know this is a volatile-"
## [1] " Yeah, taking project. Taking profits is good."
## [1] " Yeah, or even if you don’t look at it as profits and you just think that you have a US dollar component of your portfolio that sits in your Coinbase account or whatever, as your investment goes up, if you assume that there’s going to be a crash at some point, and me and you I think both said we expected at least a 40% drop at some point when we were over 10,000, I should have been selling on the way up. If I really believed in that prediction, I should have been selling on the way up to buy that 40% drop, which turned out to be well more than 40%."
## [1] " Yeah. We both got … Look, this is one of the sort of abiding credos of investing or anything, we just got very greedy."
## [1] " Yeah, we did."
## [1] " At the point where you and I probably had a combined 35 total shit coins in our bags, that was the point … Things like Tron and everything on Cryptopia were going up 600% in four days, that was a greed flare. Everything has become unmoored, and now it’s just about greed. You and I just didn’t see it. That is one of the informational things or the sort of educational things that I do think was valuable for me to have seen."
## [1] " Yeah, and I was like, “Ha ha ha ha ha.”"
## [1] " Yeah. I don’t know if he would have, but the idea seemed preposterous to both of us."
## [1] " Yeah, it’s still in play."
## [1] " Yeah, but it’s still in play. That, I think is-"
## [1] " It’s still very much in play."
## [1] " I think that’s the difference between … It’s not like my father is some sort of investment genius, but he’s older and has been through more market stuff. I think that’s the difference between being sort of like an older long-term investor and somebody who’s FOMOed in, which is like he can see that it doesn’t matter if it goes to three this year or next year, he sees some long-term potential in all this, and he doesn’t want to buy until it’s totally cratered out. The point where he decided that it’s cratered out is 3,000 now."
## [1] " Or both."
## [1] " Or both."
## [1] " Okay, here’s something that I’m curious what you think about. The two terms that are most crypto orthodox I believe would be hodl and BTFD, buy the fucking dip."
## [1] " Both getting slaughtered right now."
## [1] " Right. I think either my embrace of these ideas or my misinterpretation of them has definitely contributed to my poor performance during this crash. Let’s talk about hodl first."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Because I think hodl is like when we make the movie about this crypto era, it’s going to be called Hodl. I saw someone say this, and it should be obvious to everyone else, obviously, that if you were running a Ponzi scheme, the best thing that could happen to you for the people who had bought into your Ponzi scheme is they hodl. A Ponzi scheme is never revealed if everyone hodles."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. That’s why-"
## [1] " I’m not saying that crypto is a Ponzi scheme, but I am saying that everyone hodling has a weird group effect. When I started embracing hodling, or I started thinking a lot about hodling, it’s like hodl what? If you’re trading, you shouldn’t hodl everything. A guy hodled Sumokoin all the way down, because it was like, “I’ll just hodl. It’ll come back.” I didn’t have a methodology to sell from the top, and my only view on the bottom was like, “Uh, hodl? Hodl? Hodl?” I think hodl is a great strategy if you buy Bitcoin and never trade and hodl it, but that does not apply when you’re buying weird off-brand Microcap coins."
## [1] " I also think it makes sense if you buy in a time of low volatility, right?"
## [1] " Is there ever a time of low volatility?"
## [1] " Sure. I would say that the period when it was hovering around 11,000 is relatively low volatility. I think right now is pretty relatively low volatility. It’s been stuck at … If you believe that Bitcoin is going to have another renaissance or another push, it’s not bad to buy at 8,000. There’s no real difference between buying at 8,300 and 7,500 if you’re not-"
## [1] " Sure, no."
## [1] " It’s really insignificant, given the actual ups and downs that take place. I think it’s fine if you do that, and you’re just like, “Well, here’s where I’m going to buy in. I’m going to hodl until my exit point.” I think the problem is that for investors like you or me, or people who are even more casual, is that hodl mentality is not just based on the soundest investment advice. It’s based on a philosophy to try and destroy the world banking system."
## [1] " Yeah, which I’m kind of into."
## [1] " Yeah, so that’s-"
## [1] " That’s the part of hodling I like."
## [1] " Yeah, it’s basically like you may lose money, but you sure as hell better be dedicated to our cause. It’s like a military command almost. Don’t break rank. Don’t sell. Don’t leave. Don’t you dare have weak hands and let go right now. In that way, it makes no sense for anyone who bought into Coinbase on the way up, anyone who FOMOed in or any other sort of casual retail investors, it makes absolutely no sense for them, because all they want to do is increase their US dollar amount. They’re not trying to contribute to hyper Bitcoinization."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah, yeah."
## [1] " Hodl makes sense, I think, if you buy into the philosophy of hyper Bitcoinization. You believe that this currency will bank the bank list, that it will destroy the world fiat currency system, if you believe that a deflationary currency is better than an inflationary currency, then you’re on a team. That team is headed into … Or really it’s more just like a military thing. You’re in a platoon. That platoon cannot bail. You can’t be the person who deserts it. Everyone has to go towards the battle. Everyone has to have strong hands. They all have to charge in."
## [1] " Yeah, I don’t know if you have to believe in a world economy [flippening 00:32:35] to think in terms of Bitcoin value, but it certainly helps."
## [1] " Well, I think in terms-"
## [1] " You have to at least have a long view."
## [1] " I’m more just saying that hodl works for those people. I understand why it’s a rallying cry for those people. I don’t think it’s a rallying cry for anyone else. Look, now there is part of me that thinks that this directly conflicts with the first rule that I said, which is that I wish I had never traded, but I think the way to sort of I guess peg all those three together or sort of staple them together in a very messy way, which is to say that you shouldn’t trade based on emotions."
## [1] " Yeah, I agree with that."
## [1] " You have to kind of figure out what type of investor you are. If you’re new into this, most likely you’re just trying to make more money. Hodl doesn’t make sense for those people at all. I think that those people should just have very clearly defined exit points."
## [1] " Yeah, I think I overall agree with you. I think you’re describing it as some people should hodl and some people shouldn’t hodl. The way I think about it is hodling means multiple things. Emotionally, you’re just going to map it to whatever you want to do."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah."
## [1] " It’s dangerous to have a rule that’s like the rule above all rules, but it’s open to interpretation. I’ll say the other one, this segues into buy the dip is the other one. When people tell you to buy the dip, how are you supposed to identify the dip? The dip is another example of you don’t really know what’s going to happen with the market. To know that something’s a dip, you have to know that you’ve bottomed and are coming back up."
## [1] " That “buy the dip” mentality I think has been popularized a lot more in the last five years of the stock market, which was just seeing sort of-"
## [1] " Oh, is “buy the dip” a stock market thing too?"
## [1] " Yeah, it’s just constant growth, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " If we have a minor correction like we had last month in the stock market, then people would just be like, “Buy the dip. The SMP is unstoppable.” For people who did that a month ago, they profited for now at least. If you bought Amazon when it tanked back down to 1,100 or something like that, it’s almost at 1,600 now. You profited. That application into crypto would make more sense if we had five years of unstopped growth, but since every single timeline in crypto is so compressed, it is very hard to figure out what’s a dip and what’s a crash."
## [1] " My final idea on there is just I didn’t know it was actually a stock market idea, but in crypto, 10, 15, 20%, if I had a time machine, I’d just be like, “Dude, that’s not a dip.” In crypto, a dip is like 40, 50%. When crypto is down 50% like it is now, this I would call a dip. None of the times I bought I think were actually dips, in retrospect."
## [1] " Yeah. I think I bought one correctly, but then I never exited, so it got wiped out anyway. If I had exited at the top of it, then it would have been fine. Again, I think that this is sort of what happens when amateurs like you and I become exposed to market terms for the first time."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah."
## [1] " This is my last one, my last regret that I had. It’s that I wish that I had paid a little bit more attention to psychological factors that were entering in my brain. This is something you alluded to as well, which is that at the very beginning, I started reading books about the ways in which investors behave. Some of these things I think are great, and some of them are kind of like crackpot psychology."
## [1] " Huge."
## [1] " Where the second that you’re up, you start making different decisions, because you think you’re playing with house money. The second that you’re down, you start making much different decisions, because you feel like you’re down, and you either need to get back to even, or you don’t want to lose, so you’re cutting losses at that point."
## [1] " I would argue that every single mistake we’ve talked about during this whole show, you could have talked about that psychological effect."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly. When you and I were up, we were buying all the alts, because we were like, “Fuck it, why not. Let’s turn this into 50X instead of 2X,” right?"
## [1] " Yeah, and we were also like, “Oh, boo-hoo. We could have made a little more money if we had stuck with Bitcoin.” We’re partying."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. Exactly. The second that it gets hairy and the second where you’re like, “I will have less money than I started with,” then you really start cutting your losses and you start making-"
## [1] " You brain kicks into a different gear."
## [1] " Yeah, and I would say that if you were smart, that you wouldn’t change, that you would be able to identify patterns that work throughout your entire investing, and that you would see going down as another opportunity. I just never got there. I was always just to worried about it. It’s interesting, because you can read about these concepts. You can identify them in your own behavior. This is something I know very well from gambling, which is that when you’re stuck, when you’re down, let’s say you’re down three buy-ins at a 2–5 [inaudible 00:39:21] game, so you’re down $4,000 or something, you play so different than when you’re up, or even $200 or something like that."
## [1] " I don’t know poker that well, but my understanding is that there are some people who are very good down players who can play a short stack very well and play well when they’re down, and some people who are like, “I’m very good at building an advantage, and I can potentially win a tournament once I have it, but I’m never going to come from behind and win one.”"
## [1] " That’s tournament play, and I would say that those differences are probably a little bit over stated. The best players are able to play the same way well and tailored to their competition regardless if their up or down. That’s what you want in crypto as well."
## [1] " Yes. 10,000 hours of poker does not make you not freak out when you’ve lost money."
## [1] " It should. I think the most powerful force in crypto is probably FOMO, and the second most powerful effect is the house money effect."
## [1] " Yeah, the house money effect is very real. Embracing different strategies when you’re up and down is basically the worst thing you can do. A very clear way to do it, and this brings it around to my final mistake, is I think I was over-exposed. I think I had too much money in there. What that meant was that while I was up, I was partying, and when it came down, my strategy changed, because I was trying to preserve my money."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " I think that putting in less money … What I should have done was the opposite. I should have put in half as much money as I could afford to lose, and that would have left half on the sidelines that I could do or play whatever. I think this is a poker thing also. If you’re trying to break even, you’re not going to play poker very well."
## [1] " You should just not play poker."
## [1] " You should not play poker. You really want to be able to play with every chip that you have on the table, and I think that once we got closer to break even, I had sold some. I sold some at 11,500, which was like, “Yeah, good job. That was smart,” right? Clearly what I should have been doing was firing at 7,500. I should have been buying down and lowering my average. On the way up, I was very happy to raise my cost average, but once it was down, once I was down, I was not as aggressive at buying when it was down."
## [1] " Yeah, well that’s the thing. That’s where it really does help to basically what some trading experts tell you to do is just do the opposite of what your feelings are telling you to do."
## [1] " I don’t even know what my feelings are telling me to do. I do think having less money in there actually will allow me to play a better game. I think going forward, I would be inclined to make a smaller investment and play that hand aggressively rather than have a larger investment that I’m anxious and conservative about, because I put some stop losses, in, because I was like, “Ah, I don’t want to do it.”"
## [1] " Well, it could."
## [1] " It could, but the odds are astronomical."
## [1] " It has before."
## [1] " A 50% dip?"
## [1] " It certainly crashed back down when it seemed like it was almost impossible for them to make a large profit, given their prices."
## [1] " That’s true. That’s true."
## [1] " It really took AWS being unveiled as this massive success to really sort of supercharge them back up. Look, any of this stuff is … I don’t know if it’s 50%, but it was large."
## [1] " Put it this way. If you have a diverse stock portfolio, you can take a hit, but you’re probably not going to go to zero. I think that Bitcoin you kind of have to be comfortable playing down and playing in that negative realm and keeping your strategy going. It just seems like this probably has other parallels to poker, which is you’re playing the lower stakes game so you can play the game you want to play. Don’t play in the game that’s in over your head and you’re freaked out about the money."
## [1] " Yeah. I think that’s true. The only other thing that I would say is that it’s just a question of do you want to make more money so that you have more stability, or do you want your life to be changed?"
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " What a life-changing amount of money is, it’s a contextual thing. For some people, it’s $15,000. For some people, it’s $10 million. If you are at a point where you feel like, “I am never going to hit that spot of life-changing money,” then that’s when people sort of buy in too much. I would say that I’m pretty sympathetic to people who do that."
## [1] " I am too."
## [1] " Because I feel like at some point when you read the biographies, and they might be apocryphal, but of really rich people or people who have succeeded financially in a way that you would want to succeed at, they all take that huge risk point, like [inaudible 00:45:59] who I interviewed back when I was at Grantland and my book came out. Bill let me do the BS Report once, and all I did was talk to [inaudible 00:46:07] for an hour."
## [1] " Nice. I got to listen to that. I missed that one. That was before my BS Report was [crosstalk 00:46:13]."
## [1] " [inaudible 00:46:14] has told this story in other context, but at some point, he had, I think it was $70,000, and it was all the money he had in the world from working as a sky cap in an airport. He put it all on the Lakers to win the championship. That was probably a very risk decision."
## [1] " I thought that this story was going to have more dimensions than some crazy [inaudible 00:46:37], and it worked."
## [1] " No, no, no, no. He said that he felt the Lakers were clearly the best team. He didn’t understand why they were basically a 10 to 1 to win the championship. It was nowhere close to 10 to 1, and that he was fully confident the whole time, but that’s a huge risk he took."
## [1] " Yeah. No, I embrace that. Actually, I like the idea of taking huge risks, and I’m comfortable with it. I actually am not saying, “Oh, I’m bummed that I over-exposed myself.” I’m just bummed that my over-exposure led to shitty psychological fear that led me to play the game poorly, because if I made a big bet and I played the game well, I’d feel okay losing it. The worst feeling it would be I made a big bet, and then I also didn’t play it well. That would be like if he bet the Lakers, and it was like, “Oh God, I have too much on the Lakers. I’m going to borrow some money in hedge,” you know?"
## [1] " Exactly. That’s the problem, yeah."
## [1] " That’s kind of what I’ve been doing."
## [1] " Then you lose all bets."
## [1] " Then a dark horse wins, and you lose the hedge, and you lose it. That’s kind of how I played this. I’m going to toot our horn here, Jay. One thing we did well, I think we’ve been pretty honest about this stuff. I have not tried to overinflate my gains or soft-pedal my losses. I do think that there’s a value, I hope, to the listeners and the people out there that not everyone’s going to tell you how this stuff really goes for them. I think we’ve been trying to do that."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. For sure. I think that we have also tried, at least, and perhaps it’s something maybe we’re just blocked psychologically. We’ve been dishonest, and maybe it’s not even an intentional thing, but most of the decisions-"
## [1] " Wouldn’t it be shocking if you found out that I didn’t actually own any crypto ever this whole time?"
## [1] " Yeah, I think I would just not talk to you anymore. Something is very wrong with Aaron. I feel like even the good decisions that we’ve made sometimes are for specious reasons. It sort of highlights how chaotic all of this is."
## [1] " I think I was reacting to Dan Bilzerian."
## [1] " I don’t know."
## [1] " Noted poker player was like, “Woo, real crypto blood bath out there. Lucky I sold out a few months ago. It’s starting to look juicy again. Maybe I’ll buy in.” People notably were like-"
## [1] " Dan Bilzerian said that?"
## [1] " Yeah, notably were like, “You didn’t tweet when you sold.”"
## [1] " Buy back in if Dan Bilzerian’s back in."
## [1] " I was just like don’t believe anyone who is like, “I sold at the perfect time,” but doesn’t tell you that until after the crash or whatever."
## [1] " Exactly. I agree."
## [1] " Take anyone’s gains or losses with a grain of salt. If you really want people to believe in it, play with your hands up. Say that you’re selling, because I feel like Dan Bilzerian was tweeting about his having Monero in his portfolio a couple months ago. Maybe he tweeted that and then immediately sold, but it just seems like a lot of hindsight 20/20 kind of stuff."
## [1] " Yeah, agreed."
## [1] " Cool. All right. Now that we’re back at break even, I feel like we’re starting a new season out here."
## [1] " I know, season two."
## [1] " Yeah. I actually that’s a question I have for you. Are you just letting it run forever, or are you going to at some point kind of sell out and start over a new investment or something like that?"
## [1] " I have sold almost all of my crypto."
## [1] " Oh, so you did this accidentally you already did this?"
## [1] " Yeah. I have very little left. I probably this past weekend, I was in Las Vegas for the NCAA tournament, and I was willing to lose more betting on college basketball teams that I have never seen play and couldn’t name it than I have in crypto right now."
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " I think it needed to be sub five for me to feel like it was real blood in the water."
## [1] " That’s some bloody water."
## [1] " That’s what I’m waiting for. I’m waiting for sub 5, and then I’ll think about it."
## [1] " That’s like there’s more blood and sharks in the water than water in the water. Unfortunately, I would love to be sold out for a while so I could root for a crash with you, but I’d like to get back up to break even. I’m close to break even now, but not quite there. I figure once I hit break even, I think I’m going to maybe sell off all my alts, literally consolidate my Bitcoin back to Coinbase, because it’s all over the place."
## [1] " No you won’t."
## [1] " But that’s going to require liquidating my Sumo bag and resigning my title as a Feudal lord, which it’s almost worthless now. It’s almost like-"
## [1] " Yeah, you’re on barren lands right now. There’s like one horse on your-"
## [1] " No, it’s basically like it would be kind of a great to put on the tombstone of my Cryptopia investments that I got hacked, because it would kind of let me off the hook a little bit if I could just write that one off."
## [1] " No, it’s not your fault. It’s not your fault."
## [1] " Get back all to Bitcoin, and then maybe kind of start over for Zero again. I think this time I’m going to be really conscious about my average buy. I’m going to try to say this is my average buy. All I want to do is do well percentage wise relative to that buy. Don’t worry about too much about how much money you have in or what that is. Just try and play this like a sport and say, “If I can do X percentage based on my original buy, I’ll feel good about that.”"
## [1] " That sounds good."
## [1] " All right. Cool. We’ll see you next week."
## [1] " See you next week."

## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] " Welcome back to Coin Talk. Our very first repeat guest, Mr. Ledger Status."
## [1] " Is that true?"
## [1] " Well, congratulations."
## [1] " We’ve got a super fan and repeat guest then. I think you must be the only person who’s listened to every episode."
## [1] " You’re in the Coin Talk hall of fame, Ledger."
## [1] " So, how has it been watching us, who you saw as little tadpoles, swim into the world and get eaten by larger frogs?"
## [1] " Bears. Yes, venture out of the pond and get eaten by bears."
## [1] " While we’re on the topic of mistakes, I wanted to bring up we got some mail bag here from Laura Shin, one of my favorite crypto journalists, pointing out several of probably many, many factual errors I have made on this show."
## [1] " I feel like she was kind to us and only pointed out the biggest ones, but she might have a spreadsheet that is very, very long."
## [1] " I was gonna say her tone was generous, and she didn’t make me feel bad about it; she just wanted to educate me, so I’m just gonna put them out here. Most of these related to our blockchain show, which I will acknowledge, Jay, that we were pretty sure we got so much stuff wrong that we almost canceled releasing that show."
## [1] " We had, I believe, what was like a 20 to 30 minute long conversation about how embarrassingly wrong we were probably about every single thing-"
## [1] " Okay, so here-"
## [1] " … necessitated us actually canceling that show."
## [1] " Okay, so here are a few of the things that I got wrong in those two blockchain episodes. One, proof of work was invented in 1993. I think I insinuated that proof of work was a Bitcoin innovation. Totally wrong. Not right at all. I also think, I haven’t even actually gone back to listen to these things because I’m too embarrassed, but that I have said on this show that blockchains existed before Bitcoin. That is also not true."
## [1] " And also, you know, I think that we’re being big men here. I’m proud of us. We have a rigorous correction policy, and anyone else who says that we get anything wrong, we will look over it because we don’t really know everything about everything, and it’s very hard to sort of fact check while you’re on a microphone, but you know what? Thank you Laura Shin for pointing that out. That’s a sincere thank you."
## [1] " I’d like to nominate Laura as our public editor who can investigate various ways in which we’ve gone astray, and I’d also like to invite her on the show if she will ever come on the show. She runs one of our favorite podcasts on crypto stuff, and I highly recommend people check that out."
## [1] " All right. Should we get to some news?"
## [1] " Yeah, so I guess let’s do a little news with Ledger here, and then we’ll ask him a little bit about what he thinks about the market. I actually mostly invited him on this show just so that I would have someone to defend my bullish positions for me, so I’m hoping that occurs."
## [1] " Something caught my eye, and it really sort of is in the intersection of my interests, which are sports, and for a while I was very into boxing and also sort of celebrity fraud and ICOs, which is that … I’m not sure if you guys saw this, but Centra Coin, which is one of these coins that is sort of said that it was an amalgam of financial products on the blockchain, blah, blah, blah; here’s our ICO, here’s our token. It was one of these things where it felt like you just cut and paste words from different white papers and then sort of processed them all through some sort of random word generator, and you pop out with white paper."
## [1] " Didn’t they basically say they didn’t even really know who they were dealing with though, right? Are these the same guys who were like, before they did this, they were running a scheme to rent Lamborghinis to people and like a fake high-end car rental service or something like that?"
## [1] " I think that they are pure grifters, like if you wanted to make a film about grifting in 2014 through 2018, this would be a great template for it."
## [1] " I was gonna say, this story just smells like the outer rings of Miami."
## [1] " Or Las Vegas, right?"
## [1] " Or Las Vegas."
## [1] " There’s part of it that-"
## [1] " They’re from Florida, though, I think, right?"
## [1] " Yeah, yeah, yeah. There’s definitely part of it that I respect, which is that I kind of respect all forms of blatant grift, and I think that it sort of shows that the things that people were saying that a lot of people who have entered the ICO space are just straight up scammers who don’t know anything about Bitcoin or any of this stuff. I think it did sort of happen and that it did sort of come out around these celebrity endorsements."
## [1] " It’s funny how when people will be like, “We can’t let celebrities endorse these ICOs. I mean, how are people gonna know which ones are real and which ones are scams?” It’s like, people will know. They’re all scams. There’s no real product that would try to get Floyd Mayweather to sponsor its ICO. They’re 100% scams. There’s no sheep in the wolf pack."
## [1] " I’ve got a question for the two of you about this, which is that is there a celebrity that you would trust enough where if they endorse an ICO … Look, like Floyd Mayweather has been caught up in legal problems his entire career; Steven Seagal, he’s Steven Seagal; Paris Hilton, pretty washed up; but is there a celebrity where if they’re like, “I am really into this cryptocurrency,” that you would listen and you would think maybe actually that adds credibility to it. What is the line?"
## [1] " Wow."
## [1] " Okay. Ashton Kutcher. That is one that came to my mind as well."
## [1] " Ledger went there. Straight to Ashton Kutcher."
## [1] " I think half the Golden State Warriors have VC firms at this point, too, but I think Ashton Kutcher is on the far side of credible. Is there somebody who you would be a little bit more uncomfortable with but you would still say, “Eh, maybe this is real.”"
## [1] " Wait, Jay, you’re saying that Ashton Kutcher has too much credibility to be used in this game? Come on."
## [1] " Yeah, he’s walking around with tons of credibility on this."
## [1] " Come on. He was on a hit sitcom and has made some tech investments."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. That’s pretty good, I think."
## [1] " The crazy part here is that it’s almost all scams. People aren’t lending their credibility to like angel investments that got set up at like a Starbucks in Palo Alto. These guys are like Florida luxury car scammers."
## [1] " Aaron, Aaron. Can you answer the question please?"
## [1] " Can I answer the question? Well I have to say that when I saw some project that Mark Cuban had said he was sort of involved with, and I was interested."
## [1] " But he’s way far on that side, too."
## [1] " Oh, you’re saying I have to go dirty."
## [1] " Yeah. Who is the person who is right on that line where you’re like, “I don’t know,” but then you end up saying, “Okay, maybe I trust them.”"
## [1] " Tom Brady. Like a Avocado Coin."
## [1] " I’d say Draymond would be right on the border area for me."
## [1] " I was gonna say, “Which one of the Warriors were tied up in these VC firms?”"
## [1] " I mean, I would say that Iguodala is a definite no problem; go for it. Draymond is straddling that line ’cause I could see Draymond getting taken in by some swindlers."
## [1] " What about Clay Thompson?"
## [1] " Clay Thompson I would absolutely not invest in anything that Clay Thompson’s invested in. I know way too much about Clay Thompson. I’ve followed his Instagram for too long for me to ever consider taking advice from him."
## [1] " Ledger, is there someone closer to the line that you would listen to if they were giving you ICO investment advice?"
## [1] " Bobby Knight."
## [1] " Definitely not Bobby Knight."
## [1] " Oh, Richard Sherman?"
## [1] " Sherman."
## [1] " He got released."
## [1] " Yeah, no, [, I mean he is very smart, and he’s very entrepreneurial, and he’s also into Bitcoin. I was thinking about this, and I was like, “If Lil Wayne endorsed a coin, would I be okay with it?” And I think the answer is yes because I don’t think that if you’re that famous and if you have that much money that you would be sort of putting your money behind a scam for no reason."
## [1] " Did you see today that John McAfee said that he was getting paid $101,000 per tweet?"
## [1] " He said he was endorsing … That’s incredible."
## [1] " $105,000."
## [1] " Okay, so both of these topics actually speak to what I wanted to talk about in kind of similar ways. We’re basically talking about the deep need for marketing within cryptocurrency. John McAfee, these celebrity ICOs, they’re all basically forms of advertising."
## [1] " Swift no from Ledger Status. Jay?"
## [1] " No. I don’t think it matters so much. I mean, I think that the idea that the hyper accelerant of the crypto prices between November and December of last year was because everyone started seeing James Altucher’s face on their webpages. I just don’t buy it. If anything it was because the media hyped it up; you know, places like Bloomberg or CNBC. I don’t think it was because of these insidious ads that were everyone."
## [1] " Wait, Ledger, I have a question there because, and you’ve been around a little bit longer than we have. So, we all know about Altucher style ads, and I’ve seen ads for like, “It’s the hottest new coin!” Just like totally no name, bozo advertisements, but are Coinbase and Gemini also feeding their new user flows with this kind of advertising you think? Or is this only like the scammier end of the pool?"
## [1] " I’m gonna take the opposite tact here, which is I think for the next plateau to be reached, and we’re like so far below the previous plateau that maybe it doesn’t even matter, but I kind of think that these huge companies that want to do Silicon Valley type scale eventually are gonna need to use advertising and marketing to pad their user numbers. I guess it depends whether you look at the metric of crypto as how much money is in the system or how many people are flowing into the system, but to flow a lot of people into a tech product, you generally need to put out a lot of money."
## [1] " Yeah, I mean, full disclosure, I also host a podcast about the one other thing that you’re not allowed to advertise for online, which is weed. It’s notable to me that all of these companies in both cases were like, “The potential upside for us of this advertising market is not worth it to deal with the crap we’re gonna have to deal with around scams and bad actors, and it would actually be better for us to just not even touch this market.”"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Another thing that’s come out in the last week that it’s also a big problem with European privacy laws where there’s laws that you have to be able to take someone offline if they request-"
## [1] " Oh yeah, yeah, yeah, the Google forget laws."
## [1] " The Google forget laws could be a big problem. All these things are individually … I acknowledge them as somewhat trivial, and clearly there are outcomes where they’re not a problem, but all of this stuff does make me think crypto businesses are kind of a pain in the ass for regulators and for internet companies and for all of these people, and people assume that people are gonna root out the bad actors in the system and that the good actors will thrive."
## [1] " Yeah, but I don’t know if the ad stuff really affects that because look, I agree with you mostly here, but I would say that the one distinction that I would make is that what we’re talking about still and it’s one thing that I don’t think we’ve reached is a revolutionary movement. Like a moment where things just sort of flip and where there’s wide scale adoption, and for whatever reason, and it could be a catastrophic reason, that there is wide scale adoption of Bitcoin and people start taking it very seriously for reasons outside of just the price."
## [1] " Well, I’ll also just say as a side note that if none of these people want to take advertising dollars, it’s an opportunity for people to create crypto-related entertainment and informational products, which conserve those ads. Our sponsor lines are open. Hire cointalk.show."
## [1] " Yeah. Hey, Ledger Status."
## [1] " The Ledger podcast, as well."
## [1] " Yeah. Ledger’s podcast, Ledger Status, and so I don’t forget later, where can people find all your stuff on the web, Ledger?"
## [1] " So, let’s talk about what we brought Ledger on the show for, which is that, and this is something you’ve told us privately on telegram and through messaging, which is that the tone of the show has become very, very bearish. Basically every week we’re like, “Oh my God, my bags. My bags are so bad. The bags are never gonna get better. I’m so glad I sold some of my bags.”"
## [1] " If you were to write one sentence that describes the extant arc of this show, it’s Jay convinces Aaron everything is bad."
## [1] " So, Ledger, we wanted to have you on because we respect your opinion on these things. Of the guys who are on Twitter talking about the markets, we think that you are a standup guy, that you don’t have ulterior motives, that you do see this as an educational experience. So, what is your sense right now? You’ve read all the headlines. It’s very bad; things are down 60% from all time highs; they keep going down. But you seem to remain bullish on this. Can you explain to us why?"
## [1] " You heard him people. Come at him."
## [1] " Yeah, come on BCash rappers. Drop a verse."
## [1] " So then the narrative that you’d basically be formulating there would be people buy during the big manic up period, sell as it crashes, weak hands, et cetera, big investors buy up that cheap supply, ride it back up."
## [1] " This is basically a preview of my future. You’re [crosstalk 00:27:05]."
## [1] " Where I see the next month of my life going."
## [1] " Can I get you to come on and just say, “I told you so,” when that exact thing happens to me? ’Cause literally the question I was about to ask you was, “Well, so, if we’re kinda sitting here in shark-infested water, and yeah, we can expect a return to $9,000 or $10,000 at some point, but we could see a drop, I’m kinda like why shouldn’t my money be on the sidelines right now? It seems like no one knows what’s happening right now.” And you’re kind of espousing something of a HODL philosophy."
## [1] " Wait, wait. Ledger, wait. I want to pause you there for one second. I wanna pause you for one second. Jay?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " You have been calling for this bear market actively on this show, cheering it on like it was a college football team. How did it feel at the exact moment that Ledger just described as where everyone was like, “Yeah, but there’s gonna be that tipping point, and it’s not gonna go below … “ How did it feel as it crashed through there for you?"
## [1] " I just … Look, everything is random, right? This is something that I learned just from years of being bad at fantasy baseball, which is that you have to sort of take out the narrative part of it and what you thought, and so my thought, essentially, was a narrative-based idea, which was essentially that I felt like the buzz that went on around the holiday seasons was gone, and that a lot of sort of the scammier things, whether it was Tether and Bitfinex, which I think was overblown but certainly was not false, you know?"
## [1] " But do you feel like there was no sort of spoof trading or fraudulent trading going on, not only on Bitfinex, but also on Korean exchanges or Japanese exchanges? I mean, of course there was."
## [1] " Shots fired."
## [1] " Okay, that’s fair. Look, we don’t have to full on endorse, and that’s why I tried to hedge a bit. We don’t have to full on endorse what he said, right? But we can say that there are things that would catch the eye of any sort of financial regulator, and I do agree that what was going on in Korea with sort of money laundering, but also as for the trading that was going on over there ’cause they had absolutely no regulations on those exchanges, that it probably did drive the price up some, so I was saying that because Korea clamped down on regulations and sort of eliminated a lot, maybe not all, but a good portion of the Chinese money laundering, that I just thought that the main things that were driving the market up were going to disappear now."
## [1] " It’s unknowable in a way."
## [1] " It is kind of unknowable because we’re just dealing with random, right? So, the question that I have for you, which is that I don’t want to mischaracterize myself and say that I’m super bearish for life, right? Like I think that the technology is good. I think that cryptocurrency is philosophically interesting."
## [1] " I’m thinking about becoming an optimist once I’m rich enough to retire."
## [1] " Isn’t there a way to do a bullish attitude towards crypto that is not like, we should by now, you know? That it’s time for the market to turn. Because the one thing that I’ve noticed is that a lot of the traders, and I don’t include you in this necessarily, but that the people who are on Twitter, who are on Telegram, who are talking about charts that they have a very short-term, almost day-trader type attitude towards it. Isn’t it just possible that this just keeps going down for a while and that in the long span, even in the life of Bitcoin, which now is about 10 years or something, that it’s really not that long of a time for this to be going down, but that it might just be another six months of this and that maybe it’s better to be on the sidelines for that?"
## [1] " But you are holding some cash to potentially buy at a $5,000 or a $3,000 level should it reach there?"
## [1] " I will start robbing banks."
## [1] " I have a broad question for you and Jay then."
## [1] " If you were actually truly bearish right now, which means you don’t think it’s going to go up [crosstalk 00:36:18] from here where are at $7,000. Yeah. Basically you’re like, “Bitcoin’s not dead.” What do you think, Jay, it would feel like if Bitcoin did die? What would tell us, both of you guys, what would, like moment would tell you, “Holy shit, this really could be a death spiral?”"
## [1] " Yeah, I mean, look, I think that I would … I don’t have interest in reinvesting until it hits about under $5,000 or $3,000. I think at $3,000 I would probably get back in, but, I mean, I think that if it kept going down for another year then, like sort of this slow grind that’s happening right now, like grind down, then I don’t think I would worry longterm honestly. I still think longterm it’s a good idea, and it’s a good investment. I think that a lot of people might lose interest and that it might take a little bit longer to rekindle it."
## [1] " No, I think that makes sense."
## [1] " Or maybe it will."
## [1] " Or maybe, yeah, today was rough, man."
## [1] " Is that particularly true among tech stocks? From my understanding, the most overlapped investor pools are people buying tech stocks and buying cryptocurrencies."
## [1] " Yeah. And are getting crushed right now-"
## [1] " That’s me."
## [1] " … pretty much across the board, right?"
## [1] " Jay, are you swayed?"
## [1] " Yeah, I’ll buy at $3k, I mean, yeah."
## [1] " If it does go to $3k, Jay is gonna be partying on us so hard, and he’s gonna have so many Bitcoins."
## [1] " Yeah, maybe. Maybe. All right, so one thing you talk about quite a bit I think that we wanted to ask you about as well, which is, and look, this is a question that Aaron and I bandy about. It’s about sort of the health of alts, right? So, I think that we can broadly agree that some alts are … that they’re real projects, so like Monero or Zcash. These are things that have actual science and tech behind it, and they have a use case, and they’re interesting. Do you think that for the vast majority of shit coins, and we can define it as loosely as you want, like let’s say the line is something like Neo or even like Qtum or any of these sort of alt, [Stratis 00:43:05], that these alts that people were big on just a few months ago … Do you think that most of those are just dead at this point?"
## [1] " Some of those are kind of prestige-y alts. Qtum? That’s like an Ashton Kutcher of alts level pick."
## [1] " I thought you were down on Ashton Kutcher. Ledger and I are the Ashton Kutcher bulls."
## [1] " You know, Qtum is like, yeah, you know. It’s not-"
## [1] " All right, well let’s draw the line at Qtum is a shit coin."
## [1] " Okay fair. I will acknowledge that Qtum is completely wrecked right now."
## [1] " Yeah. Do you think that these things are ever gonna come back?"
## [1] " Ledger Status say buy altcoins."
## [1] " Oh wow! Pizpie’s endorsement."
## [1] " Can you imagine what the seniors at graduating Stanford class, like crypto shit must be like?"
## [1] " I don’t know."
## [1] " Those kids must be fucking going buck wild getting paid."
## [1] " I don’t know. I feel like the way that the world is going right now, the majority of very smart spectrum-y guys in computer science PhD programs are probably gonna all start YouTube channels and rant about political correctness ‘cause-"
## [1] " Yeah, I think those dudes want to get fucking rich."
## [1] " Like you could just make so much money as like a blockchain engineer right now. Where is all this-"
## [1] " But where? Where? Okay, I do have a question about that. Where can you make money?"
## [1] " Just work for anyone of these companies who just ICO’ed."
## [1] " They have $30 million and no project?"
## [1] " Yeah, I don’t think they’re paying for engineers though."
## [1] " They are. They are. They are."
## [1] " Hey, it’s good to be on TV."
## [1] " As Ripple will tell you, at least for a while, it’s good if you’re on TV."
## [1] " WAN."
## [1] " Literally, you could’ve just made that up, and WAN could be totally fake, and we would never catch you. I have never heard of WAN."
## [1] " Is it WAN or is it Juan? Is it like the name Juan, like Juancoin, or is it-"
## [1] " So now it’s who can lose money the fastest?"
## [1] " One addendum to that story, Jay, is that Juancoin with a J is still available, and I think it’s a kind of dynamite concept."
## [1] " Oh, you mean like we could make Juancoin."
## [1] " [Juancoin.io 00:49:18]."
## [1] " All right, well, I have one more question for you, which is we’ve gone up and down and then down and then super up and then down … What do you think is going to be sort of the point where all this breaks out again and we see what we’re seeing before? I mean, you obviously think that could still happen or else you would’ve, because you’re a smart guy and you, like me and Aaron both, have kids and bills that you would’ve flipped your money to something a little bit more stable. What needs to happen for us to kickstart this thing all the way back up?"
## [1] " Okay, but they’re already ETFs, right? Like Grayscale."
## [1] " I do agree with you on that. I think that if there was a stable representative and fundamentally sound ETF product that was available for people to trade, and it wasn’t like the Robin Hood crypto thing where there’s a billion people in line and that nobody can really access it, I do think that that would be a game changer, but isn’t that also bad for crypto in the sense that it kind of gets us further away from the philosophical fundamentals of it?"
## [1] " Do you really think that people who buy a Bitcoin ETF are then gonna buy Bitcoin and start thinking about anarcho-capitalism and stuff like that?"
## [1] " Who cares?"
## [1] " No, what do you mean, who cares? I mean, if Bitcoin has a real sort of world-wide adoption, if people get excited about it, if it is used for cataclysmic events, then the idea of it matters. If you’re arguing that the idea of it doesn’t matter at all and that you’re just doing it for the price, you should invest in something else, you know? Something a bit more stable."
## [1] " Don’t you think the very awareness of Bitcoin as an investment vehicle raises awareness globally of Bitcoin as an idea?"
## [1] " I don’t know."
## [1] " I feel like it’s like even on Fidelity, it’s still a great advertisement for it. It’s like having your movie on Netflix or something."
## [1] " Yeah, but it also might just lead to everybody-"
## [1] " Spreading your brand!"
## [1] " It might just lead to a consolidation of Bitcoin into Fidelity ETFs. That’s all I’m saying."
## [1] " It’s true."
## [1] " I think we’ve basically set up Ledger Status’s next appearance on this show. It’ll be sometime between now and September, and we will be calling back this clip."
## [1] " I’m just enjoying the image of Jay having his face melted off by Bitcoin."
## [1] " Like, there will be a FOMO point for me."
## [1] " Yeah. Jay will get FOMO quickly. [crosstalk 00:54:44]."
## [1] " You’ve seen bear Jay, but FOMO Jay is just as powerful. Just as powerful."
## [1] " Jay is gonna get wrapped in by some kind of crazy prediction market where he starts calling world news events or something, and he’s gonna end up with some Bitcoin, and it’s just gonna be right back in the game."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Please."
## [1] " Yeah, I would [crosstalk 00:56:16]."
## [1] " I believe you. I believe you."
## [1] " I believe in it, too, if for no other reason is that I feel like people just want more. People want to get back into it, you know? People want to a basketball season to start again."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " All right. Well, let’s talk again soon."
## [1] " Thanks, Ledger."
## [1] " All right, later guys."
