## [1] " This entire thing is from that. But he could’ve fad fingered, but it makes sense also-"
## [1] " Yes. It makes sense."
## [1] " Which is why it’s a good rumor. So right off the bat, did you … We both independently did a little Zero-X research."
## [1] " Yeah. And I think to give some context-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " We have to give some context about Brian Armstrong who we’ve talked about quite a bit on this show."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Which is that from what we know about him because … and from the small things in which he’s public about, for example his Toshi app-"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " Which he put out, which you and I have discussed at length. Brian Armstrong is an Ethereum Maximalist."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " Like he believes that the future of Silicon Valley in some way will be routed through Ethereum technology-"
## [1] " Future of Silicon Valley? The future of humanity."
## [1] " Future of humanity. The future of like basically the complex systems and-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " The ecosystems in which human beings relate to one another, like trade money and built societies will be based Ethereum."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Like I don’t think that’s a stretch to say."
## [1] " Yes. And the system he imagines that is referred to as DApps, which are interlocking applications and tokens that power all sorts of peer to peer marketplaces and charity and rote labor."
## [1] " He has a full vision of it."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " World is on the Ethereum blockchain and so it would make sense that in his company, that the things that he would want to promote would be things that help along that economy. And all three of those things right, Augur, which is a prediction market."
## [1] " Basic Attention Token, which is how you get paid out by the Brave browser for your browsings-"
## [1] " Yeah, and-"
## [1] " For content creators."
## [1] " And Zero-X, which is a platform in which you can generate other types of platforms. It’s sort of like a platform upon which to build other platforms, and to also build DApps."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " All three of those help Brian Armstrong’s world and so they’re all consistent with this-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Vision that we’re [crosstalk 00:38:07]."
## [1] " They’re all very different takes on like what an Eth Maximalist worldview could be. In some ways Zero-X is the most neutral take ’cause it’s like Ethereum on top of Ethereum."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " But the other two are like … are practical, real world applications of what could be the first viable DApp for mass consumption."
## [1] " Okay. So with Zero-X, what does it actually do?"
## [1] " First thing I noticed when I started looking into it, Zero-X does not have a Wikipedia page."
## [1] " That’s very suspicious."
## [1] " To me, this is like a big thing that’s happening in the world, but not even meriting … I could be totally wrong."
## [1] " I mean I have a Wikipedia page."
## [1] " It’s gonna be really embarrassing when people all send me the Zero-X Wikipedia page. But it speaks to the circularity and repetition of information online about this stuff, where I like … First I googled Zero-X and I was like huh, no Wikipedia page. That’s weird. And then I was like why do people think Coinbase is adding ZRX and it was just a Reddit thread about that Brian Armstrong tweet. And most of the information about why people think it’s gonna be on Coinbase or either from that tweet or people being like, “Many people are talking about this.”"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Not a ton of information out there and in terms of considering how Zero-X actually works, it’s an open permissionless protocol allowing for ERC-20s to be traded on the Ethereum blockchain. And the research I did would put a bold on the word frictionless."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " A big part of the promise of Zero-X is that these DApps are gonna be able to be moving all kinds of ERC-20 tokens and making all kinds of smart contracts and none of it is gonna cost or burn anything. It will be a perpetual motion machine of DApps controlling your whole life."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " If were to ask me, “Well why do you need that on top of Ethereum to power these DApps?” It seems like the upside of ZRX is that it does some of these things that Ethereum does, but without any friction, without burning anything along the way."
## [1] " Yeah. Well it does it by exporting a lot of the stuff that does not need to be on the blockchain-"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Out of the blockchain. And so it uses less gas, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Like so it uses less space. It requires less energy-"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " If you use it. So it is essentially just like an engine in which all of this can run at much, much more efficient pace."
## [1] " Yeah. And I feel like as non like technical Eth developers, we can’t really gauge how important that is or how valuable that would be. When I look at it compared to BAT and Rep, I’m like of these three things, two of them people can wrap their head around how they work-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And use them, and one of them is kind of like bringing more Ethereum to the Ethereum party."
## [1] " And you need a second level of knowledge to understand why-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " It’s necessary. Yeah."
## [1] " So to me, it seems less likely that it would get added Coinbase except as infrastructure to add more stuff to Coinbase in the future. ## [1] " No, but-"
## [1] " Or are they just a subset of ERC-20 tokens?"
## [1] " No, no. I mean you can print your own but this again is the endless dilemma about these tokens and these ERC projects that … ERC projects that print their own tokens, which is just like … It’s hard to find a use case for these tokens except for using to buy … like the ability … to use it to pay to use the service. And at that point, you’re just like, “Well why don’t I just give you Ethereum? Why don’t I just give you Bitcoin? Why don’t I just give you my credit card number?”"
## [1] " Well there are … We’ve thought of two pretty good use cases, which are Basic Attention Token and Augur-"
## [1] " No, no, no, no. I’m not talking about those. I’m talking about Zero-X."
## [1] " Yeah. But I’m saying that if we can think of these use cases for Ethereum, we can think of use cases for an even more efficient and frictionless blend-"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Of Ethereum. And it makes sense to me that there would be like additional layers. if we’re gonna create a piping system to run the entire economy through smart contracts, it’s gonna take more than like vanilla Ethereum to do so. But the other thing that really caught my eye when I was going through it is this is a real Silicon Valley project. Like if you look at the people who are working on it-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " It’s people who are ex-Google, ex-Apple. It has a real startup flavor that’s very identifiable."
## [1] " What we do know is that … Again, we are way in Brian Armstrong’s head."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " But like … And it might not be true. The two things that these things have in common is A, what we already talked about, that they are sort of helpers of the Ethereum world that he wants to build. And secondly, they are people who most likely live down the street from him or work down the street from him and that they have been rubber stamped by places that they used to work, the places where they studied computer science. It is not a shady project with a shady team. It is people who have their photos on the website, it is people who you can look up everything that they’ve done in the past. And just from looking at that, diving a little bit into what they have done, you can have a reasonable trust that these people are probably working on something real and they’re not just like sort of sitting around in a room and like looking at a Binance chart and be like, “All right. We’re a little bit richer. Let’s go home.” And I think that’s very, very-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Important for whatever is next on Coinbase. Because with the amount of scrutiny that is around Coinbase and around the crypto world in general, it would be catastrophic for Coinbase I think to link up with something that was a little bit shadier. And not even shadier, ’cause it could be that … like something like Waves that’s in Russia, it’s just as legitimate. But it’s harder for us to verify from here."
## [1] " I’m pretty sure Waves is not as legitimate. Well I’m comfortable going down that one [crosstalk 00:44:06]-"
## [1] " You would not say that if Doug Kim and the Waves hall of fame was on the podcast right now."
## [1] " Well here’s why, ’cause Waves is like housed in a country controlled by Vladimir Putin. I do think that there is a national character to these projects and especially if you’re issuing tokens on top of the project. I would not issue a token that was on a Russian blockchain right now."
## [1] " And it is much easier SEC-"
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " For example to sort of investigate Zero-X and say, “Okay.”-"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " “If you’re gonna be part of this, then this exchange is not dealing with something that might be fraudulent.”"
## [1] " And I do think like it’s strategically makes sense for Brian Armstrong and Coinbase to take their company this direction because if you win, it’s a bigger win. It’s like a bigger pot. If smart contracts take over the world, I think that is more profound than simply taking over money, which is Bitcoin."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " It’s also a bigger risk and a bigger gamble. Why I think that Bitcoin has been validated as something that people want and wanna use, ERC-20 tokens have not really been totally validated under that hypothesis. But this is how a Silicon Valley mindset operates. It’s always make the bigger bet. Do not take the 10 X-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Go for the a 1,000 X. It doesn’t matter if you’re risking the 10 X and it’s just-"
## [1] " This is Brian Armstrong’s do you know what’s cooler than a million dollars moment?"
## [1] " Pretty much … I mean like I think he’s … I don’t think it’s … I think that moment was like two years ago for him."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I think you look at Bitcoin, you almost have like two strands in the family tree of crypto, which is this one strand that starts with the dark web, and starts with people who wanna do semi-anonymous, shady online transactions and that accidentally create an entire decentralized … Not accidentally, intentionally create an entire decentralized currency around it. And then there’s this other strand of people who want smart contracts to power everything about your life and everything about your banking and identity, and everything else. And I almost don’t … Like I don’t see those two paths ever crossing over each other again. The only war they’re really at with each other is for market share. Right? Do you feel like the Bitcoin and Ethereum world views even really matter much to each other at this point?"
## [1] " No, actually … You know that’s good ’cause that’s actually the last thing I wanna talk about on this topic, which is that from a zoomed out perspective-"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " It really does seem like they’ve been more divergent in the past few weeks or … past few months. You know that you do have stories about Ethereum that do seem to be closer to being able to articulate a world in which Ethereum is a big deal and that it replaces a lot of the functions in which we use on our phone or on the internet."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And that it affects large portions of our life and that they seem to not really even be interested in talking about Bitcoin-"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " And whereas Bitcoin seems to be sort of going another path, which is actually somewhat closer to the origins of Bitcoin right, which is we are looking at a world in which a deflationary currency is a good idea, and that’s what we’re concerned about. So like nobody in the Bitcoin community is saying like let’s build Bitcoin apps. Like BApps and figure out ways in which we can like create a better version of Twitter or something like that. And I don’t if it’s for any other reason than I feel like the people who are behind Ethereum projects have recently been able to articulate their ideas a little bit better."
## [1] " And that makes sense. Like it makes sense that the V1 is different from the V3 and that people have to experiment and pivot. I think we make fun of some of the ideals of Silicon Valley. But these are people who are experienced at building giant ideas that seem silly at first."
## [1] " Or might be horrible for the world."
## [1] " Or might destroy the world. It seems like Bitcoin is more comfortable with Bitcoin being the whole idea. I don’t think Bitcoin necessarily needs to like change what it’s doing a lot in the next few years in order to validate its importance and its hypothesis. And I think that’s like made me a bit more of a Bitcoin Maximalist recently. It’s just like I get what I’m support … When I support Bitcoin, I think I’ve wrapped my head around at least like 50% of it. I don’t really understand a lot of this Ethereum world stuff and maybe Brian Armstrong understands it better than I do and he’s seeing a future that I can’t see."
## [1] " He probably does."
## [1] " He probably does but-"
## [1] " But his extrapolation … or his conclusions might be worse."
## [1] " Well they need … I do think that those people need to get better at articulating the world that they’re imagining. It can’t simply be like more, more, more tokens, more … like more Ethereum, more everything. Like has to be like a pause where we start actually showing people like what to do with this stuff."
## [1] " But what if they’re in the MUD phase right now? Which I think that’s what they would argue. Right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Like what we talked about earlier in the podcast. Like it’s very hard to articulate and extrapolate out of what we have right now, what it’s going to be, but that clearly it’s going to be something."
## [1] " I agree with that. I think we are in that MUD phase. It’s weird to talk about the joint like Ethereum, Bitcoin market cap as a result of that, ’cause I don’t understand why if Ethereum moves past its MUD phase, that’s a bad thing for Bitcoin, or Bitcoin should be like, “Oh, we’re in decline.” In some ways I always think that Bitcoin will be the gateway drug to all of this stuff ’cause it’s like much easier to understand at the gateway at least, like what you’re doing. And I expect that over time like if Ethereum is right, if the Ethereum world is right, then over time it will become bigger than Bitcoin. I think."
## [1] " Yeah. No, I totally agree with that and it does seem in the last six months at least or three months even, that there has been more diversions than there was in the past year and a half if that makes sense."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Like the two were always compared to one another. The question you and I always get is, “Hey. Like should I buy Bitcoin or should I buy Ethereum?” And I think what Ethereum wants …"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " And maybe what Bitcoin wants as well, but what the people who are backing Ethereum really want is for that question to end."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " Like they don’t wanna be involved with Bitcoin at all."
## [1] " And I think that it’s proper to think of Ethereum and Zero-X more in terms of startups. I think that they’re like startups that have a certain amount of runway and they have to make a strong case during that runway, that people should invest more in them and that their vision is gonna take over the world, or it’s gonna like fall apart. Whereas Bitcoin, I think the vision has already been executed and we can start thinking about Bitcoin as a store of value, as something that has like a long term place to park money and wealth. And if Bitcoin is basically exactly the same thing, but a little bit more efficient and has figured out some lightning network stuff in the next couple of years, I don’t feel like Bitcoin will be like behind as a result. I think Bitcoin is in somewhat of a more stable position despite the price not being stable ’cause the idea is stable."
## [1] " Yeah. Sure. I mean I still don’t wanna live in Brian Armstrong’s world."
## [1] " You wouldn’t wanna live in anyone’s world."
## [1] " I mean I’m okay living in this current world. Cool. Is there anything else you wanna talk about?"
## [1] " Oh, yeah. I got something for you. You’ll see here this lovely book here. I’ve purchased The Bitcoin Standard by Saifedean Ammous."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Do you know how to say his name?"
## [1] " Famous eater of only meat. I think he’s a carnivore."
## [1] " Carnivore. I’m gonna start this book. I was wondering if you would like to read it alongside me and we could start a little podcast book club."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. Let’s do it. I mean look, I … The books that I tend to read these days are really not gonna be that much better."
## [1] " I mean I’ve heard this book getting a lot of praise. So if you’re interested, let’s say we’ll do it in quarters."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " So we’ll do it over four weeks. We won’t start this week ’cause we’ll give you time to go buy the book."
## [1] " Mm-hmm (affirmative). Do I have to buy it with Bitcoin?"
## [1] " No. I’ll … Yeah, you can get the Kindle one. I’ll tell you, the printing is very cheap. So I don’t even know if I totally endorse getting the print copy, but pick it up in the Kindle. It’s only a few bucks, read alongside us. We’ll announce next show what the page numbers we’re gonna go up to are. I think it will be nice to … we’re like budding up against the limits of like how we can discuss this stuff based on a like 200 word CoinDesk article."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And hopefully the book will provide a framework for us to get a little deeper and people who are reading along can send in questions. We’ll answer them. Maybe we’ll have a guest or two who’s read the book on. It’ll be fun."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " All right. Cool. See you next week."
## [1] " All right."
## [1] " That was Coin Talk, edited this week by James Nicholson. Thanks very much to my cohost Jay Kang. Thanks to our partners at Medium. You can find every episode of this show including transcripts at medium.com/cointalk. It’s kind of a fast way to get through the archives if you like to read this kind of thing. Also you can send us an email hi@cointalk.show. Thanks for listening. We’ll see you next week."

## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] " Welcome to Coin Talk. Jay, so much to talk about."
## [1] " A lot to talk about."
## [1] " I feel we have to go straight for it."
## [1] " Let’s talk about what you’re wearing first."
## [1] " What’s that?"
## [1] " Are you wearing a jersey that has no logo on it?"
## [1] " No, it’s actually got a white on white Warriors thing on it. It’s like a Warriors warmup jersey. I feel like this is something you would like to go to the club and you would see Klay Thompson wearing this."
## [1] " Speaking of which, I was talking to somebody recently and I was reminded of watching game six, when Klay Thompson hit all those shots again the Thunder, when they had Durant. And I was like, “I think that I watched it with Aaron and he was wearing a Warriors poncho.”"
## [1] " That’s correct. That poncho is currently in the crypto cave. That poncho got quasi-retired after the Warriors lost to the Cavs the second year, because it seemed like it might have bad mojo after that. But I think I might bring it back for the imminent Rockets/Warriors series."
## [1] " Fair enough, fair enough."
## [1] " We’re actually going to talk later in the program about the greatest ICO athlete pairing in history, and it reminded me that I think the greatest product athlete fit so far in the marketplace has been Klay Thompson and chocolate milk."
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah."
## [1] " There’s no more natural pairing than that possible."
## [1] " It was much better than the Kevin Love/chocolate milk pairing, which is just him shooting three pointers."
## [1] " All right. We will be talking to some NBA ICOs later on. But first, I feel like we have to address the elephant in the room."
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah."
## [1] " Or should I say, the vandal in the network."
## [1] " It was Coin Talk’s first quasi-viral moment. I feel like you got a lot of re-tweets from the luminaries of the space."
## [1] " I would say that I feel like my crypto OG card has been punched."
## [1] " Yeah. You’re punched."
## [1] " Let me tell you a little about what happened for the listeners out there. We won’t go through the whole thing because it’s embarrassing trying to recount internet jokes on audio. But after many times us joking about getting hacked as a result of hosting this show, I got a DM from a listener to the show actually, shouts to him, who alerted me that aaronlammer.com, my website, had some sort of a hacking notice on it and a demand for a Bitcoin ransom."
## [1] " Yeah. And what was on aaronlammer.com? I’ve known you for maybe 8 years. And I’ve never been to aaronlammer.com."
## [1] " Aaronlammer.com is just like says all the projects I’m involved in. It links to all my podcasts and music and stuff like that. It’s of not huge value to me. I wouldn’t be glad to lose it. But it’s not like I would have bought aaronlammer.com from a reseller for $10,000 or something like I bought stoner.co. I felt like we were in a pretty good position to negotiate here. Anyway, basically what happened was I went through a long sequence with this hacker of offering him various other cryptocurrencies that were not Bitcoin and pretending to be confused about the differences between Bitcoin Cash and Bitcoin. It’s on Medium. People can look it up."
## [1] " Well, okay, so here are my questions immediately about it. I saw the hacked page, and it was pretty funny. It was like a [crosstalk 00:06:29]-"
## [1] " Jay also, I’d like to say, expressed absolutely no sympathy before and started laughing at me, no worry that perhaps the show we host together had caused me problems or that perhaps our assets could be getting hacked."
## [1] " Well, it is true. I had zero moments of sympathy."
## [1] " Yeah. And you weren’t like, “Dude, our domains or our hosting got hacked,” you just started laughing at the fact that our show got hacked."
## [1] " Well, okay, so it looked like it was a page that had been created on Angelfire or Geocities. The quality of the hacking page was very bad."
## [1] " Yes. Well, instantly, I was like I Googled the hack because it had a name and I could see that other people had been hacked in this manner with the same page."
## [1] " Okay. How much money did this guy want from you?"
## [1] " Well, he asked for .025 Bitcoins, which I originally read as .25 Bitcoins, which is … that’s where I thought we were going to come in. I thought we were going to be talking about a couple thousand dollars. But .025 is like $230-ish, kind of low."
## [1] " Well, that was my problem with the whole thing was that he asked for so little amount of money and I was trying to think what would go through a hacker’s head when they do something like this. Are they like, “Listen, we need to set a reasonable price for aaronlammer.com.” Do they have a scale where they think that certain pages are going to be worth more to people? If he looked you up, if he did this hack and he was at all … I’m sure that he didn’t, he might be under the impression that you’re this immensely successful podcaster and recording artist and that you might have millions of dollars."
## [1] " I think it was random."
## [1] " I think it was random too."
## [1] " Although, at the time, I was like, “Oh, no, I should’ve have never dabbled in coin celebrity.”"
## [1] " Yeah, and this also came on the tail end of your Cryptopia account being hacked every single week."
## [1] " Right. And Adrianne Jeffries, who actually wrote about this in The Verge had asked me, “Do you worry about getting hacked because you’re doing this show now?” and I was like, “Ha-ha. No.” And then instantly after that, someone’s been trying to brute force reset my password on Crytopia for months. It’s caused me to sell my SUMO and lose the amazing SUMO run that’s been happening since then."
## [1] " You lost your title and you lost out on gains because of that, which, look-"
## [1] " It’s just like real feudalism. If you leave your land, it’s over for you."
## [1] " I will say that when you told me that someone was trying to brute force your Cryptopia account, which, to me, is the most hysterically bad use of that sort of technology ever, that perhaps it was karma for you talking about SUMO every single episode and talking about how you had it on Cryptopia. Do you not think those two were related at all?"
## [1] " Well, now I don’t think that they were related, but, at the time, this is the nature of paranoia around these things, you’re never going to know. He’s never going to tell me how he came upon me."
## [1] " I would agree. I don’t think that this hack had anything to do with any of that though because it was so unsophisticated-"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " … and they asked for so little money."
## [1] " I have another piece of evidence there too because the actual exploit of my WordPress with through a friend’s WordPress site that I host on my server that’s for his maple syrup operation, so, basically, the door in was not my website. It was a small maple syrup WordPress site. Great syrup though."
## [1] " It’s good syrup?"
## [1] " Good syrup."
## [1] " The way that this guy tried to get you to talk to him was over Facebook Messenger, right?"
## [1] " Well, that was the most surprising thing. I was like, “Oh, great. I’m fucked. It’s .025 BTC, so maybe I should just pay it.” Also they had all these instructions about how to buy Bitcoin to pay him off. I’m like if you’re going to put someone through the trouble of buying Bitcoin, you might as well ask for more than .025 BTC. But, anyway, I click on the contact button and it just takes me straight to a Facebook page."
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " The Contact Us link was just to a specific with a name, which I’m not going to say because Medium has asked me to blur out his name on the web, but it’s just a guy’s Facebook page with a bunch of anime on it."
## [1] " Shocking. Shocking. Did he say where he was from?"
## [1] " Well, he didn’t say where he was from, but the person who alerted me to it did some snooping in some hacker forums and said that his Facebook page matched someone named Syntax Error, who’d been in hacker forums, who was in Morocco. And one of the things is the site that they put over my site had this autoplaying video in the background that was playing this ominous … I describe it as like stock music hip hop."
## [1] " Wow, so it really was Web 0.0 with autoplay music."
## [1] " Yeah. And one of the things he had said in the hacker forum was, “Make the victim listen to music.”"
## [1] " Oh, wow, so it really is like-"
## [1] " It’s really to annoy you, and if you don’t pay, this autoplaying loop is going to be on your website forever."
## [1] " That actually would work for me, I think. I don’t know if it would push me to pay the Bitcoin, but it would be a factor that I would put into my calculations. I’d be like, “Oh, my God, anyone who Googles me first is going to believe that I have the worst security on everything possible and then they’re going to be like, ‘What the fuck is this song?’”"
## [1] " One of the things I was thinking about doing as I was progressively trolling him was to … A lot of the things I was doing is pretending I didn’t understand various Bitcoin debates and I was going to pretend I didn’t know that you could send .025 Bitcoin and tell him that I was going to send him a full Bitcoin and have him send me back the change. Oh, another thing was our friend [Naraj 00:12:08] looked up the address he had supplied to send the Bitcoin and said one person had sent a ransom to that address."
## [1] " Yeah, see, that’s-"
## [1] " It’s kind of like the Nigerian scam. It’s probably millions of tries before you get one."
## [1] " Yeah, and that’s why you should ask for more money."
## [1] " Totally agree."
## [1] " That’s the part where I’m just like, well, what is his return on time invested here when he’s only asking for $220?"
## [1] " Well, and additionally, how many people even have Bitcoin or could figure out how to get Bitcoin? If you hit someone, like me, who actually has Bitcoin, you might as well try to get more than that. I actually have the Bitcoin to send him and didn’t send it to him."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. And how do you resolve this sort of thing, for our listeners who may get hacked?"
## [1] " Well, I went to my … My server is with a company called DreamHost and they were really easily, like within five minutes, been able to see on the server logs what had happened. It had to do with leaving a WordPress installation that had not been set up yet, so you could set passwords and get into it, and they got into this domain through it being on the same user. But the basic thing was that by the time I was talking to him, I already knew I had the domain back, which he did not realize, which gave me the upper hand in these negotiations."
## [1] " Yeah. It seems like a very bad hacking strategy, to be completely honest with you. And also Bitcoin is pretty traceable, but I guess it’s just the easiest thing for people to buy. He couldn’t be like, “Okay, the first thing you do is go on Coinbase and you buy Bitcoin and then you go on Bittrex, you send it and then you buy Monero and send me that Monero.”"
## [1] " I was thinking the same thing. Ransoming someone for Bitcoin is brazen. It’s like extorting someone and being like, “Mail a check to my home address.”"
## [1] " Naraj could figure out how many ransoms had been sent to this guy within six seconds of the time when you announced it."
## [1] " Well, that also empowered me to not pay him. I was like, “Oh, only one person has paid him ever? I’m not going to pay him.”"
## [1] " What you should do is you should send a bunch of fake 0.25 Bitcoin donations into that wallet so it seems like everybody is doing it, and then that’ll press you in because you’ll be like, “Oh, there must have a point where these people capitulated because something was over their head.”"
## [1] " Yes. That would have been the narrative I was looking for. If I saw that 10,000 people had paid him, I would’ve been like, “Fuck it. I’m paying. Clearly, that’s the smart money.”"
## [1] " Hopefully, he’s listening to this podcast and that he can improve his hacking in the future."
## [1] " Well, I did invite him on the show."
## [1] " What did he say?"
## [1] " He was like, “I don’t need this bullshit, man.” He eventually lost patience with me. Then I posted these chats online and, almost instantly, I would say within an hour, people were accusing me of faking the entire thing."
## [1] " Yeah. Well, look, that’s the community that you and I have decided to enter."
## [1] " Yeah, and get hacked with it."
## [1] " Yeah, everything is fake news."
## [1] " Are you worried about getting hacked?"
## [1] " A little bit, a little bit. I did triple down on all my security after this happened to you, but I don’t have jaykang.com. I think I have a Wikipedia page, but people vandalize that all the time. It’s always stuff like-"
## [1] " Jordan Peterson fans."
## [1] " It really is. There was one where somebody edited to say, “On such-and-such day, Jay Kang aired a piece that was clearly edited to slander Jordan Peterson,” or something like that."
## [1] " On this date in U.S. history, Jay Kang got owned by Jordan Peterson."
## [1] " That happens all the time. There was one that was saying that I had maliciously slandered MLS fans and called them all fascists and I was like, “Yeah, okay. That’s fine.” The last thing I will say about this hacker guy is that he is very bad at posting actual threats. I feel like if he was taking personal website addresses that people use for their businesses or to present themselves to the world, then he should have a much more inflammatory image on there so that people are like, “Oh, I hope that nobody who goes to aaronlammer.com is going to see a picture of X,” a terrible beheading or anything that nobody actually wants to see."
## [1] " I feel like he was kind of hinting at that because he kept saying, “I’m going to do horrible things to you on a hacker forum if you don’t listen to me,” and I was like, “You need to be more specific than this, like a 1990s hacker forum or …”"
## [1] " Well, are you afraid at all now?"
## [1] " I wasn’t, and then when I saw that that article that Adrianne wrote about it in The Verge went up, I was like I’m not worried about that guy, but I’m worried about some other hacker seeing it now and being like, “Oh, I’m really going to get this guy.”"
## [1] " Oh, yeah, yeah. Well, they all have hacker solidarity. They have to stand up for the other hackers."

## [1] " Art Kang in the house recently."
## [1] " Art Kang is in the house, Art Baron Kang."
## [1] " Art Baron Kang"
## [1] " Yeah. And the reason why I know it’s real is because I buy it from artists who there’s nobody who’s ever going to fake the art that they make and it’s not a thing. And so if we could go build a blockchain that retroactively could go back in time, you could actually figure out if something that was painted by Leonardo da Vinci, where it went throughout its journey. My parents actually, very weirdly, went through a version of this where my mom found an ancient Chinese scroll in a thrift shop in Washington state, I’m not kidding, and it was very-"

## [1] " Okay, so your mom’s like-"
## [1] " I’d be like, very typical-"
## [1] " Your mom’s in a thrift store and she finds an ancient scroll, a real ancient scroll."
## [1] " She found an ancient scroll, yes. And she looked at it. My dad looked at it. They are both retired so they had a lot of time. They looked at all the stamps. They looked at the brush technique. And they were convinced that they had found a masterpiece that might be worth somewhere up to between hundreds of thousands of dollars to many millions of dollars."
## [1] " I’m really hoping this story ends on Antiques Roadshow."
## [1] " Well, that’s what I suggested. What they ultimately did was that they took it to actual experts in the Seattle area who were like, “Actually, this seems like it’s real in some ways, but we just don’t know what it really is. And if it’s from the seventeenth century, then it’s worth this much. If it’s from the sixteenth century, then it could be worth actually millions of dollars.”"
## [1] " We don’t know what its haunted powers really are."
## [1] " Yes, well, that’s a little racist there. I’m glad that you put it there and that you’re … Okay, so we’ve gotten to that point. Your mom would be fine, but, yes, haunted powers are not good. It’s not like a fucking secret monkey scroll. They brought it to Christie’s here in New York, and the woman at Christie’s basically said, “This is from either the seventeenth or sixteenth century. I don’t really know, but the only way that we could do it is that we would need a quorum of experts to decide what it was.” And the reason why they can’t know what it is is because there’s no way to track where it was. But it turns out that my parents either have a scroll that’s worth maybe $1,000 or $800 or it’s worth 20 million dollars and there’s no way to tell the difference between what sells for 20 million dollars. I will say that in that instance, if you could retroactively go back and blockchain, explain where every single place where this thing was, that would be helpful and if you started it now, that would be helpful."
## [1] " Yeah, like Birkin bags or something like that, which is something that they sell. They really actually could use this sort of blockchain application. The one thing that, and, Aaron, this is something you and I talk about quite a bit, which is that, look, this is all great in theory, but it does rely on a certain number of good actors at every single place and that’s the part that-"
## [1] " Because that’s where all the most honest business people …"
## [1] " And the least forgeries."
## [1] " Yeah, and the part that was most striking, I want to point-"
## [1] " I want to just say that this was not a real painting. It was worth like $1,000, is I think what they said it was. But the part that was interesting to me was I was asking the woman, who was at Christie’s who’s the expert about it, I was like, “Well, why wouldn’t you just get a quorum together and the person who has it just pay everyone a million bucks and sell the thing for eight million bucks and pocket the rest.”"
## [1] " No, that’s what I mean. But that’s the type of thing where it’s just you can’t really rely on the actors to authenticate this thing and it doesn’t seem like blockchain would really solve that."
## [1] " No, especially when we’re talking about like conflict diamonds. It’s like, “Oh, everything’s been logged in the chain here. Oh, look, this is not a conflict diamond.” Limited edition things make sense to me because it’s like you put them all on the chain and then they’re tracked forever. Things like tomatoes, all it feels like you’re doing with the blockchain is the same thing as like when a package is coming from UPS, where it just says where it’s been and it’s like, “Well, how do I know it’s been there?” It’s like, well, someone scanned the barcode. It’s like that, in the sense of my package, I believe, but that’s not an incorruptible system that’s going to stop something like the conflict diamond industry."
## [1] " Oh, my God. That’s my dream. ## [1] " Bad Beyonce photo effect. Well, what I wonder with this case of Monero, I think we can all agree this is great for decentralized exchanges. The world that decentralized exchanges imagined is here, but it also feels a little bit like 2018 is the year of the good and bad cryptos. If 2017 was the year of the forks, it seems like everyone’s trying to, whether it’s securities regulation in the U.S. that’s trying to divide Bitcoin from some of these scammier ICOs or, here, it’s privacy versus non-privacy coins. I wonder, as we start giving them up, whether the ultimate winner is just Bitcoin because Bitcoin always lands in the good pool. Any divide you have, even Ethereum can be suspect, but no one ever seems to think that Bitcoin is amongst the bad crypto."
## [1] " It doesn’t feel like the current status of Bitcoin privacy is sustainable. Just earlier in the show, we were talking about me getting hacked and we were able to look into the wallet address of the person who was ransoming me. I just feel like, in two years, when I’m getting Bitcoin ransomed again, because now there’s a Verge article about me getting Bitcoin ransomed, I assume that I won’t be able to peer into the person ransoming me’s wallet, whether that’s because it’s a Monero wallet or because Bitcoin has in some way obscured wallets in that sort of a way. I feel like it’s almost like I don’t really feel a need to gamble between those two outlooks, I just am like hold some Bitcoin, hold some Monero, just keep on holding, because it just seems like there has to be a privacy component."
## [1] " Yeah. There’s no outcome here where I feel like Monero and these privacy coins are going to be defeated, this push to label things bad coins, in a world with decentralized exchanges, in a world where people still are using Bitcoin to ransom people’s websites and to do credit card fraud, everything like that. Even bad coin is actually good. It shows that the coin has some sort of utility that the state is afraid of."
## [1] " It shows it’s dangerous."
## [1] " Yeah. And if I was going to pick between two projects and one of them is five guys backed by Peter Thiel, who are in Silicon Valley and Marc Andreessen, and they have nice offices, they have a cappuccino machine, they play ping pong and they go to VC conferences and the cool bad guy coin, I’m always going to pick the cool bad guy coin. And I think that most people in crypto are like that, and I do think that crypto probably isn’t big enough yet where that effect of the people who want the destabilizing thing, they’re still going to have an effect. It’s not all institutional money yet. I think that this push to squash bad coins is just never going to work. I can’t see a scenario where it works."

## [1] " You want a perspective on bad trading? You’re like, “What would happen to me if I traded as an amateur? Oh, terrible things? Okay.”"
## [1] " You’re the perfect person to ask because we’ve always struggled with this. You said basically it would be cool if utility tokens work. And my whole impression, from reading about a gazillion ICOs and the whole cultural history of this era, is there was projects like Bitcoin that did not require any capital to get off the ground and then eventually people started making crypto projects and they’re like, “Hey, this is kind of like a startup. We need to pay ourselves and have a foundation.” And so they did ICOs and then they were like, “And also a utility token because the whole economy of this wouldn’t work if it …” and then people started speculating on those utility tokens. Why do utility tokens have to work, in your opinion? Why do they need to exist for all this cool stuff to happen?"
## [1] " Let me ask you a question, because I know you’ve written a lot about the Telegram ICO, and that’s the opposite of the garbage side. It’s the most prestige … well, in a way."
## [1] " What? Are we being sponsored by Telegram?"
## [1] " Jay, it’s a solo deal. They only wanted me. They didn’t want you in on it. No. Okay, I’m going to elaborate on that. It’s very big-"
## [1] " It’s not an outright scam. Telegram’s a real app. There’s a real product, etc. And it seemed like, in that case and correct me if I’m wrong, they started off down the ICO path that we’re describing with a utility token and then when they realized that they could easily get all the money they needed without going down that path, they basically canceled the original ICO and just went with a bunch of individual investors?"
## [1] " But how is this utility token future going to unfold if Roman Abramovich or whoever got all of the Telegram ICOs sitting on 25% of the world’s Gram supply?"
## [1] " You’re not worried then that those sorts of massive dumps by huge, huge investors is going to destroy that type of market and attract interest from regulators? Yes, I think in a sort of anarcho-capitalist world, that makes sense, but in a world in which people are trying to invest good faith in good faith projects, that does seem a bit dangerous to me."
## [1] " On the short-term, extremely cynical."
## [1] " Where’s the incentivization? When you take a bunch of seed money, there’s someone who’s like, “Yo, you better at least try to make this product or I’m going to be fucking pissed off at you.” And if you’ve already got 100, 5, 10, 20, 100 million dollars out of the gate and, not only have you taken the money, it’s not from hundreds of thousands of people who are all going to yell at you and try and come after you, it’s from a few billionaires who can easily lose the money. It just seems like it doesn’t even have to be a scheme, it’s just a bad way to engineer a company."
## [1] " Yeah. It was like the day when the ex-head of Ripple was the richest man in the world or whatever. We had a discussion about it. It was just like, well, what is the incentive to build Ripple at this point? Why would he build this bank to bank thing or invest a lot of money in it? He’s already fucking rich. With the Telegram thing, that was my question about it was just why are they going to build this network at this point? They could do a really shitty job of it and people are already going to be skeptical of it because of the way that they raised money and the amount of money that they raised. And the idea that people would slowly get into it and they’d try and buy it and that there would be a measured sell off of it that would retain the value and then you would have an operating marketplace, it just seems to go against almost everything that has happened in crypto so far."
## [1] " It’s a lot easier to believe in these things if there’s an independent track record of the person behind them and that involves something that’s not pure financial [crosstalk 01:05:05]. The way that you situated Telegram there made the ICO seem more legitimate to me than when it’s just like, “Hey, we’re pulling the ICO and these people got all the tokens.” How do the gears of the utility tokens in something like [inaudible 01:05:19] start going though? If it’s all held by these people, how are people going to start using it, if so many of the tokens are just being hoarded?"
## [1] " I don’t even know what the Kin token is."
## [1] " Okay, okay. Cool. Yeah, we’ve talked about Kik. Why is Kik’s token not called Kik?"
## [1] " I continue to be-"
## [1] " I appreciate your enthusiasm and belief in this. I think I just don’t want the Toshi universe where I’m a Mechanical Turk Worker and my computer is being leased slightly in the background. I’m just kind of like, ah, what, for the 75 cents, I don’t see myself earning a living that way."
## [1] " It’s hard for me to wrap my head around how all of this stuff is going to somehow shake down to a bunch of people, if we’re super interested in it and we’re barely able to do any of this stuff on it."
## [1] " You did valiantly. Thank you."
## [1] " In the spirit of defense."
## [1] " It’s hard to talk positively on this stuff. I know the negative vortex that Jay will suck you into."
## [1] " I think I got email in high school."
## [1] " I had AIM."
## [1] " We would agree with that."
## [1] " I would agree with that. To me, the crazy idea is Bitcoin becomes money, not like I’m farming server space and shoring my files with utility tokens so I can earn money from President Brian Armstrong’s Toshi corporation."
## [1] " No, no, no, no. That will be not a democracy."
## [1] " I just think it’s the most provocative idea is just digital money, just be like all the money goes digital."
## [1] " It’s kind of like the divide between what you’re talking about is sort of a consumer tech/labor tech vision and, to me, I’m more interested in the dissolution of nations. To me, the most provocative idea is countries lose control over money. Money is not linked to national identity. In some ways, the more consumer tech vision almost feels too small to me comparatively. It has to be like there’s no more countries for it to fulfill the promise almost. Jay, we got anything more before we want to get out of here?"
## [1] " No, I think we’re good."
## [1] " All right. Well, thank you, Brady. This was fun. Where can people who want to find your writing on CoinDesk find you?"
## [1] " One last question. Are you bummed to be no coining through this coin era that you’re spending so much of your mental energy on?"
## [1] " Art hustling."
## [1] " It’s weird. It’s like if sports reporters weren’t allowed to watch sports, or I guess it’d be if they weren’t allowed to play sports."
## [1] " Or bet on sports-"
## [1] " Bet on sports, which they’re -"
## [1] " … which they’re not allowed to do."
## [1] " All right. Well, thank you for coming on, Brady."
## [1] " Hey, thanks for listening to Coin Talk. I’m Aaron Lammer. My cohost is Jay Kang. Our partner in this is Medium. Our guest this week was Brady Dale from Coin Desk. Thanks to him, thanks to them. Thanks to our editor, James Nicholson, and thanks to all you people who are listening. If you want to get in touch, it’s hi@cointalk.show. We do offer sponsor slots. If you have a company in the blockchain space that you would like to promote on here, we’re happy to do so. Send us an email, hi@cointalk.show. Make sure to pick up the Bitcoin Standard. I think it’s 11 bucks on Amazon or something. It’s not expensive and we’re going to read the first four chapters for next week. So if you got it, Tweet at us at CoinTalkShow. Let us know you’re reading. We’re going to start with that, again, Bitcoin Standard by, I apologize for this pronunciation, Saifedean Ammous. We’ll see you next week."

## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] " Live in the crypto cave."
## [1] " How’s it going?"
## [1] " No cockroaches so far."
## [1] " Yeah, I know. I’ve been eyeing that guitar case where that mammal sized cockroach just went under it. But I have not seen it resurface. No shame here. We have cockroaches too in our apartment. I feel like-"
## [1] " There’s no shame in having cockroaches in New York. You could easily get into seven figures in New York in real estate and still have cockroaches."
## [1] " Yeah, I would actually say-"
## [1] " Not that I have … This place is $350.00 a month, this basement where we tape. But I’ve heard that people do."
## [1] " I don’t think that there’s any correlation between the price of the price of the place where you’re at and the number of cockroaches."
## [1] " No, I mean I kinda feel like New York City cockroaches are like this separate phenomenon that’s like, “Hey, it’s not even gross. It’s a city cockroach over there. Hey, it’s the pizza rat over here.”"
## [1] " That thing was massive though. That was actually one of the biggest cockroaches I’ve seen in my life. All right. So speaking of cockroaches-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Should we just get into the news right now?"
## [1] " Yeah, let’s get into it. People have been getting feisty on the internet. It’s like NBA playoff time, everyone’s a little chippy in basketball, you see a fight almost every night. I feel like the crypto world is ready to brawl."
## [1] " Yeah, well I feel like that actually is a bullish sign for me for crypto-"
## [1] " Oh, yeah."
## [1] " Because I think for a while-"
## [1] " Do you thrive on the conflict?"
## [1] " Well no, because I think for a while everyone was just kind of depressed and all the memes and there’s not that much fighting because everyone was super poor at once."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And now like people are starting to go back to their corners."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Like the raid is over. People feel a little feisty. Spring is in the air right now and they’re ready to scrap. So there is one big scrap this week."
## [1] " Yeah, I feel like this one hit close to my heart because we’re fans of Laura Shin and the show."
## [1] " Yeah, Coin Talk’s ombudsman."
## [1] " Ombudsman-"
## [1] " Laura Shin."
## [1] " Yeah. She’s corrected some of my numerous errors."
## [1] " I feel like she’s gotten to like 1% of our factual errors on this, but it was a very long email detailing several of our factual errors."
## [1] " Side note. So when we were prepping to talk about this, we were looking at her show. Her podcast is called Unconfirmed-"
## [1] " Unchained."
## [1] " Unchain … Well she has two. She has Unchained and Unconfirmed. I think you’re right, Unchained is the episode we’re talking about. It has a disclosure in the description that says, ‘I own Bitcoin and Ethereum.’ And I was like man, like if we had to do that, I wouldn’t even know what we would say. It’s like, “Aaron has like tons of shit in bag. A bunch of them he got bad entries on.”"
## [1] " Hahahaha."
## [1] " “Several of them have been de-listed and he can’t move them. Jay may or may not have some Bitcoin. If he doesn’t, he’s [FoMO-ing 00:04:40].”"
## [1] " Yeah, exactly. If Jay was not too lazy to buy alt coins right now, these are the coins that he would have."
## [1] " But anyway, so Laura does this show. It’s a great show. She has on lots of CEOs. I mean her guest list is mostly the people behind these coins."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. She does not go our route, which is to invite on degenerate gamblers."
## [1] " I feel like we like are both on the degenerate journalist and degenerate gamblers list, but we haven’t had that many people who are actually like building-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " The stuff that we’re talking about. So that is kinda what she normally does in the show and I’m always curious ’cause I do listen to the show and I always sort of think about this decision to have people talk about their own work. These are people who have literally billions of dollars at stake in how the public perceives their projects."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So it’s not necessarily people that I associate with deep honesty, but it’s interesting, I listen and if I have heard someone on the show it does affect whether I’d want to buy that coin."
## [1] " Yeah. Look it’s the dance that all journalists have to do-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " For a certain … especially tech journalists I think more than anybody else."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And maybe like celebrity profilers, which is is it worth having this person on in an unfiltered forum like the podcast, where I can press them on certain things or her."
## [1] " Right. And Laura to her credit, she’s not a no coiner who’s gonna try to like poke holes in what you’re doing necessarily. She-"
## [1] " And she is interested in the world."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So she’s not a troll."
## [1] " Not at all."
## [1] " I think if you and I had on her guest list, one of us-"
## [1] " Jay."
## [1] " Me, would spend most of the time-"
## [1] " There’s only one troll who’s on this show."
## [1] " Yeah, would spend most of the time trolling and asking absurd questions and trying to corner them into like stupid debate trick stuff."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " She doesn’t do that-"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Because she is a curious person in real journalism. She’s trying to get these things out. So-"
## [1] " And she’s like … generally takes the attitude of like let people like represent themselves how they wanna rep themselves."
## [1] " Yeah. I do not take that."
## [1] " So she was gonna do a show on Ripple. I guess she hadn’t done the show on Ripple. I mean Ripple is this weird anomaly where it is one of the biggest coins, but it also almost exists outside of the rest of a lot of these coins, like in a different sort of business realm. And so she was trying to get on Brad Garlinghouse who runs Ripple Inc.-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " He’s the CEO of Ripple Inc. and they were kinda giving here runaround on this. I had a lot of empathy for this ’cause I’ve had the run around before by some PR apparatuses and they were like, “We … We’re not actually getting you] Brad Garlinghouse, but like we got you the next best thing, this other guy.”"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And she basically negotiated with them and they kinda didn’t want to budge. And so she was like, “Well fine. I’m gonna do it with these two other guys.”, who she had booked. One of whom was Ryan Selkis who I admire. Anyway, the Ripple dudes kind of freaked out on Twitter and were kinda accusing of her of acting in bad faith-"
## [1] " Unbelievable."
## [1] " And trying to argue their way on."
## [1] " Unbelievable. Yeah, yeah. And then their like army of Ripple fans also swarmed Laura’s Twitter account and were making all sorts of crazy accusations towards her, which is really the sort of sad state of discourse in America right now. Where I … This is something I say to my wife quite a bit, which is that every time one of these things happen, which is that it seems like if you read Twitter that everybody is very obsessed with journalism. You know?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And that everyone thinks about journalism and journalist ethics all the time. And yet, you would think if that is true, that journalism business would be doing a little bit better. You know?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Oh."
## [1] " I think most people don’t care, like especially in the crypto world, journalism’s a pretty dirty word. Right?"
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. Well that’s what it is. Like essentially if you were part of the media and you say something that somebody doesn’t like and this has happened to me maybe 30 times, where you get swarmed with people now who do not say, “Hey, you said something that I didn’t like. I think you’re full of shit and I hate you.” They bring up these very granular and often times almost always wrong assumptions about what journalism is supposed to be and try and get you fired. Like that’s the new normal."
## [1] " If I sort of evaluate it, the whole exchange, I think I’d call it a technical foul on both parties. I’d be like-"
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " Well I don’t think she had to like … totally like air the dirty laundry quite as open. Let’s play a little bit of it."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Okay. So you get the idea. I don’t think she’s in the wrong, but she did dedicate like the first 10 minutes of the show to airing these like Ripple dudes out pretty hard, which I respect."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I understand why they like are annoyed with her and she’s annoyed with them. But as an impartial third party, an investor. Hey, I’m just speaking as an investor here."
## [1] " That’s not an impartial third party by the way."
## [1] " Yeah, totally not-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Impartial third party. The constant thin skin-ness of the people behind Ripple speaks volumes about what they’re doing."
## [1] " Yeah. It really does. I mean I … How many Ripple fights have there been now? I mean I feel like you and I get some of it just for making fun of Ripple on our podcast-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Which I don’t think anyone who listens to should take seriously as anything. Especially not like a long term referendum on whether or not this thing is an investible product or not."
## [1] " Look the way we talk about Ripple and our investment track record, everyone should be happy. We’ve been making fun of ripple and we’ve been failing in all of our investments. So you’re probably gonna do well and if you’ve been honing Ripple, you are doing well. So why are you fucking complaining so much?"
## [1] " I do wonder sometimes what a portfolio would look like if they just went the opposite direction of everything that we did. So like … You know like there are these like people who place their bets online, NFL writers."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And for times I’ve just faded them because either I have a personal problem with them or I just think that they’re always wrong or that I think it’s funny. Sometimes it really works and I feel like if somebody just faded us consistently, that they would do pretty well."
## [1] " If you’ve been fading us, you’d do well and if you’ve been buying Ripple, you’d do well and none of the arguments that I would make against Ripple or I think Laura Shin would make against Ripple necessarily mean Ripple is a bad investment."
## [1] " No, and-"
## [1] " Most of these arguments are that Ripple is a bad concept that’s kinda shitty for crypto and is not actually decentralized and it’s controlled by company, Ripple Inc., and that’s a huge problem."
## [1] " And it is-"
## [1] " That’s not a reason not to invest."
## [1] " It is barely a crypto currency and that the use case is specious at best. And it’s not just Laura Shin that’s gotten in … Nathaniel Poppers … Like every journalist who has written about Ripple essentially has gotten Ripple shamed-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " In a sort of way. So I have one question for you Aaron-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Which is that you and I do track some of this stuff on Twitter. Who are these fucking Ripple fans? Our friend Joe Weisenthal got it from the Ripple fans too. Like I just … Like I don’t get who Ripple fans are."
## [1] " Well I’m assuming they’re people who bought in when Ripple was like $3.00, most of … Like I think they’re people who really need Ripple to go back up."
## [1] " Oh, so you think they’re not people who bought in at like point seven cents-"
## [1] " I think they’re both. I think they’re both. Someone was describing to me that people who are buying Tesla, you know Tesla’s getting massively-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Shorter right now. If you’re betting on Teslas, you’re betting on hitting the … literally hitting the moon-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " With a rocket. It’s a cult of people who like just believe in Elon Musk no matter what and they’re like the Ripple fans of the stock market."
## [1] " And you are one of these?"
## [1] " And I was offended because I am Tesla hodler and I do believe in Elon Musk."
## [1] " I do not."
## [1] " But I don’t really know who these Ripple people are and I also don’t understand why out of all of these projects … There’s crazy people in all of these projects. There’s crazy Ethereum teens out there-"
## [1] " Yeah, but that makes sense."
## [1] " No, but there’s something dark about the Ripple fans, like there’s something gamergate about them. There’s something about … and I think it comes from the top down, that it attracts people like the people who are running it, who are very weirdly thin skinned, and weirdly believe that negative press coverage is a huge threat to what they’re doing."
## [1] " Okay. I figured out who they remind me of and this is a group that I’ve run across once."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Who still sometimes will tweet at me."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " They’re like MLS fans to me."
## [1] " That was so … I was wondering who you were gonna offend there. Like it could’ve gone so many different directions."
## [1] " They at me a lot. They at me a lot."
## [1] " MLS fans."
## [1] " DFS, daily fantasy fans-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Gordon Peterson fans."
## [1] " Wow."
## [1] " Kareem Abdul-Jabbar fans. Yeah, there’s been a lot. But-"
## [1] " That is the hottest take you’ve ever brought to this program, that Ripple fans are the MLS fans of crypto."
## [1] " Well let me explain which … And it really is that they … they sort of have this built in inferiority complex. Right? Because the thing that they support gets shit on by almost everybody who’s a layperson in that field. So like if you are into sports, and maybe this has changed over the last five years or so, but it used to be … Like if you looked five years ago, everyone just shits on MLS being like, “Why would you watch that? It’s a bunch of out shape guys who went to Yukon running around. You know? And a bunch of like castoffs from Europe and Mexico.” And so that builds this inferiority complex I think and that the press is generally negative towards them and so they hate the media. They have built a strange culture that to any outsider looks a little bit weird and you’re like, “Well why are these people into this thing?”"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Like it doesn’t make any sense and that that contributes to that."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And so I think for Ripple fans … Like the case for Ripple … Being a fan of Ripple doesn’t make any … It’s not cool. It doesn’t make any sense. It’s like, “Okay. So the future of Ripple is that bank transfers between two countries that do not do much business with one another … So for example, trying to send money from Argentina to Sudan will be … use the Ripple system and will use these tokens to make the transfer faster and more like seamless than it would be before.” That is not a very sexy story, you know? And so that’s why I think when people sort of point that out, the people who are fans, which I honestly still have no idea why they are. They get extremely defensive about it and then they congregate … Oh! The cockroach is-"
## [1] " It’s back. It’s back."
## [1] " Is back."
## [1] " Damn, I think that cockroach is officially the mascot of Coin Talk now."
## [1] " Yeah."

## [1] " I just picked up my shoe."
## [1] " If you could possibly like kill him without destroying him, so I could take a photo."

## [1] " Yeah, well that’s a … So you-"
## [1] " I will not be stomping on the cockroach with my Yeezys."
## [1] " If I asked you, you would not kill that cockroach with those shoes?"
## [1] " No, I’m not stomping on him with these fucking Yeezys."
## [1] " So I think of these Ripple fans, they’re people who brought like a weird beer to the party. Like they just kinda like-"
## [1] " That’s the same thing."
## [1] " There’s this weird like level where it’s like, “Okay, what kind of party is this?” It’s like, “Well, we’re about decentralization, taking money out of the hands of the government, creating an independent transparent system that people can hold value.” And it’s like, “Hey you guys, what if we like worked with the banks?” Almost everything about what this is bringing to the table is antithetical to what most of these people came here for."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And yet it’s strangely seductive, which makes me think that there’s a new generation of crypto enthusiast who is Ripple types, people who are like, “I’m into like bank stuff.”"
## [1] " Well yeah …. Here’s the disconnect that I have with the Ripple fan, which is that when the super FoMO phase of around thanksgiving of last year was happening, people at my work and people in my social life were saying, “Hey, why don’t I just buy Ripple? It’s the most reasonable of all of these. Like it’s the one that can exist within the world that we inhabit right now.” That was their big pitch."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Right? And a lot of them bought Ripple and a lot of them did very well because they bought it at like $0.20 and they sold it at like $2.00. They did awesome. You know?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Those people are not ideologically into Ripple enough to start trolling people online. In fact, I think that they thought that Ripple was uncool, which is why they got it. You know?"
## [1] " Yeah, that’s kinda why I bought Ripple."
## [1] " Yeah and-"
## [1] " It was like go against my instinct here."
## [1] " Yeah, but that’s … You would think that a dedicated fandom that would go around trolling people and sort of making these ugly spectacles online, that they would have some sort of ideological reasoning behind it. And that’s the part I don’t get with Ripple, which is why I actually think that a lot of the Ripple stuff might be bots."
## [1] " Wow. I mean I will say there’s some very high profile B-cash trolls out there."

## [1] " Yeah."

## [1] " Yeah or like nobody else does. I’ve started slowly like building my army, but like …"
## [1] " Jay, I think that the lesson of this is that you should stop trolling Wait Wait… Don’t Tell Me!, not mimic the tactics of Ripple fans to try to take them down."
## [1] " I would say that there is a … with certain things you can draw a corelation between the actual culture and that behavior. For example, you could say that there is a reason why MRA, Men’s Rights Activists, would swarm the accounts of women who don’t like men’s rights activists. Right?"
## [1] " Absolutely."
## [1] " That makes sense."
## [1] " Yeah."
