## [1] " No, no, no."
## [1] " I mean but is there that kinda activist stuff in stocks, where people are like … trying to like spread FUD?"
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. For sure."
## [1] " I mean they’re kind of spreading the opposite of FUD. They’re spreading like pro-Ripple propaganda."
## [1] " Well I mean look if they did that, it would obviously be illegal if it was traced back to a certain source that was invested in it. The thing with Ripple is it just makes so little sense to me that I will say purely speculatively and allegedly that it does seem like … I would not be surprised to find out if there was some sort of like social media campaigning that was going on in this sort of way."
## [1] " You really gotta watch out when the Russian Ethereum stands show up. That’s gonna … It’s gonna all be over then-"
## [1] " It’s all over."
## [1] " It’s gonna be curtains for our Twitter accounts then."
## [1] " All right. So let’s move on to another part of media, which is television and-"
## [1] " Yeah. We’re doing kind of an overview of like pop culture crypto right now. I guess Ripple’s not really pop culture as it’s … It’s tech culture though."
## [1] " Tech culture."
## [1] " It’s troll culture."
## [1] " Yeah. So did you watch Silicon Valley this week?"
## [1] " I did … I did watch. I enjoy the program Silicon Valley and they had been teasing like Bitcoin plot a little bit earlier in the season, then it didn’t seem like it was gonna happen and then it came roaring back."
## [1] " I feel like the link between Bitcoin and Silicon Valley has been going on for a long time, because what Pied Piper is trying to build is a decentralized internet. Right?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " And so Richard Hendricks who is the … I don’t know what the actor’s name is. But the character on the show, when he does these sort of like standup speeches about what he’s trying to build, it’s always about decentralization."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " And so Pied Piper this week was having trouble with its series B funding and there was some things written in it that the CEO did not like. And so instead he was … allowed one of the engineers who’s played by Martin Starr from Freaks and Geeks and Party Down, to convince him to ICO instead."
## [1] " Yes, let’s play it. Let’s hear a little bit of that."
## [1] " So in some ways it’s kind of inevitable to me that Silicon Valley would’ve ended up here."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " When this show came out, I was like, “Where are they gonna go with this?” You know? Is it gonna be like the same joke forever? Is it gonna like burn itself out over a few seasons? I think a lot of people feel like it did, but there seems like there’s a new life in it, and in some ways crypto is a new cultural life in Silicon Valley. It’s like a whole new world to make fun of."
## [1] " I’m surprised that it took them this long to start making fun of crypto."
## [1] " I feel like people wouldn’t have gotten the joke until year."
## [1] " Maybe. Maybe that is true and they would’ve had to explain too much. Now like-"
## [1] " And I was surprised how deep it went. Like did you hear that part where they were talking about like securities regulation?"
## [1] " Yeah, yeah."
## [1] " Let’s hear that."
## [1] " That’s a fairly like in depth way to talk about this."
## [1] " And very topical for right now."
## [1] " Yes, very up to the news cycle."
## [1] " Yes. The only question that I had about all of this … I enjoyed the episode as well. The only question I had was like, has crypto reached the saturation point in culture where you can do a episode on a very popular show on HBO about an ICO and you can actually kind of represent it well without sort of having people sit down and do explainers of every single thing that’s going on?"
## [1] " I think that there’s certain pop culture that sits as sort of the bleeding edge of introducing ideas, like South Park comes to my mind."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " And a lot of times these are shows that are written really closely to the news cycle and we can just know that this is written closely to the news cycle because the stuff about securities has only really been in the news for about I’d say what the last month-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Maybe six weeks. So South Park would do this too, where they’d do the episodes in one week and often times like the stuff that’s coming up in those episodes becomes like deeper in pop culture in the next wave, as like writing catches up. So I would read this as this is gonna be a year of a lot of crypto jokes."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And I think it’s probably good. It’s probably a bullish signal."
## [1] " Well look, their ICO didn’t turn out so well …"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " At the episode that we’re at right now, but the case for it I thought was actually quite elegant and it actually made me think that I … more of ICOs, which was that look, if you keep relying on VCs, they’re gonna keep chipping away. Right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And that they are ruthless. Like you could get the rug pulled out from you at any time. You are going to have to do things you don’t want and then this when it was that, they didn’t wanna sell ads on the Pied Piper platform. Right? And she was gonna make them sell ads. And so the case they made was that the only way that we can do this the way that we want to do it is to do an ICO, which is what they did."
## [1] " The thing that struck me when I was watching it is what if this was my first encounter with crypto. I mean young Aaron Lammer. I’m 17 years old. I like stole my friend’s parents login to HBO. I’ve heard of Bitcoin. I don’t really know what it is. Then you watch this and it’s like the really clear message of the joke in it, is that VCs are gonna get supplanted by these initial coin offerings, and that they’re like at an existential war-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " With each other. And I do think pop culture can kind of inform how the future goes with this stuff. And the fact that Silicon Valley, which I know is a show that’s like written very much within that culture and sourced with people are there, makes me think that that is a joke that Silicon Valley people would recognize and in some ways describes how people are feeling about this."
## [1] " Yeah and the rest of the episode did have like a referendum on other Bitcoin type friend things. Right?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " So there was like the VC guy who had 300 million dollars on a thumb drive and he was looking through a dumpster for it. Right?"
## [1] " Tried 35 ICOs and only one of them worked."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah, yeah."
## [1] " This reminded also that in the overall reality bleed that’s happening between fact and fiction and like real Silicon Valley and this. Alexis Ohanian, who is one of the co-founders of Reddit, was on I believe Colbert this week basically describing cryptocurrencies as the pathway towards a new internet. But I have to say I don’t totally understand it. In fact, when I think of it, I just come back to Pied Piper, which is fictional and not a real technology … or not really like something that I could see happening. So what do you think that new internet is?"
## [1] " So is Richard Hendricks just making Ethereum?"
## [1] " I won’t try to weigh in on what he’s building. But I think when people are talking in the real world about the new internet, they’re imagining some kind of the frictionless Ethereum system that has something to do with micropayments and infinite storage and totally free, unfettered access to everything, everything tracked. I don’t really know. I mean I feel like I’ve just wrapped my head around how Bitcoin works and when people have described these Toshi Ethereum land universes, I haven’t totally like wrapped my head around what this new internet is all about. I know that DApps are gonna be a big part of it, but … Well I hope we get some people on the show who can like sell us on this vision a little more fully."
## [1] " Yeah. Brian Armstrong please."
## [1] " Yeah. I’d like to talk to Brian Armstrong."
## [1] " We’ve never insulted you. All right. So let’s go to my favorite story of the week, which is the … this was in Bloomberg, their crypto vertical."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " ‘The Wealthy Are Hoarding 10 billion dollars of Bitcoin in Bunkers’, and it is the story of Xapo, which is-"
## [1] " Yeah. We’ve talked about Xapo on the show before. Yeah."
## [1] " yeah, yeah. And it is the new venture of Wences Casares, who if you’ve read Nathaniel Popper’s book ‘Digital Gold’, he is one of the real evangelists of Bitcoin at the beginning. Like what Roger Ver was doing to people in Japan, Wences was doing sort of to Silicon Valley people, VCs, CEOs, people who were interested in other types of technology, the sort of Silicon Valley elite. Wences was the guy who was converting them all over to Bitcoin. And he comes across very sympathetically in Nathaniel’s book."
## [1] " Yeah, he seems like a smart, interesting person. Of all the people … Like this venture is not like a get rich quick cash in."
## [1] " No. It is a way to store your Bitcoin in a way that feels secure."
## [1] " I mean literally-"
## [1] " Which is something you and I know nothing about."
## [1] " Literally in a bunker."
## [1] " In a bunker."
## [1] " And on a spectrum from the most insecure way to store Bitcoin would be just on an exchange, then there’s like jump drive like systems-"
## [1] " Ledger and-"
## [1] " Ledger Nano is what I have."
## [1] " Trezor."
## [1] " Trezor and then all the way at the other end of the spectrum is the Xapo. It’s X-A-P-O, which is literally a concrete bunker. It’s not connected to the internet with computers storing private keys for high net worth individuals I think mostly and family investment arms."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. So like Novogratz has his there. From the article, two Xapo clients said it houses roughly 10 billion dollars of Bitcoin. Another person close to the venture called the figure an accurate approximation. Bitcoin’s price after all is hardly steady. Now I did a little bit of number crunching at my desk at work today."
## [1] " Calculator Kang in the house."
## [1] " Calculator Kang is in the house. That’s 7% of the Bitcoin supply right now."
## [1] " I think it’s probably actually more than that ’cause … because so many coins probably are actually lost, that it would be even more than that. The actual-"
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. So in a pure system, it is 7%."
## [1] " ’Cause we actually know all the coins that are in Xapo are there, unlike all the other coins on earth."
## [1] " Yeah. So let’s take Saifedean Ammous’ Bitcoin maximalist-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Vision to the end. Right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And that Bitcoin is all the money in the world."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " 7% of the global money supply is 6.28 trillion dollars."
## [1] " Could we pay off the federal deficit with that?"
## [1] " No. Definitely not. So that is 50 Jeff Bezozes in one vault."
## [1] " Yeah, I mean it’s kind of incredible. In some ways in the present day, the bunker seems excessive. In the Bitcoin maximalist world view, they’re gonna need a lot of guns around that bunker."
## [1] " Yeah. Well I mean … So here’s my question to you, which is that look the idea-"
## [1] " I don’t know why I’m always talking about guns on this show."
## [1] " The idea of a small number of people holding 6.28 trillion dollars in a bunker, right now it would destroy any sort of world economy because so much wealth would be centralized in one spat, amongst a small number of people. Right?"
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " Does this actually make the case for Bitcoin itself taking over the entire world economy a little bit harder, because it’s so … Like none of these people are gonna sell their Bitcoin or distribute it. And so if Bitcoin does take over the world, it means that even just with this, you have a massive concentration of wealth."
## [1] " Well-"
## [1] " Does that bother you?"
## [1] " I don’t … I’m not sure I agree with that none of these people are ever gonna sell or move their Bitcoin."
## [1] " If Bitcoin keeps going up and they believe in Bitcoin in the way that they do, I don’t … I think that that concentration will stay pretty constant."
## [1] " I do think that that much of the Bitcoin in one place is a problem on several levels and I assume that as the price accelerated, there would be more Xapos scattered around the earth, and that we would try to spread out the Bitcoin amongst them. I just see it would make sense. You know? Bitcoin goes 10 X and there’s 10 times much money there, you might wanna at least say, “Hey, we don’t wanna keep more than like a 100 billion per bunker.” Or something like that."
## [1] " I guess my problem is more that like if we try and think of … visualize Bitcoin as being the standard for all wealth in the world. Right? And that some of the ethos of Bitcoin is like we’re gonna help bank the bankless-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And that’s gonna lead to … Like I think that what it basically has led to is that the people … the wealth concentration that we see right now is gonna become hyper concentrated. Right? And it’s going to just be the people who bought into large amounts of Bitcoin early, and that seems like it’s a real problem. You have very little flexibility in that world because small amounts of people are essentially gonna be nation states upon themselves, which already is sort of happening. But it will be accelerated for no reason, for no value except for the fact that they own all this Bitcoin early. Like do you see that as a problem?"
## [1] " You know I don’t know enough about the like current concentration of wealth in the world. Somehow it compares-"
## [1] " Well just think about 50 Jeff Bezozes in like one vault."
## [1] " But I mean that’s what I’m wondering. Like if you took the top 100 Fiat holders in the world and concentrated their wealth in Swiss bank. Does the Swiss banking system as a whole have that much money in it?"
## [1] " Well it’s not even … It’s just like there aren’t 50 Jeff Bezozes. Like there’s one Jeff Bezoz."
## [1] " Right."
## [1] " Right?"
## [1] " Right."
## [1] " And if you-"
## [1] " But there’s the 50 richest people on earth-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Which let’s say are like somewhere overall around 50 Jeff Bezozes."
## [1] " Yeah. No, that would get nowhere close to 7% of the total net worth in the world."
## [1] " Wow. Yeah, I mean look I think it’s a major liability. I think these people are liabilities and Satoshi’s stash is probably a liability in its own right. My guess is that the like gamblers amongst us would read that situation and say, “Probably none of those coins are ever gonna move. Let’s just look at it as a smaller supply.” That said, if someone decides to like become like a despotic tyrant-"
## [1] " That’s the problem!"
## [1] " With their money. I mean and like clearly the betting odds are on Peter Thiel here. Right?"
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " I mean we know that Peter Thiel … and not just looking at Peter Thiel the individual, but his sort of network of like companies of investments. Yeah, it could be like a major holder amongst those."
## [1] " Yeah. Do you want Peter Thiel to be richer than he already is by several, several hundreds percent?"
## [1] " I’d be against it myself."
## [1] " Yeah. And so that-"
## [1] " But I am getting rich during that scenario. Now if I go 100 X and I also know that Peter Thiel is going a hundred X, will I accept scenario? I think I probably would."
## [1] " I don’t know. I would think very, very hard about it."
## [1] " I think you also have to look at this a little bit like the force. There’s a dark side and there’s a light side and I would hope that some of the people who became powerful and insanely rich through Bitcoin, would use it to do good. And that it’s not an inherent system that those people would become like despotic, tyrant nation states. That money could be used a lot of different ways."
## [1] " I guess so, but you are still setting up a world in which there are oligarchs. You’re setting up like a mass concentration of wealth-"
## [1] " Yeah. But we live in a world where there are oligarchs already."
## [1] " Yeah and it’s not great. It’s not great."
## [1] " I mean I don’t see how you disrupt currency and also end oligarchy simultaneously."
## [1] " Well look, that’s the problem with things like Ripple right, where they start out so concentrated. I guess that-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " The thing that I would think … And this is what I think actually will happen and this is like my hottest take-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Which I think that there will be a minable coin in the future that will probably be less centralized in wealth. And that because people will be more used to the idea of crypto, that it won’t be as concentrated and that that feature, that it is not so concentrated that there aren’t these massive dents clusters of wealth, that that will cause people to actually buy into a little bit more, because they can buy into a more democratic vision. Like-"
## [1] " Kang coin. It’s for the people."
## [1] " Kang coin for the people, like let’s do it. But like the problem-"
## [1] " So part of the way Kang coin works is sort of like magnetism. If you get too much Kang coin, like it repels other Kang coin."
## [1] " Yeah. You can only … Your Kang coins are capped, right? Like I actually don’t think I would do that. But that is … If something spread and was mine to add paste, where it was sort of by propulsion was more evenly distributed, I actually think that that would probably be a better vision of it. And maybe that’s what the people who are behind Ethereum are hoping for."
## [1] " I don’t really see how Ethereum is in improvement in this respect, other than it’s a different group of people who’ve become the oligarchs."
## [1] " I personally just don’t think it’s good for 12 random people to have 7% of the world’s wealth. That’s just me. All right. So go-"
## [1] " I mean there’s also like a timeline where like Xapo is involved in some sort of like insane like atomic accident or something that-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Like I mean the incentives-"
## [1] " EMP baby."
## [1] " Destroy Xapo, if Bitcoin really was a million dollars would be intense. You know?"
## [1] " Now that would be a good movie."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Breaking into Xapo to do an EMP to like wipe out all of this wealth."
## [1] " Yeah. Kang coin can reconquer the world."
## [1] " Exactly. Oh, maybe the Kang coin should just fund the Kang coin movie."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " It should be a production house where we should make all the dumb Bitcoin movies that we think of."
## [1] " The Jaytoshi Saga."
## [1] " All right. So the second part of the Xapo story is how it actually works and this is something that I think was very interesting to me at least, which is … This is from Bloomberg’s story, ‘At Xapo, retrieving Bitcoin from the vault takes about two days. The company verifies a client’s identity and authenticates a request before manually signing the transactions with private keys from multiple vault locations. Approval from three separate vaults is required for any transactions to be authorized. The company also offers customers a trading desk to buy and sell Bitcoin and created the first Bitcoin debit card to spend it.’"
## [1] " Well for starters, that’s the first scene in the movie, is it’s you during those two days. You’re getting verified."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " But you’re really a mole who’s breaking into Xapo to like destroy it from the inside-"
## [1] " Yeah. I’m taking like a mental map."
## [1] " But you’re posing as like a wealthy Korean business man, who’s like eye scan you’ve stolen. You’re like … You’re wearing his eye balls."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly."
## [1] " I mean that sounds like pretty good security. This is interesting to me because one of the thing we hypothesized I think during the basement tapes, was that ultimately rich people were gonna … wanting to buy into Bitcoin through some sort of an ETF or some sort of a … basically an abstracted way that was secure, where they basically just owned stock. And this presents a different, I think superior vision, which is if you really have that much money, just buy … hire someone to buy a bunch of Bitcoin and go put it in this place that has a two day wait and the most insane security procedures in the world. As long as you’re putting it … making a big investment, that’s probably more cost effective than using one of these GBTC like kind of investment products."
## [1] " Yeah and I think that if you’re like a Bitcoin purest, it is certainly the most pure vision of it."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I mean it actually makes Bitcoin seem very cool."
## [1] " It’s cool to have an internet that’s not on the internet. Like they just have like … There’s just like a … Like you know? It’s like just dead inside Xapo. The computers can’t talk to anyone."
## [1] " Yeah. I’m picturing like a very, very old man hunched over, walking like from vault to vault."
## [1] " Yeah, with like a-"
## [1] " Writing down-"
## [1] " Big, big key thing with like thousands of little keys on it."
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah. And he’s like writing down the private keys on a little piece of paper and walking it over."
## [1] " Mr. Kang, you can come in now."
## [1] " Oh, thank you. Oh, hello Mr. Kang. Yeah, exactly. He’s like, “What will your withdrawal …” It sounds awesome actually."
## [1] " How was your stay at the Swiss town in the Alps Mr. Kang?"
## [1] " Maybe we should put our very small amount of Bitcoin into Xapo just so that we could get the service."
## [1] " I don’t think you’re allowed. I think it’s like you have to like meet some sort of minimum, right?"
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " I don’t know."
## [1] " I’m sure. I’m sure."
## [1] " We should try and get Casares on the show. I know it’s a long shot, but come on the show, man."
## [1] " Yeah, answer all of our questions."
## [1] " He’s a friend of a friend to me. I’m gonna try and talk him into it."
## [1] " We’ll cut you into the movie rights."
## [1] " That’s what I said. I think we should just ICO this movie about us breaking into Xapo and then we’ll use that money and put it in Xapo."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly."
## [1] " And not actually make the movie."
## [1] " We’ll give him a producer credit."
## [1] " All we need to do is story board this story out."
## [1] " Yeah. Start a kick starter that only takes … that only deals in cryptocurrency."
## [1] " Well there must be competing Xapos out there or people must trying to create competition for this."
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah. I mean look it’s too good of an idea and it is one that basically takes out … or seems to take out the biggest fear that one would have if you had a shit load of Bitcoin, which is what if someone kidnaps me, what if I get hacked, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera."
## [1] " Yeah and it also creates like a framework where you can imaging like hodling across hundreds of years."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " You know like post apocalyptic movie where people are like walking across the like shattered remains of Europe to try to get to Xapo to like get access to these billions of dollars."
## [1] " Have you seen the land before time?"
## [1] " I have."
## [1] " I feel like we could make a movie that was like … where Xapo was like the oasis, you know?"
## [1] " Oh, yeah."
## [1] " And that the world has become a post apocalyptic hellscape and a small group of people are trying to make it to Xapo."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Which is the only place with money in the world and it’s been walled off and like … It’s like Elon Musks’ computer deals."
## [1] " Oh, see I … In my vision, the world was a scorched wasteland and the people were walking to Xapo so they could get the Bitcoin out to like restart the world economy-"
## [1] " Why would you need a world economy if there’s no world economy left?"
## [1] " I mean-"
## [1] " Like what is Bitcoin worth in like a scorched earth scenario?"
## [1] " It’s like the key to rebuilding civilization, is to get the Bitcoin network back up."
## [1] " Explain how."
## [1] " I think we have to cut this off before like we just turn this into a Bitcoin movies podcast."
## [1] " Yeah, like the stoned Bitcoin movies podcast."
## [1] " Thanks to everyone for listening. We are brought to you in partnership with Medium. You’ll find all our episodes at medium.com/cointalk, that includes transcripts. Send us an email, hi@cointalk.show. We are looking for sponsors. We have big guests coming up. Jay, big guests. You don’t even know all the big guests we got coming on."
## [1] " We have huge guests coming up."
## [1] " You probably haven’t heard that many huge guests on the show and that’s because guest booking’s on a bit of a lag, but I’m telling you, we got a tsunami coming the way of this show."
## [1] " Yeah, it is gonna revolutionize Coin Talk."
## [1] " We are rock you like an atomic bomb rocked Xapo in the doomsday scenario that we are currently kick starter ICO-ing a movie about."
## [1] " Is the end of the Xapo movie when Geraldo Rivera went to Al Capone’s vault, they open it and there’s nothing in there?"
## [1] " I think the end of the Xapo movie probably has something like the end of like Planet of the Apes, where it’s like … you think it’s all happening on like a distant moon, and then it’s like, “No, it was earth. We destroyed it all with Bitcoin.” We’ll see you next week."

## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] " Jay."
## [1] " What’s up?"
## [1] " Did you read the Bitcoin Standard?"
## [1] " I did. I mean, it actually was a little bit of an effort. And I had to scrap it together from different parts of the internet. But I believe that I got all the pages together."
## [1] " After we announced this, I assumed that you would have purchased the book. But instead, I understand that you’re working from like a PDF you got off of Reddit?"
## [1] " Not entirely! To tell our future guest, the author of the book, I attempted to buy it on Kindle, and it had even a price on Kindle that I could order it on. And so I was going to pay it, but it was only in the sample. So it was like the prologue, the introduction, and the first chapter."
## [1] " That was it shows before you pay I think."
## [1] " Well I went back and I try to actually pay, and then I was like, oh no, I’m in trouble. And then I did what I do when I can’t get an NBA game to stream. So I went on like basically Bitcoin book streaming, like subreddit."
## [1] " Last week we had Art Kang, this week, bootlegger Kang."
## [1] " Yeah, like, it’s one of these things where, well look, you and I are both in our, I would say late thirties."

## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Anyways, so the point being, I did read it."
## [1] " Well that, before we get going, the point being the book is only ten dollars in print on Amazon. If you haven’t picked it up, pick it up. This is kind of our like introduction to the book. So we’re only going to do the first couple chapters. You’re going to be able to catch up if you want to catch up. And we’re just going to start talking about things that we’re thinking about as we read this book. Jay, what’d you think?"
## [1] " I thought it was a very interesting and provocative argument for Bitcoin. Being a very impressionable man, right, I find myself at times scratching my head and saying, hm. Like you know, like maybe I should just become a full on Bitcoin maximalist."
## [1] " Yeah, I mean, in some ways the vision doesn’t seem that crazy. Once you sort of start seeing the big leaps that have come before."
## [1] " Look, I think what he has presented us is a revision of the white paper. So for a lot of people who got into Bitcoin who weren’t there from the very beginning, we have a shorthand of these sorts of ideas. Of what money is, how Bitcoin fits into the evolution of money. But it’s never really fully articulated for any of us. And I think that we get, we sort of have a piecemeal understanding of it. And what this book does over the first three chapters and which I actually appreciated, even though there were parts obviously that I think anybody would, you know, I’m sure Saifedean wants people to disagree with, there were parts I disagreed with. But it was very nice to see the whole thing laid out."
## [1] " It’s interesting that you brought up the white paper there. That wasn’t what I thought about it in relation to the white paper. My thought when I was reading this, and basically like the second chapter, which is Monetary Metals, kind of goes through all of these previous incarnations of how we’ve created currency from scratch here on earth. And I was like, oh, this is definitely the stuff that Satoshi was interested in when he made Bitcoin. I always thought of Satoshi as a cryptographer. And a person interested in computer science, and it made me think of Satoshi in a more humanities, economics-based light. As someone who had really studied this human problem of currency as probably a big part of at least his passion in the world."
## [1] " Yeah, and I think that some of the earlier people who are interested in the space, whether it be like Zeba or, really anybody who was working on this currency projects before, that was also part of their interest. And I think that the 2008 crash really pushed a lot of those ideas even further when the government just started printing money. But let’s get to that a little bit later."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " So let’s start with the introduction, who is written by the man who has blocked me on Twitter, who seems to come up every single time in our episodes, Nassim Taleb. And he wrote the introduction."
## [1] " And I would like him, I’m going to try to get him to come on the show."
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " I’d love to have him on the show."
## [1] " I would too!"
## [1] " He’s like, I think a, he hates journalists so I’d like to see him like go after you a little bit. I mean he’s not a quote unquote, writer, by trade. He is an economist and a researcher. Although I find his writing very crisp."
## [1] " Yeah, it was, I actually thought it was very readable."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And that the argument was laid out very clearly in a way that I actually appreciated because I expected given Saifedean’s somewhat, I think, purposefully heightened and somewhat florid Twitter account that this would be like a really over the top defense of Bitcoin. But it’s not. It is rational [crosstalk 00:06:39]."
## [1] " No, it’s even keeled. I actually find it interesting that you have referred to it a couple times as an argument for Bitcoin. It’s so smooth that to me a lot of it reads like, and this is what happened through history and of course the logical place we’d end up with. It’s almost like the way that Marx describes the end state of socialism. Not as, hey, this would be a good idea. We should fight for it! But as like this is a historical inevitability."
## [1] " Yeah, and Marx is a very interesting example to use when talking about anarchocapitalist. But yes, I do think the rhetorical techniques are similar.So Taleb writes the introduction, I will say and I think you would agree, Taleb doesn’t, he writes a very short introduction. It’s kind of like an extended blurb."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " But there was one part of it that was, rational markets do not require any individual trader to be rational. In fact, they work well under zero intelligence. Zero intelligence crowd under the right design, works better than a Soviet style management comprised of maximally intelligent human beings. And so what he’s making an argument for is essentially markets are going to stabilize over time and that they’re going to have their own logic to them. And that they don’t need actors within the market, they just need to exist. And that that’s what his argument for Bitcoin is."
## [1] " The way that that viewpoint works is that Bitcoin is by its very creation by the Satoshi moment, like on some inexorable rollercoaster ride towards ubiquity. Although I think it’s interesting that Taleb, he’s made this point in other writing that I’ve read of his. Does not say that Bitcoin is necessarily going to succeed or not succeed. He’s like, the cryptocurrency itself, the cat is out of the bag. And even if this fails, it can be recreated now. The idea can never go away."
## [1] " That is the real question I think that was sort of facing crypto right now. And it’s something that we’ve talked about before, but it is really, I mean there’s just news that is coming out that we’ll discuss later in the show. But it’s about sort of the high concentration of Bitcoin in a very small number of people’s hands. It makes me wonderful if that is sustainable or that will sort of tank the idea eventually. But I don’t think that-"
## [1] " Really? See I thought that argument, like when you look at Bitcoin compared to all the other currencies. It’s like pretty spread out."
## [1] " No, well like the other cryptocurrencies."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " But not like world currencies."
## [1] " No, not world currencies, yes. Not legitimate currencies."
## [1] " That’s a separate argument, but I do think that the question of whether or not it will be Bitcoin is one that should be seriously asked right now. And I think eh is asking that same question as well. The person who is not asking that question is Saifedean Ammous, right? And so this book starts with a very bare bones and very sort of logical progression of an explanation of money. Did you know all this stuff about money?"
## [1] " I would say that I knew like 50 percent of it. But I didn’t know it, know it."
## [1] " At the start of money then, Saifedean sort of starts with this idea of bartering, right? That the barter system is one that still exists today and it is by far the most logical way to exchange something. Which is like you’ll say I’ll give you these fish, and you give me, let’s say those apples, right? And that’s the barter that you do. And he explains that the problem is that when you go from saying I will give you these fish, you give me a house, right? Like, how do you make that exchange? Like obviously there are many problems with it because you can’t, how many fish do you need for a house? Now, do you give the fish at the beginning, or do you give it at the end when all the fish are dead? You know, how do you deal with a perishable good, versus like an actual thing, and how do you make that transaction over time? So that’s a very logical thing, I think that’s at the core of all economics. And I think that’s where he starts."
## [1] " Well, and in the twenty-first century, there’s such a great diversity of goods. There’s such an assymetry of what one person would have that the other person would need. And then that working the other direction. Kind of reminds me of, you ever buy stuff on Craigslist?"
## [1] " Not as much as you do. You seem to have bought everything in your life off Craigslist at some point. So not quite like you. So why don’t you explain Craigslist?"
## [1] " So sometimes I’ll be trying to buy like a synthesizer or something. And they’re like, also we’ll consider bartering and trades. What is the chances that I have something of equal value that this person wants? With like no guide whatsoever. That just seems like a pretty far fetched assumption to make about the world. So it kind of feels like almost immediately you start needing an intermediary if you’re going to be able to do almost any kind of business."
## [1] " Yeah, and that’s his argument is that the history of exchanges starts with bartering, and then you immediately run into these problems when it’s not just like hunter gatherers trading things with one another. And they need to actually trade goods. So you need something that stands in for some sort of promise, right? Which is saying like this is worth this. This is a store of exchange, or this is a store of value. And that there’s a logical progression that goes through a lot of different things. Shells, for example, he talks about a lot. There were like seashells that were used."
## [1] " Those rocks with the holes in the middle of them."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. And then all these types of money have problems with them. So for example, wampum. Did you know what wampum was before?"
## [1] " I was not familiar with what wampum was."
## [1] " Okay, so wampum was a native american tribe’s version of currency, and it was shells, right?"
## [1] " Yeah, seashells."
## [1] " Seashells. And at some point, some explorers I think came, and they sort of flooded the market with wampum. And then the wampum became devalued."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And he says that that’s bad for any number of reasons. Like did you understand the reasons he was saying that was bad?"
## [1] " Well, I mean, he gives all these historical examples that seem like they’re divergent, but then end in the same place, which is technology catches up, and … So even when people like try to fight that devaluation, usually when technology catches up, and people can figure out how to make whatever it is you’re using as money, that thing is fucked."
## [1] " Yeah, so that’s one of the principles that I think he’s laying out here, which is that money needs to kind of be scarce, right? The resource needs to be scarce, it needs to be very unique in the sense that you can’t just go get more wampum out of like the wampum hole that nobody has discovered and then flood the market with new wampum."
## [1] " The end state of all this is that we resolve on these metal currencies, there’s been many metal currencies, but gold, silver, bronze, are like the biggest one in history that require a certain amount of labor to extract the medal, and it’s hard enough that the market cannot be flooded. And if it is flood, or if you do mine more, it’s not enough so that it undermines the value of the stuff."
## [1] " Yeah, there’s no sea captain coming in with like a whole bunch of gold."
## [1] " I mean the interesting, so like, those are sort of the end state of all these ideas or the like pre-fiat money end state of all these. Like we talk about like FUD, and what the like greatest existential threats to like Bitcoin system is. The greatest existential threat to the gold system was like alchemy, basically. If someone had figured out alchemy, it would have been like all over."
## [1] " Yeah, well if you could turn regular metal, that’s probably why alchemy was such a good racket for so long."
## [1] " That’s what I’m saying!"
## [1] " So Saifedean goes on to outline his case then for why Bitcoin, given all these things that we know about money, is the best version of money that there ever has been, right? And that what used to be the gold standard, which is, like the problems with gold is that it’s hard to divide up. So if I bring out a nugget of gold for your synthesizer, and I haggle you down to-"
## [1] " I’d be like, that’s a big nug man."
## [1] " Yeah, I haggle you down to like half an ounce of gold for your synthesizer. It’s very difficult for me to sit there and like hack off half an ounce and give it to you."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " And so that’s why paper money exists. Because it’s more divisible, and it is based on gold. So I think when the United States first dollar was printed, like an ounce of gold was twenty dollars or something like that. He mentioned it in his book."
## [1] " I mean, I didn’t realize that the gold standard wasn’t established until I think like the late 1800s. So like even the end state of gold is like a last 200 years kind of thing. Like we’re in a pretty young state of money."
## [1] " For the type of money that we have right now?"
## [1] " Yeah. Fiat money, like money that originally represented gold in Fort Knox. And then was printed way more than there is gold in Fort Knox."
## [1] " Yeah, and I would argue that in the United States that we had another revolution in money beyond the switchover to fiat currency, which started in probably the 80s when Wall Street was basically printing money and money stopped meaning anything. And then 2008 obviously where people’s relationship with all this fiat currency and Wall Street radically changed. And now we’re in some sort of flux period. And so I think that within that continuum it does make sense that something would change. It’s not like we’re dealing with something that’s deeply rooted and has thousand of years of history that seems pretty intractable. And I think that of all the arguments makes, at least at the beginning of this book, is the most convincing to me. Which is that if you zoom out a little bit, the idea that this would switch over does actually make sense. It’s not like human nature or anything like that to have a fiat currency that used to be peg off the gold standard and is no longer."
## [1] " He also makes a pretty strong argument at least to me, that this problem of how do you keep money and hold its value over time? Any solution to that problem is in some ways a gamble. Whether it’s holding fiat currency, buying commodities. Whatever you’re doing, you’re in some ways gambling on some future state. And as he goes through all these historical examples of different kinds of money, eventually the long term money of just holding money keeps going down and people are driven to speculate on wilder and wilder things, rather than just holding their money. Do you mind if I read a quick quote from him [crosstalk 00:17:02]."
## [1] " Yeah, no, please."
## [1] " It should be of interest to modern Keynesian economists as well as the present generation of investors that although the emperors of Rome frantically tried to manage their economies, he’s talking about these early Roman gold coins that the emperor kept clipping bits off of. They only succeeded in making matters worse. Price and wage controls and leaguer tender laws were passed, but it was like trying to hold back the tides. Rioting, corruption, lawlessness, and mindless mania for speculation and gambling engulfed the empire like a plague, with money so unreliable and debased, speculation in commodities became far more attractive than producing them."
## [1] " What you described right there in that passage seems very similar to where we are right now."
## [1] " Absolutely."
## [1] " Everything is wild speculation and people’s idea of store of value is no longer in the country itself but or in civic or government institutions, but instead are in tech companies. When you do that you are engaging in wild speculation. You know, if you have all your money invested in Amazon or Apple or something like that, that’s wild speculation by anyone’s standards."
## [1] " Well I would also argue that what you’re seeing people doing cross a variety of investment activities over the last twenty years is betting on the future. If you bought apple when it IPO’ed in 1980, you were betting on the future. If you bought Apple stock when the iPhone came out, you’re betting on the future. If you’re buying Tesla right now, against the most massive market shorting in history, you’re betting on a specific future. And if you’re buying cryptos now, you’re betting on a specific future. So people have shown a wild appetite to gamble speculatively on what the future will be like."
## [1] " Yeah, and that doesn’t even count things like real estate and everything."
## [1] " Oh, sure."
## [1] " So we do live, I think, and I’m sure some economists will tweet at us and say that we’re wrong, but it feels to me at least, and maybe it is-"
## [1] " We encourage that by the way."
## [1] " It is just you and me being also being very speculative. People with gambling problems."
## [1] " It’s a human impulse. That’s what he’s saying. People felt this way during the Roman empire. Like, it’s nothing new."
## [1] " And part of that I think does have to do with the fact that our faith in this currency and in the stability of the economy, for example like, it used to be that people worked for a company and that they would be paid a salary, but they would also be paid in the company stock, and it would never occur to them to trade that stock for something else, you know? That they could count on a certain stable life of comfort. And that’s not where we are right now, you know, we have people, like look at the people that got really rich off Bitcoin or Ethereum. Like they’re sort of the people that people look up to now. It’s not people who work twenty years anyway."
## [1] " I was struck, I mean he gives some great historical examples, but once you start wracking your mind, you can keep coming up with different ways that we’ve created weird markets that people then speculated on. And sometimes they were dead ends, and sometimes they led to giant economies. I was reading about Michael Cohen and his taxi medallions. I didn’t know what the origin of the New York City taxi medallion is."
## [1] " Oh my God, I know all about this, but go ahead."
## [1] " So it’s, during the Great Depression, in New York City, almost everyone was out of work. And lots of people had cars. So people would just start driving around trying to pick people up for like a little bit of money to drive them somewhere. And eventually there was like, huge traffic. People were like, we gotta regulate this, there’s too many cars on the road. So they were like, all right, we’re only going to grant a certain number of taxi medallions. What struck me about this medallion story was how quickly it went from being this regulation of basically unemployed people trying to make money on the side, to people were like massively speculating and accumulating taxi medallions."
## [1] " It is actually, I cannot think of a worse, if you were going to be, how would you get most wrecked and be like listen, you just get up to nose leveraged in taxi medallions? There was a period of my time, Aaron Lammer, where I considered speculating on taxi medallions. [crosstalk 00:21:50]"
## [1] " If I could short taxi medallions, I would!"
## [1] " I don’t know if this shocks you or not, but I have a friend who is a city planner. He just finished his PhD. And his specialty is transit. And so when the green cabs came out, do you remember that? So they came out before Uber."

As a person who has basically lived his entire life doing that type of wild speculation, I was not immune to the problems of green taxi medallions. And thank God, I did not do it."

## [1] " Well, and tell me if I’m wrong, as long as we’re this deep into taxi medallions, I think we should just go whole episode with it."
## [1] " Should we just start a taxi medallion podcast?"
## [1] " Taxi medallion podcast. But it seems like the guys like Michael Cohen who were deep leveraged in the taxi medallion game, liked being in that business because as far as I understand, when you have a medallion, driver goes drives a shift and gives you a hundred bucks."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And I would guess that that historically has been a cash payment?"
## [1] " It was for years the best investment that you could have because the value only went up, right? New York City’s, they cap it, right. So at some point there can’t be more. The taxi licensing commission has to put out more, they wouldn’t. You know because they were controlled by all these people who were leveraged to the eyeballs on it, so they were scarce. Population in New York City kept going up. So you know, obviously these rides are in high demand. And if you own five of them, then you have two things. Right, you have the people who you rent the medallion to who are paying you-"
## [1] " Cash, which makes you a very friendly person to the mafia."
## [1] " All the time, and the value keeps going up. And it’s so it’s like owning an apartment in a neighborhood where the price can only go up and getting rent without having to pay any sort of maintenance fees or anything like that. I mean it was an amazing investment for years."
## [1] " I believe Saifedean Ammous is arguing that Bitcoin is that investment right now."
## [1] " You can have someone drive your Bitcoin around."
## [1] " No, it’s all of those qualities that you just described."
## [1] " Yes. Because it’s deflationary."
## [1] " Because it’s deflationary. And that’s ultimately like we’ve been experimenting with all of these currencies and here’s what’s gone wrong. All of these things lead up to this point in history. And gold mining has been pretty successful. They’ve been able to control it, but Bitcoin is one step further. They’re not anymore. There’s not the same gold, I think they say there’s two percent added to the world’s supply every year. There’s 21 million Bitcoin. That’s it. You know. It’s a taxi medallion."
## [1] " So maybe this is a question we should ask-"
## [1] " Except there’s no Uber in this universe."
## [1] " Well there is Ubers. There’s like 5000 Ubers that are trying to take down Bitcoin. That’s the biggest problem. Ethereum is fucking Uber, man! You know, and Ripple is Juno. And there is competition. So but I think he would acknowledge that."
## [1] " I think he would too."
## [1] " The second part of the taxi medallion example which I actually think is pretty apt. I’m glad that you brought it up. Is that the problem with the taxi medallion is that it was not that like an immigrant family from Bangladesh would scrape together and use all their family network to pool together to buy a taxi medallion. That did happen, it was very rare. It’s that this whole thing got you know, swapped up by a small number of people who are either prospecting for it or were straight up mafia, you know?"
## [1] " Or in the case of Michael Cohen, were like Jewish attorney mafia."
## [1] " Yeah. Exactly. So that’s the problem with the deflationary currency or any sort of deflationary … And I do think that you can say that taxi medallions are a currency. Is that once it’s fucked, it’s very hard to unfuck it, right?"
## [1] " And I think that’s the risk of Bitcoin, which is you’re like, this is great. It’s taxi medallion! Also if an Uber comes out, this could be worth almost nothing."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly. And also now that I have these medallions, and I’m making money off of it, nobody else can have medallions, because I also control the guy who prints more medallions. And I’ve told him that he cannot print any more medallions. So, a few weeks ago we talked about Jim Surawak’s article that he wrote in MIT Technology Review. And one of the things that he said was that the reason that fiat currency is good is because you can unfuck things. Like you can figure out how to solve massive problems that happen."
## [1] " You can engineer an economy."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " And Bitcoin is not an engineered economy."
## [1] " Yes, like basically Bitcoin right now is taxi medallions at the height of Michael Cohen, fucking leveraging himself, borrowing money to buy more taxi medallions."
## [1] " And I think to their credit, people who believe in Bitcoin, true maximalists. People who believe fully in Bitcoin are like yeah, that’s better. Like don’t engineer the economy. Like the example we just read of Rome, it’s like they did all this crazy stuff trying to engineer the economy, but people kept wildly speculating. And it ultimately led to x and y. So I don’t embrace total free market libertarianism myself, but I find a lot worthwhile about the idea of Bitcoin and I think to criticize it from any sort of a standpoint that we need to engineer economies. If you believe that you’re never going to believe in cryptocurrencies. There’s like a fundamental disconnect. You either want engineered economies or you want some sort of amorphous, unengineered world money pool."
## [1] " And that’s what I appreciate about Saifedean’s book, which is that it is a very clear eyed, if you believe in crypto, this is what you should believe in. Like you should be an Austrian school economics person. And you should believe in anarchocaptalism. You should believe that, and I don’t know if he would say that this is true, but if he is consistent with his opinions, which I imagine he is, he’s okay with the Uber coming along."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " Like he’s okay with Michael Cohen getting completely wrecked. He doesn’t think that the government should step in and save Michael Cohen because Michael Cohen was profiting off a New York City taxi licensing commission that was completely corrupt, and was inefficient and was not servicing the number of people who needed it. And so when Uber comes along, it destroys it, you know. And that’s a good thing. So that could happen to Bitcoin as well. I don’t think he would say it would because he would say that all the other coins are shit except for Bitcoin. And that’s why Bitcoin is good."
## [1] " I don’t know what he thinks about other coins."
## [1] " He calls them all shit coins."
## [1] " But I find-"
## [1] " But that’s what part of his Twitter persona is, like everything except Bitcoin is a shit coin. And people will be like what about Ethereum, [crosstalk 00:31:34] shit coin?"
## [1] " I mean it’s sort of a gray zone. What I noted is sometimes I wasn’t sure if the things that Saifedean was saying in this were like his ideas or his interpretation of Satoshi’s ideas because they’re so close. But like the way you just described, you know, don’t save the economy. The very first thing we know about Satoshi is that Bitcoin is directly inspired by the like, banking bailout. It’s like one of the only things we sort of know is that what is what he was thinking about when he launched Bitcoin. So I think if you look at that as the foundational myth of the Bitcoin narrative, we’re driving towards some point where economies can no longer be bailed out because they’re not under the control of governments. If you look at, if you’re a true Bitcoin maximalist. I also think he makes an argument, I’m wondering what you think about this. That there’s no real half way with Bitcoin. That the only path for Bitcoin is maximalism at some point."
## [1] " Yeah, and I actually found that part of his book to be the most convincing. Was that this thing only really will get to its full potential if it becomes the standard for the world. And I actually-"
## [1] " I didn’t even think about the title until you like said that."
## [1] " Yeah, I have real problems with that pragmatically, but I actually think I might agree with it in a theoretical idea where I don’t even know which way I would go, but I would say yeah, if it’s going to work, it needs to be full on. It can’t be this thing that only certain people use. And is like an interesting idea and is only used for certain types of transactions. It need to be like the store of value for everything. And that’s where the idea, the deflationary currency really needs to be, it needs to be the only deflationary currency. And like I actually found that to be quite convincing."
## [1] " It made me think about like what the last project that I had heard about that’s goal was the whole world. Which is probably Facebook. If you invested in Facebook, when it was already being publicly traded, you’re basically like what’s the ceiling? Well the ceiling is the entire world. And at a certain point, as enough people invest in these things. Like an investor in Facebook, if you’re buying Facebook, you know as it’s already up there, you’re basically like I think it will. And at a certain point, if you’re buying Bitcoin, you have to believe in a Bitcoin maximalism. As Bitcoin gets up over 20, 50, 100 thousand dollars, if you’re still buying then, the only way you’re going to win is if Bitcoin maximalism takes over the world."
## [1] " Well yeah because the price, even at 10000 right now or whatever it’s at, 9000. That potential is baked into the price right now. It’s not like people think that a Bitcoin is actually worth 9000 dollars right now. They’re baking in the idea that perhaps this is going to take over the world. He actually brings Facebook up in the book in a way. Where he says, well look, these types of ideas have worked in technology where like look Facebook became the standard because it allowed for certain features. And as the network grew and after a certain size, all other competition became impossible. So like Google could create Orchid or Google Plus, it didn’t matter. You know, like things like MySpace fell off obviously. Massive, massive companies could try and make social networks, but it wouldn’t matter because Facebook had gotten a certain amount of share in which there was no feature you could add could actually replicate the features that happen when you have a ton of people on it, right?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " And he says that for Bitcoin to work it needs to reach that point. He believes, he seems to believe that it is close to that right now."
## [1] " Not just in value, but in terms of the nodes to the network and the connectivity [crosstalk 00:35:10]."
## [1] " The number of people who use it. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah."
## [1] " People who use it to make transactions, yeah."
## [1] " And that that’s why everything else is a shit coin that is a distraction from this idea that Bitcoin will take over in the way that Facebook has taken over."
## [1] " I think that’s a provocative argument, but let me push back on one of those points because I’m curious what you think. So you said that that’s already cooked into the 10000ish price of [crosstalk 00:35:32]."
## [1] " Of course, yeah,"
## [1] " But when I read this history of money that Ammous lays out in this book, we already know how much money like all the gold in the world is worth based on the current value of gold. And gold is the jump before Bitcoin. For Bitcoin to even pass gold, and he is making the argument that Bitcoin is like a vastly superior technology to gold, Bitcoin would be hundreds of fold more valuable than it is now."
## [1] " Oh yeah, sure, but-"
## [1] " So, so, the possibility of that is cooked into the price, but you would also say, if Bitcoin even vaguely makes good on the possibilities ascribed in the book, [crosstalk 00:36:15] millions of dollars, okay that was my read. I was like, if you believe this book is the future, Bitcoin is worth over a million dollars."
## [1] " I mean, look at the price of Amazon stock right now. Like it’s 1600 dollars a share."
## [1] " Would have been unthinkable five years ago."
## [1] " But part of that 1600 dollars is people speculate on the future, and that’s part of the price. It’s like, it’s baked in, the idea that like everything we buy-"
## [1] " The entire economy."
## [1] " The entire economy is-"
## [1] " The entire retail profit [crosstalk 00:36:39]"
## [1] " Yeah, and they might take it over like large states. You know, which is what they’re trying to do. That’s baked into the 1600 dollar price. It’s not like the actual business right now is worth that whatever it is at 1600 dollars a share. The speculation is baked in. So with Bitcoin, you know, some of the criticism of it is that there is no actual fundamental, that the whole thing is baked in potential. Which you know, Saifedean would disagree with. But which I find a little bit more convincing."
## [1] " I think that the current price compensates for a lot of scenarios that are not Bitcoin maximalism. That are like, hey, Bitcoin gets so big, it’s as big as the fifteenth largest economy or something like that. But it does not totally take over in that kind of way. Did the book make you want to buy Bitcoin?"
## [1] " Yeah, it did. And you know, I think we should go over one example that he brings up. Of why Bitcoin is good. And he, this is about Bitcoin’s potential to influence governments, right? That right now is a veil between the government and the people. So that even when you have the gold standard and you have dollars that are pegged to the gold standard. Like we can’t peer into Fort Knox or walk in there with like a little scale or something like that and make sure that the amount of gold that they say they have is what they actually have."
## [1] " Similar to my like arguments about bad actors on block chains, which is like, yes, all this works if you assume that people are not lying. But in a non-public block chain, there is a certain trust that people are not lying, just like there would be in Fort Knox there."
## [1] " Yeah, and he is essentially saying that when you have this radical transparency of money, that people will, and when money is scarce, that people are actually much more prudent about how they spend money. And so his argument is that this will affect everything. So people will actually become more engaged in how the government spends money because they don’t assume that there is an endless amount of it. And this, I actually find somewhat convincing, because like, you know what the federal deficit is right now?"
## [1] " I would not try to say it on air."
## [1] " Do you have any idea how the deficit affects the government functions?"
## [1] " Generally, like debt ceiling shut downs is the main time I hear about it."
## [1] " Nobody knows any of this. Like nobody knows actually how much money the United States government has. Nobody actually understands how it, every once in a while it’s like USA today will make a cool infographic that shows how much of it’s military spending or whatever. But that’s it, you know. And he says that if money is scarce, if it is on the block chain, if it is very transparent, then the government will be forced into only making prudent decisions. He says that that will actually cut down military spending, that because while people will feel a certain need to do things like improve health care or whatever like that, what they won’t do is sort of say, hey we should fund this small operation in Yemen. And we should fund this small operation in the in the Philippines. And this one in the Sudan. That once people are actually aware of how much money is being spent on those types of things, that they will backlash and they will vote people out of office. Do you find that convincing?"
## [1] " I think the government stuff is the final leap, where I don’t quite understand how Bitcoin works as a governmental currency."
## [1] " Well, it would just be the money that everybody uses around the world, right, so then-"
## [1] " So the US federal reserve would be-"
## [1] " Would be Bitcoin."
## [1] " 10 million Bitcoin. [crosstalk 00:40:06]"
## [1] " Yeah, well that would be a lot."
## [1] " If we’re doing really well. That’s an American maximalist scenario."
## [1] " Exactly, that’s Aaron the imperialist talking."
## [1] " You know, Trumplandia, of course."
## [1] " I mean, I think that it’s more just what happens psychologically when money is scarce and transparent, is what he’s talking about."
## [1] " Right, know I under-"
## [1] " That people would really track it a lot harder. And that they’d be more interested in short term personal outcomes instead of these sort of abstract campaigns that toss them personally money and that they would be more prone to push for things like healthcare or you know, like social security than they would be to push for like a campaign in Yemen that they don’t know why we’re doing it."
## [1] " Right, and the counterargument to all this would be the argument that we talked about. That a Bitcoin economy would be unkind, perhaps even cruel. And all the engineering that is done on the economy would be undone to disastrous effects for human life in America."
## [1] " 95 percent of the people in America would be too poor to even get themselves to a polling station is the alternative."
## [1] " Yeah, and I think that there’s usually a lot of guns in these scenarios. Like when I really start playing them out in my mind, I’m like, I believe in that world I think I’m also long on gun stocks."
## [1] " All right, well is that a good place to end?"
## [1] " Yeah, that’s not a world I want to live in. But I’d still buy some Bitcoin."
## [1] " Yes, the answer is always we should buy Bitcoin."
## [1] " Okay, so Jay, this was great, I enjoyed talking about this book with you."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " We’re going to get you a real copy of the book for next week."
## [1] " I’ve already ordered it."
## [1] " And people at home, order the book. We kind of did like the first couple chapters, a little bit of maybe chapter three there. So four through seven we’ll try and do next week. Let us know if you are listening and you have questions in your reading, comments. We’d love to hear from you, we’re going to talk to the author of this book, Saifedean Ammous, on the last episode. So listen along, catch up if you can. And we’ll be there in a few weeks. Yeah, thanks for listening. You got anything you want to talk about Jay, anything you want to promo?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Push that show man!"
## [1] " What show?"
## [1] " Oh you mean this show! That’s right, that’s what I’m talking about."

## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron: Welcome, Nathaniel Popper."
## [1] "Aaron: How’s your Consensus going?"
## [1] "Aaron: You only got to go to one of the two Snoop concerts?"
## [1] "Aaron: Is this, like, the biggest week of the year for you? Is this like Fashion Week if you work at T Magazine?"
## [1] "Aaron: I saw a lot of tweets coming out from it that, like, “Wow, this is surprisingly legit this year.” The whole production value seems like it’s stepped up a notch."
## [1] "Aaron: I read your book this week."
## [1] "Aaron: Which was kind of an unusual experience, because it’s new enough to be pretty new, but then there was a mental block I had against reading it because it was over a year old and I was like, “Eh, this is all old hat.” And it was a surprisingly emotional journey reading back through this sequence in these different people’s lies. And it strikes me-"
## [1] "Aaron: I laughed, I cried, I learned a little something. And it had struck me that you’ve been on this journey. When did you first get exposed to the coin world?"
## [1] "Aaron: It’s funny thinking back. That story is, like, perfect buzzword SEO magic. “These minor celebrities you know from a movie, like, nascent technology and massive financial gain.”"
## [1] "Aaron: The bonus."
## [1] "Aaron: Trifecta?"
## [1] "Aaron: At what point did writing about Bitcoin become part of your week-to-week life?"
## [1] "Aaron: Those stories feel, comparatively, pretty small [crosstalk 00:36:07]."
## [1] "Aaron: Like, those people are getting in line and just merging into your story so you don’t have to cover them separately?"
## [1] "Aaron: I wanted to ask you about that, because if there was a point in time where it felt like, “Wow, this isn’t enough for a full-time job,” right now, like, covering ICOs and covering Bitcoin core … I mean, these are, like, disparate fields."
## [1] "Aaron: It feels like you want a team if you are going to cover all of this stuff."
## [1] "Aaron: Warring worlds, really."
## [1] "Aaron: That’s a consistent theme. You can just say that after any statement and everyone thinks everyone else is an idiot."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah. Do people think that, when you’re hanging out with Bitcoin Cash advocates they’re like, “Oh, Nathaniel is clearly more into Bitcoin Cash than the regular Bitcoin.”"
## [1] "Aaron: Ah, you’re like a ref?"
## [1] "Aaron: You’re like an NBA playoffs rep."
## [1] "Aaron: And you’re in the tank for Silicon Valley and really want Coinbase, Ethereum world to thrive."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah, I mean, one thing I really like about the coverage that you do in the New York Times is, if you’re going to write about something like, say Ripple, it seems like you’re trying to write the definitive article about Ripple, more than the, like, 97th 300-word blog post about some new Ripple test program-"
## [1] "Aaron: With DHL and Malaysia or … There’s a level to which the news is being generated constantly, but I don’t know that reading 100 news items about Ripple actually tells you that much about what Ripple is. And the way that you’re able to focus in on sort of the general, like, “What is happening here?” Is helpful for someone like me who’s interested in this, but I don’t want to dedicate two or three hours of my day every day to reading about it. Are you reading about it two or three hours every day?"
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah. Often not very elegantly put out news."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah, even exist in three to five years."
## [1] "Aaron: I would consider it successful if a lot of these projects made an existing product that fell on deaf ears. That would be, like, a huge accomplishment for the majority of coins."
## [1] "Aaron: That’s like making it to the conference finals and it’s like, “We can all go home proud here. People didn’t want our Ethereum-based casino.”"
## [1] "Aaron: What would a company that was trying to behave honestly and for the longterm, like, how would we sort of know? I feel like we have a lot of tools for trying to understand what’s dishonest, but I don’t even know how I would know if there was a legitimate project out there."
## [1] "Aaron: Not that I’m asking you for investment advice, but you do sort through a million people who would like you to write about them."
## [1] "Aaron: And even if you were a computer scientist, you would be not an economist, and you would be not a cryptographer. There’s no way you would master all of these skills."
## [1] "Aaron: Or it’s like, “You’ll be able to use this to make more things that can then themselves generate more-”"
## [1] "Aaron: There’s a huge amount of projects, a huge amount of the best-known projects basically are to create more projects with. I would even say that Ethereum could be categorized this way."
## [1] "Aaron: Yes, CryptoKitties are real. You can really create them on the blockchain."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah. In reading back through your book, one of the things that struck me was how long it took for people to realize that the truly non-anonymous nature of Bitcoin was going to be a pretty big issue; the fact that you could just … I mean, people bring it up early on and are like, “Hey, it’s actually a terrible criminal currency because there’s a paper trace of every single thing that’s ever happened on it.” But it goes along this really long path and then, eventually, like, in the last year, that becomes a major issue leading up to, like, Zcash is now being listed on Gemini."
## [1] "Aaron: Oh, interesting."
## [1] "Aaron: Caught old-school."
## [1] "Aaron: When you were covering the Bitcoin story early on, I noticed a real contrast between writing about something like Ripple. Ripple’s a company. You can be like, “That guy, he’s the CEO. They’ve got a PR person who will respond to your queries.” And then Bitcoin is this weird, amorphous … there’s no quote from Satoshi Nakamoto, even the Bitcoin Foundation and Bitcoin Core are these kind of weird, more nonprofit-y type entities than a true company. What were the challenges of trying to cover something that had no central authority or central voice?"
## [1] "Aaron: Having seen a limited amount of Roger Ver videos, these people are not media-trained."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah. I was going to ask you. I mean, I assume you do not hold cryptocurrencies yourself?"
## [1] "Aaron: That’s policy most places where people are covering this stuff, or I would have seen a disclosure from you. Do you ever feel like you’re missing out or you’re not getting … I think of Bitcoin as such an experiential thing. Like, when you think back on Roger Ver going and putting it on people’s phones. Like, part of the whole first wave of Bitcoin, ideologically, was that you had to try it for yourself, hold your own private keys. I’m curious, like, what going through all of that period was like for you as someone who was not doing any of those things that were supposed to teach you what it was really like."
## [1] "Aaron: Are you short everything you’re not in in the entire market?"
## [1] "Aaron: This has come up repeatedly on the show, because we decided, not because we thought it was some genius idea just because we were already speculating on coins that we would do a show about our misadventures in this, and we haven’t even been in it that long. I’ve only been in for maybe a year. I already have nostalgic associations with alt coins like they were Super Nintendo games I was into. Where I’m like, I’m still holding Sumokoin because I made this joke on the show for a long time about all this Sumokoin I was holding. I mean, as a test of irrational thought, you can get yourself from 0 to 60 pretty fast the minute you start putting some real money into these kind of investments."
## [1] "Aaron: I mean, sometimes it even goes a step further than that, which is a lot of these, like, micro cap coins, when there’s a revelation that it’s just an outright scam people are like, “I don’t know. I think it might come back though.”"
## [1] "Aaron: People are, like, scamming is not off the table. Like, a good scam is still a good investment."
## [1] "Aaron: Photoshopped."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah, I mean, how are you covering the story of all these people all over the country who are buying into crypto? I think we generally see crypto from the top down, like, the creators and sort of the guys who bought low. But really, in America, the story of crypto is people making a Coinbase account and going and putting $500 in. I mean, I guess that’s not … I often struggle to be like, “Is most of the money in this or is most of the money in a Peter Thiel, like, Xapo vault?”"
## [1] "Aaron: We refer to them as the Ethereum Teens, because there’s, like, a lot of teen investment groups there."
## [1] "Aaron: They weren’t wrong in that first wave though. We were like, “Ha ha, I bet people are going to bid Ripple up to $1 from $0.30 because, you know, psychology.” And I was like, “Oh shit. This is happening?”"
## [1] "Aaron: Their dumb psychology turned out to be a human dumb psychology."
## [1] "Aaron: I’m just starting to really wrap my head around Bitcoin maximalism taken literally rather than sort of figuratively. We’re doing a book club on the show and I’ve been reading Saifedean Ammous’s book, The Bitcoin Standard, which is sort of, like, it’s laying out the case for Bitcoin maximalism."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah. I recommend it. I think it’s very good. I was sort of comparing it, because at the same time I was reading your book Digital Gold and switching back and forth. There’s lots of long-term questions about Bitcoin that existed three years ago, still exist, that I can sort of move my head around, like, “Oh, the electricity.” But I’m like, “Oh, but we actually have more electricity than we need on Earth.” There’s a lot of these things that I’m like, “Yeah, people are going to figure this out.”"
## [1] "Aaron: The one lingering one of why it’s hard for me to really embrace the idea of a Bitcoin maximalist worldview is this idea that a very small group of people, many of whom you probably have personally, socially encountered, would inherit, let’s just say 10% of the wealth of the world, not inherit, would possess that. That’s the part that’s hard for me to sort of project into the future. Even thinking as a reporter, how do you tell the story of, like, “If this works, Peter Thiel has 3% of the money in the world.”?"
## [1] "Aaron: I don’t have a good answer for that question."
## [1] "Aaron: It seems more likely the opposite would happen, which is as Bitcoin becomes more legitimate, a greater share of the Bitcoin would be possessed by, like, funds and various entities that hold large amounts of wealth."
## [1] "Aaron: Continues, yeah, always has worked."
## [1] "Aaron: Just happen to own basically, like, three or four countries worth of money now, just them and professional poker players, as far as I’ve come to tell. A lot of people who were playing online poker did very well over the last few years."
## [1] "Aaron: PayPal money becomes venture money, and Uber becomes money that got dumped into Bitcoin, becomes money that ends up in Ethereum. 300% might be conservative in terms of some of the exponential economics."
## [1] "Aaron: What does it mean that the first big idea since the internet, like, really the first thing that competes with the internet in terms of how big it could be didn’t really come from Silicon Valley, did not come from the venture capital world, the YCombinator startup world? What does it tell us and how do you think the Valley is reacting to the fact that this one isn’t really on their scorecard?"
## [1] "Aaron: Right. We assume Satoshi did not go through YCombinator."
## [1] "Aaron: As an outsider, it feels like, while many people in Silicon Valley profiteered greatly from this, that this idea came without a center authority, in some ways subverts the very idea of a company being behind the big technological leap. I don’t know. I guess it sort of starts to feel like a battle for the soul of what it is. Like, is Bitcoin the protocol or is it Coinbase? Is it the consumer vision or is it some essential, ideological core?"
## [1] "Aaron: My final question to you: What’s the big story that excites you now? I feel like each year has this kind of dominant theme. Like, last year was the fork year. Everything was all about forks. What do you see as the most important thing to be keeping your eye on right now?"
## [1] "Aaron: When is something going to happen?"
## [1] "Aaron: Well, thank you so much for doing this interview."
