## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] " Jay, it’s been a while. We’re back here in the Crypto Cave."
## [1] " Hot day today in New York but the Crypto Cave is very cool down here."
## [1] " You’ll notice I installed an air conditioner in the Crypto Cave."
## [1] " That air conditioner looks like you stole it from a Bodega."
## [1] " Well, it’s hard to get an air conditioner-"
## [1] " It’s definitely a Bodega air conditioner."
## [1] " For people listening at home, the Crypto Cave has approximately three square feet of window space."
## [1] " That’s generous."
## [1] " 50% of which is now occupied by a Bodega air conditioner, which we can’t run while we’re taping. It’s gonna be a hot summer in here."
## [1] " Let’s hope for … I’m hoping that prices start going up ’cause we’re gonna need some good news if we’re gonna be forced to sit in this room in the middle of June."
## [1] " Yeah. Heat. Us being poor and hot at the recording of this podcast is not as fun as us being slightly richer and sweltering hot."
## [1] " Well, not that it’s hot, I kind of wanna … We did that … Remember we did that episode where we took stock of our experience so far? I feel like this is another good time to take stock. Let’s wait and do that in a bit."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " ’Cause I wanna do a little bit of … Every time there’s a scam that I hear about, I don’t wanna talk too much more about scams, but this one is so good that we have to talk about it. I think we may have gotten the ultimate scam coin unfolding story this week."
## [1] " I think that this scam, at the very least is directly in the intersection of all of our interests."
## [1] " And I also would say, it’s amazing to me how much of the crypto news, the first time I’ll hear about a coin is as it goes down in flames."
## [1] " Why else would you hear about it?"
## [1] " What I mean, it’s like, they’re like, what kind of alt coins are you into? I’m gonna be like, “Privacy coins and coins that are in meshed in a horrific scandal that I can read about in real time.”"
## [1] " What presentative coins do you think that you know about are from stories about how they’ve been revealed as scams?"
## [1] " I would say 50% of the alt coins that I know about."
## [1] " Yeah, I think so too."
## [1] " At least have had their image tarnished at least once."
## [1] " I would say I know much more about the scam coins than I know about the coins that I’ve invested in."
## [1] " Oh yeah. I’m like, I could talk for like an hour about Bit Connect, and if you were like, Project Aragon, I was like, I don’t know, somebody respectable said that word once on a basement tape."
## [1] " Same. Same. It’s like when I was heavily invested in Zero X and you’re like, what is Zero X? And you’re like, “It seems to be platform of platforms something, something. ERC 20.” Any scam I’d be like sit down."
## [1] " Yeah. I didn’t mu familiar with Skycoin?"
## [1] " I am familiar with Skynet."
## [1] " Skynet. I feel like you’re already playing with fire, any kind of the sky name. I was not previously familiar with Skycoin and this one of these stories that’s all like posted as a giant image that’s cut up of different Telegrams. I think this whole thing happened more or less on Telegram. There was some echos here of the Sumocoin collapse, although I would say this one is more hilarious."
## [1] " They say, Skycoin staff were alerted to large coin balances that were being dumped and driving down the price. We investigated and found the stolen coins originated from the distribution wallets traced the stolen coins to the Chinese marketing team."
## [1] " The first thing that catches your eye here is Chinese marketing team."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Now, this is how a lot of these ICO alt coins projects start up. They have an initial coin allotment for the development and another initial coin allotment for marketing."
## [1] " I don’t really have any insight into what these marketing teams are doing. Do you?"
## [1] " I think they send out a lot of emails."
## [1] " They’re probably emailing us. ’Cause we get a lot of broken English, we wanna talk about our ICO on your show emails and someone has to be getting paid to send those."
## [1] " Yeah, and there’s a lot of, “Would you like to meet the founder of Xcoin,” which neither of us has ever heard of. There’s no explanation outside of that. It does feel like … This is something that everyone who’s in crypto has said, the volume of emails that you get from being in crypto is insane. Even when I was doing … running a tech blog for the New Yorker, I probably get 15 emails a day from PR people."
## [1] " Crypto is almost more than that. You and I have a podcast about crypto. It’s not like the New Yorker."
## [1] " I’ll say this in terms of things that I don’t really like. Some of the money I invest in a software project being used to spam people by Chinese marketers, it doesn’t seem like a good use of funds, if you are actually doing something."
## [1] " If you’re not actually planning to do anything and you’re just trying to get coins to pump them up, maybe the Chinese marketing thing’s not a terrible idea."
## [1] " It seems like a very good idea actually."
## [1] " Okay. Jay’s in favor of it."
## [1] " No, no. I’m not in favor of it from an ethical stand point. I’m in favor of it if your project is fake and all you wanna do is con some people into buying it. Then a Chinese marketing team doesn’t really seem like that bad of an idea."
## [1] " Okay, so it feels like at this point of the story, it’s fair to say, what is Skycoin?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " I’m just gonna read you the one paragraph description. The Skycoin platform is the most advanced blockchain in the world. Should’ve read that in Trump voice."
## [1] " Developed by early contributors to both Bitcoin and Ethereum, Skycoin’s platform is completely secure, infinitely scalable in ISP, independent, backed by bandwidth, storage, and computational power. Skycoin is built to fulfill Satoshi’s original vision."
## [1] " I think you can take pretty much any clause in that entire paragraph and move it to a different sentence without changing the meaning."
## [1] " Yeah. I do like the word contributors to the original Bitcoin and Ethereum project. I wonder what their threshold for that was."
## [1] " Basically, it’s the most generic blockchain project in the world."
## [1] " But also the best."
## [1] " Yeah. It’s also the best and it’s the most generic. They claim that the Chinese marketing team was taking more money than they were supposed to and they also claimed that some of the coins that were supposed to go as employee bonuses to the Chinese marketing team were being held by management."
## [1] " Not only were they claiming that the Chinese Marketing team somehow defrauded them, they claim they were also not giving their employees money they were supposed to get."
## [1] " Can I just deposit here, I do not know the outcome of this story, you are telling it to me for the first time."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I’m very suspicious that these employees exist."
## [1] " I am also suspicious these employees exist. One of the things that the Skycoin team accused them of is invoice fraud, which I don’t know if that’s a technical accounting term or what."
## [1] " We should telling people who email us asking for sponsorships on the show that we have a 12 person team that we have to pay for."
## [1] " The Chinese marketing’s team response to these accusations of invoice fraud is maybe the greatest sentence I’ve come across in crypto and potentially what we should change the tagline of this show to."
## [1] " When you eat at the restaurant and you order vegetables, you do not ask how much the restaurant paid for the vegetables."
## [1] " Wow. Wow."
## [1] " Kind of deep."
## [1] " Yeah it is true."
## [1] " It’s true."
## [1] " I’ve never done that have you?"
## [1] " No. And they’re like, “Hey, you want some Chinese marketing? Give us the coin wallet. We’ll underpay our employees as we see fit.”"
## [1] " In order to stop the Chinese marketing team from profiteering from invoice fraud, they immediately went to a hard fork to freeze the coins that they had."
## [1] " This is-"
## [1] " So it’s kind of like the DAO Ethereum thing?"
## [1] " It’s like a very shitty, tiny, petty, version of the Ethereum DAO hack. Although, they’re only talking about 100,000 coin. It’s not like it would’ve crippled the project. This is a deep spite move."
## [1] " It seems that they … I don’t know what the phrase is, but they cut off their nose to spite their face."
## [1] " Well, I feel like this is one of the overall asterisks on all of these claims of being the best blockchain in the world and the most decentralized ever. Until the people immediately do a hard fork because they are in a dispute with their Chinese marketing team. You know?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Who may or may not even exist."
## [1] " Yeah, it’s very hard to explain to your investors."
## [1] " Actually, the way that I originally came across this, was someone said on Reddit, “I’m in the Skycoin Telegram and something seems to be happening with a few of the members, including one of the main guys Synth, and another founder admin on the project. I’m not sure if their fake mad at each other, but someone is dumping Skycoin, and I have suspicions it may be the Div team and they’re being fake mad at each other."
## [1] " Members of the team are having arguments on Telegram and even throwing words calling each other autistic."
## [1] " Okay. Is Skycoin on an exchange?"
## [1] " That’s a good question. I think it is, yeah. Let’s see. Hold on one sec."
## [1] " I have one guess to which exchange it’s on. And it ends in topia."
## [1] " I mean, it’s definitely on some exchange, as you’re about to see in the story. They start getting involved in trying to manipulate the trading of it, fairly up … Oh wow, it’s down another 15% since I was prepping for the show an hour ago."
## [1] " Okay, that undercuts one of the points I’m gonna bring up in a second. Let’s see. Okay. It’s on two exchanges. You’re already correct on one out of two."
## [1] " Cryptopia."
## [1] " Yes. Guess what the other one is."
## [1] " I’m gonna go with that one that I signed up with that I can’t remember the name of."
## [1] " It’s biggest volume. On Cryptopia its 24 hour volume is only $189,000. But it did about 10 million dollars in volume on Binance."
## [1] " Oh, it’s on Binance."
## [1] " It’s on Binance. I think Binance is embracing a high low strategy of we could make the most money if we let people trade everything. Do you see how much money Binance has been making?"
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah."
## [1] " A lot. They’re making more money than Deutsche Bank."
## [1] " Yeah. No, no, no, no. Also, it’s like for people so … CZ is rich as hell."
## [1] " Synth, which I believe is the same person as Steve, he’s referred to alternately as Synth and Steve. After Steve froze the coins, nine people and five gang members showed up to my home and kidnapped and threatened me."
## [1] " They asked for 10,000 Bitcoin."
## [1] " Who is saying this?"
## [1] " This is the guy who’s like the Skycoin guy."
## [1] " Synth."
## [1] " Synth. So he says that nine people and five gang members, I don’t know if the gang members are the same people as the nine people, are they included?"
## [1] " It’s either 14 or nine showed up to his house."
## [1] " Nine to 14 people, some of whom were gang members showed up at his house and kidnapped, threatened him, and asked for 10,000 Bitcoin."
## [1] " Now, I’d like to say-"
## [1] " 10,000 Bitcoin?"
## [1] " Even in this extremely depressed market that we’re currently in, that is 65 million dollars."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Who has 65 million dollars just waiting to transfer if they’re getting … Who would break in and really thing they were gonna get 10,000 Bitcoin?"
## [1] " Does Synth really have 10,000 Bitcoin?"
## [1] " There’s actually a different account for this on the Skycoin website. Says, “At 9:30 PM on June 13th, nine individuals including and led by marketing team members Samsung, Fong, Mary Lee, Shong Dong Yan, and Jesse San Fe burglarized Synth’s home. They proceeded to hold Synth and his wife against their will for six hours over the course of which they threatened, beaten, robbed them. Thanks to wallet’s security measures, the group was only able to extract 18 Bitcoin and 6500 Skycoins. This gang also attempted and failed to steal the design framework for the Skycoin ecosystem.”"
## [1] " Okay, so this is clearly written by someone who’s seen some movies. Seen some Hong Kong action movies. The idea that someone broke into someone’s house to get the designs for Skycoin."
## [1] " Where are they? Where’s the flash drive?"
## [1] " Give me the Skycoin designs."
## [1] " Where’s the flash drive?"
## [1] " Yeah, and he’s like … Now, I’ll say, our apologies to the entire Skycoin team if this guy really was kidnapped and beaten."
## [1] " Yeah, you know what, I’m gonna just say that I feel like there’s very small amount of chance that we’re going to have to actually issue that apology, but yes."
## [1] " So Steve says, “After the kidnapping, we released the coins until all of the … And this is a hilarious misspelling. “Until all these Skycon employees were safe.” Always a problem if you’re typing coin stuff quickly, you may have a few cons in your own explanation."
## [1] " It might just be auto complete because they call it Skycon amongst themselves."
## [1] " They did a hard fork, froze the coins, then some Triad members showed up and as a result they had to unfreeze the coins until all of their team members, who may or may not exist, were safe. At which point they say the thieves started massively dumping the coin."
## [1] " I’ll say the crazy part of this story hasn’t even happened yet."
## [1] " Okay. So we have a kidnapping alleged."
## [1] " Now he’s safe. Synth is safe. He says, “Everyone’s safe now. We actually did pretty well on the market too. Even during the dump we had an early investor sell 100,000 coin and the price did not drop.”"
## [1] " This is the first person who immediately after being released by Triad members has been like, “And the coin’s doing pretty well.”"
## [1] " He’s just looking after investor confidence."
## [1] " Okay. He says, “Since they are dumping the stolen coins and we can’t stop them, we informed all the investors to completely pull out all price support. If we can buy back the stolen coins at five dollars, it would be even better. Then once they are done dumping, we will bounce it back again."
## [1] " Yeah. Okay."
## [1] " This is a wild thing to do is tell everyone to sell their coins so that they can get back the stolen coins and that they will just be able to inflate the price back to its original level. I mean, to say that there’s manipulation happening on the price here is to not even to begin to get into it."
## [1] " No. I mean, what he has essentially described is an incredible Ponzi scheme."
## [1] " This is similar to what happened in Sumocoin, although there was no Triad members, I don’t think."
## [1] " Wait, they were trying to reBuy all the Sumocoin?"
## [1] " No, no. I’m just saying this whole affair."
## [1] " Oh."
## [1] " They kind of faked people element. The money reserved for the development … It seems like a common … We can agree, you and I can agree, that of all the alt coins, at least 90% are totally bogus."
## [1] " Yeah, I’d go a little higher."
## [1] " Probably higher. We were talking about this with a friend who’ll remain nameless because of his job and we were all positing what percentage we thought."
## [1] " He was like, “Well, depends where you draw the scam line.” He said, “There’s people who are just outright scammers and there are well meaning but incompetent people trying to do things that they couldn’t possibly pull off.”"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " If we just draw the line at outright scammers, I still think we’re talking about 90%."
## [1] " We’re above 90."
## [1] " Above 90%. Okay. That is how most … Once we know that. Once we know that most of these actors are acting in bad faith, how do they act in bad faith, it seems like these allotments of coins that are reserved for the team are the place where you start really getting into some funny business."
## [1] " Yeah, because there’s no … They just printed money, essentially. All they need is a slight bounce and they can do whatever they want with their fake printed money."
## [1] " It seems like when you have in your tool kit freezing coins, hard forks, fake kidnappings, telling all the original investors to dump their coins, and that you can bounce the price back after that, you’ve got a lot of tools at your disposal."
## [1] " If you can do things that are on page one of any sort of market or SCC guideline that says, “You can not do this,” or, “Maybe we’ll just get rid of page one ’cause it’s so obvious this is illegal.” The fact that you can post about it, “Hey, let’s do this.” That is an incredible tool."
## [1] " I think the fact that you can do all that stuff in a 48 hour period suggests that decentralization is mostly in name. I don’t think this reflects on the entire Bitcoin world, but at the bottom, in the shit, and what we’re seeing is even most of the coins on Binance are in the shit."
## [1] " Yeah. I do wonder how a place like Binance will eventually respond to this because it seems like more and more of these things are getting exposed, mostly because I think … Well, I think it’s two reasons. The first is that obviously members of the media are interested in scams, but also, I think a lot of it just sort of self policing at this point that people are waking up and are starting to say, “Hey, we need to get rid of some of this stuff.”"
## [1] " Anything that seems scammy is immediately surface, whereas before, I think that might’ve been suppressed even."
## [1] " I think that maybe the people who were doing the initial ones were better at it, and now we’re seeing such growth in scammy coins that we’re seeing people that don’t really have their shit together and are like, “Okay, my first idea here is, I’ll fake a kidnapping.”"
## [1] " Okay, counterpoint though. Right."
## [1] " Counterpoint. Maybe the kidnapping was real."
## [1] " No, no, no. My counterpoint is that I’m not sure that if you are trying to cycle through as many of these as you can."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So let’s say you’re trying to give yourself 50 shots to have a scam pull off."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " What is the point of doing it well? It seems to have no correlation with whether or not the thing is real or not. I mean, not to bring this up, but, Sumocoin, for example, one I was invested in quite heavily."
## [1] " I have some good news for you Jay."
## [1] " What is it?"
## [1] " I’ll let you finish."
## [1] " You might as well do as many bad scams as possible, because it doesn’t seem like the goodness of the scam really matters."
## [1] " I think that’s right. It always tricked me out that the Nigerian scam was so hand fisted. Oh, get more creative. Different country. Different story. Just give me something. Give me some narrative. If you’re actually looking for people who will fall for an extremely simple scam, you might as well have it be pretty dumb and simple."
## [1] " You might as well use the same cookie cutter website that the Skycoin project has. You might as well make it recognizable to people so that it looks like every other ICO when it goes down in flames like every other ICO."
## [1] " The craziest part to me of all this stuff is not that it’s happening, which is pretty wild, but that the market, which, we keep ascribing these magical qualities to the market. Oh, the price already includes all this and that."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah, yeah."
## [1] " The news I was gonna give you was the Sumocoin’s back."
## [1] " How back?"
## [1] " It’s trading on Trade Ogre. And, I think it’ll-"
## [1] " What is Trade Ogre?"
## [1] " It’s sub Cryptopia."
## [1] " Do you have an account?"
## [1] " Oh yeah. It bounced back after … not all the way back. But it has experienced up motion and even Skycoin, it’s still trading higher right now than it was in like October 2017."
## [1] " Mm-hmm (affirmative)."
## [1] " It seems like a lot of these things are almost scam exposure proof. The market’s basically just as interested in them pre or post scam."
## [1] " Do you think that the people who are investing in it don’t know about the scam? Or do you think they’re bots trading that just trade things regardless of whether or not they’re scams or not?"
## [1] " I think it’s people who see a coin that’s going down in flames as a potentially good trading opportunity."
## [1] " Well, that’s what I think the bots might come in."
## [1] " I think that’s people also. What I’ve seen the Sumocoin and the Skycoin, Telegrams, and Reddits is, “Yeah, but if we survive this, this could be a great entry opportunity.”"
## [1] " So they bought into Steven’s … they bought into his gas bowl. Let’s just crash this thing and revive."
## [1] " I mean, I’ll say, that when Sumocoin reopened, at I think 35 cents, I was like, “Good for you, bye.”"
## [1] " Did you buy?"
## [1] " I did not buy ’cause I didn’t want to transfer any Bitcoin to Trade Ogre. If I had had the chance to buy on Cryptopia, I would’ve been tempted."
## [1] " Trade Ogre, by the way, is a great name."
## [1] " Fantastic name."
## [1] " It’s a very good name."
## [1] " Where does this leave us all? Should we even be talking about this kind of stuff? Does this have anything to do with Bitcoin?"
## [1] " Well, we are an entertainment podcast, so I would say that I find all these scams to be wildly entertaining."
## [1] " I do too."
## [1] " I think that anything involving the Triads and a fake coin and the demand for 10,000 Bitcoin and then they only … it’s all just very funny and I think that at this point, crypto is 60% memes and I find all those memes funny. I don’t mind talking about it."
## [1] " Obviously, we’re not protecting crypto in any sort of way."
## [1] " No. Definitely not."
## [1] " I don’t feel bad about it. I don’t know. I think that things like Bit Cointopia, things that we see that we think are funny, we should just continue to talk about it."
## [1] " I don’t feel bad. Don’t get me wrong. I don’t feel bad."
## [1] " I was like, what are you doing?"
## [1] " I feel bad that I bought Sumocoin, but not bad in the way that you’re talking about."
## [1] " I guess I mean, when people are talking about American politics."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " You take like a fringe candidate like LaRouche, do you remember LaRouche?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " He was like a guy, he would always get UC Berkeley College campus, there’d always be somebody pamphleting for him. He ran for president while he was in federal prison in the 90s."
## [1] " What was his platform?"
## [1] " I don’t remember. He was kind of like … it was a little pressy and it was like kind of uniting the far right and left. But in an earlier generation."
## [1] " This is like the Jax Liberty Coin."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly. Actually, I have no idea LaRouche’s political platform is. That might be totally wrong. Anyway, it wouldn’t be like, “Oh, the state of American politics is in disarray, look at LaRouche.” I feel like the Sumocoins and the Skycoins are the LaRouches of crypto."
## [1] " Oh, I get what you’re saying."
## [1] " Like maybe it’s just so low that it’s like, come on. Are we even gonna talk about this in the same breath?"
## [1] " Yes, but I would say that when you look at market caps for these coins and you look at the combined Shitcoin market cap, you can’t really ignore it. I mean, if you look at the … what we always talk about is these behavioral waves that happen in Crypto. The last behavioral wave is when people are pumping stuff like Tron."
## [1] " Sure. And Theos is still worth what, the number five cap coin?"
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. Or when Dentacoin was pumping."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " That’s part of crypto. And it wasn’t a fringe part. It’s like-"
## [1] " It’s a Kodak point of fans clap back at us last week."
## [1] " No way, really?"
## [1] " Oh yeah, they were like, “It’s a very promising ecosystem for photo rights management on the web.”"

## [1] " Well, okay. That’s something I want to talk about today, which was that there seems to be a Twitter war going on."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " Where the Bitcoin maximalists are coming out and sort of saying … they’re staking their ground and then they’re saying, “We’ve been putting up with you Shitcoiners for long enough. We’ve had it. Bitcoin is the only true crypto currency. Everything else is a Shitcoin. Everything else is a distraction from the goal of returning the world … not returning the world. Putting the world on a Bitcoin standard where crypto currency is the only true currency.”"
## [1] " And that, every single one of these scams makes us look bad. They’re stupid. They’re not philosophically based. They’re not technologically or economically sound. And that we need to just get rid of all of them if we have any shot at this because right now, nobody takes us seriously. Nobody is really thinking about the actual issues because everybody is caught up in these sorts of scams."
## [1] " Which are, you know."
## [1] " And in thinking of this as a media war, not a technology war, and I think one of the big developments of the last year in the world is realizing all of these things, technology, politics are all now media, mostly social media wars. I think they’re kind of right. I think these Bitcoin Maximalists are like, we’re not gonna have another big bullion until we start getting some positive news coverage, or at least something where people write about our big vision instead of some guys in Switzerland who said they were gonna put mining equipment in shipping containers, moving around where electricity is cheap."
## [1] " These are better narratives. They’re more fun. They’re what we talk about on the show. But they’re not gonna make you buy Bitcoin."
## [1] " Oh yeah, for sure. And look, I sympathize with them a lot despite not agreeing with their politics. I do think they’re fundamentally right in the sense that Bitcoin and crypto really has one shot. This is something that you said a lot, which is that the provocative idea in crypto is not a world of de-apps that kind of feel like the apps on our phone. It’s whether or not Bitcoin is real currency."
## [1] " For these guys, the better story is definitely whether you agree with it or not that Austrian School economics is good, that Thea currency destroyed the world, and that we need to get back to some sort of thing that keeps value constant so that people can understand what money is and what value is and they can base their work and their labor on that. That’s a reasonable argument to make in these times especially."
## [1] " They feel like that message can’t get out there because it is enveloped in this electron cloud of shit. I don’t disagree with them."
## [1] " That’s a noble read. And I applaud you for taking the noble side of Bitcoin for once. But, I think the part that that ignores is greed. Greed, it essentially [crosstalk 00:28:23] quality."
## [1] " No, but … But that’s me saying … that’s me saying, that they would say greed is good. They’re Gordon Gekko. I would argue that that’s part of their ideology and that actually is … There are a lot of people in the world who also agree that greed is good."
## [1] " But, you can’t say greed is good, but no Skycoiners. Those Skycoiners staged a fake kidnapping to further their greed. They told people to dump so that they could re pump because of greed."
## [1] " No, no, no. It does feel … I agree that it does, the thing that is annoying about this is that they’re kind of like, only free market Austrian School economics for us, you know, and not for you."
## [1] " You want the Bitcoin baby, you’re gonna take the Shitcoin bathwater with it. People don’t discriminate within greed. Why be noblely greedy and try and build something great that satisfies your greed when it’s easier to be shitty in short term greedy."
## [1] " For Bitcoin to work, I think people need to be a little more longterm greedy and these Shitcoins are examples of extremely short time frame greed. An example I saw on the news this week is, probably the biggest Bitcoin store since we’ve last hung."

## [1] " I agree with you a little bit in the sense of like, you know how in the NBA playoffs there’s like extreme regency bias."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Someone has a really … a team has a really bad game and their overall chance of winning the finals psychologically can swing really far."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " That doesn’t really make sense. It’s irrational. There’s a lot of variance, let’s say especially in a three point heavy game. I think the Bitcoin bull rush bearishness has a real recency bias where no one wants to buy right after it went down and everyone wants to buy right after it went up, which is exactly the opposite of how math should work in this situation."
## [1] " Yeah, it’s the Coin Talk investment strategy."
## [1] " Yeah. It’s the buy high sell low strategy. It’s very real. We know that Bitcoin buyers and Bitcoin markets are immature and some may say inexperienced. I think that could be real that we’re waiting for one piece of, one run and that that could set off a mega run. I could believe that hypothesis."
## [1] " But, we’ve always said that if there is a true breakdown, the go to zero breakdown, that it would start with exchanges."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I’m as negative as I’ve been in a long time about crypto. I don’t know exactly why. I’m trying to unpack where I lost the faith, where my belief in god went away. And, I think my central feeling is, I’m blown away by the elegance and the incredible foresight of the Satoshi system, but it feels like the biggest flaw in that system right now is that it still has to run through exchanges and even that one crucial link, it’s totally decentralized, people are running nodes or whatever."
## [1] " The fact that people need exchanges means you can’t really believe anything. You can’t really know what’s going on, because all of it is behind the Wizard of Oz curtain. Behind that curtain is CZ from Binance and everyone who runs an exchange and everyone who can really change the price based on their own software and we would have no insight into what’s going on."
## [1] " Okay. I have a question for you then."
## [1] " Not to call out CZ personally. I don’t have any belief that Binance is better or worse than anyone."
## [1] " We’re fans of CZ."
## [1] " But the whole exchange system has an immense power to make you believe the price is X. Now, that has been shaken. I don’t believe that the price was ever $19,000."
## [1] " Oh no. Question for you then. Let’s say that somebody very trustworthy who has been in the Bitcoin space forever, so like Adam Back or something like that."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " Or even Sabo."
## [1] " Sure. Way Di."
## [1] " Creates a decentralized exchange and the only thing that it sells is Bitcoin. Do you think that that’s possible solution?"
## [1] " I think truly functional decentralized exchanges would be the most bullish thing that could happen for Bitcoin right now."
## [1] " Why do you think that those have not? There are decentralized exchange projects right?"
## [1] " I think that they’re not quite there yet."
## [1] " Okay, but what about this idea that it would only sell Bitcoin?"
## [1] " I think that’s an interesting idea. And, I can see the value of it. I also think Atomic swaps are an interesting idea. Atomic swaps have similarities to decentralized exchanges. They allow you to make a transaction without some sort of a middle man. But, I think that there’s a big problem and we’re seeing this a little bit in Eos right now."
## [1] " Eos has this whole voting system where you have to vote with your private keys. But no one’s got their private keys ’cause everyone’s keys are in custodial accounts."
## [1] " Yeah, they’re all in exchanges. Yeah."
## [1] " I don’t know if custodial accounts and decentralized exchanges can really exist in the same space. Additionally, you still need a fiat on road. The decentralized exchanges doesn’t solve how do you buy Bitcoin in the first place."
## [1] " Well, it would be direct peer to peer money transfers."
## [1] " But how do you peer to peer transfer fiat for Bitcoin in a decentralized manner? Who’s taking the fiat?"
## [1] " The person who’s selling you the Bitcoin?"
## [1] " Well, then you’re having decentralized fiat swaps without knowing …"
## [1] " Well, how else would it work? You think that it would only work with Bitcoin?"
## [1] " I think that the first decentralized exchanges are gonna be for token token swaps. I think the ones that you’re talking about now, if you’re asking why are we not already there yet, they’re already decentralized exchanges? There’s not decentralized exchanges that allow for fiat trading. As far as I know."
## [1] " This is where I think that really just talking this through with you that I’ve … I think that the maximists are basically right then. I agree with you that exchanges … that we have not had a catastrophic exchange event yet, which is shocking."
## [1] " Or at least since Mount Ox."
## [1] " Exactly, since Ox. If there is another Ox, then we’re fucked."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " In that given the amount of fraud amongst, and again, I’m not trying to call out Trade Ogre … what is it called?"
## [1] " Trade Ogre, yeah."
## [1] " Trade Ogre or anything like that, but all these new exchanges are popping up. The chances that one of them are completely fraudulent is very high, right?"
## [1] " Yes. Although I’ll say this. I think there won’t be another Ox because it’s so profitable to actually run an exchange now. It’s not worth defrauding people."
## [1] " Well, but you don’t know. That is assuming that everyone is a rational actor in here, right? When somebody says, “Hold your own keys, Bitcoin is the only thing,” it’s kind of a compelling argument I think at this point, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " We just had now, a year of shit? You and I have both been … it’s been over a year I think."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " And, we just have … It’s just been an explosion of Shitcoins, explosion of exchanges. And none of it seems to be moving towards a product. I think that at some point you just have to kind of scale back and be like, “Why am I in this?” I think for me, and I think also for you, it is no longer about getting rich quickly, which is what sort of …"
## [1] " We sort of just-"
## [1] " We’ve gotten poor slowly."
## [1] " We’ve gotten poor slowly is right. Very, very slowly, but we have learned a lot. If it’s not about getting rich quickly, then what it’s about, it’s about eventually holding something that you feel like could be a integral part of future economics, right, then you should just hold your own keys and you should just have Bitcoin."
## [1] " Yeah, but there’s all sorts of shoulds in the world. Generally in my interest in user experience, you can’t say should. Yeah, you should encrypt your email, you should use PGP technology."
## [1] " No, no, no. I’m just talking about a personal choice."
## [1] " You shouldn’t be on Facebook."
## [1] " I’m talking about a personal choice."
## [1] " But I think the problem is, if enough consumers take the easy route, then this utopian future can exist."
## [1] " The last time we were talking where it was going, I thought it was going more in the coin base direction, which is a mega Silicon Valley backed custodial everything. That is one eventuality. But that gets you very deep into the manipulation territory."
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah."
## [1] " Where there’s a central player who really can control the market and at least the first generation of central players who can control the market, the Bitfinex, the Ox’s have been short term greedy and fucked up a lot. I do believe until we reach that decentralized exchange state, I’m not really gonna believe the price as much. Not believing the price, makes me not wanna buy."
## [1] " I know, but I don’t understand what that has to do with this idea that as a personal choice that one should … if one believes in crypto, that they should just hold their own personal keys."
## [1] " People can’t figure out how to use passwords either."
## [1] " But I’m just talking about if you should know how to use a … keep your own keys if you really believe in crypto."
## [1] " I guess what I’m saying is, even if hold my own keys, if I don’t believe that the mass of crypto users are gonna hold their keys, it doesn’t help me that much that I’m holding my keys."
## [1] " I think it does."
## [1] " Not if the price is being massively manipulated and centralized custodial accounts."
## [1] " Yeah, but it does in the sense that you are then free from [crosstalk 00:55:25]."
## [1] " If you’re entirely price agnostic, and I will say-"
## [1] " But that’s what my argument is, I feel like at this point when we have no idea what the price is because of all this manipulation, that one … and look, some of our friends who are super into crypto are like this and I think that they’re ultimately right."
## [1] " Yeah. At least they claim to be."
## [1] " They claim to be, yes. I think that one should be price agnostic right now."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " You shouldn’t buy at this level, but you should just hold."
## [1] " My feeling is, let me ask you a question. When we started taping the basement tapes, I think Bitcoin was like 4000ish."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " If Bitcoin was where it is now, 6500, that’s not actually a bad return."
## [1] " 50%."
## [1] " Yeah, 50% in a year. Beat mutual funds."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Would it be healthier if we had slowly crawled to 6500 versus speeding to 19,000 and then running the whole way back down?"
## [1] " I don’t know, maybe. Again, I think that goes into the question of, that the hype cycle did help in terms of converting a lot of people at once and that a lot of those people now are really mad at Bitcoin, but I think that more people are still happy about Bitcoin, are still believe in Bitcoin than would happen if we had slowly climbed here."
## [1] " I think I think we runed some of that good first wave, although, look, many waves have been runed, the Oxers were runed, Bitcoin has bounced back before. That’s why I’m still in because I do believe it can and will rebound."
## [1] " Also, you can’t sell right now."
## [1] " I don’t wanna sell right now. But, I will say, I’m as skeptical and negative as I’ve ever been, and I have had angry, swirling, dark visions that we all got scammed. The only people who really … The people who succeeded here are all the short term greedy people. They have the right strategy."
## [1] " Yeah, that’s what I’m saying, Steve is right."
## [1] " The people who ran exchanges-"
## [1] " Steve and Skycoin were right. They’re just like, they actually saw it for what it was. You know?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I feel like if you look at this landscape and you say, okay, we have a completely open market, there are no regulations, how can I most profit off of it? That probably was the right mentality. I think that’s why these Bitcoiners, these maximists are so mad because they feel like something was destroyed and that they got jacked and I think that they can’t really come to terms with is the reason why it got jacked was because of their underlying philosophy about all of this."
## [1] " Yeah, I mean. Look, if you believe it was a jacking, basically what happened is, people came along and sold people increasing amounts of Tether in exchange for US dollars that were traded for Bitcoin at like $15,000 and then that popped and like all that it took to do it was just a bunch of Tether."
## [1] " You can trade Shitcoins and double your Bitcoin or whatever. The real winners here are the people who are running the casinos. Those are also the people who are really in control. I don’t know if you’re ever gonna wrestle control back from them after they centralize this much power."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " That’s the other thing about these decentralized exchanges. Decentralized exchanges are not gonna be happy about them."
## [1] " Yeah, and I don’t understand … they hold so much … they hold everyone’s Bitcoin and Shitcoin. How do you leak that out to those places? It’s difficult."
## [1] " The value to me of that Silicon Valley coin that is not Ripple that you describe, would in some ways be a reset."
## [1] " That’s what I think we need. That’s why I think the reset, given the both … the concentration of Bitcoin in the hands of smaller people, which makes the vision for hyper Bitcoinization terrifying. Just all the problems that we have right now."
## [1] " I think that we kind of need it, something that people can believe in. I’m not sure if you can really dust these two things off. I think you could with Bitcoin, but I think it would just take a long time."
## [1] " Yeah. I think Bitcoin is almost like a country or like a fiat currency. It’s like, it’s been through some shit. Has some dents in it. Some murders were ordered, but we’re moving on now."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Well, I’ll leave you with one parting note."
## [1] " What."
## [1] " Just me and you have long tried to get our own coin, Kanecoin. It’s gone by many names, and as people know, I made a bet to take over control over the Sumocoin project in its darkest hour, I was rejected. It would be a lot of fun to run one of these game plans ourself."
## [1] " I think that we actually should just do Kanecoin."
## [1] " Can you imagine the Telegram channel where I’m like, Jay has been kidnapped. The Triad has gotten him. They want 10,000 Bitcoin. And, then people are like, “They’re faking. They’re fake mad at each other.”"
## [1] " I’d be like, no, I’m really mad at Jay. We hire our Chinese marketing team."
## [1] " I’ll just be the Chinese marketing team. A fake Chinese … We could have like 50 employees that don’t exist."
## [1] " Yeah. I mean, we’re gonna be deep in Chinese money laundering, that’s one … I also feel like instead of just advertising all the same generic stuff, our coin would just advertise all of the actual applications of these coins."
## [1] " We’ll see you next time."
## [1] " All right. Bye."
## Joining, by = "word"

## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron: Welcome, Saifedean Ammous."
## [1] "Aaron: I always like to ask people who are deep into Bitcoin what their initial experiences were like. When did you first come across Bitcoin?"
## [1] "Aaron: For our listeners who might not be aware of why that was an obvious connection, can you explain why there was such an interest in the, I guess, Mises School or the Austrian School of Economics people in Bitcoin at that time?"
## [1] "Aaron: As a academic economist yourself, are you hearing about all kinds of different schemes that try to improve upon money? Is it common to have something like Bitcoin that’s a new idea come along?"
## [1] "Aaron: Sure."
## [1] " What happened, like, around 2013 that got you taking it more seriously because, you know, the white paper already existed. I think that some peoples affiliation with the types of economics that you prefer had already been stated, you know, like, that there had already been this connection, so, what happened where you were like, “Wow, this is something I should take seriously.”"
## [1] "Aaron: Sure."
## [1] " I was about to say Rubini."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah, something we’ve talked about on the show has been that, I was of the same belief that you, that Dark Net markets would ultimately discredit Bitcoin, but looking back over that history, it almost seems like Dark Net markets are just ahead of the curve in technology, which I guess would lead you, at this point, to be interested in projects like Monero that have replaced Bitcoin on the Dark Web. As an economic historian, why do you think there wasn’t that kind of a crackdown where people got thrown in Guantanamo? Do you think that was a conscious decision of government?"
## [1] " One thing I was struck by while reading your book was that the first half seems to be a lot of argument in favor of the gold standard. So, for example, you talk about how World War I was accelerated and I think in some ways, I think you would argue, caused by the fact that governments just started funding money to fund this endless war, and that the gold standard was better. Can you just talk about when you started to think that perhaps Bitcoin was an alternative to gold or why it would be a better version of gold?"
## [1] "Aaron: Particularly difficult during wars, to move a bunch of gold."
## [1] "Aaron: You wrote something in the book that captured my imagination, which is, you said that, “If you’re writing a book about gold, you wouldn’t feel need to explain its chemical properties in order to explain gold.” And, I think the analogy carries out that perhaps not everyone needs to know about the deep, inter workings of the Bitcoin system, but there’s definitely a big part of the Bitcoin culture, which suggests that people should hold their own keys, people should understand the technical stuff."
## [1] " This is a question that Aaron and I talk about quite a bit, which is that, like, you lay out a pretty compelling vision of how this could go forward and what the future might look like, and the one thing that I keep tripping up on is the fact that, you know, the way that Bitcoin is distributed right now is that small numbers of people hold large, large amounts of Bitcoin and that I don’t see them sort of relinquishing that percentage of what is a deflation area of currency, which if Bitcoin does become the standard of all currency, means that we have a sort of super rich, super wealthy, almost like Demi-Gods-"
## [1] "Aaron: Feudal lords."
## [1] " In the economy. Is that something that concerns you, as well, about Bitcoin going forward? The fact that like, what you have is not … you have somebody who-"
## [1] "Aaron: Bitcoin going forward and the fact that what you have is not … you have somebody who would be approximately a thousand times wealthier than Jeff Bezos and you would have maybe five to 10 of them and that they would inevitably have a large amount of power in the world."
## [1] "Aaron: Are we talking about Roger Ver right now?"
## [1] "Aaron: Let’s just say that Winklevoss twins, for example, they are not a group that is starting a bunch of other Shitcoins or encouraging forks and slowly bleeding Bitcoin back into the economy. So much of what you write about that I find compelling personally, just because my own politics about individual sovereignty and a new sense of freedom that could arise out of this, the part that I always get tripped up and we talk about Bitcoin philosophically, which is what interests me is that I am not sure in the world in which the Winklevoss twins essentially are a nation state upon themselves that, that would lead to more individual freedoms."
## [1] "Jay: So the example that you brought up in the book is that if you have a person who … you have two people who are fishing and one person builds a fishing pole and one person decides to fish by themselves and the person who spent the time to build the fishing pole eventually will build an economy around the ability that he is a bit able to pull out more fish and that will serve more people, right?"
## [1] "Aaron: It strikes me when I read your book that if we truly move to a Bitcoin standard, the whole idea of nations will change. And perhaps the idea of people identifying themselves nationally will change. What kinds of effects do you think that this shift will have on citizenship and how people perceive themselves around the globe?"
## [1] "Aaron: I was actually … I was going to ask you about rick kids because one of your analogies about a non-inflationary system is that people who act rationally within this system will accumulate wealth, say in the form of Bitcoin and that, that wealth will be passed across generations, which is a virtuous thing. And I sort of like the idea, but as someone who grew up amongst private school students with extremely rich parents, isn’t it a liability to do so? I didn’t find those people to be the best arbiters of the world when I encountered them in high school."
## [1] "Aaron: This is basically how monarchies fell, right? Monarchies you have one dud prince that’s the end of the monarchy."
## [1] "Aaron: You’re against certain forms of modern art. I get the feeling that you don’t particularly like most modern music. Is that correct? Without getting too personal."
## [1] "Aaron: So the part of that, that I’m sort of surprised by is, to me, that modern art is the ultimate manifestation of a free market, which is people are choosing to speculate wildly in paintings that most people find no basic aesthetic value in. And this is even true going back 500 years that during the Renaissance people were speculating on art. It was a way to curry favor with the pope was to commission art and to deal in art."
## [1] "Aaron: Please."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah."
## [1] "Aaron: My grandfather was the exact same way."
## [1] "Aaron: I’ll put a link in the show notes."
## [1] "Aaron: I see it in a totally different way because I love a lot of music that’s come out in the modern era in the Arab world, but I guess I would say that those art forms are sort of modeled on the culture of their time. So let’s say in the Renaissance you’re going to hear the early operas. That is the format of the time. Now, we live in the era of Bitcoin and the smartphone and it makes sense that music is more compressed and it’s more of a quick hit."
## [1] "Aaron: I agree the thing you’re describing exists, but I don’t think it invalidates the human artistic project that there’s a lot of crap art. There is good art that’s come out in the last 25 years, in my opinion. In some ways it feels to me like you’re describing a Shitcoin and saying, “See, it’s like that. It’s like Bitcoin.” I’m like, “No, no. It is not.” They have superficial similarities. They’re both four minute songs, but the whole spectrum is possible within it. And I want to ask you, actually, about that. That’s a good transition since I don’t want to argue with you about art forever."
## [1] "Aaron: My whole … the whole history of my computer use has been about software dying. And I can’t believe how quickly … if you told me people won’t be running DOS in 10 years … I’d be like, “What? That’s crazy! DOS is great!” Languages that have come and go. It’s file formats that have come and go. Everything is this massive, this entropy with a really short half-life. And so I’m wondering as someone whose lived through the same period of time, there’s a certain outlook, I guess it’s the Myspace outlook, that everything about technology is about to be replaced. Why is this not true of Bitcoin?"
## [1] "Aaron: Yes."
## [1] "Aaron: Making it anonymous, say would be like some people think that’s a hugely important feature that needs to be added."
## [1] "Aaron: Okay. Let me push back, though."
## [1] "Aaron: Right."
## [1] "Aaron: They gave people a discount on something that had no value to begin with, something. Yeah."
## [1] "Aaron: Taleb, who wrote the introduction to your book, said something that I’ve thought a lot about since. He said that Bitcoin has reached a sufficient state of maturity now that even if something happens and Bitcoin ceases to exist, we know how to make it. We’ll be able to remake it. It can’t be wiped from the face of the earth. So in some ways that it’s the idea that’s a Bitcoin, not necessarily this original chain that exists right now."
## [1] "Aaron: Interesting."
## [1] "Aaron: Right. They’re centralized by their own founders or their own leaders at least."
## [1] "Aaron: You’re in an interesting position because you’re a Bitcoin believer but you’re an altcoin skeptic, which in some ways makes your views similar to certain no-coiners, at least about the scammier end, let’s say of the ICO spectrum. All the way up to the sort of Ethereum level stuff. As an economist, why do you think Bitcoin and crypto in general has just … People like Roubini who you brought up, they almost seem more obsessed with it than the people who are believers. The critics are just as passionate, if not more passionate. Tell me what it’s like being an economist in this crypto world, and where you think the no-coining viewpoint comes from."
## [1] "Aaron: And that’s the end of the friendship?"
## [1] "Aaron: I’ll ask you my final question, which you naturally segued to perfectly. As someone who is not personally an Austrian school libertarian, it’s not how I see the world, I think it’s fascin … Bitcoin is great because it’s allowed me to see the world through this different prism that doesn’t come naturally to me. But I always want to believe that there is someway that these systems can harmoniously co-exist. When I read your book, which I found very convincing, it felt like central planning and Bitcoin standard are in a fight to the death and there can be no in between. One of them has to ultimately destroy the other. Is that your view? Is there any way for us to go to a partially deflationary system or this something that has to come to head and has to get resolved?"
## [1] "Aaron: That’s how I feel. People have asked me, if you don’t believe in this stuff, why are you buying Bitcoin? I was like, well, I don’t want to be poor after the free market takes it. Like, I still would act within self interest if this was the tsunami I saw coming even if I don’t necessarily want it to come."
## [1] "Aaron: It sounds like a fascinating but brutal future. Like I want to see the movie, but I’m not totally sure if I want to live it. Maybe like, I like your in the next couple hundred years-"
## [1] "Aaron: Thank you so much for this interview. It was great."

## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] " Welcome to Coin Talk. I’m here with my co-host, Jay Kang-"
## [1] " Hello."
## [1] " And a very, very special guest, Gideon Lewis-Kraus, live here in the crypto cave."
## [1] " Gideon, what do you think about the crypto cave?"
## [1] " Thank you. Thank you."
## [1] " You’re our first full-time guest."
## [1] " Yeah, that’s true."
## [1] " Usually we have the guest sit on a stool in the corner."
## [1] " Yeah, you’re-"
## [1] " So Adrian and Charlie Warzel were sitting in a [inaudible 00:01:51] stool in the corner. You’re our first full-time guest."
## [1] " You’ve been given a position of prominence here. I hope you feel honored."
## [1] " Yeah, either that or a place where we torture people to get their private keys."
## [1] " It’s a very manly space, I gotta say, Aaron."
## [1] " It’s to compensate. This room is like the poor man’s Lamborghini."
## [1] " There are two … Do you see two … There two … Every time I’m down here, I’m fascinated by the fact that you have two vicious looking crowbars hanging, and [crosstalk 00:02:24]-"
## [1] " Well, I’ll say-"
## [1] " What do you need two crowbars for?"
## [1] " I’ll say this. What happens if your first crowbar breaks?"
## [1] " Why do you have one crowbar?"
## [1] " I’ve used that crowbar before?"
## [1] " Really? Okay."
## [1] " That’s because I’m always out there crowbarring in the rain."
## [1] " Oh, okay."
## [1] " Gideon, you wrote an article for Wired about Tezos. I’ve never actually been clear. Is that the correct pronunciation?"
## [1] " I remember … I can’t even remember … It was in the article, but where did the name Tezos come from?"
## [1] " Does it use some sort of combining multiple different languages or something?"
## [1] " So he failed, because it’s tehzos, tayzos, or teezos."
## [1] " How can a made up word be in English?"
## [1] " Not used in English."
## [1] " Pronounceable. Okay, yeah."
## [1] " Well, so that-"
## [1] " Well, the weird thing is that when I first got into crypto, I was always confused by Tezos and Trezor sounding … Both having a T and a Z, and I actually, I’ll admit, I originally thought that was one thing."
## [1] " Did you think they were both related to Trent Reznor?"
## [1] " The NIN coin’s still waiting out there to happen."
## [1] " The NIN coin."
## [1] " So I want to get to Tezos and your story, but do you guys want to do a little news first?"
## [1] " Yeah, let’s do it."
## [1] " Gideon, we were actually talking about that … What is it? The National Bureau-"
## [1] " Economics report. Tell us the basics of what that report said."
## [1] " I mean, we’ve come back to it a lot of times on this show. It’s kind of incredible that the Satoshi elegant system works as well as it does. If you had told me this eight years ago, I would have been like, “It’ll hit some sort of roadblock. It’ll be something that people haven’t foreseen and it’ll destroy the whole system.” I don’t think the fact that it’s existed for, what, 10 or 11 years now, means that won’t happen, but we have passed many similar roadblocks along the way, where I was like, “This seems like a fatal problem.”"
## [1] " Yeah, I mean, this is … We’re still due … Jay, do you want to do a close read of the white paper as our next book club?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I think we’re overdue, because I’m remembering this all from the white paper but hazily, but I do remember that all of the explanation of 51% attacks basically assume that 51% attacks are done by thieves, by people who are financially motivated, and I think you’re correct that if we reach possible Bitcoin Maximalist state, and let’s say the adversary stops being thieves and starts being the state itself, A, the resources are higher, and B, the game theory inputs are different, and you wouldn’t have really thought about that problem in advance. I haven’t even really thought about the state shutting down Bitcoin through a 51% attack rather than through throwing people in jail, which I think is most people’s baseline assumption of how Bit-"
## [1] " Yeah, I hadn’t really thought about that, either, but I don’t understand why they wouldn’t … It seems like that’s the silver bullet that the state will always have."
## [1] " Yeah, it’s going to be like NATO and [inaudible 00:07:53] together to do a 51% attack."
## [1] " I don’t … At the point where they’re like, “Maybe we should kill this thing,” they can just pool their money together and be like, “Okay. It doesn’t exist anymore.”"
## [1] " Is it possible the state wouldn’t be able to get enough chips and computers through that? I mean, is there enough hardware on earth to buy out, to do it?"
## [1] " Some would argue they already have."
## [1] " In terms of countries that would attempt a 51% attack on Bitcoin, who do you think the front riders are? China?"
## [1] " But they’re destroying a lot of the wealth, because a lot of the money’s in China."
## [1] " I don’t think that any country right now is incentivized to destroy Bitcoin. The number one is probably Russia, because if they can actually create a competitor coin, and then they destroy Bitcoin, but I don’t [crosstalk 00:08:45]-"
## [1] " Ooh, I like this idea."
## [1] " I don’t really see … Because there’s going to be like … They want the crypto ruble."
## [1] " It’s like a Putin and Vitalik conspiracy to crash Bitcoin."
## [1] " Well, no, because they actually are trying to create a nationalized cryptocurrency, so it does kind of make sense for them to destroy all the other cryptocurrencies, and then have all cryptocurrency enthusiasts kind of begrudgingly, maybe, use a crypto ruble or something like that. I think they’re probably number one."
## [1] " Yeah, and it also assumes that you have all of the hardware and all of that. But it would be interesting to play out a scenario in which certain governments are pushing a 51% attack on the Bitcoin network, and other governments are protecting the Bitcoin network, potentially because their current … they have gone to a Bitcoin standard."
## [1] " Yeah, you just described an extremely boring Bitcoin movie."
## [1] " Yeah, I was just like [crosstalk 00:09:58] … Who do you think would be leading the 49% resistance? The Swiss would be the kind of country that would be protecting the Bitcoin network."
## [1] " I think they’re too neutral. I think that it would have to be a ragtag group of cipher punks."
## [1] " A Venezuela in resistance?"
## [1] " They have no nation, but they just want to save Bitcoin because they believe in it, and they end up working for the state. It’s like Catch Me If You Can, the Leonardo DiCaprio movie where he’s a check forger. I think it would be like that."
## [1] " Well, you brought up, Jay, in our last episode, when we were interviewing Saif Ammus, you were like, “Do you really think it’s a good idea for the Winklevoss twins to have more than 1% of the world’s wealth?” And he was like, “Absolutely.” But the people who would truly be able to defend a state 51% attack would be like futile oligarchs of our future, like the Winklevoss twins."
## [1] " Oh, that’s true."
## [1] " Oh, interesting. Interesting."
## [1] " That’s true."
## [1] " Yeah, who’s got all the power? There are some countries that just have a lot of electricity-"
## [1] " Iceland."
## [1] " And that’s going to become more and more pronounced as energy becomes environmental rather than oil-based."
## [1] " This would be a fun board game to play, where we’re all trying to get electricity and miners."
## [1] " Yeah, I’m kind of into it. And you can do like the flag-"
## [1] " You could do like a [crosstalk 00:11:32]-"
## [1] " Yeah, it takes 11 hours to play and has 700 pieces, something like that. I’m attacking from Kamchatka with my [inaudible 00:11:42] two."
## [1] " I have started development on nuclear fusion. Will take 245 turns."
## [1] " Yeah, I think this is … I think we should just do this Kickstarter, guys. Kickstarter’s actually a good transition, because I remember, Gideon, that you wrote about a failed hardware Kickstarter."
## [1] " How long ago was that? Three or four years ago?"
## [1] " Three years ago."
## [1] " And there’s nothing that the ICO environment resembles to me more than a failed hardware Kickstarter."
## [1] " Just to pause, you guys. Doing a Kickstarter or an ICO with your wife? Easily one of my lowest life priorities. I would never do something like that."
## [1] " Yeah, the challenge was mass producing it."
## [1] " Yeah, it’s kind of an issue in miners, also."
## [1] " But until mining became a huge industry, most of the early miners were pieces of shit."
## [1] " And this is … As we’ve talked about ICOs on this show, this has been a consistent theme where I’ll ask Jay, “What percentage of these Altcoins are scams?” And Jay will say, “More than 95%.” And I’ll go, “Well, I see it more as 90%.” And then we’ll be like, “Well, the difference in those two figures depends on how you perceive some of these things that are colossal failures but potentially well-intentioned, or at least neutrally intentioned as projects.” Which is a good way to describe … I don’t think many people started Kickstarters as true scams, but many people who back Kickstarters got scammed."
## [1] " Did you ever have a espresso that was made in their espresso machine?"
## [1] " Was it good stuff?"
## [1] " But having a functional product puts them at least three tiers above all ICOs for me."
## [1] " Yeah, they were going to the ICO hall of fame for that."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly."
## [1] " For building but failing to scale-"
## [1] " This is the most reputable, successful ICO in history. Hall of fame."
## [1] " I think that you just described, actually, what the closest similarity between the Kickstarter and the ICO is. The audience is in a similar position, where you’ve got their money. You’re supposed to deliver something and you may or may not actually be able to deliver it, and a lot of the people who are selling it, not necessarily people you would bank on to be able to deliver the thing that they set out to deliver."
## [1] " And that already existed."
## [1] " But it existed-ish."
## [1] " In terms of where they were at that-"
## [1] " Gideon, this one of the things that … This is a total aside, but it was one of these things that I think your writing is good at with little details, but isn’t it the first time they went … that these two, the Breitmans, went on a date, that he took her to a narco-capitalism meeting?"
## [1] " Under false pretense. She believed that she was going to a different event."
## [1] " I was going to say, that is the worst first date idea I’ve ever heard of in my life."
## [1] " That’s definitely the first scene in the crypto movie, though, is the guy being like, “Hey, you want to go to a meetup with me?” And then it’s just all dudes."
## [1] " It’s so crazy to be like, “I’m interested in this woman. My first idea will be to take her to a crypto anarchist meetup.”"
## [1] " Do you think he did this serially? He would find women that he thought might have libertarian leanings, and then just be like, “Come to a classical liberal meetup?” Is there even such thing as a classical liberal meetup?"
## [1] " The only thing I can think of that would be worse is if you went to a Craft Homebrew Convention, that was your date. I think I would rather got to a narco-capitalist meeting than a bunch of home craft brewers. Anyway, I’m sorry. This is quite a diversion, but go ahead."
## [1] " This is like a description of a person that I would just run away from. I mean, South-African living in Switzerland with a background … I’d be like, “No, don’t want to do business with this person.”"
## [1] " You do a Bitcoin podcast, Aaron. I feel like that’s the next thing in that list there."
## [1] " At this point, trusting someone because they were or claim to be associated with the Ethereum Lodge, terrible idea. There must have been 10,000 people involved with the launch of Ethereum if we are to believe-"
## [1] " Well, how how involved was he? This is a legitimate guy, though, I’m just saying."
## [1] " Yeah, you’ve actually looked into this person."
## [1] " What year are we in right now?"
## [1] " And additionally, part of the claim is, “Those tokens will allow you to ride the rides, and this amusement park is going to be so awesome that everyone’s going to want to ride these rides, and your token will increase in value as a result.”"
## [1] " So this will allow you to ride one ride, and [inaudible 00:24:20], there’s a decentralized exchanged in which you might be able to sell it, but hey, who knows?"
## [1] " What was that coughing noise you made?"
## [1] " I was just saying that’s like there’s a wink-wink element which says, “While this is like a ticket to ride, it’s also a ticket ride where there’s an elaborate system for trading tickets to ride already in place.”"
## [1] " Additionally, as I understand it, when you take something like Ethereum, you’re selling tickets to ride, but people are buying well more tokens than they would ever have an appetite for roller coasters, so you at least … If you don’t believe that it’s going to speculatively be worth more, you at least believe that you will be able to exchange with other people those tokens."
## [1] " Yeah, it’s a-"
## [1] " Because otherwise you’re signing up for a life of amusement parks."
## [1] " But that’s-"
## [1] " Right, and Jay and I, if I went deep on roller coaster coin and Jay went on giant soda coin, I’m like, “Hey, we could swap. I could get my giant soda. You can ride the thing. Everyone wins.”"
## [1] " You pay rent coin."
## [1] " And it was mined."
## [1] " So people didn’t have to put in fiat in the first place. People were able to create the initial value through mining, which is not true in the case of Ethereum or Tezos, as far as I understand it."
## [1] " Well, I think economists would also argue that people figuring out how to mine it is a form of productivity."
## [1] " Not surprising that there’s a Swiss loophole that makes it easy to do things that are financially frowned upon in other countries."
## [1] " I mean, it’s also strange … it’s a strange environment that by a factor of 10, people are uncertain about how much money they’re raising. When people have raised money for startups, etc., they have some idea of what they’re raising it for. Like the idea that something-"
## [1] " But people had to deliver it. For each person who backed the Kickstarter, they had to deliver one product, so it was scaled. I mean, it’s just … It’s strange to think a company that conceivably could have delivered a product for $10 million within rational thought also could take $200 million."
## [1] " $10 and $20 million is actually a lot until people are raising $200 million."
## [1] " I mean, Ethereum was $18 million-"
## [1] " And that was considered a lot when it happened."
## [1] " And we’ve got a great name like the canton of Zug."
## [1] " Pretty quickly, right?"
## [1] " Well, how did they get … What was the marketing that made it so effective?"
## [1] " And this is not a totally original idea. There’s … Decred is another."
## [1] " Okay. At the time it was-"
## [1] " Well, I mean, I thought you were going to say the flip side of that, of why this one, why then, is coming off of Ethereum, a much smaller raise. Everyone made a shit ton of money who bought in early, so there’s a bunch of that. A bunch of the money that’s coming in is not true fiat but people who’ve made a bunch of money by speculating on Bitcoin. So people are gambling with-"
## [1] " A lot of house money, and house money gambling has been very good to people at the time. I always kind of read it, and tell me if you disagree, that Tezos was a bit at the right place at the right time."
## [1] " I still don’t totally understand what Tezos is, though. I want to read the description from your article. “While the irony of preventing the fragmentation of cryptocurrencies by releasing a new one does not escape us, the second paper concluded, Tezos truly aims to be the last cryptocurrency.” So my frame of reference here is Ethereum and various what we refer to as matryoshka doll cryptocurrencies, which are … it’s a currency that you can make more currencies with. It’s a token for making more tokens."
## [1] " So there wasn’t like an ERC20 of Tezos."
## [1] " So the whole thing could run just on Tezos. Okay."
## [1] " There’s a moment in the story, I would say maybe the most damning moment of the story, in which Breitman wife, what’s her name?"
## [1] " Kathleen says, “It’s just like tote bags.” And this has been a longstanding question we’ve had about ERC20 tokens, Tezos, whatever, which is, is the token guaranteed to actually do anything?"
## [1] " Because there’s this company in San Francisco, I can’t remember the name, that was selling a token based on the idea that they would do security audits, and the whole thing was built on the idea that the only way to get these security audits was to buy their token, and then they actually sold the token, and then they’re like, “Oh, some people wanted to get a security audit, so we just sold it to them in US dollars, and some of them paid in Bitcoin.” And it was like, “Oh, well, there’s not really a market for that anymore.”"
## [1] " They’re like souvenirs for-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Or if you … The context in which she said it was like, “If you give money to NPR, they’ll send you an umbrella,” or something like that, and that’s a gesture of appreciation."
## [1] " And she didn’t say this to you. She said this to a Reuters reporter who originally wrote that in a story."
## [1] " Sure. It’s kind of hard to describe how tokens work, because even people who understand them, I don’t even put ourselves among them. There’s not a unified view on them. You … Yeah, okay. [crosstalk 00:43:36]."
## [1] " Hmm. I don’t believe that."
## [1] " Do you believe that? I’ve never heard of a single person buying because of that."
## [1] " I think it is 99% speculators, 0.9% people who are like, “Maybe I can use this to build another coin,” and then 0.1% who might be not real either."
## [1] " Let me make a counterpoint, though. I agree that almost everyone who’s investing deeply in cryptocurrency is ideological and has a religious belief."
## [1] " Really? I mean, I invested, and I had no ideological or religious belief."
## [1] " Well, at least early adopters."
## [1] " We’re talking about at the time of that."
## [1] " People who haven’t touched a vegetable in a year. But my point was going to be, I think you can be both. You can be an ideological believer and a speculator."
## [1] " And someone like Saifedean would say, I think, that in the case of Bitcoin … Saifedean hates shit coins, right? But in the case of Bitcoin, if you buy $1,000 worth of Bitcoin, you are buying that percentage of the overall supply of Bitcoin in the world. You are actually … You own a piece of Bitcoin. You may not have governance rights to it, but you … Actually, you do have a form of governance rights because you can buy and sell forks, but you’re owning it, whereas in the case of an ERC20 token, or an ICO, you’re buying into something that doesn’t have some clear supply relationship like that. You’re getting a little bit … It’s more like a tote bag. You’re signaling and you’re speculating, but what the thing is … One Bitcoin is not the same as one ERC20 token, and that-"
## [1] " Right, or an Ethereum token, let’s say."
## [1] " The deflationary world."
## [1] " Mad Max."
## [1] " I feel like people would … If you’ve listened up to here, read the story for how it all fell apart, and suffice it to say, it all fell apart, and not in a code-based way, not in a security flaw, in a very human way."
## [1] " Yes, and has yet to produce anything with that billion dollars."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Just awesome."
## [1] " Amazingly, one of the best business models might be to do a failed ICO that just gets you a bunch of ETH, and just sit on it."
## [1] " Don’t make me get down the crowbar. We only allow Austrian school of economics here."
## [1] " I mean, they failed in that respect. They failed as much as two people could possibly fail."
## [1] " Interesting. So you believe that they could come back from something like this. When we got into crypto a year ago, if you had started typing ICO scam, Tezos would have auto-corrected from Google. It became synonymous with a project that people poured a ton of money into and produced nothing except hilarious if you didn’t put money in stories, and additionally, I think that there’s a certain schadenfreude here, which is anarcho-capitalists who believe that the market can solve anything being thwarted by the most basic of human conflicts and everything that happens that makes things not a pure market, like when you get into business with a South African Swiss [inaudible 00:51:33], it may not just play out as a frictionless system of energy bouncing around. Where are they at now?"
## [1] " Rich?"
## [1] " This happens in a lot of … This happened in Bitconnect, everything. It almost becomes a worthwhile project simply because it’s built a passionate audience, because that passionate-"
## [1] " Aaron is talking himself into $SUMO again right now."
## [1] " Well, but this is the psychology the people who hold these tokens that go down in flames, is if this is our low moment, we got a bunch of people here. If we could just build this back, we could at least get our money out, etc. This seems like a dangerous form of thinking, though."
## [1] " A thing we’ve talked about on the show before is that it’s hard to figure out why anyone’s actually going to build these projects if they’re rich. If you make a ton of money on an ICO, and it sounds like, actually, they didn’t, but some of these ICOs are structured so day one, the founders are fuck you rich, why actually build something? What incentivizes people that-"
## [1] " Really? I mean, do they mean that? Or-"
## [1] " Okay, but we hear the same-"
## [1] " Austrian school. Good."
## [1] " We hear similar things from every tech company. I mean, so what level of sincerity compared to, let’s say, your average Silicon Valley startup that is figuring out how … building spikes so that the homeless can’t sleep on the sidewalks, and then saying, “We’re trying to help the world.”"
## [1] " Well, if you consider exposing people to free markets and stateless banks as good, then that’s good, right?"
## [1] " Okay, but I don’t think that that’s true of ICOs, though, because this is something Aaron and I talked about last week, which is that … I don’t doubt your reporting at all. I think that if you tell me that these people are well-intentioned, then I believe that they’re well-intentioned. The reason why the initial response is to be skeptical is because I think that part of what Ethereum did was that it made it so that it’s so easy to print coins and so easy to do ICOs, that in fact there is no emotional labor or anything to get one, and we just find a whole bunch of them, that there is no good intention. There’s actually no intention, period. It’s just, “Hey, maybe they’ll open this door.”"
## [1] " Mozart sucks."
## [1] " So if we remove intentions, and I agree, intentions are hard. If a scammer and a well-intentioned failure end up in the same point, it makes it difficult to say, “Oh, intentions are everything.” In some ways it becomes results. So in thinking about what went wrong here, and I think at this point we still have to classify Tezos in the what went wrong camp."
## [1] " That’s a Silicon Valley ideology."
## [1] " They’re post-human, in a way."
## [1] " Like Saifedean talks about the Blockchain extending for hundreds of years, beyond a person’s lifetime."
## [1] " Don’t make me get the crowbar down."
## [1] " Well, I think that’s absolutely true, and also it seems like they ran up against some of the limitations of people."
## [1] " That we keep imagining these frictionless market systems in which people can’t intervene or whatever, and they only assume this slight bit of human trust, but the minute you give the guy the only keys to the bank or whatever, that’s a human thing in there, and I feel like crypto imagines itself to be post-human, but the realities of doing anything in the world right now are that you have to interface with people, and I don’t know. I guess I’m curious about projects that would sort of assume that, rather than assume, “Oh, people won’t play into it.”"
## [1] " If this was a novel, I’d be like, “Eh, it’s hitting the nail on the head a little bit hard here. Did they have to get screwed over by the Swiss South African bank guy?” Yes, they did. They did."
## [1] " Where can people find the story?"
## [1] " And where can people find you?"
## [1] " Are you going to continue to write about Blockchain and crypto related stuff, or do you need a five-year vacation at this point? This story took a lot out of you. You’re grayer than the last time I saw you before you were working on this. Yeah, and you were personally threatened during this thing."
## [1] " Okay, well, if you disappear mysteriously, I’m going to investigate, okay? Will you come back on next time you get something on this copy?"
## [1] " Awesome. Thanks."
