## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] " Jay, you done with that Chinese food?"
## [1] " No, but I’m not going to finish it."
## [1] " You’re going to eat that a second time?"
## [1] " Look. There’s this Chinese place near the Crypto Cave. It’s generally very reliable for B- takeout Chinese food, which is actually the type of Chinese food I prefer."
## [1] " Now let me ask you a question. Does anything get less than a B- in all of New York City, if that’s a B-?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " Definitely."
## [1] " So you’ve been to Chinese restaurants worse than the one across from you guys?"
## [1] " Let me just clear this up here, which is that there are three types of Chinese restaurants in New York City. There’s good Chinese restaurant that are mostly in Flushing and in some parts of Chinatown, I would say."
## [1] " Authentic."
## [1] " Midtown has a few of them."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " Not necessarily authentic, but they’re just kind of places where Chinese people go, and they’re good. Then there’s all the takeout places, many of which have bulletproof glass."
## [1] " Yeah. Anywhere that has wings on the menu."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly."
## [1] " One of those places."
## [1] " The most common order is fried wings and fried rice, a combo. Those places I think are all about the same. Then there’s a worse type of Chinese restaurant, which is trying to bridge the gap between those two."
## [1] " Oh I see, I see. You’re drawing a distinction where you’re like intentionality is important."
## [1] " For example, there’s one on 12th and 2nd avenue in Manhattan that I went to that was horrific. I was like, “Well, you’re trying to hard. Just fucking go behind the bulletproof glass and serve the fucking wings. This isn’t working.” Those are all worse than a B-. I would say those are all about a D."
## [1] " Well, okay, this is a good segue, because the show that we’re going to do today is involved in fakers, fakery, and what happens when you try to create an alternate clone of something?"
## [1] " That’s quite a stretch of a segue, but I’m going to allow it."
## [1] " Hey, hey. If it’s not a stretch, it’s not a segue, okay? But before we get into that actually, I wanted to ask you did you see that stuff that came out about Zcash and the executive compensation for Zooko?"
## [1] " I did. I saw a-"
## [1] " The leader of the Zcash project?"
## [1] " I saw the kerfuffle on Twitter."
## [1] " Yeah. I’m always curious about how the faces behind these projects interact with both the technology, the price, and the perception of it being a shit coin or a legit project."
## [1] " Before we start, why don’t you tell us who Zooko is."
## [1] " Zooko is, as I understand it, I believe he is the head. Well, actually, I don’t really know. What’s his official title? Do you know?"
## [1] " I think he’s the chief engineer and more or less the face of Zcash."
## [1] " He’s certainly the figurehead of Zcash. This gets into weird stuff where I’ve referred to Riccardo Spagni as the founder of Monero. He’s not the founder of Monero. We don’t have a great word for it. It would be CEO, if this was the business world, but it’s not exactly like a CEO, because you’re not brought on by a board, and you can’t be deposed in that same kind of a manner. It’s not exactly a job."
## [1] " Zcash I think was similar in that it was the compilation of several cryptographic projects that academics were mostly doing under different names. They all got kind of composed together, lumped in together to start Zcash, which I think was around the time when Zooko came into the project. It wasn’t like Zcash was named Zcash because his name starts with a Z, I don’t think."
## [1] " As far as I know, the Z overlap is purely coincidental, although that would be good for a conspiracy minded out there. But there’s a whole foundation for Zcash that has a lot of big name crypto people on it. Matthew Green, the cryptographer that we both really like from Johns Hopkins works on Zcash. It’s not like he is the only person associated with this project, but if you were to pair … I have a little chart in our backend. We have a weird little spreadsheet. I have a field for one person associated with each coin. I think it’s really important who that one person is. In the case of Zcash, it’s absolutely Zooko. He is the face of Zcash."
## [1] " There’s two models, right? Under the first model, one would expect that they get a ton of it, where most of the coins are for them. You look at something like Ripple and the amount that’s help for the people who started ripple or even worked at Ripple early is staggering."
## [1] " Yeah, and that’s a company. We’re talking about the company Ripple, not the currency XRP."
## [1] " That’s the company. Yeah, yeah. But even the former head of it, the former CEO, when he was the richest man in the world, that was for 18 minutes or something like that, but good 18 minutes, that’s what I would assume a lot of these shit coin or alt coin things are based on is this idea that the founders get a ton of the money."
## [1] " Well, when we look at the scandals that we’ve talked about on the show, whether it’s Skycoin, my own beloved Sumokoin, a lot of times when the thing catches on fire, it’s because it turned out that the people behind the project had their hand in the cooking jar and were taking more money than they had claimed out of the pre-mined or pre-set aside coins."
## [1] " That’s my baseline assumption is that, right? There are other projects, like Ethereum or Bitcoin where I assume mostly mined coins that where I feel like most likely the founder has some smaller percentage of it, but that they aren’t leveraging the entire project so that they get rich immediately, that they’re proceeding in good faith. That would be the second time. Both types though I would say I would expect the founder to be having to get a lot of money. I’d expect all the founders of any mildly successful coin to be rich."
## [1] " Well, okay. Two previous examples that I’ve thought about this. Charlie Lee divested himself of all of his Litecoin."
## [1] " That’s a very kind way to put it, but yes."
## [1] " Divested for profit from Litecoin at high-"
## [1] " To end apartheid."
## [1] " … at a market high. He took one for the team and sold all of his Litecoin. His reasoning made sense to me, which was every time he did anything, it was affecting the price, and he was getting accused of shilling his own bag, basically. Making decisions to enrich himself. He decided to subvert that by enriching himself. I know that Riccardo Spagni, who runs Monero, I don’t know, I hope I’m pronouncing his name correctly. Has said, “I actually don’t have that much Monero. The amount of Monero I have is overblown. I don’t have any particular … Also, another notice, the Riccardo Spagni went to Consensus with a million dollar wristwatch on."
## [1] " What’s the difference?"
## [1] " Well, the difference is I think in the public perception of what it means to lead one of these projects and what it means if … Okay, in the case of Zooko, it was revealed that he receives about 1% I think of the Zcash."
## [1] " 0.9%."
## [1] " 0.9% of the Zcash. Is that the yearly mining he receives 1% of?"
## [1] " He receives about $3.6 million a year in Zcash."
## [1] " Yeah, I think about 20% of it is reserved for the foundation and all the people split it. Of that, he has about one 20th, which gives him about 1% overall. Which I’ll say when people were freaking out about this online, I was like, “It doesn’t seem like that much.”"
## [1] " 1% of all the currency?"
## [1] " 1% seems like a lot. $3.6 million a year to be the public face of Zcash doesn’t seem outrageous."
## [1] " Well, I don’t know. Okay, so what we’re sort of dancing around here is the idea of whether or not there is an acceptable level taste wise almost for a founder to be profiting in an early stage for a project that doesn’t really exist and that is supposed to be about decentralized revolution of the economy."
## [1] " Wait, Zcash exists. People use Zcash-"
## [1] " No they don’t."
## [1] " … people mine Zcash. Yeah, but when-"
## [1] " How many shielded, secure, anonymous Zcash transactions do you think [crosstalk 00:11:14]?"
## [1] " Okay, I don’t think it’s fully mature, but if Edward Snowden is out saying, “Your project is great,” that is at least a marketing success."
## [1] " A lot of people said nice things about Theranos too."
## [1] " It takes a public figure, I guess I’m saying, to go around to crypto conferences all year. I don’t expect that he was doing that shit for free. Now does he deserve $3.6 million? I think that’s an interesting debate to have, but within a factor of, let’s say, 1 to 100, you could have told me that he was making $300,000 a year, $3 million a year $30 million a year, $300 million a year. Some of these people who are doing ICOs are pulling in more than $3 million on their first day at work."
## [1] " I agree with you that the entire range is there, and that in fact I would have put the floor, the bottom most least possible at $3.5 million a year."
## [1] " Oh really?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " If you had found out he was doing it for $300,000 a year, you would have been like, “What a moron.”"
## [1] " I would have been like, “Why are you doing this? What’s the point?”"
## [1] " It’s also like if you’re Zooko, I know he’s got kids. We’ve both got kids. If you’re actually only making only a couple hundred thousand dollars a year on Zcash, Zooko could go out and do a Zcash fork right now and be like, “It’s like Zooko Coin,” and easily make many millions of dollars. People would buy that in a second."
## [1] " Or he could go to-"
## [1] " People bought Zcash, Zclassic."
## [1] " Yeah. He could walk up to Goldman Sachs and be like, “Hey, I only make $300,000 a year. Can you use me on whatever crypto stuff that you’re doing?” They would 10 times his salary immediately. $3.5 million a year is a lot. It is about what you would make as a maybe below average backup point guard in the NBA. It’s really not that much."
## [1] " Yeah, he’s not even making Nick Young money."
## [1] " No, definitely not."
## [1] " That’s kind of my bar."
## [1] " He’s making a little bit less than DeMarcus Cousins just signed for the Golden State Warriors. For crypto, when you have people who are starting projects that literally don’t exist where you can’t send a transaction in the way that you can with Zcash, and those people are making nine figures, this seems kind of small. If you were going to name the top 10 people in crypto who are the most important and the most reported on and the most well-known, he’d be in the top 10."
## [1] " Oh yeah."
## [1] " It’s not like some small shitcoin or something like that. If Riccardo Spagni is walking around with a million dollar watch, one would assume that he makes more than $3.5 million a year, or he’s horrible with money. Charlie Lee cashed out for nine figures, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Out of Litecoin."
## [1] " But there is a distinction between people who are massive hodeling whales and people who are receiving compensation for their [inaudible 00:14:11]."
## [1] " Okay, but I don’t understand why people are so mad about this. It doesn’t seem like that much money. I’m sure at some point, Aaron, maybe, oh, let’s say seven months ago you and I might have conceptualized that maybe we would make $3.5 million in crypto."
## [1] " We still might."
## [1] " The odds are very, very low, but we might."
## [1] " This is per year. This is also per year."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " Over the arc of Zcash, let’s say he’s going to walk away with 10 to $20 million in compensation? I agree with you. I think it is appropriate, and I think the incentives are properly aligned, which is to day he didn’t set a salary of $3.5 million for himself. He set a salary of a percentage of the mine of Zcash, and it’s because Zcash has been able to establish legitimacy and establish value that that’s worth $3.5 million. That is no small part due to his efforts."
## [1] " It’s better than having him own 30% of the coins and then dump it on everybody when it pumps. This actually does seem like an incentive structure in the way that it is paid out month by month, where it actually prevents him from trying to artificially pump it up and dump it. Make sure that he is somewhat invested over some long period of time now. That might not be the same as if you and I started a tech startup and we didn’t have a product and we were getting VC funding, etc, etc. But in reality, if you and I were doing that, we might be … It was a project as successful with as much hype as Zcash, we’d probably be making $3.5 million a year. Of all the offensive things in crypto, I don’t understand why this is even scratching the surface of offensive."
## [1] " I think that we’re moderates, Jay. Did you know that? We’re like crypto moderates."
## [1] " Did somebody tell you that?"
## [1] " Well, I realized that after I interviewed Saifedean."
## [1] " Oh okay."
## [1] " I realized that my viewpoints on all this stuff are like, “Whoa, moderation. Please exhibit moderation.” I think what makes people uncomfortable is that people are very ideologically enthralled with decentralization. People want to believe that all these alt coin projects are decentralized, just like Bitcoin is, but actually to run a big project like this, if it’s not Bitcoin, which kind of amazingly and elegantly does run without a Zooko-like figure-"
## [1] " Arguably."
## [1] " Yeah, arguably. I guess what I think makes people uncomfortable about this-"
## [1] " And there’s still Bitcoin Core and stuff like that."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. But I think what makes people uncomfortable here is that it makes you realize that maybe Zcash and Ripple aren’t such distant cousins."
## [1] " I would argue that that’s true."
## [1] " That actually Zcash is maybe a little more like a startup and a little less like Bitcoin."
## [1] " Yeah, I agree. Crypto moderates though."
## [1] " Are we? I don’t know. This is something I want to talk about with you."
## [1] " Okay. Are we like the people in the New York Times and Washington Post Oped who are calling out for civility?"
## [1] " Decency. We need a return to decency."
## [1] " If Zooko gets kicked out of a restaurant because the chef is mad, are we going to be like, “You cannot have this happen in a civilized society?”"
## [1] " Yes, yes. That might be our role."
## [1] " Okay. You know what? That might be our role. That sucks."
## [1] " I look at whether you’re an extremist or a moderate depends on the environment. I don’t think I’m a moderate in most environments, but in crypto, I’m constantly like, “Everyone calm down. We don’t need to entirely destroy the world here. We don’t have to.”"
## [1] " It is a good indication that you and I, who in our other worlds are … You know some as being unhinged trolls, at least one of us. I’m talking about me, and squarely a moderate in the crypto world, which I think is actually an accurate portrayal."
## [1] " Yeah. When I was talking to Saifedean Ammous, we were talking to Saifedean, who is decidedly not a moderate, he hates alt coins for the most part. He thinks they’re all shit coins. I wanted to push him on, okay, some of them are obviously shit coins, but why is a Zcash a shit coin, or one of these top 20 coins? His explanation is that for the most part, he has lots of criticisms. One of his central criticisms is that they’re run by these cults of personality, and that if that cult of personality, whether it’s a Zooko or a Vitalik either disappears or is in some ways loses their status, that the coins, all the value proposition of the coin is locked up in this single point of failure."
## [1] " Or if the person gets in an airplane crash or something like that."
## [1] " There was a fake Vitalik car crash, and it’s like, “What happens to Ethereum if Vitalik dies in a car crash, or repudiates decentralization and says it was a mistake?” There’s a million ways that unforeseen events could happen, but I think what’s the most interesting to me about Bitcoin is that it does not have that ."
## [1] " Well, it does, but it is protected by several layers of mystery and anonymity."
## [1] " Yeah, it’s kind of like the Jesus myth. It’s like Jesus was here. He’s probably coming back, but you can’t talk to him right now."
## [1] " Yeah, so you might as well believe in what we’re telling you, because he’s coming some day."
## [1] " Yes, and I think it’s one of the reasons that Bitcoin has been so powerful and so hard to dethrone. It’s really like a great foundational myth. Every time where you would reach a fork in the road and the so-called leader would have to make a centralized decision about where we’re going, the community just has to figure it out themselves, because you can’t ask Satoshi."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. Are you aware of anything about the history of the Mormon church?"
## [1] " Yeah, I’ve read the John Krakauer book about Mormons."
## [1] " Okay, so I did not read that book. I am instead going off of my 11th grade American History class. But Joseph Smith was taking people west to the promised land."
## [1] " Another way to describe it was he is taking people west, because they kept getting kicked out of towns, because they were scammers, but they were moving in a westward direction."
## [1] " Okay, that’s all I’m saying. All right. Let’s not be pedants here. He said that he had tablets, right?"
## [1] " Yes. Twice."
## [1] " On those tablets, they’re behind a secret wall, and nobody could see them."
## [1] " Well, he had a translator. He had to look in his hat to see what’s in there."
## [1] " But the tablets didn’t exist, most likely."
## [1] " Well, first his wife destroyed the first transcription of them, and then they did it again."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " But yeah, no one saw them."
## [1] " Nobody could see them, and when people would say, “Can we see them?” He would say, “No.” At some point, I believe, again, according to 11th grade history class, somebody snuck in and they said there’s no tablets here, and he said that God had warned him that somebody was going to sneak in, so he had moved them or something like that, right?"
## [1] " Yes. I would describe Joseph Smith’s entire life is a sequence of events like this where it’s like, “No, I wasn’t scamming, I was …” Ball of smoke, moves to a town one town over."
## [1] " Yeah, it’s like Waiting for Guffman where they think they’re in California, but they haven’t really reached it there."
## [1] " Basically yes, yeah."
## [1] " That’s how I see the Satoshi thing, right? Where there’s no way to confirm anything. There’s no way to know what’s real, and so you can have blind faith in it as long as nobody knows what it is, and that if the truth comes out, no matter how spectacular, it will most likely be disappointing, and that’ll most likely hurt the Bitcoin economy."
## [1] " Yeah. How would Christianity deal with Jesus actually coming back?"
## [1] " Well, we’d all be dead, because it’s the rapture."
## [1] " Or how would Mormonism deal with the actual appearance of those tablets?"
## [1] " I think in that one, also everybody is dead."
## [1] " Yeah. I guess I’m saying-"
## [1] " It’s all very like Heaven’s Gate where the end is everybody is dead."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly. It’s like the entire run of Mormonism or Christianity on earth is up until the point that the person reappears. In my opinion, nothing could be worse for Bitcoin than the reappearance of Satoshi."
## [1] " It’d be so bad."
## [1] " I would be like I could not sell fast enough if a guy was on CNBC. It’s like, “We found Satoshi.” I’d be like, “No!”"
## [1] " You would not be fast enough. I feel like there’s trigger releases on that just for that. The value of Bitcoin would probably fall to, what, 60, 70%?"
## [1] " It’s totally unpredictable. I think there’s some people who would say it’ll go up now that we can put a name-"
## [1] " No, I think those people are wrong."
## [1] " I can think of several factors that inform my feeling that it would go down. When I think about the BCH fork and the whole period of Bitcoin forks, that whole time that Satoshi was like a real person that we could talk to, people would have been saying, “So, should we 2X or not 2X? It was your idea.” Every petty squabble within the community would ultimately fall to Satoshi. Every time there was a scare about people buying drugs with … There would be movements to throw Satoshi in jail, to confiscate his pre-mined funds. He would have to deal with the tax situation of, “We know that you pre-mined a million coins. Your tax bill is more than the GDP of …” These are really big issues that would come up if Satoshi reappeared, no?"
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. Also, I think that most people would probably be really not thrilled with figuring out who he was. The whole mystery part of it goes away. Once the elegance of Bitcoin, everything that we think was made by a super genius goes away the second that you see some dude on TV, and he’s talking to some TV anchor or something like that, and you’re like, “Oh, this person might not be that smart.” It might be unfair or something like that, but people will lose their faith almost immediately. Right now, he is seen as this mythic genius figure. There’s no way that you can hold that up the second that you go public."
## [1] " Yeah, I think that immediately, there’s so many ways to interpret Satoshi that in his absence, we can maintain all of those interpretations. You and I can be Bitcoin moderates. People can be like Mad Max, Scorched Earth, Bitcoin gold standard fans, and I don’t know if we can all coexist peacefully, but at least each person can think that they have the right ideas. Yeah, it’s a little bit like if Jesus came back, we’d be like, “So which one was right? Protestantism, or the … Tell which one of the sects had it right here.”"
## [1] " Calvinism."
## [1] " Probably within a day, people would re-murder Jesus."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I think Satoshi would be destroyed by reappearing. One of the reasons I think that Satoshi is really smart is because he hasn’t reappeared. It’s the absolutely right decision."
## [1] " I’m going to hold you to what you said before. What is the scenario where Bitcoin goes up if Satoshi is revealed?"
## [1] " That’s a good question."
## [1] " What if it’s Elon Musk?"
## [1] " Yeah, that’s what I’m saying. I think if it was Elon Musk, Bitcoin goes up, people are like, “Whoa, Elon Musk? Buy Bitcoin.”"
## [1] " Maybe a year ago."
## [1] " I actually can see Wall Street, I remember our interview with a surprisingly reasonable Ripple fan. He’s a banker right? He’s a finance guy. He was like, “I was always uncomfortable with the fact that Satoshi was anonymous.” People don’t really know who’s behind this project. I think that actually Wall Street could potentially react positively towards the reappearance of Satoshi, if Satoshi … You don’t think so?"
## [1] " I done believe that you even think that."
## [1] " Well, we’re assuming that Satoshi has got purple hair and just a cypherpunk."
## [1] " No, no, no."
## [1] " No?"
## [1] " I’m picturing him as an overweight, slovenly dude."
## [1] " Oh, okay. I as picturing him more as like Shingy."
## [1] " There’s no one in the Bitcoin space who is like Shingy at all."
## [1] " That’s what I’m saying. He’s not someone we know about. You think he’s basically a Nick Szabo, Hal Finney type, like a nerdy dad probably?"
## [1] " Yeah, he’s definitely a nerdy dad."
## [1] " Okay. I agree, but you don’t think Wall Street would like a nerdy dad?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Yeah, probably not."
## [1] " No, I think they would prefer Shingy."
## [1] " I think finding Satoshi has always been the most interesting Bitcoin mystery for journalists."
## [1] " Yeah, for me it’s what got me into Bitcoin."
## [1] " Yeah, I think it draws a lot of people in. There’s a lot of depth to the mystery. Bitcoin’s elegance as a system is really fascinating to me. Then you can’t say this is an elegant, fascinating system, and not be interested in who made that."
## [1] " Yeah, so as a journalist, I’ll just say that there are very few mysteries that are this big that are unsolved that have been this unsolved … Actually, it is probably the only one, outside of the zodiac fucking killer."
## [1] " Yeah, pre Bitcoin, but … Okay, there’s a lot of, “Who killed this person?” But outside of violence, are there other great artists, great creators who’ve remained anonymous? Who’s the most famous anonymous person?"
## [1] " Well, this is a distinguishing factor why this Satoshi thing is so interesting, which is that there are other anonymous things. Who made the Rosetta Stone or something like that?"
## [1] " Yeah, who made Stonehenge?"
## [1] " Who made Stonehenge? Or where did those Klay Thompson heads show up on Easter Island? Who made that?"
## [1] " There’s a lot of mysteries around Klay Thompson."
## [1] " Who made Klay Thompson?"
## [1] " Who sent those toasters back in time and got him to sign them?"
## [1] " Point being, every single other mystery has almost no data. The thing about the Satoshi mystery is that there are these emails. There’s a ton of people who interacted with this person. All of that is public. Anybody can find almost all the message board stuff. There is a sense that there is enough data that you should be able to figure this out, but nobody has been able to. That’s why for journalists, I think it’s so interesting, because you feel like you’re almost there, but you’re not. You can’t figure out why, and so you can go, like our good friend and former guest, Adrian Chen, who has been thinking about this for many years and who’s one of, I would say in terms of figuring shit out, weird shit out on the internet, probably the best journalist out there. That’s why these types of things drive people crazy or journalists crazy, because we can’t figure out why we can’t figure it out."
## [1] " I think that this happening in the modern era makes it even that much more exciting. It makes sense that it’s hard to figure out how painted a masterpiece in the Renaissance. There’s been so much decay, and also things weren’t recorded in the same way. Everything that Satoshi did, the whitepaper, the actual code for Bitcoin, the message board posts, that’s all perfectly preserved. It hasn’t decayed at all. The only way, really all we have to go on is this text, these little lines of text. The main way, and I think Adrian talked about this when he was on the show, it seems like the best lead for Satoshi is to match his writing style."
## [1] " Many people have tried to do that. The best case for Nick Szabo always was that it was similar writing styles, but then there would be times where Satoshi would use Briticisms, and people didn’t quite understand that. Should we just get to the thing that we’re talking about?"
## [1] " Sure. Yeah."
## [1] " Okay. A few days ago on the internet, there was a news site that was anonymously registered through Amazon Web Services. It’s called the Nakamoto Family Foundation. There’s one post on it which was explaining that this person who is purporting to be Satoshi was now going to be writing a book, and that they wanted to alert people that there was an excerpt of that book that was going to be available. You can just click on it. It’s a PDF. Anybody can read it right now. Bloomberg ran a story about this, and I think the title was something that was like, “Has the mysterious creator of Bitcoin written a book?”"
## [1] " Yeah, if you came to it through the Bloomberg story, it seemed maybe legit. It wasn’t like some crank is pretending to be Satoshi. It was like, “We may have found out who Satoshi is.” That was the tone of the article."
## [1] " I think that’s saying it a little bit too strongly, but I think that both the fact that it was Bloomberg, which I think is a reputable organization, and the fact that it didn’t say, “This probably isn’t Satoshi,” that’s about as far as they get, but that’s pretty far."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " What we have instead are about 21 pages in PDF of a first-person narrative mostly of the early days of Bitcoin, purportedly written by Satoshi. I’ve mostly muted or unfollowed most of crypto Twitter to keep my own sanity recently. What has the reaction been like in crypto Twitter?"
## [1] " I was surprised, because the last time that someone did this, it was Craig Wright, right? I think the best account of the Craig Wright saga is John Lanchester’s reporting and the London Review of Books. Highly recommend that if you missed that hilarious incident. But basically to recap, he spun, spun, spun, waited, waited until the last second, and then couldn’t really show the private keys that would have identified him as Satoshi. The standard for proof was established at that point as showing the private keys for the wallets of the original Bitcoin pre-mines."
## [1] " Yeah, so for those who may have forgotten, it’s two actually very good journalists, Andy Greenberg and Sam Biddle, both wrote stories at a time saying this might be Satoshi. It’s an Australian guy, Craig Wright, who if you’re involved in crypto at all, you know who he is. They published, and eventually it turned out that there was one type of signature that Craig Wright could have provided that would have easily proven he was Satoshi, but he could not provide that."
## [1] " He has a whole raft of explanations for it that you can look up online if you’re interested. I feel pretty comfortable in saying that Craig Wright is not Satoshi and is also not behaving like someone who’s Satoshi."
## [1] " What’s his behavior like?"
## [1] " He’s like a brash, showoffy, asshole-ish. He is not acting like a person who pulled himself off-grid and hid for a long time."
## [1] " Yeah. He’s another person who has blocked me on Twitter, by the way."
## [1] " How do these people … Are you on some sort of a universal block list? How does Craig Wright know enough about you to block? I’m sort of flattered for the show."
## [1] " Yeah, me too."
## [1] " Like Craig Wright blocked you. But it also is probably based on something completely different."
## [1] " I don’t really remember why … I’m blocked by a lot of people, and for most of them, I don’t remember why. Tim Kawakami, do you know who that is? He’s a Bay Area sports reporter."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " He blocked me on the second day that I was on Twitter in 2009 or something like that, and he’s never unblocked me."
## [1] " Well, you have a lot of … I’m sure people had grudges against you from before the Twitter era they just brought into the electronics."
## [1] " I wasn’t even in media before the Twitter era though."
## [1] " Look, I don’t know what you were like before Twitter, but I could see people just being like, “Okay, who would I want to block, first block ever? Okay, Jay Kang. Jay Kang.”"
## [1] " Craig Wright, if you had to put a percentage on the chances that Craig Wright is Satoshi, what would you put it at?"
## [1] " I would say, since we’re in the World Cup here, I would have given Craig Wright Saudi Arabia chances."
## [1] " To win the whole thing?"
## [1] " To win the whole thing, and Nick Szabo, he’s not Brazil, but he’s like-"
## [1] " Belgium?"
## [1] " Columbia, Belgium.I think he’s like a 10 to 1, 15 to 1 chance."
## [1] " Yeah, about Belgium. Let’s talk about this actual text though, the 21 pages. You and I have both read it."
## [1] " This is just a general impression from glancing across it. A lot of people are making fun of it, as you would expect. A lot of people are like, “This is ridiculous.” It’s not hard to pick apart, and I’m sure we are about to pick it apart. It’s kind of a fascinating document, even as fiction."
## [1] " We should say I think here is that any time that anyone says they’re Satoshi, the general reaction since Leah McGrath Goodman and Newsweek said that Dorian Nakamoto was Satoshi. It’s all been derision. Nobody believes in it. It’s not particularly hard or surprising that this was immediately dismissed."
## [1] " Yes, but this is coming from a different angle, which is there’s been a lot of people who’ve tried to unmask Satoshi. I file this with the Craig Wright, because it’s someone trying to call their own shot as Satoshi."
## [1] " All right. We’ve both read it. I’m going to give my case for why I think it is Satoshi."
## [1] " Wow."
## [1] " Yeah, and let me caveat this by-"
## [1] " Now you may want to turn down the volume on your phone, because this take is going to come in a little hot."
## [1] " I don’t necessarily believe this, but while reading it, some thoughts did pop to my head, right?"
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Okay. The first is that the writing style that this is in is very loose. It resembles nothing of the white paper. It is essentially like a series of diary entries written by, I would say, a somewhat stoned, maybe, college student."
## [1] " It reminds me a little bit more of when someone’s dad sends a really long email, and it’s the formatting is a little all over the place."
## [1] " The formatting is weird, yeah."
## [1] " It’s kind of like, “Oh, and another thing. Oh, and also your mom said blah blah blah. Oh, and also,” it does not appear to have been edited."
## [1] " Very stream of consciousness."
## [1] " It’s referred to as an excerpt. Now both of us have crossed paths with the publishing industry. I used to work in publishing. This is not actually an excerpt. That is not correctly identifying what this is. An excerpt is when you take an entire book and publish a chapter of it or some subset of it. This is more of a scattered pitch for the book."
## [1] " It’s like a sampling."
## [1] " Closer to an outline."
## [1] " It’s not a contiguous excerpt, but it’s different parts of it."
## [1] " It’s not linear at all."
## [1] " I find it hard to believe that if this is somebody who is trying to mimic the style of writing of Satoshi Nakamoto in both the many emails he sent, in the whitepaper itself, in all the correspondences on forums, that they would write it in this style, because any normal person who is trying to mimic a style will look at the source text and be like, “Hey, I should make it kind of look like that,” right? Whatever things that are used in that real source text, I’m going to put in this, because people will match A to A, and they’ll say, “Hey, this is a real thing.”"
## [1] " Okay, I don’t want to agree with you, but there are certain parts of your logic I do agree with. Here’s one of them, which is I grew up in Berkeley, California. Many of my friends’ parents were famous academics, well-known thinkers, people who published books. There’s something that happens to people when they get on email or they’re supposed to be writing a long document that they don’t really understand the accepted formatting of. When people get loose, they can get really loose. I know people whose parents have been Nobel Prize contenders, and I’ve seen emails from them that you would be like, “That’s not the same guy.”"
## [1] " That person is illiterate."
## [1] " This has a little bit of that flow. You know when people will be like, “Oh, that’s a great idea. You should write a book about that,” and you’re like, “Come on, that’s not a good idea for a book.” This is written like someone who doesn’t know how to write down the idea for a book. It’s just a bunch of reminiscences and grievances scattered. It keeps trying to sort of react. It’s like, “I know you’re thinking that Satoshi is a real name, but it’s not.” No one thinks it’s a real name. It has a weird tone that I would almost describe as you know in a movie trailer when it’s like, “That’s me. I bet you’re wondering how did I get into this jam?”"
## [1] " It’s record scratch. Yeah, Ferris Bueller."
## [1] " Yeah, it’s like, “Oops, I created Bitcoin: The Book.”"
## [1] " That’s my general argument for it, which is essentially like if this was written like the whitepaper, I would say that it’s most likely fake, because who really writes that way? Nobody writes in that dense sort of way when they’re like, “Oh yeah, and then I met Hal Finney. Hal emailed me, and we had a,”-"
## [1] " “He’s a great guy.”"
## [1] " “I really liked him.”"
## [1] " Hal. It’s like clearly no one’s edited this."
## [1] " Yeah, but it seems like everything is kind of … It feels like somebody just wrote this down loosely, and that … Look, if some of the details are very specific, but the thing is, and ultimately I think what will send this all crashing down to earth is that all the details that are in there that seem like they might be revelatory, are things that can be easily cross-referenced and taken back."
## [1] " I don’t think that’s possible, but I think it’s a funny scenario. In that timeline, I guess Satoshi is in the Barbados, drunk on the beach writing this."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly."
## [1] " Has been living off of the massive proceeds, not of the pre-mined walled where nothing is ever moved, but some other secret wallet that has, say, 10,000 Bitcoin in it. Okay, there’s a few things that you have to at least make the case for me why this is true."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " I used to be a ghost writer. I worked in publishing, and then I was hired by the publishing company to write several business books. I think I’m a pretty good identifier of style. These are so clearly written in a different style that I’m not clear how this person could have written the whitepaper, unless they had help. There’s a weird level. I don’t know if you noticed this across the course of the document, but any time that there’s something where something new could actually be revealed, he’s like, “This will be in the book.” Anytime that there’s-"
## [1] " Yeah, but that’s called a tease."
## [1] " It’s a tease, but it’s like if you were really teasing the book, wouldn’t you want to throw people one bone that’s something that people genuinely did not know that is verifiable? Also, he seems to be writing this as if he’s responding to someone noticing all the flaws in it. He’s like, at one point he says, “I must admit though that I notice my style of writing has changed slightly in the years since. I don’t double space like before.”"
## [1] " It’s like have you seen that document, it was based off a David Grann story about that 30-year-old man in Spain who pretended to be a kidnapped 10-year-old?"
## [1] " Oh yeah, totally. The imposter."
## [1] " Imposter, yeah."
## [1] " Yeah, it has a little of that. It has a little bit of, “I know you’ll have problems with this story, but bear with me while I give you a concocted reason why all of them are irrelevant."
## [1] " Does that mean I’m right now the family that took in the 30-year-old and continued to believe that it was their long-lost child?"
## [1] " Yes. I think that is you. I’ll say to your credit, I do think when people are responding to criticism and a whole period where they’ve gone silent, they can come back kind of, “Blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah.”"
## [1] " Yeah. Guess what rich people do when they are rich and not doing anything? They look at the internet for people who are criticizing them and then they build up long lists of grievances against those people that are criticizing them. You wouldn’t think that’s true, but that is almost universally true."
## [1] " There’s a part where he talks about, he’s like, “I didn’t get all of my ideas into Bitcoin, like smart contracts. I wanted to include that.” It was like him preemptively being like, “Vitalik ripped me off.”"
## [1] " That also seems real to me. Okay, so for example, sports example, if you, in 1998 say, you were to read a transcript of Michael Jordan’s Hall of Fame speech in which basically it is a long list of Michael Jordan responding to people who criticized him and who he thought were his enemies. At the time in 1998 and throughout his entire career, Michael Jordan didn’t have any real enemies. This is a person who is constructing enemies and saying, “I vanquish all of you.” Would you have believed that that was really Michael Jordan? No way. You’d be like, “The Michael Jordan I know is a corporate guy. He’s very careful about what he says. He’s very likable. He’s the guy from Space Jam.” You would not think this is an unhinged person who basically is only motivated by spite."
## [1] " I’m going to follow you here and say what if this is real? If this is real-"
## [1] " I’m glad this is working."
## [1] " … why, if you’re Satoshi, do you go dark for the better part of a decade and then reappear in this manner? What would possibly motivate you?"
## [1] " Well, I can’t answer that question. He does answer why he went dark, which is that he was really worried about Bitcoin being destroyed, but also him personally being destroyed because he was correctly identifying it as a potential threat. I think that he is right, and you said this on the show before. It’s something that we talked to Saifedean about as well, which is that Saifedean always thought that Bitcoin wasn’t going to work, because he thought that they would just throw everyone in jail. Then once Silk Road happened and they didn’t throw everyone in jail, they just through DPR in jail, that he was like, “Oh, maybe this thing has legs.”"
## [1] " I don’t think the book exists. I think this is everything that exists of the book. This excerpt is not the product of someone who wrote a whole book and then wanted to put part of it online. This is like-"
## [1] " That’s true. That is true."
## [1] " … someone who wrote a long single-spaced Word document the day before something was due and sent it in as an unformatted email. It has sentences that don’t make sense at a sentence level."
## [1] " I’m not as concerned about the lack of editing. I’m more concerned about this idea that half of this post seems to be trying to explain why his writing style is so bad. But hey, who knows?"
## [1] " Here’s my biggest reason why I think this is not Satoshi. There’s 1,000 reasons, but this one is central, which is Satoshi developed an elegant, innovative system of trustless commerce where two people can both agree on something with voracity without a trusted intermediary third party. If he, Satoshi, was really coming back online now, I think that he would recognize that the audience would need a verifiable trustless piece of third-party proof to accept it. I think that the first thing he would do would be like-"
## [1] " That’s the biggest problem that you have with it?"
## [1] " Well, I think that the very first thing he would think was, “How do I think about this like a computer scientist, like a person who created Bitcoin? Why would I lead with 20,000 words of like, ‘I remember my old friend Hal Finney,’ when I could just post the keys at the front of it and prove it was me, and then explain the whole thing?” It just seems strange to back-load all of the truth."
## [1] " Yeah. No, I agree with that, but I-"
## [1] " Bitcoin is about don’t trust verify. This whole thing is very Joseph Smithy. It’s like, “Only I can look inside the hat.”"
## [1] " Okay, but to continue with my take, to respond to that as the believer, I would say that that type of confidence also makes me think that he’s real. He’s just like, “Fuck it, it’s me. Who cares if they don’t believe me?”"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " It might be that he is trying to do some huge reveal here. Here’s the other question I have, right? This was an anonymously created site called the Nakamoto Family Foundation, right? It was created on AWS, and suddenly it appears on Bloomberg and then everyone in crypto is talking about it. How was this found? If you type in Nakamoto Satoshi Bitcoin, there’s hundreds of thousands of pages of garbage. It’s not like somebody with a Google alert for Satoshi Nakamoto was going to get this. How was this found?"
## [1] " You know what’s another great historical corollary to this? Is the fake Howard Hughes autobiography."
## [1] " I don’t know, what is that?"
## [1] " Basically a journalist claimed that Howard Hughes had brought him into his inner circle and given a bunch of secret extended interviews to write a secret auto … This is during the final days of Howard Hughes when he was a recluse. This guy published, I think his name was Clifford Irving. It was ultimately debunked, I believe, by a woman that Clifford Irving was having an affair with was like, “He did not ever meet Howard Hughes. This is all totally fake.” He basically wrote a fake auto-biography and then sold it for a $2 million advance and published it, and it was totally bogus. But much like this, it’s probably more entertaining than an actual autobiography of Howard Hughes would have been. The actual autobiography probably would have been like this. It would have just been a bunch of fucking grudge settling, but it was like this vibrant, wild autobiography that Clifford Irving had largely strung together through publicly available information. He did a similar act, which is he took things that people already knew to be true and strung them together as if they were secrets."
## [1] " Okay. Here’s another similar corollary in the literary world, which is that nobody really knows if J.D. Salinger actually had books that he was writing for the 40 years that he was in seclusion. Some people think he didn’t do anything, and some people say that they saw vaults of books. J.D. Salinger has been dead five years now or six years, and nobody still knows. If some of these things leaked out and you said that this was a text of J.D. Salinger, there’s actually no way to corroborate whether it’s real or not, because the last thing that J.D. Salinger published was this thing called Hapworth 1924, which is an almost incomprehensibly bad story that does not resemble anything else that came before. It was because J.D. Salinger had gotten so into Mahayana Buddhism that the only thing he wanted to write about was Buddhism. The story doesn’t matter. There are no more characters. No character has any sort of motivation, except thinking about the Buddha. There’s no way I think reliably to say that this thing does not look like the thing that happened 10 years ago, and therefore it must not be real."
## [1] " Yes, I agree with that."
## [1] " Okay. That throws out a lot of the debunking that’s been going on right now, because people have already started on the internet, I did look into this a little bit, they’re trying to do matchup things with algorithms and things like that to say this writing style is not like the writing style that happened before."
## [1] " I think Craig Wright has tried to dispute the chronology of when he met the different early players, like Mike Hearn."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah, yeah, he said all the dates are wrong."
## [1] " Gavin Andresen, he was like, “No, Gavin was before Mike Hearn,” which I can’t comment on, but that would be one way you could criticize it."
## [1] " Mike Hearn is featured a lot in this, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Mike Hearn, who was one of the early people who worked on Bitcoin, Mike Hearn could just come out and say whether or not this was real or not, but as far as I know, Mike Hearn hasn’t commented on this at all. Is Mike Hearn a live?"
## [1] " Yeah, I think Hal Finney is the only person who’s not still alive."
## [1] " Well, that and the other guy who was a police officer who [crosstalk 00:52:17]."
## [1] " Yeah, the guy in Florida who would have been the Craig Wright partner."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Yeah. I was a little surprised by some of the tone. He says, “I want to state something that I’m sure Mike will agree with me on, and that is that Bitcoin started as most things do, a love, an idea, a dream.” That is not how I thought Satoshi would talk about Bitcoin. That is like some fast company, “How I did it,” kind of talk that’s like, “You’ve always got to believe in your dreams. When I came up with the idea of Bitcoin, lots of people told me it’ll never work, but I believed in myself.” That is not the tone of Satoshi, I feel pretty clearly."
## [1] " Okay, so here’s a followup question for you. All right, if this is Satoshi, and Satoshi now is this guy, what happens to the value of Bitcoin if people can confirm this is Satoshi?"
## [1] " Well, okay, I’m going to give a segue into that. This comments almost nothing on the entire period that Satoshi has gone dark, which is basically the public history of Bitcoin. This does not talk about the Bcash 4. This does not talk about price action. It does not talk about exchange manipulation. It doesn’t talk about Mount Gox. It’s basically got a black hole. You could say that’s all going to be in the book, but none of it’s here. It’s almost like someone wrote this intentionally to not talk about an entire period of time. As a result, and it’s an extremely un-ideological discussion, I would expect that a real Satoshi would be a little bit more like a Saifedean Ammous, someone who is deeply, deeply, passionately interested in economics and what Bitcoin has done for libertarian causes and for the cypherpunk causes. Really, that’s not very much in here. This is like a person who’s just kind of like, “It was such a cool project. It’s grown so much without …” It’s a very cheery take on the history of Bitcoin."
## [1] " I believe that that’s also maybe how the real Satoshi would sound."
## [1] " If you ask me what would the appearance of Satoshi do to Bitcoin, and this is actually Satoshi, just a guy who can write like an Ink Magazine, “How I made it as an entrepreneur in open-source software,” piece, I think that could be good for Bitcoin."
## [1] " That [inaudible 00:54:44] Bitcoin. They’re like, “Satoshi seems to be …”"
## [1] " This is kind of the Richard Branson take on Satoshi a little bit."
## [1] " I don’t know. Look, we should say that neither of us believe this is actually Satoshi. However, I think I’m much closer to believing that this is him than you are."
## [1] " I think if Satoshi wants Bitcoin to survive, he’ll never reappear. Everything I know about Satoshi has led me to believe Satoshi is a pretty smart, canny person who’s pretty careful. This does not seem like the actions of a canny, careful person."
## [1] " There are details in this that do seem like … Craig Wright says that these details are wrong, but Craig Wright also is a liar. There are ways that you can follow the trail of all of this. I do think that some people are probably doing it right now. I actually read a couple of them, but people tend to default towards the same things, like we were talking about, like trying to match the writing style, etc, etc, to debunk this. I actually think that’s a bad way to do it. I don’t think we’ll actually know the question of whether or not this is real or not. Right now, I’d say I’m about 2% I think this is real until the next excerpt comes out."
## [1] " That’s interesting. I generally think that a lot of the forensic techniques people use in these, like trying to match people’s writing is pretty flawed."
## [1] " Oh yeah."
## [1] " I would liken it to the blood splatter analysis in the staircase where it’s like yeah, there’s certain things you can read into it, but the idea that it’s one to one like DNA testing, it’s not. That’s not how these things work, particularly once you inject layers of editing over the top or if someone’s imitating an academic writing style. There’s just a lot of factors. I even think with the chronology, if I were to find out factually that he met Gavin Andresen before he met Mike Hearn, that would not dissuade me from believing this was Satoshi. This was all a decade ago. Do you remember exactly what sequence of your work history happened 10 years ago?"
## [1] " I remember almost nothing from 10 years ago."
## [1] " We’re talking about 2008. Jay, what were you doing in 2008, straight off, right off the top of your head, what were you doing?"
## [1] " I was surfing every day in San Francisco, and I was teaching a half-schedule at a private school, high school English. I think."
## [1] " I think I was ghostwriting then, but that could have also been 2009 or 2007."
## [1] " I literally have no idea, yeah."
## [1] " This may be, particularly if Satoshi has been drinking that sweet Barbados rum the whole time, he may have very little recollection. He’s like, “I don’t know. I started my computer mining. Who knows?”"
## [1] " I can’t even remember when we decided to do this podcast."
## [1] " Exactly."
## [1] " It was like a year ago."
## [1] " Is it also possible that Satoshi is not a crypto nerd and hasn’t been following along closely? If you just got super rich and you were like, “My whole idea was to make the software and the whitepaper. I’m not into day trading or anything like that,” you could actually imagine a scenario in which Satoshi is like, “I don’t really pay attention to Bitcoin anymore,” the same way former pro athletes, some of the guys who are like, “I used to be in the NBA,” and they’re like, “I don’t really watch basketball anymore.”"
## [1] " Hopefully very low."
## [1] " If I was Satoshi, my wife would still be like, “Shut up about the Bitcoin.”"
## [1] " It’d be like our wives."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly. There’s no reason to believe … Okay, who was Satoshi? He was 14 when he got into cypherpunk stuff. Okay, so that means he graduated, let’s say he graduated from high school around 1998, if that’s true."
## [1] " He’s my age."
## [1] " He’s your age. In 2008, he was 30-ish. He was a 30-ish working in academic programming, computer science, cryptography kind of stuff maybe. Okay, who’s that person married to? Probably not another cryptographer."
## [1] " Hopefully not."
## [1] " Probably someone in a university town, someone who works with the university or whatever. All of his contact about the Bitcoin project is online as his alter ego. At most, maybe a small handful of people he knows do this. Those people are probably not into Bitcoin. He may not have had a bunch of in-depth conversations with people who were really into Bitcoin. He probably doesn’t go to Bitcoin conferences."
## [1] " I would hope he doesn’t go to Bitcoin conferences. This I think is true. I think if Satoshi saw what the, for example, this Jack’s Liberty party on the yacht that was giving away the Aston Martins, he’d be fucking horrified."
## [1] " Yes, he’d be like, “I’m burning all of my private keys. I fucking want nothing to do with this. I’m so sorry for what I have wrought.”"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " He’d probably be like Oppenheimer talking about the atomic bomb. He’d be like, “After I saw the Jack’s Liberty cruise party, I decided to destroy Bitcoin.”"
## [1] " It’s like MacNamara talking about Vietnam."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Yeah, look, we did a very compelling case together as to why this Satoshi based-"
## [1] " I think you probably convinced me."
## [1] " … entirely on what you and I would do if we were really, really rich."
## [1] " I think the most, if I were looking for Satoshi right now, and we got to get Adrian back on the show and do another detective episode and see if he’s got any updates for us, because if anyone’s going to figure it out, it’s going to be Adrian. Thinking less about who was Satoshi when he made Bitcoin and thinking more about what has Satoshi been doing during the run of Bitcoin I think is an interesting way to go about it."
## [1] " Yeah, well that’s why I think the best bet for who Satoshi was was always a list of Hal Finney, Nick Szabo, Craig Wright way down, but the usual suspects. Then there’s a field bet, like somebody who we have no idea who it is. The field bet was probably the best chance of all of them. It is somebody who nobody actually knows who actually was able to secure their identity for a long time. That was actually the only reason I thought, when I first started thinking about the Dorian Nakamoto story, the Dorian Nakamoto thing kind of made sense to me, whereas, “Oh, well maybe it is just somebody who was completely random.” I still think that the best-"
## [1] " But that wasn’t someone who was random, because it was someone who had the same name as the person."
## [1] " Yeah, that’s true. That small detail."
## [1] " That’s what’s wrong about all these theories. It’s always someone that there’s something deeply wrong with. This scenario of a person who truly went dark and doesn’t even know about crypto, the best OPSEC, if you’re Satoshi, is to never even think about Bitcoin again."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah, and to not worry about it so that you don’t feel like you need to weigh in on things like the 2 X 4 where you’re like, “This might destroy my project, so now I have to weigh in.” You’re just like, “No, you know what? I actually don’t really even know what that is, so I’m not going to worry about it.”"
## [1] " The crazy thing is that if Satoshi is who we think they are, which is a cypherpunk born in 1978, they are probably professionally getting shilled Bitcoin all the time and are probably living as a fake nocoiner. It’s like, “Ah, Bitcoin won’t work.”"
## [1] " Maybe it’s Nouriel Roubini."
## [1] " Yeah. Is there going to be another except that comes out from this? Did they say anything about that?"
## [1] " I really hope so. When [Nirage 01:03:14], our friend sent this to us, I didn’t pay any attention to it. Then I started reading it. Then I was like, “Oh man, this is fucking weird.” That’s why I like it, because it’s weird."
## [1] " This is unofficially our next book club book."
## [1] " I think if it was more credible in the way that it was written, then I would believe it 0%."
## [1] " Yes. I’ll say that one thing we’ve learned over and over again from scammers in crypto and otherwise is that the best scam is not always the scam that tries the hardest. The Nigerian scam isn’t trying to reinvent the wheel with its copy. It’s the same broken English, “I am a prince. I need to get the money out. My family has gold bars,” story. There’s something powerful about doing things that way. There’s something powerful about this."
## [1] " Oh yeah, yeah. People are really shitting on Bloomberg for running with it. I don’t know. I think it’s interesting. If I was Bloomberg’s crypto editor, I might have kind of been like, “This 99% chance is not him,” but I think that’s all I would add. I think I would have run it. I wouldn’t have been like, “Oh, this is just another random crank.” I’d be like, “Hey, this is kind of interesting. Probably not him, but it’s worth looking at.”"
## [1] " I think the failed fiction writer and stunt enthusiast in me is a little envious that I didn’t think to write a fake autobiography of Satoshi Nakamoto. To imagine that Satoshi Nakamoto is toiling away at NC State or something, it’s a really fascinating person to imagine."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. Maybe our Bitcoin movie, we should go more art housey, and we should do-"
## [1] " I like it."
## [1] " … an adaptation type movie where we have … Have you seen that Woody Allen movie, New York Stories, which is seven separate small-"
## [1] " Yeah, yeah."
## [1] " Yeah, we could do something like that where it’s like seven different sketches of who Satoshi could be."
## [1] " I thought you were going more of like a Palindromes kind of thing where it’s seven different people play Satoshi at different stages in Satoshi’s story."
## [1] " We could do that too. Yeah."
## [1] " All these low-budget ideas I think are more achievable. We need to build up to the Mad Max, Scorched Earth Bitcoin dystopian movie."
## [1] " I don’t think so. I want to go-"
## [1] " With a few art house features to establish our reputation in the crypto movie making field."
## [1] " I don’t think that’s a good path, man. I think we’ll make a small art house Bitcoin Satoshi movie that will bomb terribly, and then we’ll be done."
## [1] " Cool. All right, well should we do another mail bag soon? We’ve been getting some mail bag."
## [1] " Yeah, let’s do a mail bag."
## [1] " Okay. Send us mail bag stuff. It’s hi@cointalk.show."

## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] " Hello Jay."
## [1] " Hey, how’s it going?"
## [1] " Very good. I just returned from the beach in your home state, North Carolina. Beautiful state."
## [1] " What beach were you at in North Carolina?"
## [1] " Figure Eight island."
## [1] " That sounds… is that in the outer banks somewhere?"
## [1] " It’s right outside of Wilmington, North Carolina. Michael Jordan has a house. Here are two people who have houses supposedly or at some point had houses on Figure Eight island. This is maybe like the weirdest Venn diagram possible, Michael Jordan and John Edwards."
## [1] " Ah, two of North Carolina’s finest."
## [1] " Only in North Carolina."
## [1] " Michael Jordan’s from Wilmington. So that makes sense."
## [1] " Exactly. This is the like rich people island right off of Wilmington. It’s like a gated island. I think I’m the only Jew who’s ever been on it."
## [1] " Did you get on because of your Bitcoin holdings?"
## [1] " What’s that? No, I got on a thanks to my Christian in laws."
## [1] " So a big pretty big week in crypto news, since we last spoke, felt like something popped up almost every day that I wanted to talk to you about, although none of those things popping up were the price of Bitcoin."
## [1] " I wanted to ask you, how do you get your Bitcoin news now? Because like I’ve, I’ve started to detox off of news-"
## [1] " You’re off Twitter."
## [1] " Yeah and so most of the news I get is through push alerts from random sites that I signed up for push alerts or by accident mostly. And I will say that if you intake Bitcoin news that way, all the news is bad. There’s like, no good news that way."
## [1] " I don’t know how it comes to me, we’ve got a few telegrams going that I’m in and you’re in with a few people and people post links on there and sometimes I feel like actually like, I don’t like the crypto twitter, but I’ll use even in the blockfolio app, it’s just got a little news feed. And it’s got a lot of bullshit on it, but usually if I scan through it I will eventually see the thing that interests me."
## [1] " Oh, speaking of blockfolio, some good news from crypto was the guy who won the world series of poker last night, who I believe is Korean-American, I looked at his twitter feed and unsurprisingly a lot of crypto, but he was wearing a blockfolio patch on one of the days and then he mysteriously took it off in the middle of the day."
## [1] " Jay, as a Korean American celebrity, one of the most notable Korean Americans around, do you feel like this guy knows who you are?"
## [1] " There is no way he knows who I am, but he actually knows Doug. Doug Kim, friend of the podcast."
## [1] " Now Doug, we were on telegram with Doug. Doug was at the world series of poker. I think he had already crapped out by the time I talked to him. But how deep did our friend Doug."
## [1] " Well, and for those who don’t know, Doug in 2006, which was the biggest year I think of entrants forever, maybe it was 2008, whatever the year was where they had the most entrants Doug came in sixth, I think, or seventh and won over $2 million. And so that started his poker and crypto journey. So he plays every year now and he kind of hates poker, which is, you know, reasonable. He also seems to hate crypto."
## [1] " That’s par for the course. I think that the love hate story of poker should be instructional to followers of crypto in that something that draws people in and is wildly addictive, doesn’t necessarily stay in their heart forever."
## [1] " Yeah. And also like if you do really well and make a lot of money in the first month, it certainly does not mean that you will continue to do that forever. So I think Doug, who is a good poker player, and who has been able to continue to make a living doing, I think he crapped out on the third day or something like that, which is pretty good."
## [1] " That’s pretty good. Yeah, I’d be very happy with that result."
## [1] " I think I would rather either make money or lose on the second hand because three days of playing poker for nothing is sounds actually horrible to me, but, you know, I bet it’s exciting."
## [1] " Well, we gotta get Doug back on the show because I want to take the temperature of the crypto talk at the World Series of Poker. Definitely seeing some patches, some crypto hats on display over there. And, I wonder what the sentiment in the room is about the next year in Bitcoin."
## [1] " One of the announcers for the World Series of Poker said that part of the reason that she thought that there are so many entrants this year, because there are a ton of entrants uh, was because crypto was down and people might be interested in poker again."
## [1] " Yeah, guys are trying to win back their tax burden."
## [1] " They’re like this crypto thing really didn’t work out for me now that it’s crushed down, bought too much at 16 thousand. So, I’m going to have to win the world series of poker."
## [1] " If there’s one thing that I know about degenerates, it’s that even if you win a major tournament, and you win that in Bitcoin and Bitcoin goes 20X, at that point, when Bitcoin goes back to 10C, you’ve probably over leveraged and are in some horrendous tax crutch or a have bought some kind of a boat. There’s just no way it ends well. It’s like winning the lottery"
## [1] " Yeah, what you just described is basically breaking even. Like that’s the break even point. Anything else and you’re down over a lifetime if that happens to you. All right. So, what are we talking about this week? There was a lot of news."
## [1] " I feel like the news that like, reached deep enough that it was like in the beach house dinner conversations was the revelations, the indictments of the 12 Russians associated with the hacking of the Hillary Clinton campaign and disclosures that a certain of the activities were paid for with Bitcoin."
## [1] " Yeah. Not surprising by the way."
## [1] " Well, I think the main thing that I heard sort of, and this echoed my thoughts is the surprising part is not the crypto payment. It’s the Bitcoin payment. We were expecting that Russian operatives would have already made the jump to Monero or ZCash."
## [1] " Well, yeah, I can’t tell if it’s good or bad for the privacy coins. Given that people don’t use them or don’t seem to really use them for these types of transactions, does it mean that they don’t work or does it just mean that Russian operatives don’t really know that there are better options and they don’t…"
## [1] " I read it more as, as like, you know, sometimes you’ll see someone who’s like a government like official. You’ll see someone in the FBI with a really clunky, they’re like on a blackberry, like a windows phone or something. I don’t necessarily think it’s because they think Zcash or Monero didn’t work. Remember we’re not talking about today. We’re talking about payments that were made during the presidential campaign…"
## [1] " In 2016, yeah."
## [1] " A couple of years ago, did you know about Zcash or Monero a couple of years ago?"
## [1] " No, no."
## [1] " Apparently neither did the Russian spying community."
## [1] " And at that time I don’t think that it was as obvious how transparent a Bitcoin transaction is. So yeah, I think that it probably, I don’t know, like what about this story was the most interesting to you? Because I will, I do agree with you that it was the biggest story of the week in Crypto, but I don’t know really how to take it because like, you know, we always try and process things. Is this good or bad for Bitcoin? I can’t tell which one it is."
## [1] " Well it’s kind of a weird one because what they were doing was not particularly nefarious, I mean hacking a presidential campaign is nefarious. But you know, registering a few websites and taking out VPN. These are the kinds of things you do like if you want to a download Game of Thrones via bittorrent and not get caught. Like you buy a VPN. And if you want to put up a website that’s like, waitwaitdon’ttellmesucks.com. And you don’t want it to be traced back to you, maybe you like, you know, you need to register a website anonymously."
## [1] " Certainly Bitcoin is useful in these kinds of transactions, but it’s not really a particularly big deal. You could borrow a VPN from someone or you know, steal a VPN registration from someone. Most of the stuff is like fairly pedestrian that they were doing with Bitcoin. It’s not like they were buying like black market uranium with it. They were registering a website called DCleaks.com."
## [1] " Yeah. And I don’t really quite understand how, like it was not a large amount of money, it was like $95 thousand that were laundered, the indictment says specifically the defendants “Conspired to launder the equivalent of $95 thousand through a web of transactions structured to capitalize on the perceived anonymity of cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin.” That could describe 95 percent of Bitcoin users. I guess I’m just not like, I’m not either shocked and are too concerned about this, you and I being Bitcoin moderates who do believe in Bitcoin. Like I don’t quite understand why this is some sort of terrible news."
## [1] " Well, okay. So there’s sort of, there’s a sinister tone to the New York Times story. I’m going to read a quote from it. “In early 2016, Russian intelligence officers obtained a new pool of the virtual currency, Bitcoin. They quickly put the digital money to work.” So when they say they obtained a new pool of it, that just means they bought some Bitcoin, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Like they didn’t like cook this up and like a secret lab."
## [1] " Yeah. That does make it seem kind of nefarious. Like it seems like somebody was trying to release something."
## [1] " Like maybe they already had the Bitcoin, I mean when they said what they did with the Bitcoin, I was like, that whole thing would cost like one Bitcoin. I mean now it would. I guess in 2016 we’re talking about like Bitcoin under a thousand dollars?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Anyway, I agree with you. There is nothing super notable about this story. If I were to draw anything that’s memorable about this, to me, it’s that these people were actually caught through Bitcoin. This was another example of Bitcoin being a terrible criminal currency in which the fundamental evidence that these people were involved in the hacking of the Hillary Clinton campaign is the Bitcoin immutable blockchain evidence. That they probably didn’t know about it in 2016 and now they’re like, oh, I wish I had read up more on how the blockchain works."
## [1] " It’s another feather in the cap for the hot take out there that Bitcoin is a honeypot that was created by the government to entrap people on the dark web."
## [1] " I don’t think that is true, but I do find the argument ultimately convincing that the truly libertarian privacy enthusiast will not be able to support Bitcoin in the long run unless it’s somehow remedies it’s anonymity issues."
## [1] " Yeah, and that’s something that [inaudible 00:13:06] and also Jamison Lop talked to us about, which is that at some point they will probably be able to put a privacy layer on it, but at that point you’re just like, well, there’s privacy coins. You know."
## [1] " So I, I think we both agree that this isn’t a story that particularly shifted the markets or public perception. I mean, except maybe it’s just another terrible mainstream Bitcoin story."
## [1] " Yeah. If anything, it pushed people more into the camp of believing that Bitcoin is only popular amongst reactionaries, Russian trolls, people who deal drugs and and steal people’s credit card information, but you know, the between the lines take of all this ironically enough is that if you want to do all those things, you shouldn’t use Bitcoin. And so, I don’t know, that might be a zero sum game."
## [1] " My favorite part about this story was the, I don’t know if you saw this, but in the indictment it says that they used fake names, the Russian officers, and two of the fake names are Ward Declore and Mike Long."
## [1] " I liked, there was a guy on the Russian World Cup team whose name was a [inaudible 00:14:16] There goes [inaudible 00:14:19]"
## [1] " They also had a Brazilian, like they’re running, you know, like Olympic style stuff where they’re having a Brazilian guy who had just gotten his Russian citizenship two years ago playing for the Russian team, which, you know, we don’t judge here, but, you know, certainly not Russian."
## [1] " Also in the news this week, big news out of Coinbase, I kind of took my eye off of this story. When we first got into to spending way too much time on Crypto, the question of what’s coming to Coinbase next. Nothing could have been hotter than this. And all of a sudden Coinbase announces that they are exploring adding five coins all at once."

## [1] " I got this from my self on Telegram."
## [1] " Aaron, please credit me next time."
## [1] " Thanks, I’ll make sure to note you as the curator."
## [1] " I thought it was a joke. Like I couldn’t. I thought it was fake or something. I couldn’t figure out if it was real or not because it, look, first of all, it goes against everything they said during the disastrous BCash launch, right? Where they said that they were going to give a lot of heads up and that they’re going to try and do these things a little bit more diligently that they didn’t want to have an undue influence on the market. And in response…"
## [1] " But I think they are doing that. They said they were telling people because of that, they’re like, we’re telling our employees right now, so we’re going to tell the public right now. I think they’re trying to answer your criticism, but there’s a weird way no matter what they do it always seems to be wrong."
## [1] " That’s my point, which is that like the idea that they don’t want to have an undue influence on the market and that they want to decrease whatever footprint that they have. They don’t want everyone to freak out and you know, like kind of look towards them to make a certain decision and speculate. Right? Like, the opposite of that has happened, right? If they were trying to figure out a way to solve this, this was not the actual solution, which was just to put out a tweet that says, maybe one of these five, you know, we’ll decide. We’re not going to tell you when, we’re not going to tell you what our methodology it is, but you know, just buy all five of these and probably one of them will spike."

## [1] " Can we just talk about what the five coins are?"
## [1] " Absolutely. How, it’s crazy that we’ve"

## [1] " Which is, but those two are pre-mine, huge volume coins-"
## [1] " Stellar Lumens from the founder, originally of Mt. Gox. Then a co-founder of Ripple, left Ripple on bad terms Started Stellar Lumens, huge gains over the last year. And the things they were always into was like XLM and [inaudible 00:20:01] you know, in the end I think they were probably right about XLM, because this is actually a huge boon for them."
## [1] " No one has actually ever shilled XLM to me. You have a slightly different work life than I do, but…"
## [1] " Well not anymore, but yeah."
## [1] " The other huge surprise is Zcash, I felt like there was a prevailing sentiment in crypto that was almost canon, that Coinbase would never add a privacy coin. I believe that’s a quote from young Kang. I mean, I guess we should have read Gemini pushing through Zcash as a sign that like Coinbase is probably going to look pretty hard at it, but I am still surprised."
## [1] " Yeah. Here’s my question to you as Mr. Privacy Coin, which is, I mean, do you think that, the fact that the two biggest US exchanges at least in terms of reputation, right, and backing, do you think the fact that both of them now list Zcash is meaningful?"
## [1] " I think it’s hugely meaningful. I think that these nerdy discussions about the different privacy algorithms at play in these are important, but not nearly as important as how available coins are through Fiat and the fact that you can go with a US bank account and end up with Zcash, I guarantee that the next Russia hacking style crypto scandal will involve a privacy coin and I predict it will be Zcash. Put that on your auger markets."
## [1] " We’ll get to that. But I was…"
## [1] " Too academic?"
## [1] " I don’t think it will, because I just think that Zcash, I don’t know, it just doesn’t seem like… if Monero is already working for a lot of these markets, which, I think that we have some evidence that it is, right. Why would you switch to the one that is in going to be higher publicity that’s going to have more scrutiny on it and that is going, that ultimately has not really proven that it can do at mass transfer yet. You know, like I think that Monero is still probably is the best out of all these coins and I think that actually being on two huge exchanges and having all this, having like a big guy like Zooko who is having magazine profiles written about him, et cetera, et cetera. I don’t know, if I was a criminal who was trying to launder money, I think that I would stay away from that one if the other options worked. You know, obviously you want to pick the best one, but what’s the evidence right now that Zcash works better?"
## [1] " Let me give you the counter example. Okay. So I’m a criminal. I’m selling the the synthetic [inaudible 00:22:34] from my Chinese super villain laboratory, or I’m in like the Philippines or somewhere like making all kinds of crazy synthetic drugs. And I offer them for sale on some kind of a dark market. And my primary customer base is in America. I mail the packages. So someone says, Hey, I want to buy x amount. And I say, great, you need to send me a payment. And they’re like, do you take bitcoin? And I say, absolutely not. Why would I take bitcoin? This transaction is going to be there forever. And you go, okay, no bitcoin. And I say, okay, well the best one’s Monero. And they said, well how do I buy Monero? And it’s like, Oh God, well I’m gonna have to tell this person to like buy bitcoin and then like an exchange account and swapping out Monero, versus you can just get a Coinbase account. You can just get a Gemini Account and by Zcash and complete the transaction, it seems like a big advantage."
## [1] " Yeah but what if the person’s like, Hey, uh, you know, that seems like a really too easy and open way. I’m putting my credit card number in this thing?"
## [1] " But you’re not putting it into Zcash, you’re like buying the Zcash, but like the transactions on the Zcash chain are invisible. So like, I dunno."
## [1] " Well, not all of them."
## [1] " Well I did my instructions on my dark web website. I’m like, make sure to check the box for a hidden transaction. I cannot emphasize this enough. No, it’s true. I agree."
## [1] " No, no, I mean, but when you buy it, like, you know, when you buy it off the exchange, I think that that probably is not a shielded transaction. If it was, you know, then that would be appealing. But I can’t imagine that these companies do that, you know, but I have no idea. And so I don’t know."

## [1] " Yeah, because they would get richer. I’m just talking about for use. Like you said, if the Russian operatives who were hacking into the election, if they had been around in 2018, I’m pretty sure they wouldn’t use Zcash. I just can’t imagine that they would use Zcash."
