Although probably like these are all just intertwined economies and in the long run I would expect these ERC20 tokens to move with Ethereum and probably just like, it’s better to ultimately hold bitcoin for most people. It’s probably better to just ultimately Ethereum if you believe in this whole Ethereum cult that’s going on. I mean, the other one is also basic attention token. Another ERC20 token, part of the brave browser."
## [1] " That’s the fifth-"
## [1] " That’s the fifth new one. He had already tipped that he was going to add support for ERC20 tokens. So I guess we shouldn’t really be like so shocked."
## [1] " Yeah. I don’t know. I mean I guess here’s my, this is my last question about this to you. I don’t really care if Coinbase adds these coins and I don’t think it’s going to have too much effect long term because I don’t know if the trading economy that was going on around this time last year and into the new year, so for about six months, like I don’t know if that really exists anymore, you know, the volume on all of these sorts of trades and all these coins is down so much and everything seems so pegged to bitcoin survival in the short term, short term meaning like the next six, nine months or something like that. That I don’t know. I just, even if they’re on Coinbase, I don’t… many people who downloaded a Coinbase and bought a small amount of bitcoin about like November of last year, how many of them are still checking the app and you know, trying to make trades and trying to make money off of this. You know, because that’s really who we’re talking about that would matter for Coinbase adding this and I don’t know, I guess I just don’t anecdotally know a lot of those people who are still involved in that sort of way, but I also just can see it in the volume charts."
## [1] " The volume is definitely not there. And also these bounces are not the bounces we’d expect to see what these coins getting added during a normal happy market cycle. Like we were seeing coins jumping 15 percent, like these bitcoin cash getting added. Even, I think this is a little bit closer to but not quite as much of a bounce as Ethereum classic got when it was added. So in some ways I feel like these, like he kind of did achieve what you described, which is like these aren’t actually trading on here and people aren’t actually jumping on them. There’s going to be another bump hopefully when they get added. But as you said, I think that’s mostly going to be dependent on what bitcoin’s doing."
## [1] " Yeah. Think about last, let’s say last January or something, Aaron. If ZRX had been added to Coinbase…"
## [1] " I think it could double in a day. I would have expected it to double."
## [1] " I think it would have gone up like 400 percent that day, you know, like I don’t think that that’s crazy because that really was the time when you had checked Bittrex and there are coins that had gone up like 940 percent and you’re just like, what the fuck?"
## [1] " Part of that is because a ZRX is a little bit more mature. It’s already run a bunch of times, on Bittrex and on these other exchanges. Like it’s a coin that’s done very well already. So I wonder if there’s not quite as much ceiling as there once was. But I think the lack of ceiling is mostly just because people are terrified because bitcoin is trading for $6300 right now."
## [1] " None of these coins really did do huge moon shots. Right? Like basic attention coin…"
## [1] " No, these were like, a lot of these were like 20, 25 percent bounces with five, 10 percent retraces. So like if you’re holding them, good. Also Zcash has always traded kind of weird, Zcash has always kind of failed to take off when people thought it was really gonna take off. I mean it does trade pretty high already. I feel like the mark…"
## [1] " You and I have been burned."
## [1] " Yeah we’ve been burned many times by Zcash and I guess the market saying that this isn’t like enough to like really change the situation, which is crazy. I would have [crosstalk 00:35:39], but the thing I was the most surprised not to see on this list was Augur."
## [1] " Yeah, me too. I mean, good segue. So why were you surprised not to see Augur."
## [1] " Augur is… this would be an amazing time to announce Auger because the Augur markets opened this week and there was a lot of attention on Augur. I think it shot up to being in the top five [inaudible 00:36:00] apps on the Ethereum network by daily volume pretty much right out of the gate. It seems like people are pretty excited about it. When you told me about it, I definitely was like, what questions are on it? What’s happening? It’s the kind of project that gets your imagination going, which is sorely needed, I would say at this point."
## [1] " Yeah. And this is something we’ve discussed quite a bit, but it actually interfaces with the exact thing that you and I think crypto in the short term should be focused on, which is gambling, you know, gambling prediction markets."
## [1] " I’m going to amend that to the short, long and [inaudible 00:36:36], which is, that’s the thing people actually want to do is gamble."
## [1] " Yeah. But right now what can crypto maybe handle? What can smart contracts maybe reasonably handle, like gambling, seems like one thing. Right? And so yeah, I was a little bit surprised as well, like it did seem like there was a lot of hype, but then I actually took a look at some of these prediction markets that they have. So for those who don’t know, a prediction market is essentially like a way of betting and you are essentially crowdsourcing an opinion and you can bet for or against that as the line moves up or down. And so for example, if you think that like, leading up to the election, basically if you thought that Donald Trump was going to win, you could go on a prediction market and you could put a be in, and you would get amazing odds because Hillary Clinton’s chances of winning were valued somewhere around, I think like 92 cents to the dollar. Maybe there’s a little bit less than that, but it’s like an odds maker essentially."
## [1] " Yeah. And that plays into the general crypto world belief that smart open markets can answer any question and can efficiently find the perfect line. And that if we just open ourselves up to them, we can almost read the future. I mean, people actually believed that we’d be able to predict terrorism and events like that through prediction markets."
## [1] " That’s how it started. Prediction markets started because DARPA decided to create a prediction market. And"
## [1] " Decided to created a prediction market, and their only question was, where will the next terrorist attack be? And their belief was that, somebody would eventually be financially incentivized enough to put a lot of money into the place where they knew it was going to be, and that it would be some sort of tell into what was actually going to happen, that obviously was stopped for several ethical reasons. Prediction markets are pretty easy to find now, I mean, you can find all sorts of them here that you can do legally in the United States. So, it’s not like Augur is a particularly new idea, but it supposedly was gonna get around the biggest problem of prediction markets which is that it is gambling, and so it’s illegal. And so all prediction markets in the United States have to basically have a .edu address, or have some sort of affiliation with a university."
## [1] " Do you ever go to a place, and they would ask you to use your student ID, or there are certain deals you have to set up where you have to have a .edu address. That’s kind of what a prediction market is. It needs to have some tie to a university. And also the charge on these things is insane, so to withdraw money I think they have like a 5 to 10% chop on the money that you try to withdraw out of a prediction market which, you know, kind of kills your odds immediately. So they’re very hard to win."
## [1] " There’s one other major difference between a traditional prediction market and this, which is that users themselves can set any question into offers."
## [1] " Yeah, there are versions of that that exist, but they’re not legal, so. The decentralization of this kind of makes it better in the sense that you can bet almost anything. Like Aaron, you and I could have made a Augur prediction market that was like, will this podcast recording take over an hour or something like that."
## [1] " Right. I mean, we’d have to find a taker on the other side for it to actually create a contract."
## [1] " I mean, you and I could take opposite sides."
## [1] " Oh I see, I see. And then you just start grandstanding and trying to push it over and hour."
## [1] " Yeah, and you’ll be like, I actually have the button that makes this stop recording."
## [1] " I’d be like, oh, can’t hear you, talk later, bye! There’s a few things that surprised me, I mean. When you go on it, there’s not actually a way to access it unless you’re, I believe, running an Ethereum node. Or you can run the software for it. But someone made a web GUI for it. What is it, something like global.predictions or something?"
## [1] " Predictions.global."
## [1] " Predictions.global. So this allows you to visualize the biggest best on the Augur network."
## [1] " Yeah. So I’m gonna read a few of them to you. Have you looked at the percentages of these?"
## [1] " Yeah, the lines seemed really wrong."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. So for example, the first one is, will the price of Ethereum exceed $500 at the end of 2018? 52% say yes, and that there’s 72,000 at stake."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Apparently, so then there are ones that you’d expect that are more exciting like World Cup Final, France versus Croatia, resolved after 90 minutes. Augur predicts that 50% France wins. I mean, that’s a terrible line."
## [1] " Okay, so let’s pause here, because you’re a more experienced gambler than I am."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " The first thing that looks fishy there is, that would suggest that France and Croatia have even odds. And every line I saw in any kind of a sports book has France heavily favored."
## [1] " Yeah, France is heavily favored, so if you are a smart better, than what you will do is you will bang France on this line, because you’re getting a much better price."
## [1] " Right."
## [1] " So what that indicates is two things. The first is that it’s kind of exciting, which is you can get it on early betting and you can profit from it, right."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " But the thing that is more concerning is that the second that you and I and everybody else that’s seen the action line bangs France on this, the line adjusts, you know. As it’s supposed to."
## [1] " Right, but aren’t you locked into the line though, when you bet?"
## [1] " Yeah, you are, but I mean the line changes for the next person. The handicap shifts."
## [1] " Right. And it should get better and better over time."
## [1] " It should get closer and closer to the real odds, but the weird thing is that this, it just didn’t shift at all, which means either nobody is using this, and nobody actually made these bets, although it says that $27,000 are at stake. Or it means that something’s broken. And that it’s not just reflecting anything."
## [1] " Well, even though this is a top five D app, when they actually show the volume, the daily volume use, there’s only 330 address or something like that that are being used, so this is not a large enough pool to get anywhere close to real lines, especially with the weird crypto ish questions, which I’m like, if Ethereum exceeds $500, I’m like … it does suggest a pretty crazy future in which you can create futures on anything, on any coin, on any crypto position, by asking and letting it zero in here. But it seems like we need thousands if not hundreds of thousands of betters to really get full coverage, enough to be accurate for most of these questions, because there would be a lot of questions at that point also."
## [1] " Yeah, well. There’s two theories about this. The first is that you are right, and that things need a certain volume. But for specific questions that get no volume, for example, not who will win the World Cup but something like, the number 4 question here which is, will MedCredits release Hippocrates medical app on Ethereum mainnet by October 15th, 2018? Shockingly, Augur predicts that 85% say yes, right. So what does that tell you. It just tells you that somebody that is involved in the MedCredits Hippocrates medical app created this market and put all the money on it for some reason, right. Hoping that someone would take the other side so that they could profit off of it. So in that way, that is more telling, because you can almost certainly trace it to somebody who’s involved with that market. But I would say that something like France, or the popular ones, like will Donald Trump be the president in 2021. Those types of things you need some sort of volume for it to be interesting at all."
## [1] " The final two, the number 29 and number 30 questions are, will Donald Trump be impeached before the end of his first term? 30% yes. Will Donald Trump complete his first term as President of the USA? 90% yes. These things are not even being matched with each other. So, look. This is in a very rudimentary state. I almost feel goofy trying to critique it because it’s obviously not fully working yet, and I think that the developer Joey Krug who’s behind it was like, yeah, there’s some problems, what do you expect. This is a rough launch, you know."
## [1] " There are tons of things that launch better than this. My favorite one is number 11, which is will the REP token — REP token being the, I believe that is the currency of Augur, right. Will REP token trade above $32 at the end of 2018. Augur predicts 90% yes. I mean, I will just say this. As a gambler, as somebody who likes prediction markets, as somebody who is into crypto and would rather use Ethereum to bet honestly, than giving my credit card over to any number of shady offshore places. This is exciting, but man, this is not a good launch. It could have gone a lot better."
## [1] " So, you’re a gambling man. It’s well known, it’s discussed on this show. All of these bets are paid out in Ethereum. So despite REP being the token of Augur, these bets, I assume that you put Ethereum into escrow, and then at the end of these terms, which like in the case of the World Cup would be today. In the case of that Donal Trump question would be in a couple years. There is a system which users vote on which side was right using the REP tokens as some sort of a staking-"
## [1] " Wait, really?"
## [1] " Yeah, that’s how it works. And then it pays out."
## [1] " Oh, so like basically, you have to use a REP token to vote on whether or not something that happened, happened?"
## [1] " Yeah, and you earn REP by saying the right one. So it’s almost like, 51 percenting. And bitcoin."
## [1] " Who audits whether or not it’s the right one?"
## [1] " Well, it’s like the majority of users. More and more users vote on it, and it figures out using some sort of a smart way. Look, I don’t really know. But the surprise to me is I always thought, I’m a REP holder, I hold a little bit of REP. That REP would in some way be used in the settlement. I was completely wrong, the settlement is all in Ethereum. Which is, for real, and will probably be worth more in the two years or in the long run as these bets play out. Would it make sense for us, and I mean you, because you’re the gambler among us. To go in, hunt, and pack, and find some of these ridiculous lines, and lay a little Ethereum on it? Especially if they’re ones that are gonna resolve fairly quickly."
## [1] " Yeah maybe, but I don’t think it would be wise to do a lot, because we don’t know what the future of the project is. And so the biggest problem with betting really on anything strange or anything exotic is that, it’s hard to get your money paid out, you know? And so, there are all sorts of books out there that advertise better vigs than other books, but at some point you’re more willing to pay an extra 2% because you’re confident that you’ll get paid out than-"
## [1] " Absolutely."
## [1] " 72% and not knowing what the hell you put your credit card information into."
## [1] " I would certainly be worried when I see, will Serena Williams win the Wimbledon 2018 Women’s Tournament, it says it ends in 21 hours."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " That’s already resolved. So I’d be a little bit worried about weird after hours — I don’t quite understand how this stuff works. That said, looking at some of these lines, if you did go bold and bet on them, you could make a pretty good amount of money."
## [1] " Yeah no, I agree with that, I just feel like I think a small controlled about is the right way to go about it, and just hope that Augur works. And then eventually these kinks are fixed. I actually think that they will be, I think that this product will probably work eventually, I just think that at this point, going around, hunting around with Ethereum. And also apparently one of the problems here is that to make the transaction work, you have to pay gas, which is the Ethereum tax to make something happen. Apparently the gas fees are pretty high, and so you might actually do better just going to a normal prediction market, you know. Because depending on the gas that you’re basically paying as a tax in every single bet, it might actually be worse value than just going to a established prediction market that you know at least you’ll get paid out on."
## [1] " Yeah, but these lines are just radically wacky. Like, okay for instance. Will Ethereum trade above $500 in July 2018. So that’s the next two weeks, more or less. That means — and the line is 75% yes. That means to take Ethereum-"
## [1] " What’s Ethereum at right now?"
## [1] " It’s at like, four hundred something dollars. It’s not that close. Here, I’m gonna look it up right now. Right now, Ethereum is trading at $449. So that’s saying that you can give me four to one, that Ethereum won’t go up $50 in the next two weeks? I’ll take that. In a second."
## [1] " Yeah, I would take that too."
## [1] " Very good, fantastic."
## [1] " Actually, you’ve convinced me, let’s do this."
## [1] " Yeah, let’s grab some Ethereum off of people, that’s fantastic."
## [1] " Isn’t it impossible to get money in in these markets, though? I mean, you and I do not, we don’t run an Ethereum node."
## [1] " I don’t know, we haven’t tried."
## [1] " Do we run, do you run an Ethereum node?"
## [1] " Okay, if you’re listening to the show, and you can set us up an Ethereum node so we can take some of these bets, I think we should go through and cherry pick the worst bets here. I also think, will the REP token trade above $32 at the end of 2018? 90% yes. That means to take no, which is basically just that it’s gonna go down, is ten to one? I’ll take it."
## [1] " Yeah, I would take that too. Yeah. Huh. Yeah, actually you’ve convinced me. I don’t have any Ethereum, but-"
## [1] " I’ve got some Ethereum-"
## [1] " It’s gonna take me two days to figure all this out, but maybe we should do it. Let’s do it and see what happens for the next show."
## [1] " Look, if you’re listening to this show, send us an email, and tell us how you can help us make some of these bets. They’re not financial advice, in fact we’re saying they are terrible bets, which is why we want to take them. I think we want to get in while it’s early on some of these. I feel like it’s like the rare Pepe cards, you know. The first people to buy in get a good one, and sell them to the next sucker down the line. Because that’s another thing you can do, with Augur. Is you can lay a bet, and then sell that bet to someone else."
## [1] " Yeah, prediction market works that way, in which you get it at 50 and then it moves to 90, and then you can sell at 90, right. You can sort of take your profits whenever you want. Which I think is cool."
## [1] " I feel like we should scoop up some of these Trump to win second term bets, and then just resell them in a few weeks for more."
## [1] " I mean, I think he’s gonna win again, so which side would we take?"
## [1] " I don’t even care which side, I’m gonna look at whatever the line is, and I’ll take whatever the obviously better side is. Like for instance, will Donald Trump complete his first term as President of USA? Augur predicts 90% yes, that’s ten to one that he doesn’t. I don’t know if I like that, actually."
## [1] " Yeah, I think he’s definitely gonna finish his first term, don’t you."
## [1] " Yeah. No, not definitely, if you give me a hundred to one, I’m all over it."
## [1] " Yeah, ten to one is not a hundred to one."
## [1] " I’m just saying, there’s a point to some of these. I would just cherry pick the lines and work up."
## [1] " Yeah, let’s do this."
## [1] " And the longer term one."
## [1] " I mean, I do not want to buy Ethereum, but maybe I’ll borrow some of your Ethereum, let’s do it."
## [1] " So you can post one of these questions without actually putting up money, and then other people would put money into it. So if you go far enough down, you start seeing the questions that no one has put money on. Here’s one, number 42, will Warren Buffet die by the end of 2019."
## [1] " Oof. I don’t want to answer that."
## [1] " The other thing you can do is lay some uneven ones here, and then try and stake our spot on some of these. Like, no one has bet yet on who will win the next Superbowl."
## [1] " Actually, I see an answer on that, which is Eagles."
## [1] " Some of these are double posted, too."
## [1] " Yeah. I see one that has no money, will Chelsea win the English Premiere League in 2018/2019. And there’s no money in any of that. So I don’t know, it seems like there are questions that have answers that already have betting answers. Like that for example, you can definitely go see what Chelsea’s actual odds are, and you can bet it both ways and you can see which way it swings, and you can get in and you can get out. And so, in some ways that’s attractive in the sense that you have a very, very virgin prediction market that you can manipulate. But at the same time, I don’t know if you and I are the sharks to do that, you know? We might be the ones that are being taken advantage of. But yeah, I don’t know. This is interesting. Maybe we should have Doug on, and we should tell Doug that we want to do those, and have Doug do it too."
## [1] " Yeah, let’s have Doug on. I say that we put one Ethereum in on behalf of the show, and just buy up whatever the dumbest contracts we can on here."
## [1] " Okay, let’s do it."
## [1] " Alright, cool. Well, talk soon?"
## [1] " Yeah. All right. Talk to you soon."
## [1] " All right. See you later."

## [1] " Yeah, this is the closest we’ve done in recording in a long time."
## [1] " This is a rare Coin Talk tutorial session."
## [1] " How’s the Crypto Cave doing after the recent flooding events?"
## [1] " The Crypto Cave is on a flood plain. You know where you’re uninsurable, you’re gonna flood again, you need to move off of this bayou?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I’d say that’s basically the status of the Crypto Cave."
## [1] " It’s like real estate in Coastal Long Island right now."
## [1] " I Googled the best mop for floods. Because I decided I needed a flood mop.."
## [1] " What’s the answer?"
## [1] " No one … they don’t make a flood specific mop."
## [1] " The only way that I could see that a mop would be made for floods if it was really big."
## [1] " That’s basically what I was asking."
## [1] " Here Google, hey what is the biggest possible mop?"
## [1] " Comically large mop."
## [1] " You need to go to a prop store or something like that."
## [1] " So, last time, last episode, you and I talked a little bit about Augur."
## [1] " Yeah, in an episode which was full of misinformation, we should say."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I think that we have a good justification for the misinformation."
## [1] " Personal incompetence."
## [1] " Well more that like, you and I approach this show in a we are the average consumer."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " We are the average crypto consumer, and we will do an average amount of research into these things."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Sometimes we do more than average-"
## [1] " Sometimes we’re a B minus. Sometimes we’re a C minus."
## [1] " Yeah, we’re never a solid B."
## [1] " We’ve never received an A."
## [1] " We dipped into the F plus."
## [1] " We’ve had a couple Fs. Look this stuffs confusing."
## [1] " I think that my justification for it would be like look, if Augur wants to launch and if it really wants to be what it’s worth and it wants to put out a product which is rare in Crypto, that product should be easy to understand. I don’t think that we were approaching this as full noobs. We understand here I see twenty tokens, we understand Ethereum smart contracts. And we understand-"
## [1] " We’re very experienced at gambling."
## [1] " Yeah, we understand gambling and prediction markets. And so if we couldn’t figure it out after a few hours of reading about it, then I would just say that that’s Augur’s fault and not our fault."
## [1] " I’m gonna take the other side here, which is Augur’s brand new, just launched and I take this product the same way I take Crypto as a whole, which is, you can think about it, talk about it, read about it, you don’t really have a full impression until you try it. Until you actually buy coins, hold coins, and in this case of Augur, actually download Augur get it going, have the experience. It’s almost like there’s a way it’s described and there’s a way that it actually is. I found that way it actually was much more interesting than how it had been described to me."
## [1] " Okay but what if Blizzard put out a game right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And there are no instructions to the game, and you couldn’t figure out really how to download it and then there was a ton of misinformation about the game. And there was no attempt from Blizzard to differentiate between real and fake information?"
## [1] " But this is almost like what games were like in the Pong era or whatever. Or like when I was trying to-"
## [1] " I’m pretty sure that we can figure out Pong."
## [1] " I mean, that we’re in the infancy. Remember how hard it was to run Leisure Suit Larry on DOS?"
## [1] " No"
## [1] " Jay, you know what I’m talking about."
## [1] " C:// run-"
## [1] " Run.exe. So I decided that I would give Augur a run, and for people who are interested in doing this at home, we chose this project because it appealed to us and we wanted to give it a try. I went into this, I didn’t read the instructions, there didn’t seem to be instructions. So the first thing you do is you just download Augur. It’s an app for Mac, Windows, Linux. A quick download."
## [1] " Okay, and just for those who are listening who don’t know about it. The two second explanation of Augur is that it was one of the hottest Ethereum apps or Ethereum ideas in companies in coins that came out early on. The people who made it became pretty wealthy, I think they’re part of the Crypto community in Puerto Rico now?"
## [1] " I think Joey Krug lives in San Francisco."
## [1] " Okay but they’re in one of the rich Crypto houses."
## [1] " Yeah, and I believe that Joey Krug who’s behind the project is also part of a fund and has been involved in other-"
## [1] " Yeah, no shaming of them for that. But just to show that this is not a small project."
## [1] " This is a very hyped up project. And I think it’s also a project that for the layman, for the noob out there who’s not into Crypto, it’s easy to explain why this might be an interesting idea. You can create, ask any question, and create a market for it. And anyone can come gamble on that market."
## [1] " Yeah, so we could ask, will Coin Talk be around in 2019?"
## [1] " Right. Will Donald Trump be elected to a second term? That’s currently-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So that’s the kind of stuff people would be asking on here. So you download it, and then you have to choose a network. Now, I’m going to tell people here, you can choose a bunch of networks including a couple of test nets here."
## [1] " You have to pick a network?"
## [1] " Yeah, you have to pick a network."
## [1] " Is that like a blockchain that you-"
## [1] " Yeah, yes. I’m going to get there, I’m going to get there."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " So, I recommend that you pick the main net. I tried it on a couple of the test nets, and I wasn’t actually able to get the live data, I was only able to get the questions. So, if you go to main net, you connect through a service called Infura. Infura.io. You’ll see the HTTP endpoint is mainnet.infura.io. So, when Augur was first coming out, people were like, you are going to have to run your own Ethereum node in order to run Augur. This is not totally accurate. You can use this service called Infura, which it is a centralized node, but they kindly give you access to it. However, once you choose the main net, you have to click update connection and it will sync the Ethereum chain to your local installation. Currently our good friend Ledger Status who will be on the program later, is sitting there waiting until his node syncs. Jay, I’ve done you the great courtesy of syncing this node before he arrived in the-"
## [1] " Oh yeah, it’s like a cooking show where you already put the stuff in the oven."
## [1] " Okay, so this story started a few hours ago. When I synced the node. I think it took me half an hour to an hour or so. I don’t have great wifi here. It’s a clunky, slow antiquated way to do things, but it’s a window into how things are going to work on the blockchain. Which is, in order to interact with the Ethereum block chain, you’re going to have to sync it."
## [1] " You have to download software and sync it."
## [1] " Directly or through Infura. I understand that lots of people who are decentralization purists would say that it’s not that great to use a service like Infura, but okay we’ll come back to that."
## [1] " Okay, so, this is not on video, but we have been staring at the number 99.9% for about a minute now."
## [1] " Say that it crawled up into the high 90s and after it got there, it gave me the option to open the Augur app, so I guess you don’t have to be at a full 100%. But once it gets up to about 99.9, look at the button that says open Augur app. That becomes lit once it’s ready to go. So I’m going to click that, and what it does is it opens Augur in your web browser."
## [1] " Oh."
## [1] " So, we’re now connected to the Ethereum block chain, but we’re in the web browser. And I’ve two option here, I’ve got markets and I’ve got account. Without actually making any kind of account, or putting any money in or anything, you can go and look at all these markets. If you want to make markets or place wagers, you need to click account. Once you’re in the account tab, you basically need to sync it up to some kind of a wallet."
## [1] " It’s the same service that was used for Cryptokitties."
## [1] " Yeah, and Shape Shift is kind of similar if you’ve used it before. They support Metamask, Ledger, Tressor and Edge. I just happened to already have a Metamask going here, so I’m going to connect Metamask."
## [1] " Okay, so we’re five clicks in so far."
## [1] " I think we’re doing pretty well-"
## [1] " We’re doing pretty well-"
## [1] " … at keeping our clicks down."
## [1] " … and I gotta say, as a person who doesn’t care as much about logos and UX as you do, it looks kind of nice."
## [1] " It’s pretty slick."
## [1] " It’s like a very pretty purple-"
## [1] " If you tell me this was a successful new application start up out of San Francisco, I would not doubt you."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Okay, so now I’m logging into my Metamask account. Now, I’ve gone to the liberty, Jay, of popping a couple ETH into my Metamask account so that we would be fully funded-"
## [1] " Okay. Great."
## [1] " … when we got here. So let’s go check out the markets."
## [1] " So at this point we are ready to make our first yes no bet in prediction market."
## [1] " So if you click over to markets, I believe they’re sorted by popularity. So the most popular market’s at the top. This has been the most popular market since launch. I now see that it has moved a bunch today."
## [1] " Yeah. So the way that a prediction market works, for those who don’t know, is that the question is, “Will the price of Ethereum be over $500 by the end of 2018?” And you bet on it. There’s a price that comes out. Yes right now, is what 70-"
## [1] " Well it’s weird, it’s putting it at 70 because that’s the median between the best bid and the best ask."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So the bid is 63 and the ask is 84-"
## [1] " Okay, so well let’s call it a 70-"
## [1] " Okay call it a 70."
## [1] " … the way this works is that if you believe Ethereum is going to be higher than 500 by the end of 2018, then you say yes, and if you get that price at $0.70, you have 1 share at $0.70 and if it is over $500 at the end of 2018, that $0.70 becomes $1. So you get 30%, so you’re basically 1 to 2.6 or whatever."
## [1] " Okay, for people who’s primary reference here is sports gambling, basically, if you think Ethereum is going to be over $500 at the end of 2018, you can bet 7 to win 10, and if you think it’s not, you can bet 3 to win 10."
## [1] " Yeah, that’s a … and the difference between a prediction market like Augur and sports betting is that you can sell your shares at any time, which is actually a … because when you make a sports bet, it’s locked in. If you buy it at $0.30 to say no, right, so 3 to win 10, and Ethereum takes a huge tank and the price shifts to like 50/50, you can sell it at that. You’ve make a 70% profit, you can sell it at that profit. Right there."
## [1] " And simultaneously, if you bet the no, and you’re like wow, Ethereum is already over $1,000 and the line is now instead of 30%, 15% you could lose half of your stake there and sell it off then."
## [1] " Those are the basics. Obviously these types of markets exist in the United States, I think we talked about it last time on the show. But for those who weren’t listening, you can do this very legally in the United States, it’s not really considered gambling because it’s seen as academic research."
## [1] " How is that academic research?"
## [1] " Because it’s basically tied loosely to Political Science departments-"
## [1] " But you can put money on it?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So I can go put money right now, legally in New York City on whether Donald Trump will win the next election?"
## [1] " Yes. For sure."
## [1] " Really? Online?"
## [1] " Yes. Online it’s all legal."
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " The problem with prediction markets is that they have very high costs of withdrawal, which is what they do instead of charging a vig, which is what a sports book would do. They charge a withdrawal fee which, I don’t remember what the percentage is, but it’s something that is completely prohibitive. And you have to be really good to beat that fee. The appeal of a decentralized prediction market is A that you can come up with any question that you want and get people to bet on it which is great, and that you don’t have the withdrawal fee outside of whatever you’re paying for the gas for the Ethereum network."
## [1] " Last week we talked about predictions.global, which is basically a web interface for Augur, in which you don’t need to be logged in, you don’t need to do anything. You can just look at the predictions. It does not, I will say, have nearly as rich information as actually being on Augur. You can see stuff once you’re actually on Augur, like the volume of shares here-"
## [1] " This is for will Ethereum be over 500 at the end of 2018."
## [1] " Yes, 1400 shares. So that, each share represents one ETH."
## [1] " Okay so-"
## [1] " So that means 1400 ETH is what’s been wagered."
## [1] " Which is about at this point like 7-"
## [1] " $642,000."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Okay? So, it’s a pretty good amount of money. Once you start getting into other markets on Augur, you’ll quickly find that there’s almost no shares and no volume. But this seems to be the topic people have most closely grabbed onto. And also, I think this is going to be really interesting to look at, not so much now, because it hasn’t been up very long, but you can basically look at what this question has been trading at at various historical periods."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " So, it looks like the percentage chance that ETH will be over $500 at the end of 2018 has been going up, starting closer to 50/50, creeping up to 70% now."
## [1] " Oh wow, so it started out at 50/50?"
## [1] " Yeah, well it’s a little hard, there’s so little volume you can’t really see where it is here. You can also see what the market depth is, looks like right now, it’s kind of stuck between .8 and .6. there’s a lot of buy interest at .6 and a lot of sell interest at .8. that’s for the yes market. There’s really like a full order book here in which you can see."
## [1] " Yeah. That’s because there’s not much volume. As there’s more volume, the price will become more normalized, I think."
## [1] " Okay, so I’m a little confused Jay, you understand stuff a little better than I do. The only outcome listed here is yes. So if I want to put a no in here, then I sell the yes position?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Okay, so you can sell something that you don’t have."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Unlike in a Crypto portfolio."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " So if I want one share in no, I sell one share."
## [1] " Yeah and look, this is an extremely confusing way in which they’ve done this. If you go on places like predict it, you just click yes or no and then it does it for you."
## [1] " I assume that they will make this UI more friendly to the amateur gambler as time-"
## [1] " Yeah. I mean, saying yes or no is not that difficult to put. But maybe we should have a no button. But yeah-"
## [1] " They also have multiple choice markers-"
## [1] " Sure. But you would think that putting no would make it a little bit easier, but I mean, we don’t have to complain about that right now."
## [1] " So, another thing here, is they show you what the fee is. This fee is not the gas fee, the gas fee that you pay to Ethereum is on top of it. When I was trying to make new markets, the fee was about $1.70. This fee is a percentage based fee, which goes to the creator of the market and those who report on the outcome of the market to ensure its veracity."
## [1] " Oh okay, so this is like, for example in the futures bets on some of the more exotic online sports books for a while there was a bet on whether or not Danica Patrick and Aaron Rogers would break up by the end of 2017, I think it was?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And the terms for it was that, the break up had to be reported by TMZ."
## [1] " Oh okay."
## [1] " Yeah, so like instead of that, it seems like what Augur has done is created an incentivized democratic way of litigating whether or not this is true?"
## [1] " Yeah, and my understanding is that you can actually earn the native token of Augur, REP, Reputation by backing the right side. So if 100 people report on an issue and 98% of them are on one side and 2 are on the other side, then resolved to the 98 side and all 98 of those people get some small REP stake."
## [1] " Okay, here’s a question then. Let’s say that you and I put 15 ETH into this bet, which is more than you or I have, but let’s say that we’re heavily leveraged into this bet."
## [1] " Jay do we have to put in 15 ETH for our very first bet? You degenerate."
## [1] " Why couldn’t we just … and we have like 500 friends who are also betting this market at a certain price, why couldn’t we just, even if it doesn’t go over $500, why couldn’t we just vote the wrong issue? Or the wrong outcome as the outcome?"
## [1] " This is how I understand it to work, none of this is investment advice. It’s also not gambling advice. It’s not legal advice."
## [1] " Also we don’t have 15 Ethereum, so please don’t try and-"
## [1] " It’s not advice about how to get the REP token by reporting incorrect answers on Augur. So I think it works sort of like a 51% attack. You actually, the people who are putting, you stake your own REP when you say what the outcome was. All of the people, once it becomes a majority, they, the people who picked the right side, steal the REP from the people who were repping the wrong side. So if you and your friends got together and tried to brute force the untrue outcome, an even larger group of Augur people could come on and put in the right outcome and they would then win your REP because they were right. If you have the 51%, good man. But that’s kind of generally how all Crypto stuff works, is if you can get a large enough pool of people to try to defraud it, you could do it."
## [1] " So, like we’re dealing with extremely metaphysical questions about truth-"
## [1] " Yeah, yeah."
## [1] " If you get enough people to say that something is not true, that is true and you have money on it, then you can actually make that the actual outcome-"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " … as it relates to this specific bet."
## [1] " But, this is an interesting topic which is, I had always thought, have you owned the Augur token?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Okay, I own some Augur, some REP. I thought that I would be betting with that REP. Not true. All of the bets are made and settled with Ethereum, REP is only used in this verification rewards system."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Which brings up a question I want to ask later when we have our good friend Ledger on, which is, why is the REP token going to go up in value if this is popular?"
## [1] " Yeah that’s a good question. Like all ERC tokens, it seems like they were a little bit vague about what it actually did at the beginning and what it actually does is it facilitates actions within inner layer things within the product. Which is how most ERC pointed tokens actually work if you look at the use case for it. Not that compelling to me, I’ve got to say."
## [1] " So, let’s look at this market. It’s the most popular market, it’s got the most liquidity. What do we want to come in here on this ETH over $500 dollars at the end of 2018 issue?"
## [1] " Okay, so you and I have talked about this for the past three days and we have decided that we should bet no, on basically every single Crypto bet, we should take the bear-ish position on almost all this."
## [1] " We should act like some no coiners, basically."
## [1] " Yeah and the reason for that-"
## [1] " We should hate on Crypto."
## [1] " … is that there’s three things that I think are happening here just from studying it in a very cursory way. The first is that a lot of the biggest markets seem to be have created by people who are somehow linked to Augur, so the second most popular market is will the REP token be over $32 by the end of 2018?"
## [1] " That would make sense. This is one of the promises of Augur is that we can have an options market for any coin ever. Sumo coin could have its own future market."
## [1] " I’m surprised that you haven’t started an Augur on Coinbase market. I think that there’s a lot of people that are incentivized on saying yes. The Bitcoin Crypto community is extremely bull-ish by nature and probably over confident in prices. I think this would be similar to saying if you had a prediction market that said … oh and the last thing being that almost everyone who used Augur is definitely heavy into Crypto."
## [1] " To take that idea even further, we’re basically saying that Augur users are probably on tilt. Right?"
## [1] " Oh yeah."
## [1] " I would believe that there’s some-"
## [1] " Perma tilts."
## [1] " Some Bitcoin haters in the mix, but I think you’re going to see a lot of ETH fans."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " This is a ERC 20 token, it’s been … it rapidly shot up to be one of the most used Ethereum apps within the first couple days it was out. This market, this first market should be one of the most tilty markets on here."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " The sort of long Ethereum market."
## [1] " And the way that prediction markets and actually any betting works is that large bets swing the number proportionally, so if 200 people bet one Ethereum, and one guy bets 200 Ethereum, they have the same exact effect. I imagine that as this thing started, just like Cryptokitties, just like Crypto Art Auctions, there’s some whales who want to see this thing work just because … not because they think they’re going to even make money off the bet, but because they want these thing to be healthy because it’s better for the entire ecosystem-"
## [1] " Right."
## [1] " … I cannot imagine that any of those people would vote no. I think we probably have some whales who are betting yes just to sort of seed this thing. I think the best option would be to go against them"
## [1] " Right, okay. So, the fact that there’s this big spread between the ask and the bid, if we put in a bid here for a no, or if we put in a … if we sell in order to get-"
## [1] " Yeah we sell some yes-"
## [1] " … no shares. Does someone else have to take the other side of that bet for it to-"
## [1] " I don’t know how this one works. But generally if you use a prediction market all those mechanics are done without you having to worry about it."
## [1] " Right, okay."
## [1] " So what are we gonna do here? Are we shorting Ethereum here?"
## [1] " Well the weird thing, are you holding any Ethereum?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " See, I’ve got Ethereum in my bag, so I guess if I bet Ethereum under $500, I’m basically hedging-"
## [1] " Yeah. But you’re hedging at a good percentage. If we can get the price at like $0.30 to $1, and it goes up to $0.80 a dollar, then you’ve done basically what almost 2.6 something to 1 which is a great hedge because you’re getting that extra value in there."
## [1] " Okay. So let me ask you a couple of questions about that. Do we worry that Ethereum is going to be at 502 on January 1st and we’re going to get double REPS?"
## [1] " That’s a disaster for us, but I’m not so worried that it will be at 502."
## [1] " Okay, let me ask you one more question. 500 nice round number, a lot of people are looking at Ethereum 500 the way that we used to look at Bitcoin 10,000, you know?"
## [1] " Are they though? I mean, Ethereum’s already gone up to like 1200."
## [1] " Here’s what I’m saying. If it’s December 31st and Ethereum’s sitting at 497-"
## [1] " Yeah, I think that we’re in trouble."
## [1] " … are some bull-tards going to come together and look at it and say we can rack a bunch of these shorts by getting it over 500?"
## [1] " I don’t know. Because if there was … let’s say that there was 500,000 Ethereum in this market, then I would say maybe there is some-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " … fear of that, but right now we’re at 1400 Ethereum."
## [1] " But this only launched this week and there’s 1400 shares. I mean, this may get more and more popular."
## [1] " The market cap of Ethereum is enough where I’m not so worried about that."
## [1] " Here’s what we’re going to do. We’re going to act like idiots right now, and then we’re going to call Ledger and get him to tell us everything we did wrong."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Okay so, I’m going to say our bet, Ethereum is currently sitting at … Ethereum is at 468. Okay? So, if we bet it right now, and we bet, let’s say .05, that’s like $20 worth of Ethereum."
## [1] " I think I’d go heavier."
## [1] " For our introductory dumb bet, we have to make it bigger? We just described how we were probably doing this wrong."
## [1] " Let’s do at least .1."
## [1] " I’m reimbursing myself out of show funds for this. Okay, so-"
## [1] " Tax deductible."
## [1] " … so if you put in .1 on the sell side, it automatically inputs the bid price, which is only .63, even though we’ve been quoted a 70% median price."
## [1] " Oh wow, that sucks. Can we change that? There’s a little clicky bar over there."
## [1] " Let’s see, can we change it to .70? But will-"
## [1] " Yeah someone has to take that then."
## [1] " Someone has to take that. So we’re basically just … yeah. And then there’s a check box for fill orders only."
## [1] " What was the default? Let’s go with the default."
## [1] " Default was off."
## [1] " Okay so lets go with default because we don’t know what we’re doing."
## [1] " Okay then we’re going to hit review. So okay, so this is good. If we win, this bet, we will make a 233% profit."
## [1] " All right!"
## [1] " Yeah, look if we lose this bet, we will lose our entire share which is .075 ETH."
## [1] " So we’re getting plus 230 on our money which is a pretty good price."
## [1] " But we don’t know if this is actually going to work, because we just quoted a higher price [crosstalk 00:28:19]."
## [1] " Let’s see what happens."
## [1] " Okay, so then you click confirm and then it opens a Metamask window. So it looks like we’re going to pay $1.60 transaction fee and I’m sending $36 in ETH, .07. All right, here we go."
## [1] " Did it work?"
## [1] " It says order placed."
## [1] " Okay, so we don’t have it yet."
## [1] " No, someone’s … hey if you’re listening-"
## [1] " Yeah someone buy our-"
## [1] " … and you’re some kind of an ETH head-"
## [1] " Someone buy our action please."
## [1] " [crosstalk 00:28:48]"
## [1] " Yeah. Okay lets see what we did wrong."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Hey, Ledger. AKA Brian."
## [1] " Is it okay to call you Brian on … is it okay to use your government name in this Crypto broadcasting space?"
## [1] " So, okay, so we’ve been trying to get our way through Augur, and we’ve got a few questions for you, because I know that unlike myself, you’ve dabbled in the futures market before Augur made it easy to do on the Ethereum block chain."
## [1] " Are you using the main net, the Infura one?"
## [1] " I connected to some of the other ones and they didn’t work also. So you’re not missing anything."
## [1] " It’s so easy to run an Ethereum node. Tell me how."
## [1] " Yeah-"
## [1] " Yeah, we just placed our first bet. You will be shocked to know that we have already degened into betting on this thing, just after … I would say about what, 44 minutes after we signed on for the first time."
## [1] " I’ll say, we were considering waiting and having you vet our bet first, but instead we decided to carry on with the tradition of this show and do something stupid and then get someone to explain why it was stupid after we had done it."
## [1] " If you had put a heart rate monitor on me during that whole time, the second the button came up that said place order, my heart rate would have spiked and we were like, do it!"
## [1] " I’ll recap-"
## [1] " Do it now!"
## [1] " … that we were like, let’s just make a stupid small bet for the show, and then I inputted and Jay was like, come on, a little bit more than that. So, well I think it says something initially just Brian, in your government name life, you’re deeply involved in WordPress development, and the fact that you’re not easily able to load this, suggests it’s maybe not totally ready for prime time yet?"
## [1] " Exe file?"
## [1] " Only on Windows, and Mac is a DMG."
## [1] " I sanitized my whole description of this. I was like, you just download the app and then you boot it up and then you connect to Infura. Then you’re on then you load it in the web browser, then you get a Metamask account. And then you take the Metamask account-"
## [1] " It felt very much like someone from Augur had gotten to Aaron to explain that this was a really easy process. I was like this seems impossible."
## [1] " Let’s do it."
## [1] " Thank you Brian, I was thinking that a couple days ago when we first talked about this, that it wouldn’t be that hard to just even make an app, you know like it doesn’t even have to be a phone app. Like a browser in which you could just hit yes or no and it would be really easy. I don’t understand why that doesn’t exist, because it would make the launch a lot more exciting because you wouldn’t have to go through all these difficult processes. It would actually make the markets bigger, which I think would probably entice more people to trust it to actually put money into it."
## [1] " So the number one market, you’ll be unsurprised that the first things to catch on here are Crypto currency futures and the biggest market is for Ethereum. So the bet is, will the price of Ethereum exceed $500 at the end of 2018?"
## [1] " That turns out not to be true. So-"
## [1] " … there was … well it sort of ranges between 63 and 83?"
## [1] " It actually reminds me of a sneaker sales and buys. If you try and get a specific type of sneaker and there isn’t much market for it, but it’s a pretty rare sneaker that you’ll see such a wide range between the bids and the asks that it makes the … like you could get it from anywhere between like let’s say $240 and like $490 it just depends on the luck of what you actually get. The spread in this does sort of reflect any type of market that doesn’t have that much volume in it."
## [1] " So, we could have just bought at 63. 63 is the bid that’s just sitting out there. We didn’t want that, so we put in a 70. Let’s just pretend someone takes our 70-"
## [1] " Brian, you’re the no side of 70."
## [1] " We’re taking the no side, do you want to take the other side? How’s your progress on downloading the Ethereum block chain over there?"
## [1] " Okay, so the theory then, like the way the prediction markets work is that you’re saying that at some point Ethereum will be like $520, and that many more bull-ish people will get into this market. And that it will go from like 70 say if you bought it at 70, to 80 and that you would sell at the 10% profit there. You would see a profit opportunity there because you felt like the second it goes over 500, people will feel some combination of bull-ishness and confirmation bias, and they’ll say it will never go under 500 at this point. They would buy into the yes side."
## [1] " Where else would someone be able to make a bet like this on Ethereum?"
## [1] " Yeah. So is that how most people play these kind of markets? Not as I’m going to sit on this, hold all this share until January 1st and either win or lose. But most people are looking at them as an asset that they intend to trade, buy, sell over the course of that period?"
## [1] " It’s like $0.99 an ear."
## [1] " It’s like $0.99 an ear right now, at the supermarket near my house."
## [1] " A famous example of that is airlines do that with the price of gas."
## [1] " Or the price of crude oil. They hedge themselves again increases in the price of airline fuel."
## [1] " Brian, so one thing that is interesting to me here, when I was thinking about this in the idea of making your own market. That the biggest opportunities and the biggest thing that was interesting to me was what you said, is that you could find these arbitrage opportunities. The problem with exotics in sports betting or just general betting is that they cap the action on it."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " Here’s the scenario that Aaron and I talked about a little bit, which is that if all the yes or no, for example … basically if truth is weeded out by REP tokens and like 51%, so if Donald Trump loses, you could actually vote theoretically that he won. And that you would win that bet, right? What would prevent somebody for example then, to basically place like 5,000 random markets that only a few people will be interested in that they might eventually even forget that they were a part of, hoard REP tokens and then use that to win every single one of those bets even if you lost it? There’s all these weird opportunities for cheating in something that’s this decentralized, where it does seem easier to just have somebody being like, nope, Donald Trump actually lost the election or won the election, whatever the truth is."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Just tell our listeners about that."
## [1] " Yeah tell our listeners."
## [1] " This is not a joke."
## [1] " It’s a fake news token."
## [1] " Ledger if I read you correctly, you’re saying that you can use the REP token to fight the fake news media?"
## [1] " That’s amazing."
## [1] " Jay just bought a [inaudible 00:46:26] huge bag."
## [1] " That is the biggest, this is the most bull-ish time for REP I’ve ever heard."
## [1] " Isn’t it kind of like a 51% attack, where if enough people say you were right or wrong you win or lose or something like that?"
## [1] " There’s also a market for who is Satoshi?"
## [1] " I’m going to try to get Jay to put some money where his mouth is. That story on Nakamoto is Satoshi."
## [1] " I don’t know if you heard Brian, but Aaron and I are both convinced that Excerpt Toshi, the guy who put out the book Excerpt is actually Satoshi. I don’t know if you want to keep having us on your broadcast after we said that, but we’re convinced."
## [1] " Our reasoning was, that it’s so clearly not Satoshi, that it has to be Satoshi."
## [1] " We were like these details don’t make any sense, if you’re not actually Satoshi. Like, my grandmother worked at a publishing house."
## [1] " Do you think that couldn’t happen? Like too many Pina Coladas and [inaudible 00:48:25]. Then we was just like you know what, fuck it."
## [1] " I got home from a Buffett concert and I was jazzed."
## [1] " With Satoshi, I feel like if that market ever swings huge in one direction, that that actually is a clue, don’t you?"
## [1] " I feel like it would be the most Libertarian move ever to bet heavily on who Satoshi is, if you are Satoshi, and then win the who is Satoshi bet, by coming out."
## [1] " [crosstalk 00:49:12] but that’s how it is predictive, that was the idea was that somebody in Al Qaeda or something like that would find this thing and think of it as a way to make money. They would just out everybody by betting on it. Then the line would swing. In that way I think it’s actually kind of interesting. What do you think?"
## [1] " I’ve divested from journalism. Okay but Brian, so this is the scenario, let’s say that there’s five choices right? Excerpt Toshi, Craig Wright, Dorio Nakamoto-"
## [1] " Excerpt Toshi is not in the top five."
## [1] " … and let’s say that at some point this market has, let’s say it has $2 million in it. And then $5 million come in on Aaron right? Would you see that as any evidence that Aaron was about to come out as, with irrefutable proof that he was Satoshi Nakamoto, because that’s how a prediction market is supposed to work"
## [1] " No. I mean, you just crushed me. I know you’re clearly not but I still-"
## [1] " It wouldn’t until there are hundreds of millions of dollars moving on there, and then you start getting in some weird snitching situations that could be interesting."
## [1] " Yeah, if Aaron was like 80 to 1 and it was Aaron, and I knew it was Aaron, and I was broke, and Aaron was not going to give me any of his million Bitcoin right? I might just take all the money I have and put it on Aaron and get like whatever, 80 to 1. Then out Aaron."
## [1] " This is the way to finally take down Craig Wright, once and for all. Just be like, if you’re really Satoshi, you have to put your wealth on the yourself bet on the Augur Satoshi market."
## [1] " This is still game-able. I delete my Twitter and he still had me blocked, but Aaron you should tweet that."
## [1] " He’s turned down opportunities to put his own skin into his own game?"
## [1] " Would you take, would either of you guys take the field? If I gave you like the big four, like Sabo, Finney, Craig Wright … who else is on that list?"
## [1] " Excerpt Toshi."
## [1] " Excerpt Toshi. Versus the field, versus everyone else on Earth. I think I’d just take everyone else on Earth."
## [1] " It depends on the bet. If it Hal Finney was involved in all, does that cancel the bet? It needs some sort of hedge like that."
## [1] " That market’s probably never going to get resolved, right?"
## [1] " I don’t know, I think we’ll eventually know who Satoshi is."
## [1] " That’s a great question."
## [1] " I guess you could sell it, but-"
## [1] " Yeah, and who’s going to buy that from you also?"
## [1] " Outside of silly theoretical ideas, Brian, we wanted to call you because you’re the guy who we know who understands the full ecosystem of different hedge opportunities of different markets the most. When you look at Augur, what is the most exciting opportunity for you, in trading terms?"
## [1] " He’s still at 74%. He can’t look at the market."
## [1] " You can see the markets on predictions.global then even if you’re not … if you don’t have access."
## [1] " Yeah but they’re wrong. I’m not convinced that somebody gave you a bunch of REP tokens to-"
## [1] " No, predictions.-"
## [1] " … to gloss over all the wrong."
## [1] " … global is showing some kind of a median price that’s not actually what you can buy, but it’s close enough for argument."
## [1] " All right, so are you going to use this as a way to hedge out of certain things? Are you going to use this as a way to hedge certain positions? If you do hold Ethereum, which Brian, I don’t know if you do or not right now you don’t have to say. But if you were holding it, would you consider this as a hedge opportunity, or do you think there are better hedge opportunities out there?"
## [1] " Too late. Guilty."
## [1] " Yeah guilty. How much liquidity are we talking abour right now? How big do these markets have to be to function in anyway, like an options or derivative market that you could buy at Schwab or whatever?"
## [1] " There’s about $642,000 currently riding on that question."
## [1] " Call your pick Ledge, call your pick."
## [1] " What was the stock? We need your tips."
## [1] " Wait, Jay I want to blow up your centralized Augur, where you make the market that people can use."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And I think you should allow parlaying where you can parlay like three Augur bets into an Augur super bet."
## [1] " Not yet."
## [1] " But you could create a-"
## [1] " It’s called a Kang special."
## [1] " … you could create a market of will I win these three bets?"
## [1] " Will Jay succeed?"
## [1] " You might eventually get a better price than the actual parlay would give you."
## [1] " Okay, so Ledger, we want to run how we traded this one, and you tell us what you think. So we went in this really dumb. I didn’t think about trading my position at all, I just thought about buying a position and holding it until the expiration."
## [1] " Yeah, we just were, will be right or wrong. That was our only concern."
## [1] " We don’t really know what the chance Ethereum’s going to be over $500, it feels like it’s better than 50%, but maybe, I don’t know what it is. But we looked at who’s probably betting right now on Augur. It’s a bunch of early adopters. Augur is a total ETH world darling. It’s people who are bull-ish on Ethereum. So whatever they’re buying this at, we were like, they’re probably a little too bull-ish on Ethereum and we should take the other side."
## [1] " Okay. Now knowing that that is our strategy, should we hold it along the way, you think? Or should we dump it at some point? At some point, let’s say there’s some sort of regulatory snafu and Ethereum dumps a bunch. Would you hold on to it there, or would you say, no this is great, my chances are now improved and I’m just going to hold my position?"
## [1] " Yeah 70% chance."
## [1] " Is there anywhere else I could look this up and understand what it’s trading at somewhere else?"
## [1] " Yeah ring the bell."
## [1] " What happened?"
## [1] " When I did the promo for Ledger’s podcast, I said that he should come back on Coin Talk when we saw an $1,000 bounce from the bottom."
## [1] " Oh."
## [1] " And the bottom was what, like $5800 or something?"
## [1] " Check out my friends podcast, it’s great. Bitcoins, so much fun."
## [1] " [crosstalk 01:02:25] at $500 yesterday."
## [1] " Yesterday it hit $500."
## [1] " The other problem that we have here is that, and Brian tell me what you think, Aaron you too. Is that it just dawned on me that if this is a biased market, right, towards being bull-ish, then will a spike up to like 520, will it make us more underwater than we should be. And will there be more sale side action when there should be, if everyone who’s involved in this needs to try to download this app 17 different times and it has such a high barred entry. Will the only people here be Ethereum Maximus, so that even when we should be seeing swing from 70 to 50%, it might not happen."
## [1] " Fuck! But then we just hold it and let it expire and hope we win."
## [1] " Yeah so the only way that we can do this, and please tell me if I’m wrong, I’m probably wrong, is that my theory now at this point is that what Aaron and I should do is that we should buy all the way up. And then hope that we win, so we should not hedge our bet but that we should continue to double down our bet, over and over and over again under the idea that the market is over valued."
## [1] " And I’m assuming in this plan that we keep betting more and more each of these times?"
## [1] " Yeah. We keep pressing our bet, what do you think?"
## [1] " Yeah load the hell out-"
## [1] " I would argue that the … I think what you said was bull-ish sentiment in a bear-ish market, doesn’t that pretty much describe today?"
## [1] " Especially like Ethereum users on Augur?"
## [1] " All right, let’s double our bet right now."
## [1] " [crosstalk 01:05:18] You can put in limit buys at whatever price you want, and so we could actually just theoretically put a scaling up series of limit bets, or limit sells."
## [1] " You have to get your own account if you wanna do that. I’m not lending you my Metamask account."
## [1] " What’s wrong you look very stressed out? Oh man, I’m so leveraging [crosstalk 01:05:46]"
## [1] " There’s like one end point that just pings 24 hours a day, it’s Jay refreshing the market. Ledger, we had a question that came up earlier, and I know you create a lot of alts, which is, I hold Augur, I’ve had an Augur bag for a while. I always thought, oh when Augur comes out, I’ll be betting with Augur, and if a lot of people bet with Augur that’ll make Augur valuable. The betting is actually with Ethereum, and the REP is used in this scheme we discussed for verifying the truth. Why, if Augur does become popular, and we start seeing a lot of volume in these markets, why will REP go up? Or will it?"
## [1] " This is something that has always bugged me about the Crypto space, the alt coin space. Which is that, it seems like it is banking on some level of stupidity by the buyers, right? And so-"
## [1] " The case is essentially that most of the people who buy this see it as a security for a new company and that they don’t understand that the token itself is not what we are vaguely saying that the token might be. Then they buy it and it comes out and the product comes out and it turns out that the token is basically a way to put in votes for something that if you are putting in any amount of money that you don’t necessarily are to even do. I find that to be a little bit scammy, gotta say."
## [1] " I also think it’s what people want. I would want to own some of Augur."
## [1] " I would want to own part of the company, but buying the token is not that. I just think that at some point people will stop being tricked by this. They will stop thinking in this sort of way, and that I don’t know what that does to the alt coin market, or if that actually has already happened at this point. I don’t know. When we were buying ZeroX, very early on, Brian you and me. We couldn’t quite articulate what the use case for it would be, right? But we just liked the project itself."
## [1] " Another project among the list of stuff that had gotten added to Coinbase, is Basic Attention token, which is another ERC 20 token that I would say, like Augur is maybe among the closest to actually sort of existing. Augur is an ultimately optimistic story right? They sold a bunch of these tokens and they actually at least like made the prediction market."
## [1] " There’s a product it’s crazy."
## [1] " I think we should give them a little clap because- [crosstalk 01:11:59]"
## [1] " Yeah and you’re using the brave browser. I had thought about, I don’t remember who it was, some friend of ours, was like my investment hypothesis is only buying things you can actually use. I looked at Basic Attention token and I was like, okay maybe I should buy this, you can actually use it. I have some Augur. The reason I’d be buying it is because I think it’s going to go up when it gets onto Coinbase if it gets onto Coinbase."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Do you think this could lead to a future where people aren’t really holding coins and private keys and that kind of thing, and are mostly just speculating on the future of them?"
## [1] " We have to stop right there. We’re not going to have a better final summation than that."
## [1] " Aaron and I agree with you as Crypto moderates, which is something that Aaron came up to describe us as."
## [1] " What is that?"
## [1] " I think maybe we could call ourselves the Government Namers also."
## [1] " I think Cryno actually works. It’s basically the right idea that we are saying that we are Bit coiners, and that we do a Bitcoin podcast, but everything we say is what’s wrong with Bitcoin."
## [1] " I also would accept Crypmos."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " I don’t want to get mistaken for a Crip."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " I generally believe in Bitcoin. I will say that Augur is interesting to me in the sense that I do think that if there was fun ways in which you could do this with a very low cost, that it could actually be used in personal ways that actually I think are more interesting. You could, right now, theoretically use your smart contract way as a way to escrow money in a big bet right? That’s one of the examples. But I don’t know how to do that. Do you know how to do that? It seems very complicated. If there was a way that you could just privately do small markets, for like $1.60 fee or something like that, and you’re betting someone $5,000-"
## [1] " Who’s the verified trusted party in that though?"
## [1] " Oh yeah, that’s true."
## [1] " Jay just scammed himself, somehow."
## [1] " I just scammed myself."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I-"
## [1] " Yeah, yeah."
## [1] " … there was, I can’t find it again now, but there’s some place you can get to an Augur, it doesn’t speak well that I can’t find it again, now. Where it says universes, and there’s only one universe right now, which is the current Ethereum betting market that we’re discussing. But it almost looks like the software is set up sort of the way Warcraft. You’re on a specific server-"
## [1] " Like Battlenet West."
## [1] " Yeah. It seems like the services architected so there can actually be multiple Augurs within Augur that potentially there could be a private Augur, or a Augur that you have to pay a membership fee to be a part of. It seems like they’re prepared for a lot of different outcomes."
## [1] " Yeah I think it all strikes me as to what you said at the beginning, Brian, which is that it is compelling, interesting and fascinating solutions to things that exist that have small but manageable problems. And that by introducing these solutions, right now, not in the future perhaps, that you actually are introducing way more problems than the problem that you solved."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " They put their foot out there."
## [1] " You know how like in the NFL, if you’re like the 15th best quarterback in the world, you’re like a piece of shit? You know? Like a middle of the NFL quarterback is getting crapped on?"
## [1] " Yeah but they’re rich."
## [1] " They’re rich, but so are all the people [crosstalk 01:17:27] in Crypto currencies. What I mean is we criticize this because it’s rudimentary, but this is the best Crypto product, I have ever seen. Actually on the block chain, actually interacting with the Ethereum network."
## [1] " Do you think it’s better than Cryptokitties?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " I don’t think so."
## [1] " Or the places my brain can project it getting-"
## [1] " Yeah it has more potential than Cryptokitties."
## [1] " It’s a much bigger-"
## [1] " I’m very bull-ish on the idea of Augur. I am less bull-ish on the, especially hearing what you just said about how the founder is now doing other things. Making this work is going to be an immense amount of time and effort. It is the fundamental problem with ICO things, which is that if the people are already rich and they’ve made all the money they’re ever going to make off this thing, what is the incentive to actually make it work? Which is something that Aaron brings up a lot which I tend to agree with. This one seems to be laid with the same problems."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " That’s going to take time to figure out. It’s going to take smarter people who aren’t just engineers who are into Crypto. That takes a lot of investment. I just have a hard time believing that they’re going to get over the finish line."
## [1] " There’s plenty. I feel like they are in the perfect place to get a lot of investment. They’re like a gambling market for Crypto."
## [1] " But if you have $600 million, the most work you’re going to do is to get from zero to $600 million. To get from $600 million to like $1.2 billion, you’re not going to do as much work. I guess that’s my point."
## [1] " Can I ask a question? There’s a fee built in for the maker of the market, it’s 1% on most of these markets, less on some. Is the maker of the market Augur, or is the maker of the market the person who made that market, like the user who made that market? Do you guys know?"
## [1] " That’s what I thought."
## [1] " Okay, so Jay, you guys, planning our next show. I think the way we can get rich is to make some really good markets."
## [1] " Some really awesome bets."
## [1] " Yeah, they have to be super popular."
## [1] " And then we have to pump these bets."
## [1] " They have to be very Crypto, Twitter and Telegram friendly though. Something that is spread virally through that ecosystem."
## [1] " Yeah. I think we’re the right three to do this, and this way we can profiteer on Augur, without getting too deep into the hedging economy."
## [1] " Something like is Parabolic Trev a cook?"
## [1] " We’ll workshop that."
## [1] " Huge action."
## [1] " So far, Jay has only produced unsolvable questions. Or questions that scam themselves."
## [1] " Months ago, when Augur was going to soft launch, that was the question they were going to launch with, “Will Augur be hacked?” And they were doing that obviously because they were trying to figure out in true prediction market style if a bunch of money came in at once on yes, then what that might mean."
## [1] " Here’s one that I think could work. I’m going to give you, this is a tease. We’re going to end this episode with a tease for when we come back here. If there was a market right now, for what will the next coins, not counting the five that have already been explored, but what will be the next coin added to Coinbase?"
## [1] " Oh and actually that would be a lot of action as well."
## [1] " Right."
## [1] " For our market fee. So Brian, we’ll create this market because you can’t connect. And we’ll just stake you into it, how about that?"
## [1] " Aw, damn I don’t have it here. I was going to-"
## [1] " I’m the Augur market maker."

## [1] " Oh yeah. The new logo."

## [1] " Oh, I’m sorry XRP hat, I’ll be wearing my XRP hat."
